HEADLINE: Too Many Dammed Rivers

BYLINE: By Stewart L. Udall and W. Kent Olson; Stewart L. Udall was Secretary of the Interior from 1961 to 1969. W. Kent Olson is president of American Rivers, an conservation organization.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Of the 3.5 million miles of river that once laced this continent, an estimated 15 percent now lie dead behind 60,000 dams of all kinds. For every river mile preserved under the national Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, 65 have been extinguished.
Today, in parts of the northeast, barely one river in 20 runs damless to the sea. New York's rivers are plugged by no fewer than 188 hydropower projects. Although the state enacted its own scenic rivers law, the actual protection is minimal. Even watercourses in Adirondack Park are vulnerable, including the spectacular Oswegatchie, whose main stem and tributaries are burdened with 20 hydropower dams already. New York's Black River is threatened by poor operation of some of its 12 existing hydropower plants, and the Raquette, with 18 dams, faces a proposed new one. On the Genessee, developers want to add a hydropower facility to a water storage dam, which would drown a recreationally important reach of free-flowing river. 
This is ''hydromania'' and, in New York and elsewhere, the hydropower push is on. Many dam builders enjoy special treatment under Federal laws, and rare, free-running rivers are being sacrificed for minuscule amounts of electricity.
In some cases, private dam builders can get extended tax credits and accelerated depreciation - subsidies amounting to hundreds of millions of dollars so far - and they can confiscate streamside property. These producers even get a guaranteed market - big utilities must buy it whether or not it's needed.
In some states, utilities purchase the power at rates exceeding the costs of alternatives. The small hydropower industry benefits from protectionism, courtesy of the taxpayer. That, not consumer demand for power, is what drives hydromania.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees non-Federal hydropower projects, approves nearly 250 new licenses annually. Since 1978, the agency has received more than 6,500 hydropower applications. Roughly 1,000 are likely to pass the commission's environmental criteria and hundreds of live river segments will soon be converted to static lagoons.
Some experts believe that if all the feasible small hydropower proposals were put on line, the total electric output would equal that of a single coal-fired plant. The new dams would produce 0.03 percent of the nation's present fossil fuel usage. Are Americans willing to lose yet more rivers for so meager a payoff?
Hard-bitten economists are starting to understand that streams enhance the value of nearby property; communities are discovering that accessible river banks make a town comely. Rivers and their environs give places to fish, hunt, boat and hike, and provide natural corridors for animal and plant wildlife - all for free. They are functionally beautiful elements of the living landscape.
Fortunately, because of recent amendments to the Federal Power Act, citizens can have a say in hydropower proceedings. The law says dam operators ''shall give equal consideration'' to power production, wildlife and recreation.
More hydropower dams won't better our national energy picture. In light of the extinction of rivers -600,000 river miles buried behind concrete so far - we should scratch new dams from the list of alternatives to atomic plants and get on with preserving more natural streams.
At a time of giving thanks, there is no better way to do it than to contemplate moving water, which mirrors the flow and play of life, and recall the words of Henry Thoreau: ''Man is rich in proportion to the number of things he can afford to let alone.''

HEADLINE: Dinkins Moves To Find Names For Chief Posts

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
David N. Dinkins appointed five committees yesterday to look for candidates to head major agencies in New York City, but his transition aides noted that all the jobs will not be filled by the time the Mayor-elect takes office on Jan. 1.
''I am not going to hazard a timetable yet,'' said Nathan Leventhal, the chairman of the transition team. ''We should have a lot of key positions announced before Jan. 1, a great number before then.''
Mr. Leventhal said a new administration can never select all its officials before entering office. 
About 150 people are on the search committees announced yesterday. Several are associated with the man Mr. Dinkins defeated in the Democratic primary, Mayor Edward I. Koch; other names are well known, like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's son, Andrew, and another Democratic mayoral candidate, Richard Ravitch.
 
Labor Leaders and Ministers
The committees are composed of a wide range of New Yorkers. Most are from outside government, Mr. Leventhal said, so that the committees can choose a broad spectrum of candidates, including labor leaders, lawyers, financiers, ministers, academics and heads of civic groups. Mr. Leventhal said they represent ''a reasonable demographic mix of the city'' but added that no attempt was made to achieve ''a political balancing act.''
He said he will meet on Tuesday with Mr. Dinkins, who is to return on Monday from a vacation in Puerto Rico.
Mr. Leventhal said the committees announced yesterday will divide themselves into subcommittees, search for job candidates, interview them as early as possible and prepare lists of the names they think Mr. Dinkins should consider.
Mr. Leventhal stressed that the Mayor-elect will take ''final responsibility for selecting people for his administration.'' He said the search committees themselves were selected from lists drawn up by Mr. Dinkins and the transition committee.
While Mr. Dinkins was on vacation, The Daily News reported this week that there was dissension within the transition committee.
That was disputed yesterday by Mr. Leventhal, who said that members of the committee have ''lively discussions'' but that the talks are conducted in ''a spirit of cordiality.''
''The concept that there is dissension or personal animosity is absolute and total nonsense.'' he said.
Barbara Fife, special senior assistant to Mr. Dinkins, also denied that there was discord.
She and Mr. Leventhal said there had been some discussion of whether Mr. Dinkins should come back from his vacation early to work on normal transition matters. That proved to be unnecessary, she said.
 
Koch's Manager on One Panel
Each search committee has two chairpeople and from 21 to 35 members.
Among the members are Paul Crotty, who managed Mr. Koch's campaign in the Democratic primary; F. A. O. Schwarz Jr., former Corporation Counsel for the city and head of the Charter Revision Commission; Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers; the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, and the Rev. Herbert Daughtry. There will be five committees. One will seek candidates for economic and financial agencies. It is headed by Ron Gault, public finance director of The First Boston Corporation, and Peter Goldmark, president of the Rockefeller Foundation.
Another will seek candidates for planning, environmental and quality of life agencies. It is headed by Max Bond, an architect in the firm of Bond Ryder James, and Linda Davidoff, executive director of The Parks Council.
 
Lawyer and a Law Professor
A third panel will deal with legal and law-enforcement services. It is headed by Peggy Davis, a law professor at New York University Law School, and Victor Kovner, a lawyer with the firm of Lankenau, Kovner & Bickford. Mr. Kovner is expected to be Corporation Counsel in the Dinkins administration.
A fourth committee will deal with social service agencies. The group is headed by Dr. June Jackson Christmas, head of the Manhattan Borough President's Commission on Youth, and Dr. Isaura Santiago, president of Hostos Community College in the Bronx.
A fifth panel will seek candidates to lead agencies for service delivery and personnel. It is headed by Ellen Chesler, president of the Parks Council, and Dr. Rafael Lantigua, a doctor at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.
Mr. Dinkins also named Dr. Gerald Lynch, president of John Jay College, as chairman of a subcommittee seeking candidates for Police Commissioner. In addition, Dr. James Dumpson, of the New York Community Trust, was named chairman of a subcommittee that will search for candidates for the job of Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration.

GRAPHIC: Nathan Leventhal, chairman of the Dinkins transition team, said many key positions would be announced before Jan. 1. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.) (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: State Plans Ads for New York City

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
The state will try to help New York City bring in tourist dollars with a $3 million advertising campaign using network television, national magazines and direct-mail advertising, Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development, announced Thursday.
Mr. Tese said the city would receive extra money for the four-month winter advertising campaign from the state's I Love New York program, even though the budget for the program's own advertising and marketing division had been cut.
''New York City's tourism industry needs our help more than ever before,'' he said. The city is suffering from lower hotel-occupancy rates and lower ticket sales for the theater and many other events, he said. 
The state campaign will ''remind travelers of New York City's special charms,'' Mr. Tese said.
 
Television Commercials Planned
Through the end of March, the state plans to run 30-second commercials on popular programs on the three major networks, including the Tony Awards, the Grammy Awards, specials featuring David Letterman and Barbara Walters, ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Cheers'' and ''L.A. Law.'' The advertisements will show glimpses of Broadway shows, museums and shops and other sights.
Commercials showing the lighting of the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center and other special events will be shown through March 25 on the Cable News Network, Arts & Entertainment, Discovery and USA networks.
Viewers will be invited to call a toll-free number for a New York City vacation kit of a city guide, map and directory of tour packages.
Color advertisments, featuring the stars of musicals under the slogan ''No other city has so much character,'' are planned for Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit, The New Yorker, Travel and Leisure and Vanity Fair. The magazines have a total circulation of 57 million, Mr. Tese's office estimated.
Citing successful direct-mail experiments in the state's spring and summer advertising, the state announced that it will also use that medium, including advertisements in the Carol Wright mailer, Bloomingdale's spring catalogue and a booklet by A.T.&T.
Finally, couples planning to marry will be reminded of honeymoon packages in the city with an advertisement in Bride's magazine.

HEADLINE: Adirondack Park Panel Seeks Balanced Future

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
The Adirondack Park, six million acres of forests, mountains and lakes in the heart of New York State, is many things to many people: a slice of wilderness, a livelihood, a home. Members of New York State's Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century have traveled around the state to hear residents discuss their visions of the park. Now the commission must develop a plan for the park's future to present in the spring to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The commission chairman, Peter A. A. Berle, said in a recent interview that the commission sees its mission as balancing a wide array of interests, including ''protecting the wilderness, marking sure the hamlets are places that people want to live in and can provide a sound economic base for the residents, and providing growth as long as it is in scale.'' 
The park, a checkerboard of public and private land, is not a park along the model of Yellowstone or Central Park. In the 1890's, the State Legislature, recognizing that the land was a resource that needed to be protected, designated it a park and set a boundary around it known as the Blue Line.
The state has made it a priority to buy land within the Blue Line, and though its acquisition program has come under criticism from environmentalists who say the purchases are moving too slowly, it now owns about 40 percent of the acreage. Privately held land within the park is subject to a special set of zoning requirements. Another Long Island? The commission's last of more than a dozen hearings was held this month on Long Island, a place as symbolically distant from the Adirondacks as can be found in New York. Many Adirondacks residents regard Long Island, with its dense development, as the embodiment of what they do not want their region to become. And many Long Island residents look to the Adirondacks as a place to make up for past mistakes.
Typical of the opinion expressed at the hearing, held in Mineola, was that of Carl Waswo, 80 years old, a native of Shoreham, L.I. ''What happened to Long Island was stupid and greedy,'' he said, ''and it's the same thing that is happening to the Adirondacks.''
Alvin Hauser, who spoke on behalf of the 6,000 members of the Long Island Sierra Club, said that open space on the island had shrunk so severely that the club's most recent land-acquisition fight was over a plot of just 20 acres.
''The Adirondack Park preserve was bought and paid for by all the people of New York,'' he said. ''It belongs to all New Yorkers, and all New Yorkers must continue to be represented'' in decisions about it.
 
Snapshots on the Lawn
But if people around the state see the Adirondacks as a place where development must be stopped at any cost, those who live in the park, many of them blue-collar workers with modest incomes, often resent the interference. Protective of their property, many residents say they know how to govern their land better than people who live hundreds of miles away and come only to visit.
At an earlier meeting in Saranac Lake, within the park, Mary Ellen Keith, the Supervisor of the nearby town of Franklin, told the story of a neighbor who returned home one day to find a group of tourists setting up cameras on her lawn to photograph the sunset.
The neighbor asked them to move because she could not get into her front door. She said the tourists responded, ''This is just as much our park as it is yours.''
The majority of those at the Long Island meeting had visited the park and been struck by its beauty. As a result, many members of the Long Island audience did not take it kindly when Barbara Stolen of Chestertown, in the Adirondacks, said the downstaters were treating the Adirondacks as ''a great playground.''
 
'Hey, You, Move Out'
''I'm really moved by the lack of feeling for the people who try to make a living in the Adirondacks,'' Mrs. Stolen said. ''It's like going down to Jones Beach State Park and saying to the people who live nearby, 'Hey, you, move out.' ''
But Mrs. Stolen was criticized by other speakers, who said the park's residents had to be prepared to give up some land-use and development privileges enjoyed by people in more populated areas.
Kim Elliman, vice chairwoman of the Adirondack Council, an environmental group, said, ''Those who live in the park may have to realize that their choice of life style may not afford as many economic opportunities'' as in other areas.
And D. C. Shakeshaft of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., said: ''The Adirondacks is not the place you go to start a business. I as a taxpayer have supported the area as a pristine park, and I would like to see it kept clean and pristine.''
While there was often a clear disparity between the desires of those within and outside of the park, Mr. Berle said that what struck him about the meetings was that the two sides appeared to be coming together. Twenty years ago, when there was an earlier round of discussions that laid the groundwork for the park's current management plan, the relationship between upstaters and downstaters was much more bitter, he said.
 
Support for Preservation
Now, Mr. Berle said, there is a common commitment to protecting the environment and insuring orderly planning in the park.
''The thing that is quite different now is the breadth of support for the need to preserve the values and character of the park,'' Mr. Berle said.
With the hearings over, he said, the commission's next step is to work on the plan for Governor Cuomo. Mr. Berle said the plan would be specific, with suggestions on the regulatory structure for the park and how its land would be managed.
The commission will be taking an especially close look at the Adirondack Park Agency, established more than 25 years ago to deal with zoning questions. The agency has come under fire from critics on both sides - some saying that it is too intrusive, and others that it is not vigilant enough.
Mr. Berle said the hearings were meant to get a feel for New Yorkers' views about the park. But, he said, with all the competing interests, ''whether you can make everyone happy is very unlikely.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1989

 BODY:

 
 
Companies
 Primerica announced plans to acquire the consumer finance business of the BarclaysAmerican Corporation for $1.35 billion in cash. The acquisition would add 220 offices to Primerica's highly profitable Commercial Credit Company, which operates 490 offices in 29 states. Barclays has offices in seven states, including California, where Commercial Credit has not been represented. [Page 31.] A crowd gathered in front of B. Altman & Company long before the stores on Fifth Avenue opened for the traditional start of the Christmas shopping season. Clapping their hands against the cold, stepping over patches of ice and pressed close together behind police barricades, customers came, often in hope of a bargain, but more often, they said, to witness the end of a favorite store. [1.] General Motors reduced its stake in Isuzu Motors Ltd., the Japanese auto maker and a long-time G.M. affiliate, by selling 20 million shares to Japanese financial institutions, reportedly for $138 million. G.M. remains Isuzu's largest shareholder, although the sale cuts its stake to 38.2 percent from 40.2 percent. [31.] Robert Maxwell is offering $250 million for a 50 percent stake in Israel's Clal conglomerate, a spokesman for the British entrepreneur said. Clal, a publicly traded company controlled by the Israeli Discount Bank and Bank Hapoalim, has businesses that range from the textile and electronics industries to insurance and finance. [33.] Crane said it would like to acquire the Milton Roy Company, a maker of analytic instruments and pumps, for $21 a share in cash. The offer values Milton Roy at about $119.7 million. [33.]
 
International
 American securities firms, having made gains in Japan, are now discouraging Federal officials from playing an activist role in widening access for fear of losing what they have won. Some foreign firms are discovering how nice Tokyo's cartel-like arrangements and fixed commissions can be for those on the inside. [31.] An OPEC majority is trying to persuade two Gulf Arab states, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, to agree at their Vienna meeting to cut oil output so that excess production will not weaken prices early in 1990. [32.]
 
 
 
The Economy
 Californians may soon see some fruits of their insurance initiative, more than a year after they voted for a sweeping rate-cutting measure in a costly, hard-fought contest. But they will get far less than they expected. [9.]
 
 
 
Markets
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.77 points, to 2,675.55, but stock trading was exceptionally slow in post-Thanksgiving trading. For the week, the Dow rose 22.89 points, or slightly less than 1 percent, helped by the Federal Reserve's apparent move to ease credit on Wednesday, sending Federal funds to 8 1/4 percent. [31.] The Federal Reserve moved unexpectedly to arrest the decline in interest rates by draining some of the reserves that it had added to the banking system before Thanksgiving. But analysts were quick to discount the action. The Treasury's bellwether long bond yielded 7.86 percent. [34.] Gold prices reached highs for the year - with the contract for delivery in December at $419.30 a troy ounce on the Comex - as the resignation of Czechoslovakia's Communist rulers raised tension levels among European investors. [39.] The dollar weakened against most major currencies, trading near an 11-month low at 1.8010 marks against the strong West German currency. [39.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 To avoid losing the deductibility of their retirement plans, many owners of small businesses and professional practices need to act before the end of the year to bring them into line with rules imposed by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Your Money. [32.] Space vehicles would be launched by magnetic propulsion from a 1,000-mile vacuum-pressure tunnel under a system patented by Michael A. Minovitch, an independent inventor, who says that chemical rockets are enormously inefficient. Patents. [32.]

HEADLINE: An Acquisitive Utility Spreads in the West

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
Pacificorp, the company bidding $2.08 billion for the Arizona Public Service Company, has grown through acquisitions from a little-known Oregon company into the third-largest utility in the West. In the process, it is becoming known as a leader in the trends toward distributing power across many states and diversifying into non-utility businesses.
In January Pacificorp completed the $1.8 billion acquisition of the Utah Power and Light Company, the largest merger of two utilities in 50 years.
The Utah deal and the proposed Arizona deal are part of a strategy to acquire transmission lines to deliver cheap hydroelectric power from the Northwest to hungry southern markets where it can command a premium price. Demand in markets like Arizona and Southern California peaks in the summer for air-conditioner use, while Oregon demand peaks in the winter. Serving both regions would enable Pacificorp to channel excess power where it is needed over its own lines. 
That ability to transfer power could help Pacificorp avoid the expense of building new power plants for some time.
What is more, the acquisitions can add to efficiency. Pacificorp says that the economies of the Utah merger alone will give it pretax savings of $50 million this year, with annual savings of as much as $160 million within five years.
But Pacificorp's acquisitions have also generated debate. Some rate-payer groups are troubled by the size of its seven-state transmission area. Acquiring the Arizona utility would give Pacificorp operations in every Far Western state except Nevada.
These groups say that an acquisition of a Nevada utility would give Pacificorp the ability to dominate the flow of power into California and to dictate prices to the West's two largest utilities: Pacific Gas and Electric, which serves Northern and Central California, and Southern California Edison.
''In less than two years, Pacificorp will have changed from an obscure utility serving sparse areas in seven Northwest states to a utility which controls the generation, transmission and distribution of electric power from Canada to Mexico,'' said Scott Hempling, an attorney with the energy project of the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington.
''You can condition every deal so that by themselves they're harmless, but when you're done you still have one company controlling vast areas,'' Mr. Hempling said. Conditions Put on Deal His group successfully sought protections for consumers from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in the Utah deal. For one thing, Pacificorp agreed to allow any competitor to use its transmission lines at cost.
Traditionally a company that controlled transmission lines could deny access to others or charge them a premium price for making the connection, a ''wheeling charge'' in industry jargon.
The conditions imposed by the Federal regulators even require Pacificorp to build transmission lines if a customer asks for them.
So far the conditions apply only to firm contracts, not the spot market, and only to other utilities, not end users. Nevertheless, Pacificorp's acceptance of the conditions raised a storm of protest from executives of other utilities, who feared a precedent was being set.
 
Concerns About Competition
Utility industry leaders fear that ''open wheeling'' by Pacificorp will encourage competition not only from other utilities but also from independent power producers. The independents, who are less bound by Federal and state regulations, could operate with a far more leveraged capital structure, allowing them to undercut the utilities in pricing electricity.
A. M. Gleason, Pacificorp's president and chief executive, conceded that other utilities were ''fighting tooth and nail'' against open wheeling. He also said that Federal regulators would probably impose similar conditions in an Arizona deal, but he added that he did not consider the conditions to be a precedent. Pacificorp accepted them, he said, because the costs of carrying power for competitors are easily offset by savings like those realized in the Utah merger.
''We simply don't see the same bogeyman that the rest of the industry does,'' he said. ''We don't think that we're setting a standard. The conditions were set by F.E.R.C. and simply not found objectionable by us.''
 
The Arizona Offer
While the Arizona Public Service bid is in many ways a twin of the Utah offer, its timing was dictated not by Pacificorp but by the troubles of the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Mr. Gleason said. Pinnacle, the parent of Arizona Public Service, desperately needs cash to prop up its Merabank unit, an insolvent savings and loan institution. Pinnacle's board is evaluating Pacificorp's unsolicited offer.
Arizona Public Service has said it needs a 20 percent increase in its rates in order to bring the second of its three nuclear reactors into service, but Pacificorp's bid stipulates that it will increase rates only 8 percent, spread over the next four years.
Jill Jenkins, an analyst with Sutro & Company in San Francisco, said ''regulators in Arizona are really pushing this, out of concern that Pinnacle will go under, leaving Arizona Public Service tied to a bankrupt holding company.'' She said that another bidder could emerge and that Pacificorp's offer was at a 15 percent discount to book value, while most utility mergers were at premiums of 1.8 to 1.9 times book value.
Ms. Jenkins added that she had ''a lot of respect for Pacificorp management'' and assumed that the price differential was based on uncertainty about Merabank and Arizona's three Palo Verde nuclear power plants.
She described Pacificorp as ''one of the most successfully diversified public utilities,'' with strong performance at its telephone subsidiary, Pacific Telecom, and its coal mining company, Nerco. She also applauded Mr. Gleason for deciding to scale back the company's financial-services unit.
 
Acquisitions by Other Units
Other divisions of Pacificorp have been active acquirers as well. Earlier this month Pacificorp and Pacific Telecom agreed to acquire North-West Telecommunications Inc. for $250 million. Under the agreement, shareholders of North-West, which operates telephone and cellular telephone services in Wisconsin, would receive 90 percent of the purchase price in Pacificorp stock, with the balance in cash.
Executives at other utilities declined to discuss Pacificorp's acquisition activity, but described the company's management as shrewd.
''They are well thought of in the industry,'' said Joe L. Gremban, chairman, president and chief executive of the Sierra Pacific Resources Corporation, a utility based in Reno. He added that he was not worried about Pacificorp making a bid for his company.
Nor should he be, Mr. Gleason said. Asked whether Pacificorp had its sights set on either Sierra Pacific or the Nevada Power Company of Las Vegas, he said no.
 
Views on Strategy
He described the company's history of growth by acquisition as more a matter of opportunism than any desire to dominate its market.
''It's not part of any grand strategy,'' Mr. Gleason said.
Some analysts think Pacificorp's acquisition strategy is to some extent a defensive one. ''I don't think Pacificorp wants to control transmission so much as to insure that it has access,'' said James V. Smith, an analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago.
While some analysts have predicted that there will eventually be only 50 utilities nationwide as increased competition forces small companies to merge, Mr. Gleason said that so far there had been only two or three significant mergers. A proposed merger between Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas and Electric is proceeding very slowly.
''I've always taken the position that there won't be a lot of utility mergers,'' Mr. Gleason said. Because the industry is so highly regulated by state and Federal agencies, ''there won't be huge premiums over book values because you can't earn enough to pay for it,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Post Broad Gain; Trading Off

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks gained strongly yesterday in exceptionally slow post-Thanksgiving trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.77 points, to 2,675.55. The bellwether indicator spurted to a 15-point gain within the first hour of trading, added seven more points by noon, and remained stable until slipping shortly before the close. For the week, the Dow rose 22.89 points, or slightly less than 1 percent. 
Blue-chip stocks held their gains after the Federal Reserve apparently moved to ease credit on Wednesday by adding reserves to the banking system. Analysts perceived the new target for Federal funds to be 8 1/4 percent. Yesterday, in an unexpected move, the Fed moved to arrest the decline in rates by draining some of those reserves from the banking system, but market analysts discounted the move as technical.
 
Prime Rate Cut Expected
''I think the major banks will reduce their prime rates a half a point, to 10 percent, early next week,'' said William M. Lefevre, investment strategist at Advest Inc. ''The recent strength of the long-neglected high-tech stock sector tends to improve the possibility for a significant year-end rally.''
Yesterday, major technology stocks were narrowly mixed, with I.B.M. up 1/4, to 100 3/8; Motorola up 5/8, to 58 1/4; Hewlett-Packard unchanged at 44 3/8, and Digital Equipment off 5/8, to 89 1/2. In over-the-counter trading, Intel was up 1/4, to 34 3/4, while Apple Computer was unchanged at 44 3/4.
Volume on the Big Board plunged to 86.3 million shares, its second-lowest turnover this year, from 145.7 million shares Wednesday. The slowest day so far this year was on July 3, when only 68.9 million shares were traded.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by more than a 2-to-1 ratio, with 931 issues up in price and 447 down.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.06 points, to 343.97, while the Big Board composite index added 1.08 points, to 190.29.
Interest rates declined in the credit markets. Prices of long-term Government bonds, which move in the opposite direction from interest rates, rose modestly, putting their yields by late in the day at 7.86 percent.
Among individual stocks, Primerica rose 1/2, to 28 1/2. The company announced that it had agreed to acquire BarclaysAmerican/Financial, the American consumer lending unit, from Barclays Bank for $1.35 billion in cash.
 
Texas Instruments Up 1 3/8
Texas Instruments jumped 1 3/8, to 37 7/8, in active trading. The stock continued to be spurred by Japan's recent awarding of a semiconductor patent to the company.
General Motors edged up 1/4, to 43. The company estimated an after-tax gain of about $82 million from the sale of a small part of its current 40.2 percent stake in Isuzu Motors Corporation Ltd.
Unisys was the most active Big Board stock, jumping 1 1/2, to 16, on a volume of nearly 3.5 million shares, including a block of one million shares. Earlier this week, it said a Defense Department contract could be worth $700 million.
 
Active Blue Chips Rise
Among actively traded blue chips, McDonald's rose 1/4, to 32 7/8; Philip Morris 1/8, to 41 1/2; Unocal 1/2, to 27 5/8, and Bristol-Myers 1/4, to 56 3/8. General Electric was unchanged at 60 1/8.
Gold and precious metal stocks continued strong, this time buoyed by a $7.90-an-ounce rise in the Comex spot price of gold, to $418.90 an ounce. Homestake Mining was up 1 1/8, to 19 3/8, while ASA added 1, to 57 1/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index gained 1.42 points, to 373.14, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.49 points, to 456.63.
Texas Air jumped 1 1/8, to 13, on the Amex. Pilots and flight attendants ended their strikes against the company's Eastern Airlines subsidiary.

HEADLINE: OPEC Seeks Kuwait and Emirate Oil Cut

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 24

 BODY:
An OPEC majority tried today to persuade two Persian Gulf Arab states, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, to agree to cut oil output, for fear that their excess production could weaken prices early in 1990.
Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were huddled in caucus groups in their hotel suites here on the second day of talks aimed at setting new output quotas, effective Jan. 1.
 
'Plenty of Ideas'
''There have been plenty of ideas, but we're still working,'' Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalaby, said. 
Kuwait and the Emirates, which are among the wealthiest members, have effectively boycotted OPEC accords for most of 1989 because the majority would not give them quotas as generous as they wanted. They have produced as they pleased, taking total OPEC output above 23 million barrels a day.
But other members are concerned that unless producers exercise some restraint in their output, prices could fall in the early part of next year.
''OPEC will have to agree to a cut in output of around 1.5 million barrels a day to have any chance of maintaining current prices,'' said Steve Turner, an oil analyst with a London brokerage firm, Smith New Court.
The global economy is expected to slow down, and that is expected to brake the rebound in demand for OPEC oil. In addition, North Sea oil is now flowing steadily after recent interruptions caused by accidents.
A Gulf Arab source said most of the 13 members believed that a ceiling on total OPEC supply could be safely set at 21.5 million barrels daily and perhaps as high as 22 million if all members agreed to stick to the rules.
The ministers are now grappling with the problem of getting Kuwait and the Emirates in under that ceiling. A compromise would require the two states to cut their output and oblige other members to cede some of their share of the total allowable OPEC volume.
The biggest exporter, Saudi Arabia, has so far refused to accept anything less than its current 24.46 percent share of whatever OPEC sells and shows no sign of easing that stance.
 
Another Makeshift Package
A failure to compromise would force OPEC to settle for a ''pro rata'' deal. That is shorthand for another makeshift package, probably again excluding Kuwait and the Emirates, in which new quotas would be assigned on the basis of existing percentage shares.
Consumers are not likely to be affected much either way. Current world prices range from $17 to $20 a barrel after averaging $14 in 1988.
New York futures for the January contract on the United States benchmark crude, West Texas Intermediate, remained today at $19.82 for a 42-gallon barrel.

HEADLINE: Farm Exports At $39.7 Billion

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The nation's exports of farm products in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 came close to the $40 billion forecast by Agriculture Department experts three months ago.
According to a detailed report by the department's Economic Research Service, the value of shipments in the 1989 fiscal year was almost $39.7 billion, up 12 percent from $35.3 billion in 1988. 
That was the biggest export value since the record $43.8 billion in 1981. It also marked the third consecutive year-to-year increase since exports plunged to $26.3 billion in 1986.
Officials said the 1989 export surge came despite a sharp cutback in the department's Export Enhancement Program, which subsidizes selected exports to designated overseas markets.
Agricultural imports, meanwhile, were valued at a record $21.5 billion, up from about $21 billion in 1988, the previous high. Vegetables, grain and grain products, sugar and rubber showed the largest increases, the report said.
As expected, the actual volume of 1989 exports of key commodities was down from the previous year. But higher unit prices for many items offset the decline in shipment tonnages.

HEADLINE: Drop Noted In Housing

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The F. W. Dodge Group, an industry research subsidiary of the McGraw-Hill Information Services Company, reported yesterday that 6 percent percent fewer homes were started in the United States in the third quarter of 1989 than in the corresponding period a year earlier.
''Housing starts have been running a steady 6 to 7 percent below last year's output since early in 1989, and the latest quarter brought no sign of an expected improvement,'' George Christie, chief economist at Dodge, said. ''But it's only a matter of time before the recent decline of mortgage rates stimulates a higher volume of building.''
Third-quarter starts totalled 364,369 units, compared with 387,758 a year ago.
The Government reported last week that housing starts surged 12 percent in October, for the biggest gain in three years. Housing starts react to changes in interest rates and are viewed as a leading indicator of activity in the real estate industry.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Weaker As Rise in Mark Continues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against most major currencies in quiet activity yesterday, trading near an 11-month low against the West German mark.
Currency dealers said the dollar's decline was largely a result of the mark's continuing strength.
The dollar slipped to 1.8040 marks in Europe, down from 1.8157 late Thursday, and the lowest level since it stood at 1.7955 marks on Jan. 5. 
In New York, the dollar traded at 1.8010 marks, down from 1.81275 marks late Wednesday. Financial markets in the United States were closed Thursday for the Thanksgiving holiday.
Louis Quilici, a dealer with the Harris Trust Company in Chicago, said the New York close was the lowest since Jan. 5, when the dollar closed at 1.8003 marks.
The mark has risen on anticipation that West Germany might have to raise interest rates to keep its economy from overheating. It is widely believed that West German growth will accelerate as East Germans continue to pour into the country after the recent political changes in East Germany.
Higher West German interest rates would raise returns on mark-denominated investments and stimulate demand for marks.
Concerns that American interest rates would fall because of weakness in the economy also helped depress the dollar, dealers said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.80 yen, down from Wednesday's 143.88 yen. The market in Japan was closed Thursday for a holiday. The dollar traded at 143.57 yen in London, but rose to 143.60 yen in New York, up from 143.10 Wednesday.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. A pound cost $1.5635 in London, up from $1.5610 late Thursday. But in New York, the pound traded at $1.5625, down from $1.5655 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday, included: 1.6095 Swiss francs, down from 1.6110; 6.1415 French francs, down from 6.1835; 1,326.75 Italian lire, down from 1,337.00, and 1.16725 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16875.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Is It Time to Buy Your Phone? Maybe

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is planning to raise rental rates for telephone equipment early next year, and consumer advocates are urging people who lease their home phones to buy them.
Most American households now own their telephones instead of leasing them from A.T.&T. or other private phone companies, as they had to do under the Bell System monopoly that was dismantled in this decade.
But about 30 million households still rent telephones from A.T.&T., which said last week that it planned to raise its leasing rates by an average of 12 percent in the first quarter of 1990. The increases would range from 25 cents to 95 cents a month, depending on the phone model. 
Nevertheless, not everyone should rush out and buy a phone; there are advantages to leasing for some consumers, and you can always change your mind and buy a phone.
 
Reasons for Leasing
 One reason to continue leasing is that no matter what happens to the phone, A.T.&T. will replace it, the company said. Households with young children should consider renting at least one phone that might be subject to accidents or abuse.
Another benefit of leasing is that consumers can experiment with different styles and colors. That is because A.T.&T. allows customers to exchange the rental phones at will.
Based on cost alone, the Consumer Federation of America, a consumer advocacy group in Washington, has advised residential consumers to buy their telephones because rental fees would cover the purchase price in less than two years. Renting A.T.&T.'s Touch-Tone phone at $5.10 a month for 10 months, for example, would cover the $49.95 price.
 
Quality of Phones Varies
 Gene Kimmelman, a spokesman for the consumer group, said, ''There's no question that you pay more for your phone if you lease it so it makes economic sense to buy.''
People buying telephones should be aware that there are more than 25 manufacturers of residential telephone equipment for the United States market, and their products vary in quality and performance.
Although most telephones that are for sale, including those from A.T.&T., come with a warranty of from one to five years, such coverage does not include damage to the phone from external sources; manufacturers will repair only malfunctions that occur in normal operation.
Sales representatives at electronics and telephone stores in New York recommend that consumers buy a phone with a well-known brand name that has at least a two-year warranty and easily accesible repair service.
Consumers will have to spend $20 to $60 for a decent telephone, and should avoid features they do not need. The store representatives recommend a touch-tone phone with a lighted dial pad and memory dialing, which allows emergency numbers to be put into the phone to be automatically dialed as needed.
A.T.&T. makes about 25 percent of the residential telephone equipment bought in the United States; sales of more than $1 billion for all brands are expected this year. The industry, which will produce 22 million residential phones this year, is highly fragmented. It includes big companies like Panasonic, Radio Shack, General Electric, Goldstar, Northern Telecom and Swiss Telephone, and also many small foreign and domestic concerns with little-known names.
''A lot of people buy A.T.&T. phones because of the name, and they think A.T.&T. phones will work better,'' said Yash Jesrani, president of the Phone Boutique in Manhattan, which competes with A.T.&T.'s stores. ''But that's not necessarily true, because these people are thinking of the old A.T.&T. electromechanical phones that were meant to last 30 years in the rental market. When you buy an A.T.&T. phone today, you are buying an electronic phone that will not take the beating that these older phones have taken.''
A spokeswoman for A.T.&T., Jo Johnston, said, ''If we were to make a phone that was guaranteed to last 20 years, the cost would be more than people are willing to pay.''
The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said consumers should be aware that several discount electronic stores have been selling refurbished telephones at the same prices they charge for new phones. If you buy a phone from a discount electronics store, ask if it is refurbished. By law, the store must inform the consumer if that is so.
A.T.&T. has expanded the products it leases to include cordless telephones, speaker phones, answering machines, facsimile machines, two-line phones and memory telephones. A cordless phone rents for $11.95 a month and costs $169 to buy; an answering machine leases for $8.50 a month and sells for $129, and a facsimile machine rents for a minimum of 12 months at $111.73 a month; after a year, it can be bought for $1, said Toni Mallozzi, manager of the Phone Center store on Staten Island.
Jeannette Noyes, research director for consumer communications at the Yankee Group, a market research firm in Boston, said, ''The future of the leasing market will be in offering these products, which give consumers an opportunity to sample equipment they are curious about but are not certain they want to buy.''
 
TO BUY OR LEASE?
 
LEASING
 
* Companies that lease pones will usually repair rental equipment no matter what happens to it.
 
* Rental phones canbe readily exchanged for different colors and styles.
 
* Telephone answering machines, cordless phones, facsimile machines and other divices can all be rented.
 

 
BUYING
 
* Cheaper than leasing. Monthly rental fee would cover the cost of buying a phone in less than two years.
 
* Buyers have a greater selection of styles, features and colors, including novelty phones.

HEADLINE: New Japan Car War Weapon: A 'Little Engine That Could'

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Having attracted American buyers for years with high quality and reliability, Japanese auto makers are now moving to win sales with a new competitive edge: technically advanced engines that burn fuel more efficiently and produce more power than most American engines.
The new engines, already available in many Japanese models, could provide Japan's powerful auto makers with another tool for increasing sales, just as Detroit seems to be closing the gap in quality and durability.
That prospect is particularly worrying, many experts say, at a time when the Big Three American auto makers are struggling to sell cars and keep their factories open.
 
More Efficient Fuel Use
The new ''multivalve engines'' are compact yet use additional engine valves to aid combustion. Burning fuel more efficiently, the advanced engines may also give their producers a lead in meeting tougher Federal regulations that are expected for pollution control and gasoline conservation. 
Multivalve engines increase efficiency by adding extra valves to the cylinders. A car gets power by igniting fuel within each cylinder, repeatedly creating an explosion that drives a piston. The pistons, one in each cylinder, move the shafts and gears that propel the wheels.
In a conventional combustion engine, each cylinder has one valve that lets in air that produces explosions when mixed with fuel, and one valve that vents exhaust. Thus, a typical four-cylinder engine has eight valves. But the most familiar engines used by Japanese auto makers in cars sold here now have four valves in each of the four cylinders. Even more advanced engines have five or more valves per cylinder.
Why are four valves, or more, better than two? By increasing the number of intake valves and exhaust valves and by moving the control shafts, or camshafts, closer to the valves, the engine can be made to produce much more horsepower without adding cylinders or making them bigger. The additional valves allow more air and fuel to enter the cylinder and allow exhaust to leave faster, increasing efficiency and power at higher operating speeds.
 
Japan Pushes; Detroit Lags
While Japanese car companies have pushed hard to bring the multivalve engine to the marketplace, Detroit has lagged. Among the big American producers, only General Motors offers the advanced engine, and in just a few models. Many auto industry analysts fear that the Detroit auto makers will pay for their sluggishness.
''It's important for domestic manufacturers to get these engines into vehicles aimed at younger buyers,'' said Christopher Cedergren, senior analyst for J. D. Power & Associates, a consulting firm on automotive issues. ''The domestics are stalling for time. By the end of the 1990's, the older engine technology they use today will be completely out.''
Like the videocassette recorder and the facsimile machine, the multivalve engine was invented in America but commercialized in Japan. It was first developed in the United States early in the century. Japanese auto makers introduced it in Japan in the early 1980's and in this country a few years later. The engines are now in a significant number of Japanese cars here, including many assembled in this country.
Just this month, for example, the Nissan Motor Corporation began selling its Infiniti Q-45, a $38,000 luxury car equipped with the most sophisticated multivalve engine yet offered in the United States. The Infiniti could steal sales from Cadillac and Lincoln.
Until recently, American auto makers for the most part delayed investing the money required to develop multivalve designs and mass-produce them, reasoning that consumers do not care what engine powers their car. The Big Three will not have those engines generally available for three to five years, people in the industry said.
 
More Flexibility in Design
Automotive engineers, foreign and domestic, agree that multivalve technology gives designers more flexibility because in many cases multivalve engines are smaller than engines of comparable power.
Aware of those advantages, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are each pursuing new multivalve engine programs. But all the while, Detroit executives and engineers continue to point out the engines' drawbacks.
Because they must operate at higher engine speeds to produce greater horsepower, multivalve engines have been criticized as too noisy and high-pitched. Big Three engineers say most American drivers are accustomed to a low-pitched, quiet rumble from conventional engines. A more important problem for the simplest multivalve engines is that while they can eventually bring the cars to higher speeds and accelerate faster at higher speeds, they offer somewhat slower pickup from a stop than a conventional engine.
 
Difficult to Repair
Multivalve engines are also more expensive to make and can be more difficult to repair. But Japanese auto makers have been steadily refining the engines and are offering models that address some of these problems.
Stiff taxes on large engines in Japan encouraged auto makers there to make small engines more powerful. The Japanese have begun to use the engines on all their cars, developing not only small multivalve engines that are peppy but also larger ones that are extremely powerful.
''You'll be seeing more and more of these engines in all cars,'' said Takashi Oka, general manager for product planning and marketing for Nissan. ''The cost of building multivalve engines is lower in Japan. All the Japanese manufacturers have been offering it, which reduces the cost, and we have a lot of experience, which also reduces the cost.''
A recent study by TRW Inc., a maker of valves, showed that every Honda car now sold in this country has multivalve technology, as do 70 percent of Toyotas, 54 percent of Nissans, 37 percent of Mazdas and 24 percent of Mitsubishis.
 
Europe Not Such a Threat
European auto makers have also begun to use such engines in high-performance and luxury cars. But these are not considered as much a threat to American models because few European models sold in the United States are in the low- and middle-price ranges.
But Japanese auto makers use the engines in the Toyota Camry and the Honda Accord, two of the most popular cars sold in this country. The newest of the engines in cars like the Infiniti Q-45 and the Honda NSX exhibit refinements that have not been matched by any manufacturer except Mercedes-Benz.
The Q-45's eight-cylinder engine has 32 valves, or four per cylinder, and uses complex electromechanical timing devices to vary the valve openings according to the speed of the engine.
With better valve control, the Q-45 accelerates quickly from a stop. This ability, in theory, removes one of the main reservations of American car makers about the multivalve engine. Most multivalve engines, however, do not have the refinements of the Q-45.
 
Big Three School of Thought
Many Big Three engineers dismiss the multivalve technology as inappropriate for a large portion of the American market and not worth the huge investment. According to this school of thought, many American consumers, particularly older drivers, prefer conventional American engines.
But the notion that consumers are not aware or are only dimly aware of new engine technology is being challenged by marketing experts. They maintain that more and more American car buyers make their decisions based on which products are more advanced technologically.
''The world's way isn't the American's way,'' said Leon Mandel, publisher of Autoweek, an enthusiasts' magazine. ''The rest of the world likes the hard-breathing little engine that could. To cling to big engines is begging for the return of the brontosaurus.''
 
Sales Are Faltering
Domestic auto makers can ill afford further erosion of customers; many assembly plants face permanent closings as sales fail to meet expectations. Since 1978 the share of the car market in the United States belonging to domestic producers has dropped from almost 84 percent to just under 69 percent in 1988.
Don Miles, chief engineer for G.M.'s Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac group, said G.M. engines ''are every bit as sophisticated'' as any in the world. Many engines produced by the Big Three are based on designs in use since the early 1960's, but there have been improvements through the introduction of electronic controls and the reduction of friction, he said.
Mr. Miles acknowledged the superior efficiency of multivalve engines, but said it comes at a cost. ''Obviously, multivalve engines are more complex, more expensive to manufacture and have higher piece value,'' meaning their more numerous components cost more, he said. For those and other reasons, G.M. rejected multivalve technology for its current line of six-cylinder Buick engines, he said.
 
G.M.'s Design
G.M. is the only American car company that makes a multivalve engine for use in this country. G.M.'s advanced engine is called the Quad Four and is offered as an option on several 1990 models, including, for the first time, some midsize cars like the Buick Regal. G.M. built about nine million engines last year in North America, about 190,000 of which were Quad Fours.
Producing these engines requires a high degree of manufacturing precision, a skill at which Japanese auto makers have proved adept, said David Cole, director of the University of Michigan's office of transportation studies. American manufacturers only recently improved their production processes enough to begin considering such projects.
Industry analysts calculate that an American car company would have to spend $500 million or more to design a plant to produce it. G.M. will not say what the Quad Four program cost, but the price is thought to be in that neighborhood.

HEADLINE: Law Professor Takes Soviets by Storm With Crisp Oratory and Hard Work

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The fastest rising political star in the Soviet Union is not a Communist Party luminary, flamboyant populist, angry dissident or smoldering nationalist.
He is a law professor named Anatoly A. Sobchak, and as the new Soviet legislature struggles to build a legal foundation under its wobbly experiment in greater democracy, it sometimes seems that the entire country has become his classroom.
Thanks to the appealing televised sessions of the Supreme Soviet, Mr. Sobchak has become the most influential of the country's radical reformers - apostles of free markets, private property and competing political parties - and seems to have eclipsed Boris N. Yeltsin, the popular Moscow maverick, in the public's affection.
When Soviet pundits and voters speculate about an eventual alternative to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the name that comes up most often now is Mr. Sobchak's - an ambition he is very careful to disavow as wild speculation. 
 
'Time for Teaching'
''Some people think in five years I'll be in jail, others think I'll be the President,'' he jokes when pressed on his plans. ''But I think in five years it'll be time for me to go back to teaching.''
In the eight months since he was elected to represent a district in Leningrad, Mr. Sobchak, who is 52, has become a national favorite by combining strong opinions and a crisp oratory with a mastery of lawmaking.
Because the Soviet Parliament has only a handful of lawyers among its 542 members - and most of those, including Mr. Gorbachev, are really career party functionaries - Mr. Sobchak's skills are indispensable as the legislature defines basic principles like the rights of ownership, freedom of the press, police powers and the mechanics of democracy.
''In the United States, I was surprised to find an ironic attitude toward lawyers,'' said Mr. Sobchak, who recently returned from his first venture to a capitalist country. ''You have so many lawyers that the people, the constituents, even the Congressmen themselves tend to smirk at them.''
 
A Neglected Profession
In this country, however, the law, like history, has been a neglected profession because promising candidates knew that the Communist Party was frequently above the law.
One result of the deficit is that it is hard to imagine the new legislature without Mr. Sobchak. He is chairman of a subcommittee that clears all legislation on the economy, sits on a committee that keeps track of new laws for compliance with the constitution and is also a member of special committees drafting a new constitution, investigating police violence in Soviet Georgia and planning next month's Congress of People's Deputies.
He bounds to the microphone to speak on almost every proposed law, citing international precedents from memory, chopping the air with his hands, and usually commanding respectful attention from his colleagues.
Early in the session, he led the battle to defeat the Government's candidate for Foreign Trade Minister, arguing that the nominee was unqualified. A majority agreed with him, and the verdict was one of the first clear signs of the new Parliament's independence.
 
On Communists' Standing
More recently, he took on Mr. Gorbachev on the question of eliminating Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which enshrines the Communist Party as ''the leading and guiding force'' in Soviet life.
Mr. Sobchak, a party member, argued for repeal, saying the party should be required to earn its power. Mr. Gorbachev contended that this would be an unwarranted slap at the party just as it is trying to coax the country in an unsettled period.
Mr. Sobchak fell two votes short and would have won except that many members abstained. He said he expected to prevail at the full congress, some 2,250 deputies from which the 542-member Supreme Soviet is chosen.
Mr. Sobchak has been aggressive in defense of free enterprise, arguing that economic power is the real front line in the battle with hard-liners in the party and Government.
 
Compromise on Cooperatives
When a group of legislators mounted an assault on private cooperatives, reflecting a general public resentment of the new and prospering entrepreneurial class, Mr. Sobchak crafted a compromise that restricted high-stakes speculators but minimized the effect on most businessmen.
Mr. Sobchak has his share of enemies in Parliament, including representatives of the official trade unions, who have recently tried to gain political ground by waging a grass-roots campaign against free enterprise.
This week, he was fiercely attacked in the union newspaper Trud for opposing a union-backed price freeze. He lost that one.
Mr. Sobchak nonetheless takes his free-enterprise argument to factories, where he tells blue-collar constituents that the reason American workers live better is because they work harder, and that is because capitalism generally punishes lazy workers and rewards productive ones.
 
Blue-Collar Popularity
''Our demagogic slogans about equality have made our people lose their love for work,'' he said.
Soviet journalists say that informal polls and letters to the press show that Mr. Sobchak's popularity among blue-collar voters is extremely high, despite the unions' attempt to paint him as a closet capitalist.
Mr. Sobchak joined the Communist Party only last year, holding out, he says, until Mr. Gorbachev vowed to withdraw all Soviet troops from Afghanistan.
Along with Mr. Yeltsin, the human rights campaigner Andrei D. Sakharov, the historian Yuri N. Afanaseyev and others, he is a member of the fledgling parliamentary opposition, the interregional deputies group. But he has grown frustrated by the group's internecine squabbles and inability to mount legislative campaigns.
Mr. Yeltsin has all but dropped from sight, after a couple of spectacular political pratfalls, including his mysterious claim, later retracted, that abductors tried to drown him in the Moscow River. Mr. Afanaseyev, bitter at the slow pace of change, remains an outsider. Mr. Sakharov participates in legislation, slowed by age and illness.
 
Suporter of Gorbachev
''A parliament cannot exist without factions,'' Mr. Sobchak said. ''The interregional group is a prototype. But it's hard to say what will become of it.''
Although Mr. Sobchak describes himself as a fervent supporter of Mr. Gorbachev, he criticizes the Soviet leadership for wavering at moments of crisis, for being afraid to rely on the new laws it passes.
He argues, for instance, that the Government should not have dawdled in prolonged negotiations with this month's strike by coal miners in northern Siberia.
''We passed a law providing measures for dealing with strikes that are found to be illegal: close the enterprise and fire all those who took part in the illegal strike,'' he said. ''Remember how Reagan stopped the air controllers' strike. If a strike harms the interests of the people, decisive action must be taken. Not by using the troops but by using the law.''
''I think the greatest danger is indecisiveness, half-way measures, and deviations in the work of the leadership,'' he added. ''The greatest danger today, I think, is Gorbachev's loss of authority among the people. That's the greatest danger, because it's precisely the loss of authority of the present leadership could lead to dire consequences.''

HEADLINE: U.S. May Cut Dues to U.N. Over Arab Resolution

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The United States will drastically cut funds to the Rome-based United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization if the agency agrees next week to cooperate with the Palestine Liberation Organization on agricultural development in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Administration officials say.
For the first time, Arab members have introduced a resolution in the agency's governing General Conference calling on the organization to ''provide the Palestinian people with the assistance necessary for their economic development in close cooperation with the Palestine Liberation Organization.''
If the Arabs secure the backing of a majority at the General Conference, the resolution is certain to pass, American officials say. They point out that France appears ready to back the resolution. 
''We are very concerned about this resolution and expending every diplomatic effort at this late hour,'' John R. Bolton, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, said in a telephone interview. ''If it is passed, it will be a sad day for the F.A.O.'' The resolution, due for a vote on Monday, says ''that the practices of the Israeli occupying authorities impede the basic requirements for the development of the economy of the occupied Palestinian territories.''
It ''expresses opposition to the Israeli confiscation of Palestinian land and the expropriation of Palestinian water resources.'' The resolution asks the agency to include the occupied territories in ''future programs and activities in line with present cooperation and coordination between the Palestine Liberation Organization and other United Nations agencies.''
United States officials say they strongly oppose the resolution, arguing that it amounts to ''massive politicization'' of a technical United Nations body charged with promoting agriculture in the developing world.
Since the Palestine National Council declared the existence of a Palestinian state in the occupied territories last year, the United States has successfully blocked Arab campaigns to win recognition of the P.L.O. as a government by the United Nations and several of its specialized agencies, including the World Health Organization and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
But this time the Arab members are asking the organization to treat the P.L.O. as the Palestinian people's representative in agricultural matters.
Approval of the resolution, officials say, would trigger immediate retaliation by the United States in the form of further reductions of its payments to the agency. ''They would go to the bottom of the heap,'' one official said.
American officials point out that the P.L.O. resolution comes after the General Conference defied the United States and other Western contributors by forcing through a 3-percent increase in the agriculture agency's 1990 budget after making allowance for inflation.
This violated the major Western contributors' collective policy of seeking to impose zero real growth on all United Nations spending. The United States and other major contributors, which together pay 58 percent of the agency's costs, either voted against the new budget or abstained.
The Administration originally asked Congress to pay to the agency $61.3 million, the full assessed contribution of the United States, as well as an additional $8 million toward its accumulated arrears of $82 million. The agency's budget for next year is $270 million. The United States pays about 25 percent of the budget.
But since Congress voted less than the Administration requested for all regular dues to United Nations agencies and gave no money for arrears, the Administration is bound to cut its payments to the agency next year.
Just how much further the Administration could cut its contribution to the agency raises the sensitive question of whether the United States wants to retain full voting rights in the organization, officials say. If the United States pays less than $18 million next year, its arrears will total two years' dues and it would be liable to lose its voting rights in the organization.

HEADLINE: Polls Find Their Way to a Bigger Role in India

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Nov. 25

 BODY:
As India moves into its fifth decade of regular democratic elections, opinion surveys and the polling of voters are beginning to play bigger roles in political reporting and analysis.
Polls have begun to alter the way newspapers and magazines cover election campaigns. This year, with more polling planned, premature leaks of results could affect voting in a country where ballots are being cast over five days, some politicians fear.
Polling is being done mostly by private research groups. Political parties do not have their own polling organizations, although the ruling Congress Party is known to use the services of the country's Intelligence Bureau to assess its chances as well as monitor its opponents. A former Congress Party minister now in the opposition said that Intelligence Bureau reports also aided in determining election dates. 
The growth of polling in a country of more than 810 million people living in sharply different regions and cultures, speaking more than a dozen major languages and hundreds of local dialects, raises questions about how accuracte opinion samples can be in reflecting a common Indian view. ''There are fairly major problems here,'' Prannoy Roy, India's leading poll taker and analyst of political statistics, acknowledged in an interview this week.
The findings of polls made for two influential news magazines, India Today and Sunday, were released last weekend. Both showed the Congress Party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi losing its majority in a 545-seat Parliament, though by differing margins. Both indicated that Mr. Gandhi would have to build a coalition of some kind to remain in power. An Indian Prime Minister is not directly elected, but chosen from the party or parties commanding a majority in the lower house of Parliament.
Mr. Roy commented on what he considers some of the essentially Indian obstacles to succesful polling. ''First, there tends to be a bias in favor of the ruling party, which has to be discounted in opinion polls,'' he said, adding that many Indian voters, the majority of whom are illiterate and rural, are apparently fearful of speaking against authority. Polling is not yet a familiar process to them, and may be mistaken for an official survey.
Some political analysts say that if this factor is taken into account, anti-Government opinions expressed in recent polls may be stronger than they appear on the surface.
Mr. Roy, who recently selected the constituencies to be included in the nationwide poll made by the private Marketing and Research Group for India Today, said that he believed that answers given to poll interviewers in India had an accuracy - or truthfulness - rate of 60 to 75 percent.
But he added that apprehension about revealing biases or what are regarded as unacceptable opinions was not uniquely Indian. He pointed to recent reports of polling skewed in the United States by white voters unwilling to admit publicly that they would vote against black candidates in mayoral and gubernatorial races.
Polling in India does encounter other problems unfamiliar to Western poll takers, according to Mr. Roy, a former adviser to the Ministry of Finance and teacher at the Delhi School of Economics who is now a member of the Policy Group research organization and a political commentator on television.
''In Hindi, or other Indian languages, there is no word for privacy,'' Mr. Roy said. ''People interviewed alone about their political preferences clam up. In groups, they don't mind talking openly about their voting behavior.'' He said that this pattern was common in talking about other personal, even intimate, concerns.
Mr. Roy said there were two ways to circumvent the Indian's unwillingness to be interviewed. One is to ask the respondent to mark a sample election ballot, an anonymous and familiar task. The other is to give in to local custom and interview people in groups.
The value of polling is not limited to election times, scholars here say. Poll results, and the analysis of electoral statistics, would go a long way in explaining to political scientists how and why Indians vote. In this use of polls, India is beginning to find its way.

HEADLINE: Europe's Changes Mean Earlier Word of Attack

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
American intelligence experts have concluded that the United States is likely to have about a month or more of warning of a full-scale Soviet attack in Europe, or far more than it previously thought, Administration officials say.
The new intelligence assessment comes as Pentagon officials are already rethinking military planning as a result of the political changes in Eastern Europe and the need to trim military spending because of the Federal budget deficit.
For years the Pentagon's basic planning document, the Defense Planning Guidance, has assumed that the West would have just 14 days' warning of a full-scale Soviet attack in Europe through monitoring Soviet troop movements by satellite and other means, military officials said.
But a new intelligence analysis indicates that the increased openness of Soviet society, Soviet cuts in conventional arms and improved American capabilities for intelligence gathering would now give the Pentagon about a month to three months of warning of a full-scale Soviet attack in Europe. 
 
Impact on Purchasing Decisions
The question of how much warning time the United States may have before an attack has an important bearing on a number of crucial military issues, including whether the Pentagon should spend billions on new planes, like the C-17 transport plane, or ships, which would take longer to move troops and supplies to Europe. In addition, it has important implications for whether the United States should depend more on reserve units, which would be mobilized in the event of an impending war.
Although Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said recently that the risk of a Soviet attack is the lowest since World War II, planning for even the remote possibility of a full-scale attack remains a central Pentagon mission.
The revised analysis, distributed throughout the Government in September, updates an earlier National Intelligence Estimate on warning of a Soviet conventional attack and reflects one of the first steps taken by the Government to adjust American national security thinking to changing conditions in Europe.
 
Disagreement on Warning
Pentagon experts disagreed, however, about the degree to which the revised warning estimate should alter military planning.
One senior Pentagon official played down the importance of the change, asserting that there was a risk that the United States might not make effective use of early indications of Soviet moves and prepare for an attack. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a couple of additional weeks of warning would not be enough to overturn basic purchasing decisions.
But other military experts said the increase in the amount of warning time was potentially significant. They said the actual warning is likely to be even greater than the month, which is the minimum of the range suggested by the new intelligence report, because of continued changes in Eastern Europe. The report reflected a consensus among the different intelligence agencies.
Experts also said the National Intelligence Officer for Warning, a Central Intelligence Agency official responsible for assessing warning time, has informed senior officials that he believes Washington would have more than 60 days' warning of Soviet preparations for full-scale war. The warning would be based on changes in the Soviet economy, mobilization of reserve units and changes in the training tempo of units.
The risk of a surprise attack, in which the Soviets would not undertake an extensive mobilization before attacking, is considered to be low because the Soviets are cutting their forces in Europe.
 
Delay in Producing Report
The changes in the intelligence estimates come as Pentagon officials have begun to redraft the planning guidance. That guidance, however, has yet to be completed even though it was scheduled to be finished by Oct. 1.
The delay in outlining new planning assumptions that could be used as a guide for budget cutting has led some military officials to complain that deliberations over budgets in future years are being carried out in a policy vacuum.
But aides to Mr. Cheney say the delay in completing the planning guidance stems from the rapid pace of change in Europe. The new planning guidance is expected to take account of Soviet cuts in their forces in Europe that would be made under an emerging conventional arms agreement by outlining changed assumptions about the rate at which the United States would then need to reinforce its units in Europe if war was near.
The question of how much warning the United States might have of a full-scale attack has been debated within the Pentagon for years.
For years the planning guidance has outlined a scenario in which a full-scale conflict would begin with a Soviet attack on Iran, which would be intended to extend the Soviet military reach to the Persian Gulf. That would be followed by an attack on central Europe. Under the planning scenario, the West would have 14 days of warning of the conflict, said Pentagon officials, who asked not be identified.
Dov S. Zakheim, a senior Pentagon official during the Reagan Administration who oversaw the preparation of the planning guidance, said some top military officials questioned the plausibilty of the planning scenario.
 
'Add Some Realism'
''An effort was made during the Reagan Administration to add some realism to the scenario,'' Mr. Zakheim said, adding that senior officials questioned the realism of the planning assumptions ''in terms of both warning time and the way in which the purported conflict began.''
Mr. Zakheim asserted that the effort to reform the military guidance foundered because it undermined major assumptions for some purchasing plans.
The issue of strategic warning came up again when the Bush Administration conducted its review of military policy this spring.
Robert B. Costello, then the Assistant Defense Secretary for Production and Logistics, pushed for a reassessment of warning time.
''It is substantially longer than assumed. We probably have months instead of weeks,'' he said in an interview this week.
Mr. Costello, who left the Pentagon in May, said that there was strong resistance to adopting new warning assumptions, which would call existing Pentagon plans into question. ''I fought like hell to get one sentence in there saying that warning time was an important issue and was not well defined,'' Mr. Costello said.
 
Exaggeration or Realistic
A senior Pentagon planner, however, asserted that Mr. Costello was exaggerating the significance of the changes in warning to buttress his case for canceling the multibillion program to produce the C-17 transport plane. The planner said other factors, like the level of Soviet forces in Europe, were more important considerations in American military planning than warning time.
Another Pentagon expert, who discussed the warning issue on the condition that he not to be identified, said the assumption of 14 days of warning of full-scale attack was a ''plausible answer in the 1970's.''
''It probably remained a plausible answer as we worked our way into the 1980's. But things began to change on both sides,'' he said, noting the effects of the Reagan Administration arms buildup and political changes in Eastern Europe.
This official argued that the Pentagon needs to be prudent in revising its military plans in case the changes by the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev fail, leading to a reversal of Soviet policies. He also noted the difficulty that Pentagon planners have in grappling with the fast pace of changes in Eastern Europe.
''This is seen as chapter one,'' this official said of the new warning estimate. ''This story is not over.'' But Mr. Zakheim, the former Pentagon official, said the Pentagon needs to update its planning guidance despite the uncertainities. ''If the Defense Guidance is not changed materially from past few years, it will be absolutely useless to Cheney,'' he said.
