HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Scholars Say Veneer of Nonchalance Masks Worry on German Unification

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Experts at American universities say anxiety about the prospect of German reunification is widespread in Europe and the United States despite declarations by Western leaders that they are unconcerned and that the issue should be resolved by the Germans themselves.
Reached while visiting Munich, Fritz Stern, a Columbia University professor who is an authority on Germany, said ''there is concern in Europe'' despite the ''official statements from Western leaders saying they are not worried.''
Mr. Stern, the Seth Low Professor of History at Columbia, said he believed that ''an early reunification is extremely unlikely, for any number of reasons.''
''The only possibility, I would say, would be that if the magnificent and disciplined spontaneity of the East Germans gets out of hand, so to speak, and forces a decision,'' he said. ''If that occurs, then one doesn't know. Then everything's up for grabs.'' 
''At the moment, I think there is puzzlement and reluctance, even in Bonn'' about reunification, he said. ''I hope it is not ever going to happen without very careful negotiations with the four Allied powers'' - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France.
 
Neighbors Remember the Past
''What I'm concerned about right now is that when Germans start thinking about a future of greatness, their neighbors begin to think about the past,'' he went on. ''This has disturbing psychological implications.''
''On the other hand,'' he said, ''one ought not to forget that the circumstances in which a united Germany would find itself,'' say, at the beginning of the 21st century, ''would be very different from the conditions that existed in 1900.'' Then, he said, ''Germany faced a nonintegrated Europe, and its power was greater than that of any of its neighbors.''
Speaking from California, Gordon A. Craig, an expert on Germany and a former president of the American Historical Association, said he found ''a good deal'' of concern in the United States, as well as Europe, about reunification - concern that he said ''is offset by our admiration of the progress that democracy has made in West Germany, which is undeniable.'' Just an Enlarged West Germany? Professor Craig, who is retired from Stanford University, said, ''I don't think reunification can be avoided in the long run.'' He observed that some commentators, including Vice President Dan Quayle, ''have indicated that they believe it would be fine because a reunified Germany would be simply an enlarged German Federal Republic.''
''Other people, including myself, would consider that a singularly incautious statement,'' Professor Craig said. He noted that other analysts, including Henry A. Kissinger, have said ''they believed reunification was inevitable, but nevertheless indicated that they hoped it could be done, if it must be done, under certain restraints and not too fast, and without destroying the balance of power in Europe, which has been based, after all, on a divided Germany and has endured and given peace for over 40 years.''
Professor Craig, whose books include ''The Germans'' and ''The End of Prussia,'' suggested that the negative feelings were a growing undercurrent in the United States. He added, ''I was surprised to find in the San Francisco Chronicle a cartoon showing Adolf Hitler wearing a label saying 'Reunification.'''
The professor rejected that linkage, saying, ''We have never had any occasion to fear a sudden flare-up of the kind of nationalism'' represented by Nazism, ''or a return of an Adolf Hitler and that sort of thing.'''
 
Fear of Shift in German Thinking
But he raised questions about the thinking and politics of a reunited Germany, saying ''There is no doubt in my mind that a nation of 80 million people, united under one government, will sooner or later begin to think differently than a divided Germany of 57 million on one side and 17 million on the other.''
''How differently they will think, we don't know,'' he added. But he said there was likely to be a greater emphasis on the view that ''we Germans are a nation in the middle of Europe with our own interests, and we are not a Western nation.'''
Professor Craig, an emeritus J. E. Wallace Sterling Professor of Humanities at Stanford, added, ''It would be interesting to speculate on what the composition'' of the parliament ''would be in a new united Germany, how many new parties there would be, and what the strength of the pro-Western democratic parties would be compared with the others.''
William E. Griffith, the Ford Professor of Political Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a specialist on contemporary European history, said he felt ''there is more anxiety'' about the prospect of reunification ''in private among non-German West European and American elites than has been publically stated.''
 
Changes Wrought by Defeat
But Professor Griffith, an official of the American Embassy in Bonn in 1985 and 1986, said, ''The governments of the West are - quite correctly, in my view - supporting the concept of German unity, assuming that the East and West Germans want it.''
''The polls show that West European and American mass public opinion generally seems to endorse this,'' he said, ''and I personally think the fears of these elites are incorrect.''
He pointed to changes wrought in both Germanies by the shock of the German defeat in World War II. ''The Germans have learned the same lesson that the French learned at Waterloo,'' he said, ''that nothing fails like total failure.''
Professor Charles S. Maier of the Harvard University history department, whose books include ''The Unmasterable Past: History, Holocaust and German National Identity,'' said ''One reason you haven't heard more expressions of alarm'' about the prospect of a reunited Germany is that officially the Allied Powers ''never were opposed to the idea of reunification.''
''Indeed, they envisaged it as part of postwar development,'' he said, ''and if in 1945-46 the four powers were committed in theory to reunification, it's hard 40 years later for them to change their minds.''
 
'1989 Is Not 1939'
Another reason that more worry has not been aired, said Professor Maier, who specializes in 20th-century European history, is that ''1989 is not 1939: the power relations in the world in which a reunited Germany might one day reappear would not permit Germany that same drive for hegemony that it earlier demonstrated.''
He said that he and like-minded analysts ''who are relatively accepting of German reunification'' feel that way ''because we see it within a framework of many sorts of cross-cutting guarantees and economic connections among the European states.''
''Whether it's West Germany or reunited Germany, one faces a country with an extraordinary amount of economic muscle,'' Professor Maier said, ''and it will not always be pleasant dealing with a power to which one becomes economically beholden. But I don't see substantive danger.''
''I don't rule out that there could be a revival of an unpleasant nationalism'' in a reunited Germany, he continued. ''But the West German republic has demonstrated essentially 40 years of decent democratic behavior.'' Referring to West Germans below the ages of 35 or 40, he said ''they may eventually want a reunited Germany, but this generation of Germans is a European generation, far more than any of the earlier generations were; they don't want to lose that.''
 
Wanting to Be 'Good Europeans'
Joseph Rothschild, the Class of 1919 Professor of Political Science at Columbia University and a specialist in East Central Europe, said he did not believe the East Germans ''would want to or would be capable of reversing'' what he called the eagerness of ''the West German public to be deemed good Europeans and to participate in the further integration of the European Community.''
Andrei S. Markovits, a Professor of Political Science at Boston University and the author of ''The Politics of the West German Trade Unions,'' said, ''My head says there's nothing to worry about'' in the prospect of reunification. ''It says very clearly that the Federal Republic has become one of the most stable, reliable, liberal democracies.''
But, he added, ''My heart tells me the track record was actually pretty bad'' earlier, with ''the Germans being mainly responsible for three major wars'' in less than 75 years - the Franco-Prussian War and the two World Wars.
He said he felt some anxiety that in ''a worst-case scenario,'' the world might witness the rise of a ''nationalist, expansionist, dominating, potentially remilitarized Germany that will completely upset the balance of power.'' But he said that a best-case scenario was more likely, in which Germans eventually would become ''the vanguard in establishing liberal democracies all over over Eastern Europe.''

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
In Moscow, Support for Pole Is Moral but Not Financial

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, said today that he had achieved ''complete unanimity'' with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on key issues of European security, but he evidently won no immediate help from the Kremlin in dealing with his economic crisis.
At a news conference tonight, the Solidarity Prime Minister could cite no progress on a number of economic issues that he raised with Soviet officials, including increasing deliveries of Soviet oil and gas, cutting the share Poland pays for the upkeep of Soviet troops on its soil, postponing repayment of the country's large debt to Moscow and compensating Poles deported to the Soviet Union during and after World War II.
''I would ask you to understand that we can hardly expect that in one or two days we can solve all those issues,'' Mr. Mazowiecki told reporters. 
 
Katyn Massacre an Issue
Moscow has also withheld, so far, one concession that would allow him to return home in triumph, a change of official position on the massacre of thousands of Polish officers in the Katyn Forest during World War II.
The Soviet position, currently under review by an official commission, is that the crime was committed by Nazis in 1941 and not, as the Poles and Western historians contend, by Soviet troops acting on orders from Stalin in 1940.
Mr. Mazowiecki is to visit Katyn on Sunday, and the possibility remains that the Soviets will use the occasion to signal a change of position.
Mr. Mazowiecki seemed buoyed by his Moscow visit, which has confirmed for Poland and its neighbors that a Government led by non-Communists can have a cordial, even blossoming relationship with Moscow.
The leaders agreed heartily on maintaining the postwar borders in Europe, and Mr. Mazowiecki said he would support a statement by the four major victorious allies in the European theater of World War II - the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union -reaffirming the current boundaries as inviolable. ''Respect for the existing borders in Europe is a guarantee of stability,'' he said, adding that he and the Soviet leaders were in ''complete unanimity'' on such questions.
 
Longtime Taboos Discussed
The meeting itself, between the first non-Communist Government leader in the Eastern bloc and the Soviet leader, would have been unthinkable a year ago, and many of the subjects on the agenda were also longtime taboos.
It was clear that the most difficult issues were economic, with Poland suffering from huge foreign debts and long-range fuel shortages, but Moscow in poor condition to help.
The Poles have asked Moscow to increase natural gas deliveries in the next five years from 40 billion cubic meters to 50 billion, but Mr. Mazoweicki said tonight that deliveries were to continue at the same level. Moreover, the Poles are to move toward paying in hard currency, rather than in the easier currency of Polish-built machinery.
Mr. Mazowiecki said that he did not question the presence of 40,000 Soviet troops in Poland but that he did ask the Soviet Union to review Poland's payments for their upkeep, receiving a promise of study but no clear commitment.
Mr. Mazowiecki has also met with Poles living in the Soviet union, and in talks with Soviet officials he offered to send Polish language teachers to help them preserve their heritage.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Japan Will Help Poland and Hungary

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Responding to appeals from the Bush Administration and European nations, Japan has announced that it would provide $150 million in loans to Poland as an initial step to help both Poland and eventually Hungary deal with their financial crises and break loose from the Soviet bloc.
Japanese officials said the initial sum would likely be followed by more for emergency food aid and technical assistance for both Poland and Hungary, plus a ''fairly impressive'' sum of money for economic development for Poland and Hungary once they work out some of their financial problems.
In making the announcement on Friday, officials in the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said the money for Poland, while only a fraction of what is being raised in the United States and Europe, was considerably higher than the Foreign Ministy had expected to provide only a month ago.
 
Widening Scope of Aid
The recent dramatic opening of governments in Eastern Europe was said by the officials to have spurred them to widen the traditional scope of Japan's foreign assistance, until now generally geared to poor countries in Asia and Africa. 
Aides to Mr. Kaifu say also that Mr. Kaifu would like to visit Poland and Hungary in January to strengthen his credentials as a statesman, and that the announcement on the aid was timed to coincide with such a trip. Mr. Kaifu said recently that support for Eastern Europe was ''increasingly important for Japan.''
Japanese officials say Tokyo has moved cautiously in aiding Poland and Hungary because of budget constraints, charges of waste and fraud in its foreign aid programs, and the belief by many officials that Japanese foreign aid should be restricted to the world's poorest countries.
Some officials said that it was extremely difficult to persuade the Finance Ministry to release even the $150 million for Poland, and that one condition for its release was that it would be given in the form of low-cost loans rather than outright grants.
 
Conditions Set for Poland
Japanese officials also said the loans would be granted on the condition that Poland works out a debt rescheduling and adjustment plan with international agencies, such as the International Monetary Fund.
Tokyo has provided only nominal economic assistance over the years to countries in the Soviet bloc, except for loans to spur Japanese exports to those countries. For example, more than a billion dollars in loans were granted to Poland from the 1970's to increase, but these are now in arrears.
Japanese officials said the repayment of these would have to be rescheduled before new loans could be authorized beyond the $150 million announced today.
The $150 million is to take the form of low-interest credits for the purchase of commodities, not necessarily from Japan, with the ultimate purpose to help Poland stabilize the exchange rate of its currency, the zloty.
Poland has asked for the establishment of a $1 billion fund to set up a single legal exchange rate for the zloty, which is now sold for dollars on the black market at nearly 10 times the official exchange rate. The fund would buy and sell currencies to establish the value of the zloty as somewhere between the official rate and the black market rate.
 
More Aid Under Study
Japanese officials said they could provide no figures on the amount of emergency food aid and technical assistance for Poland, but some news reports in Japan suggest this money would be in the range of $40 million.
The Japan Economic Journal, a leading newspaper, said Japan was considering an addition $40 million package for Poland and Hungary to help it adjust from a state-controlled and state-owned economy to a free-enterprise economy.
Some officials say the Japanese aid could provide an incentive for Japan's private businesses to increase their trade and investment in Eastern Europe, although businessmen say they are wary because of the poor history of repayment on investments.
According to the Japan Economic Journal, trade between Japan and eight Eastern European countries was only 0.4 percent of Japan's total $452 billion trade in 1988. It said further that Japanese companies have only 32 joint ventures in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, compared with more than 3,000 joint ventures with other western nations.
A Japanese automobile company is considering a project to produce passenger cars, the newspaper said, but is mindful of past difficulties in setting up similar projects in other Eastern European countries, including a stalled project by Suzuki to build a passenger car plant in Hungary.

HEADLINE: Farewells and On to Moscow for Younger Set

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Aeroflot flights from here to Moscow were serving a younger-than-usual clientele this week, as dozens of Soviet teen-agers slung backpacks over faded denim jackets and bid farewell to the educational, economic and emotional realities of the United States.
While Soviet visits are hardly remarkable in an age when flights from Moscow are routinely full, American educators and Government officials believe the sheer number of Soviet high school and college students coming here - 700 this academic year, and as many as 1,500 next year, compared to fewer than 20 in 1986 - represent a fundamental shift in Soviet priorities.
Where once Soviet officials used the limited academic exchange slots for postdoctoral physicists, chemists and engineers, hoping to transplant Western scientific skills, they now use the vastly expanded exchange opportunities to send lawyers, sociologists and high school and college students. The goal, American officials believe, is to transplant less quantifiable skills: independent thinking, motivation, risk-taking and choice-making. 
 
'To Make Up for Lost Time'
''They are trying to internationalize themselves in a hurry. If they are going to enter the modern information stream, they are going to need people who've had some outside experience,'' said Alan Kasoff, who heads IREX, which for three decades has handled exchanges of Soviet and American scholars. ''They're trying to make up for lost time,'' he added.
''There is an awareness at the highest levels of the Soviet educational leadership that there are gaps in Soviet training that need to be dealt with now,'' said Dan Davidson, an official of the American Council of Teachers of Russian who heads the United States-Soviet High School Academic Partnership Program, which began last year under the auspices of an agreement signed by President Reagan and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow in 1988.
''They need developmental work on how to read critically and think independently,'' Mr. Davidson added. ''There is great admiration there for the way Americans are motivated, the way they go to work on their own.''
Of the 900 students coming to the United States on exchanges this year, 700 are in high school and are staying for about a month each, and 200 are undergraduates staying for either a semester or, in most cases, a full academic year. Several Soviet students have also matriculated in undergraduate degree programs at American universities.
 
U.S. Behind in Math and Sciences
Soviet admiration of American education, Mr. Davidson and other specialists agree, is not unalloyed. Many of the Soviet college and high school students who arrive here find their American counterparts two, three or even four years behind them in math and the sciences.
But what American students lack in depth of knowledge is balanced, Soviet exchange students and teachers said, by their ability to explore different fields and put their knowledge to practical use.
The American students' comparative freedom to explore academic alternatives was particularly alien and enticing for students brought up with a Soviet education, where the educational authorities, parents, or both, play a sometimes heavy-handed role in a student's academic career.
''Look at what's happenned in the social sciences over there,'' Ray Benson, head of the American Collegiate Consortium for Academic Exchange, said. ''The whole bunch of cant-oriented social sciences are out. A whole glossary of terms is meaningless now.'' Mr. Benson in the mid-1980's served as midwife for academic and cultural exchanges as a top official at the United States Embassy in Moscow.
 
Supervises the Exchange
This consortium, in its second year of operations, is supervising the exchange of 63 Soviet college students, about a third of the total number of Soviet undergraduates who are studying here this year.
As a result of the rapid changes in fields like history and sociology, Mr. Benson said, a whole bunch of children are changing majors in midstream. ''They find interesting the opportunity our students have to do that. They are intrigued by the freedom with which we do it, the ease with which we do it, the lack of guilt and the encouragement from parents.''
Katya Dunina, a 16-year-old Soviet student who was returning home after four weeks as a student here, said, ''You have more discussions in your lessons here.'' As she moved her luggage closer to the Aeroflot baggage counter, she said, ''In our classes, the conversations take place between the teacher and a single student at a time.''
Miss Dunina and 11 other Soviet students at the Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School in Maryland were among 700 who are coming to 50 American high schools this academic year, living with students' families, visiting American shopping malls, taking multiple-choice tests and living the multiple-choice lives of their middle- and upper-middle-class host families.
 
Living With Soviet Families
In the year, a like number of American students from the host schools will spend a month living with Soviet families in Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev and other Soviet cities.
But while Soviet educational officials are trying to equip the next generation for a society of choices and changes, their American counterparts are trying to adjust to the ever-changing realities of an academic exchange program whose growth and expansion is presenting unforeseen difficulties, sometimes giving the American partners a crash course in new and old quirks of Soviet life.
For one thing, now that Soviet universities can arrange their own exchange programs independent of the Ministry of Education - and, in some cases, can earn coveted hard currency in doing so - they are somewhat more reluctant to commit the necessary apartments, dormitory beds, and class space to the traditional exchanges.
And, on the American side, the huge backlog of visa applications at the United States Embassy and the United States Government's unbending requirement that a 16-year-old student undergo the same complicated clearances as a Soviet military officer, is making it diffcult to get Soviet students here. Last week, students from Odessa had to postpone their visit indefinitely when their visas could not be obtained before the date of their flight.
 
Costly Dental Treatment
Some American participants in the exchanges have also been surprised by the hidden agendas of the visiting Soviet students.
For instance, Mr. Benson related, college officials at Colgate University, Swarthmore College and other schools in his consortium were caught by surprise when students arrived with dental problems requiring root-canal treatment - with bills up to $1,500 going to the colleges.
''This year, again, there were some immediate complaints about teeth,'' Mr. Benson said. ''But the listeners were a little more savvy. The institutions faced them down just a little bit, and asked them to wait and see if the pain went away.''

HEADLINE: Andrew Young Going Afield to Run for Governor

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta is aggressively traveling the state these days, buttonholing all who will listen to his plans for a run at the Governor's mansion in 1990.
The main premise of Mr. Young's campaign is nonracial and remains what it has been since January, when he first hinted he might be a candidate: his ability to bring some of the same economic development to the rest of Georgia as he has helped bring to Atlanta.
But the underlying message is similar to that conveyed by L. Douglas Wilder in his successful gubernatorial campaign in Virginia: here is a pragmatic and experienced black politician who is able and nonthreatening.
''I don't know of a black candidate for any office beyond a predominantly black district, with the exception of Jesse Jackson, who has run and accelerated his blackness,'' said Stoney Cooks, a longtime confidant of Mr. Young's who has run several campaigns here and is now a consultant to the gubernatorial campaign. ''You stress qualifications and experience and, as in Wilder's case, you make the race issue difficult to raise.'' 
 
Seeking Broader Support
So aggressive is Mr. Young's quest that last week the 57-year-old Mayor traveled to a nearby roadhouse known for its jukebox stocked with country music classics and two songs with ''nigger'' in their titles. The restaurant is in Marietta in Cobb County, one of Atlanta's populous northern suburbs whose politics are heavily influenced by white, conservative blue-collar voters. It has voted heavily for Republican Presidential candidates in recent elections.
It is an area, a resident said, where ''our necks aren't exactly fire-engine red - just a little pink.''
Publicity about the visit to the restaurant prompted the owner, a supporter of Mr. Young, to remove the two songs temporarily and limit the gathering to invited guests to avoid any embarrassment for the Mayor of Atlanta.
But Mr. Young, who had insisted on that location, did not arrive wearing his sensitivities on his sleeve. Instead he brought two records, a Ray Charles song and a Hank Williams Jr. song, as possible replacements, and quietly made his point.
''If I want to be governor, I have to be governor for them too,'' Mr. Young said of restaurant customers who might not be offended by the two original song titles. ''I'll go anywhere to talk to anybody about the future of Georgia.''
Some black figures in the state, like the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, have warned Mayor Young that blacks might resent his trolling for white votes in places like the Marietta restaurant. They say that it could weaken his support among a group that represents nearly 30 percent of the registered voters and traditionally accounts for about 40 percent in the Democratic primary.
Campaign strategists are banking on nearly solid support from blacks to guarantee that the Mayor, who was President Jimmy Carter's chief representative to the United Nations and who represented Atlanta in Congress, will emerge from what is now a four-person Democratic field and at least advance to a runoff.
 
'A Tough Row to Hoe'
''He has a tough row to hoe,'' Mr. Lowery said. ''I think most black voters will understand that he has to compromise and go to a redneck bar, but if he compromises on principle he will be on shaky ground.''
When Mr. Young hands over the city government to Maynard H. Jackson in January after serving two terms, he will leave behind an eight-year record boasting sustained growth of the city's economy. While many criticize him, saying he did not spread the effects of that prosperity broadly enough, others say his leadership has created a stable environment for development that will pay future dividends.
Business leaders in the city praise him for ''bringing us all together'' and say his celebrity in national and international circles has given them an edge in the competition to attract business and investment to the city.
For his part, Mr. Young talks of the broad network of acquaintances and contacts that he says have often made the difference in the city's ability to compete. He cites Atlanta's new skyscrapers, noting that they brought jobs and did much to help the downtown compete the growing suburbs.
And he is credited with other accomplishments: new mass transit links from downtown Atlanta to the airport, a gleaming reincarnation of Underground Atlanta as a tourist attraction, plans for a domed stadium, attracting the 1988 Democratic National Convention and an international campaign to bring the 1992 summer Olympics here.
 
Help From Fellow Carter Alumni
As he enters the race for governor, Mr. Young is trumpeting his strong backing from the city's business establishment. His campaign chairman is Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney General under Mr. Carter, who is an important partner in the city's most prominent law firm. Terry Adamson, a Carter-era assistant to Mr. Bell who is supporting Mr. Young, said the presence of powerful white leaders like Mr. Bell is not merely symbolic.
''They are willing to go a step further than the routine for Andy because they believe in him,'' he said.
More than a year before the election, Mr. Young has already raised $600,000 and few people expect that he will have any trouble raising the estimated $4 million to $5 million he will need in a statewide race.
For his campaign manager Mr. Young has reached out to former Mayor Hobby Stripling of Vienna, Ga., a former president of the Georgia Municipal Association, which represents 457 cities in the state.
A poll taken earlier this month showed that Mr. Young had a higher approval rating than any other announced Democratic candidate. Thirty-eight percent of the 758 Georgians polled by The Atlanta Journal and Constitution just before the Virginia gubernatorial vote gave Mr. Young a favorable rating. Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller was close behind with a 30 percent approval rate, while State Senator Roy Barnes and State Representative Lauren McDonald got approval ratings of 4 percent. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
His associate Mr. Cooks, shying away from labeling Mr. Young a front-runner, said the poll could reflect a ''Wilder effect,'' in which white voters inflate a black candidate's acutal support because they are reluctant to admit to poll takers that they would not vote for a black.
Charles Gentry, a farmer who owns a great deal of land in Mill Haven, near Savannah, said there are still white Georgians who identify Mr. Young more as an aide to the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. than as a former Congressman, United Nations delegate, big-city Mayor and pragmatic Democrat who has often risked offending black voters.
''The association with Martin Luther King will make it so some whites would never consider voting for him,'' said Mr. Gentry, who is white. ''But here is a guy who they give parades for when he goes to foreign countries, and if he can bring that kind of recognition to Georgia, others won't even see his color.''
Like Mr. Wilder, Mr. Young faces white opposition that is conservative and is likely to highlight his liberal positions. But Mr. Stripling believes that Mr. Young will surprise many white voters by appearing ''not as a wild-eyed liberal'' but as someone who understands their concerns. ''The civil rights movement is part of his life and we won't diminish that,'' Mr. Stripling said. ''But our strength is to show him as he is and not try to deny that he is something that he is not.''
 
Conservative Stands
Nevertheless, there are signs that Mr. Young is taking steps to present himself more conservatively than usual. He was recently photographed on a police pistol range with the new semi-automatic pistols that he and others advocated for officers, and in campaign appearances he talks about what he has done to curb crime in Atlanta and his support for new prisons.
He has stood firm in his support of abortion rights. But he recently appeared to soften his longtime opposition to Georgia's death penalty. He suggested that he would not try to change the law, although he still believes the death penalty does not deter crime.
Mr. Lowery said such statements might hurt Mr. Young among black voters. ''For many the death penalty remains the most racist element of our criminal justice system,'' he said, ''and it remains to be seen how black voters who have not really been as vocal on this issue as some black leaders will react.''

HEADLINE: Salo W. Baron, 94, Scholar of Jewish History, Dies

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Prof. Salo Wittmayer Baron, who was recognized as one of the century's great historical scholars for his sweeping multivolume history of the Jews, died of congestive heart failure early yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.
''He was undoubtedly the greatest Jewish historian of the 20th century,'' said Yosef Hayim Yerushalmi, a former student of Professor Baron's who now holds the Salo Wittmayer Baron Chair of Jewish History, Culture and Society at Columbia University. The chair was established in 1979 to honor the scholar, who had taught there from 1930 until his retirement in 1963. 
Arthur Hertzberg, another former student, who will officiate at Professor Baron's funeral tomorrow, said, ''He was equally at home in everything from ancient history to the modern era, and the major father of Jewish historical studies in the United States.''
On April 24, 1961, Professor Baron set the historic framework for the Israeli prosecution's case against Adolf Eichmann. In a manner both learned and passionate, he testified at the Nazi official's Jerusalem trial about anti-Semitism, European Jewry and what the Nazis had done to it.
 
Suffering, but Joy Too
Professor Baron wrote 13 works on Jewish history, many of them multivolume efforts. He edited four other books and produced hundreds of articles and addresses.
His magnum opus was ''A Social and Religious History of the Jews'' (Columbia University Press), which began as a series of lectures, turned into a three-volume overview of Jewish history published in 1937 and finally grew into a revised version, of which 18 volumes have been published.
Well into his 90's, Professor Baron labored on volume 19, and he had projected at least two more volumes carrying the account of Jewish life through 1650.
Besides his enormous learning and energy, Professor Baron brought very distinctive views to his scholarship. He inveighed against what he termed the ''lachrymose conception of Jewish history,'' sometimes identified with Heinrich Graetz, a great 19th-century Jewish historian who found the main elements of Jewish experience through the ages to be suffering and spiritual scholarship.
''Suffering is part of the destiny'' of the Jews, Professor Baron said in an interview in 1975, ''but so is repeated joy as well as ultimate redemption.''
He always fought against the view of Jewish history as ''all darkness and no light,'' Mr. Yerushalmi said. ''He labored mightily to restore balance.''
 
'Writing Social History'
Professor Baron also strove to integrate the religious dimension of Jewish history into a full picture of Jewish life and to integrate the history of Jews into the wider history of the eras and societies in which they lived.
''Salo Baron was writing social history, insisting that spiritual creativity and the political situation were all borne by a living society and its changing forms,'' Mr. Hertzberg said. ''Although he himself came from the rabbinic aristocracy, he was always sensitive to the creativity and courage of lower classes.''
Mr. Hertzberg compared Professor Baron to great 19th-century historians like Theodor Mommsen and Leopold von Ranke. ''He wrote history in the grand manner but with modern notions about what society is like and what is the matrix out of which ideas spring,'' he said.
 
Learned 20 Languages
Professor Baron was born on May 26, 1895, in Tarnow, today situated in Poland but then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. His family was educated and affluent, part of the Jewish aristocracy of Galicia. His father was a banker and president of the Jewish community of 16,000.
At the Eichmann trial in 1961, Professor Baron put his case for the unprecedented character of the Holocaust in personal terms when he noted that 20,000 Jews lived in Tarnow before the war but that after Hitler, there were no more than 20. His parents and a sister were killed there.
As a child, the future scholar quickly made his talents evident, learning chess at 3, writing Hebrew poetry at 12, and adding Yiddish, Biblical and modern Hebrew, French and German to his first language, Polish. Eventually he learned 20 languages and could lecture - as he always did, without notes - in five.
In secondary schools, he was outstanding in physics and mathematics, but as his views swung between Polish nationalism, rigorous religious Orthodoxy and Zionism, he fixed on studying Jewish history as a way ''to do something for the Jewish people,'' he told an interviewer in 1982.
Not only did the young man pursue rabbinical studies - he was ordained at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Vienna in 1920 - but he earned three doctorates from the University of Vienna, in philosophy in 1917, in political science in 1922 and in law in 1923.
 
Teaching at Columbia
After teaching at the Jewish Teachers College in Vienna in 1926, he was invited by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise to teach at the Jewish Institute of Religion in New York. In 1930, he began to teach at Columbia in the newly established Miller Chair of Jewish History, Literature and Institutions.
Besides pursuing his scholarly work, Professor Baron was active in organizational efforts to maintain and strengthen the Jewish community both before and after World War II. From 1950 to 1968, he directed the Center of Israel and Jewish Studies at Columbia. He received more than a dozen honorary degrees from universities in the United States, Europe and Israel and was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
In 1933, Jeannette Meisel, a graduate student in economics, consulted him about a dissertation she was writing. They married in 1934, and Jeannette Baron became a collaborator in his scholarly work.
''He and his wife, in their heyday, were a kind of partnership,'' Mr. Hertzberg recalled. ''She helped with every one of his books, and they signed a couple of monographs together. Their apartment on Claremont Avenue was a place to which everybody in Jewish life eventually came. To be part of their circle was somehow to be part of the great tradition of Jewish scholarship.'' Mrs. Baron died in 1985. Professor Baron is survived by two daughters, Shoshana Baron Tancer of Phoenix and Tobey Baron Gitelle of Manhattan; a sister, Tanya Horowitz of Pittsburgh; seven grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Frank Southard, 82, Economist

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Frank A. Southard Jr., a former senior official of the International Monetary Fund, died of cancer today at a hospital near his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old. 
Mr. Southard served as the fund's deputy managing director, its second highest position, from 1962 until his retirement in 1974. He had worked as an executive for the fund's board and also as special assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury.
Mr. Southard was born in Cleveland, the son of Frank A. Southard and May L. Bowsher. He received a bachelor's degree from Pomona College in California and a doctorate from the University of California, where he subsequently became an economics instructor. He later taught at Cornell University's economics department, where he also served as chairman, and conducted research with support from the Carnegie Endowment, the Guggenheim Foundation and the Social Science Research Council.
In 1941, Mr. Southard joined the Treasury Department as assistant director of the division of monetary research. He was involved in the earliest planning for the International Monetary Fund, which later emerged from the 1944 Bretton Woods Conference.
His work at the Treasury Department was interrupted in 1942, when he served as a Naval officer with the Allied Force Headquarters staff in the Mediterranean. From 1942 to 1946, he was engaged in the design and operation of the financial aspects of European liberation, most notably in Italy.
Mr. Southard is survived by his wife, the former Mary I. Hay, and a sister, Elizabeth Marshall, of Sewanee, Tenn.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Wellesley;
Sorority Applies For Recognition, Stirring a Debate

DATELINE: WELLESLEY, Mass.

 BODY:
The distinction between a ''society'' and a sorority has sharply divided students at Wellesley College, since a national sorority applied to be recognized on campus. If accepted, the Lambda Upsilon chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha, a predominantly black public-service sorority, would be the first national Greek society established at the 114-year-old women's college.
Alpha Kappa Alpha has applied to be ''constituted'' by the college government, a step that would allow it to use campus operations and receive student-organization funds and recognition in college publications.
Although the chapter is chartered at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in nearby Cambridge, 16 of its 31 members are Wellesley students. Wellesley students have been joining the M.I.T. chapter since 1977 and have served as chapter presidents this year and last. 
After learning that the sorority would be among the organizations applying for official standing this year - and that the application might become the focus for a debate over the legitimacy of both sororities and societies on campus - students flocked to the weekly student government meeting. The debate became so heated that the issue was tabled to allow a subcommittee to examine the issue.
 
Societies Applying
The situation is further complicated by the existence of several on-campus ''societies,'' two of which are also applying for recognition this year. Tau Zeta Epsilon is an arts-oriented group that sponsors lectures and concerts, while Phi Sigma sponsors panel discussions and workshops.
Most of the societies were started when Wellesley was founded in 1875, mainly to foster intellectual discourse outside the classroom. Many have Greek-letter names, but none is affiliated with national sororities.
Jacqui Broughton, the president-elect of the M.I.T. Alpha Kappa Alpha chapter and a member of college government at Wellesley, sees the societies as ''Wellesley sororities'' and believes that if they have been officially recognized, her group should be as well.
Ms. Broughton, a senior in political science and black studies, said the sorority was listed as an organization in last year's College Government Student Handbook, as were all the societies, only three of which were officially constituted at the time. But she said members of the college government's publication committee had told her the Alpaha Kappa Alpha listing was a mistake.
Members of other campus societies are divided over whether their organizations are indeed sororities.
A member of Tau Zeta Epsilon, Heather McDevitt, a senior majoring in political science from Glens Falls, N.Y., sees Alpha Kappa Alpha's national affiliation as a ''crucial difference,'' although she supports its efforts to become recognized.
 
'Not Much of a Difference'
The president of Phi Sigma, Mary Griffin, a junior majoring in cognitive science from Little Silver, N.J., said that after talking to members of Alpa Kappa Alpha, she decided there was ''not much of a difference'' between the group and the campus societies. Both, she said, are geared toward serving the college, and Alpha Kappa Alpha specifically serves ''to uplift the black community at Wellesley.''
Ms. Broughton said she thought the debate over her group's status is a racial one.
Farhana Khera, vice president of the college government and a junior in political science and economics from Painted Post, N.Y., disagreed. It is, rather, ''the whole notion of a new society or sorority on campus,'' she said. Ms. Khera said she felt most students see societies and sororities as the same thing and have little tolerance for either. ''The whole notion of a new society or sorority'' is what bothers people, she said.
In an attempt to forestall other disputes over which organizations should be legitimately constituted on campus, the student government has instituted new guidelines. To merit official recognition, a group must open membership applications to all Wellesley students (societies currently exclude first-year students), must publicize all events and must hold at least one open meeting per semester. Existing societies now have to amend their rules to conform to these guidelines or risk being denied official standing, for which all campus organizations must apply every year.

Marsha Karen Lasker, an administrative assistant at the New School for Social Research in New York, and Prof. Edward John Nell, the chairman of the graduate department of economics there, were married yesterday at their home in Shady, N.Y. Sidney Slayton, a town justice of Woodstock, N.Y., officiated.

HEADLINE: The Nuclear Industry Tries Again

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Right now, the American nuclear power industry appears headed for extinction. Every plant of the more than 100 ordered since 1973 has been canceled, and many others are approaching retirement. But reactor manufacturers say that fears of global warming - the greenhouse effect - are giving them a second chance.
Nuclear power advocates have, of course, been predicting the industry's rebirth for years. But the plans are becoming more specific, and political calculations are coming into play. Reactor builders are readying designs for a new generation of plants that, they say, will be far safer, less expensive and simpler to operate. The General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the two biggest reactor manufacturers, and General Atomic, a small company with an innovative reactor design, each received $50 million from the Department of Energy in September to work on their models. They are spending hundreds of millions of dollars to bring nuclear power back. And they are presenting the opposition with a tantalizing series of ''what-if's.''
* What if fundamental design changes made plants a hundred times safer? So safe that many elaborate safety features in today's plants - equipment that must be radiation-proof, fire-proof, tornado-proof and generally failure-proof - were not needed? 
* What if all the power and all the pumps and valves could fail, all the operators could be seized with indecision - and the plant would come through without further damage? Designers say such a plant is in their blueprints.
* What if, as designers promise, the parts that are most likely to fail were redesigned or even eliminated? If many of the parts that are trickiest to install - like earthquake-proof piping with flawless welds - were drastically reduced? What if cost overruns were the worry of the manufacturer, not the utility and its customers? Would such a reactor sell?
* What if plants that were licensed for construction were accepted by the gvernment once built, not subject to costly new requirements before completion, or after? New rules approved by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and now before Congress would accomplish as much, the industry's boosters say.
Even those in the industry agreed that utility companies are unlikely to buy new plants soon. ''Anyone suggests a nuclear reactor to a utility board of directors, they will send for the guy with the net, and with good reason,'' said Shelby T. Brewer, head of the nuclear division at Combustion Engineering Inc. - a reactor manufacturer that has agreed to be bought out by ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd.
But the manufacturers, who have been subsisting on paltry foreign sales, say they must prepare for a second nuclear age. With new equipment, new construction procedures and reformed regulation, they say, the orders will come. At Westinghouse, promotional material speaks of a new design ''restoring the domestic market.''
The reactor vendors are counting on growing environmental consciousness and growing demand for electricity. The world's choices of other power sources will be constrained by fears of air pollution and global warming brought on by the burning of coal, oil and gas. As Hans Blix, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, a United Nations agency based in Vienna, asked, ''Are you more scared of nuclear than of adding more carbon dioxide?'' The next few years, reactor manufacturers believe, will bring electricity shortages in this country and higher power needs abroad.
Environmentalists are skeptical, suggesting that if there is a high-tech remedy for the greenhouse effect, it probably lies in more efficient light bulbs and motors, or photovoltaic cells and other new generating technologies. It is unclear what the leading technologies will be at the turn of the century, the very earliest that the first of a new generation of nuclear plants might be completed.
Environmentalists also point out that even if all the nation's electricity came from reactors, global emissions of carbon dioxide would be cut by only about 3.5 percent.
But utility executives say they would like a nuclear option; although mindful of public opposition and the huge cost overruns of the 1970's and 1980's, they are not lining up to buy. At a recent conference on nuclear power and the greenhouse effect, organized by the Institute for Resource Management, an environmental group, many experts said the revival of the industry was a realistic possibility, but that it depended heavily on public opinion.
As Alan Crane, senior associate project director at the Office of Technology Assessment put it at the conference: ''You can't just keep the utilities happy. There's a jury of 240 million people out there.'' Though polls show the public believes nuclear power will be important in the future, he said, ''Nobody would countenance one in their own backyard.''
Though some new reactor features have been tested, others exist only on paper. But the industry's basic selling point is that eight pounds of uranium can make as much energy as 6,000 tons of oil or 8,600 tons of coal. A single large reactor could supply 1.5 million households. If that energy had to come from coal, each household would aggravate the greenhouse effect by burning half a ton of coal each month. Among currently economical technologies, only hydroelectric power and perhaps wood replaced by replanting can provide electricity without worsening the greenhouse effect. But both sources are limited.
By themselves, these arguments sway few outside the nuclear community. Safety and cost, which killed off the market for the current generation of reactors, still must carry the day.
The United States invented the civilian nuclear reactor as a spin-off from the bomb. For decades, in the ''Atoms for Peace'' era, the nuclear industry had a near-messianic tone. The nation's resulting disillusionment was all the more severe. Now American manufacturers say this country can use standardization and other reforms to make nuclear power work again - at least as well as the French, Japanese and Koreans, who all prosper with American designs. ''As we see the world,'' said Bert Wolfe, vice president for nuclear services at General Electric, ''it's hard to see how you can meet the energy needs in the next century without nuclear power.''
General Electric's Simplified Boiling Water Reactor and Westinghouse's Advanced Passive 600 are dramatic departures from the reactors these companies have built before. They are smaller, simpler and more forgiving and reliable. ''Even the current reactors tolerate a lot of stupidities,'' said Mr. Blix, in an interview at the United Nations. ''The ones that will come in the 90's will tolerate even more.''
The designs for the 1990's differ in many ways, but all are only about half as large as the biggest now in service. General Atomic's plan is for even smaller reactors, which would be built in groups of up to four, with all four together only the size of a smallish plant today.
 
A Revolution in Design
 Down-sizing represents a revolution for reactor manufacturers, who, like auto makers, had long equated size with progress. For years the reactor designs grew larger because manufacturers thought the utilities could achieve economies of scale, generating more power with the same plant staff. But bigger plants took longer to build, raising costs and leaving utilities too dependent on single projects.
Utilities also found that they had overestimated power demand for the early 1980's; smaller plants, more quickly built, do not require such accurate long-range projections. Smaller reactors also make it easier to design cooling systems without mechanical pumps or the need for quick action by operators.
The other revolution in reactor concepts has been for vendors to complete their designs before they build. In the 1960's, utilities blithely broke ground on plants when only a quarter of the design was in hand, even when the plants were to be three or four times larger than any reactors already operating. ''Fast-tracking'' was the motto, with construction crews pouring foundations while engineers decided, in effect, where to put the kitchen and how many bedrooms to put upstairs. In a period of rapid inflation in building costs and high interest payments on an unfinished project, fast-tracking was meant to save money. Instead, it created confusion and raised costs, as piping ordered by one set of engineers often failed to fit equipment designed by another.
Fast-tracking was especially difficult because the first generation of reactors included scores of one-of-a-kind designs. ''We had 50 separate learning curves,'' said Victor Gilinsky, a physicist and former member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Virtually every plant was a prototype, and the experience of building one was of little help in building another. And there was no standardization in operations, either. ''It's as if the Navy had allowed every commander to design his own ship, hire his own contractor, designate his own ranks,'' said Mr. Gilinsky.
Standardization is essential to swift construction, the experts say. As Howard J. Bruschi, the director of nuclear plant programs at Westinghouse, complained, ''The French are using Westinghouse reactors, and they build them in five years. We've managed to stretch that to 14 in the United States.''
Westinghouse and General Electric are both seeking generic approval for their designs from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission by 1995. They also want one-step licensing, to replace the current process of applying for a construction permit and then, after construction is nearly done, applying again, for an operating license. Under the proposed changes, utilities could order a reactor the way a not-too-fussy homebuyer could order a house from stock plans, with only minor adjustments to conform to the particulars of a site.
The commission has already approved simplified licensing for standardized plants. Watchdog groups have complained about the potential loss of public say, so the industry wants to head off legal challenges by having Congress write the simplified procedures into law.
The new designs confront several other chronic problems of earlier nuclear reactors. Some examples:
* In case of accident, existing reactors automatically pump in water to cool the fuel. But a cooling system failure could be catastrophic. New designs by Westinghouse and General Electric depend on gravity and convection to inject cold water and remove heat.
* Existing reactors overheat quickly if cooling water flow is interrupted because they squeeze a large amount of fissionable uranium into a small space. Solution: Change the concentration of fissionable uranium in the fuel to lower the concentration of heat produced, by about 40 percent in General Electric plants and 30 percent in Westinghouse plants.
* The current plants were plagued with questions about the adequacy of welds. As a result, one $2 billion plant, Zimmer, a General Electric design in Moscow, Ohio, is being converted to coal. Westinghouse has designed a new plant with long, gently curving pipes that have half the welds of a conventional design.
* Reactors that boil water directly in the core now use pumps to circulate the water, but the stainless steel piping connected to the pumps has sometimes cracked. General Electric has designed a reactor that relies on natural convection instead of pumps to circulate water. This design also eliminates the need for large pipes to penetrate the reactor vessel below the level of the uranium core, so that if a pipe breaks, the water will not leak out.
* Reactors today have emergency diesel generators, which provide power for crucial instruments, pumps and valves in case of a blackout. But the diesels require expensive maintenance and sometimes fail in tests, requiring a plant to close while they are fixed. Westinghouse has designed a plant that it says shuts down safely, dissipating heat with water delivered by gravity, convection and other passive means - without the use of valves, pumps or instruments, and thus without emergency diesel generators.
 
The Cost Contest
 Even an industry that meets all the safety criteria still faces huge challenges - most of all, cost. With more and more states requiring their utilities to solicit bids for new power supplies, rather than simply building another generating station and charging customers, nuclear will have to compete with new, highly fuel-efficient gas- and oil-fired generators.
In extreme cases like New Hampshire's Seabrook nuclear plant, which recently took a major step toward operation, costs reached $5,400 per kilowatt of capacity. About $3,600 was for direct costs, the rest for interest payments. The Electric Power Research Institute, a utility research consortium in Palo Alto, Calif., believes that to be competitive, nuclear plants must be built for $1,500 a kilowatt in direct costs, a target that manufacturers believe they can meet. Westinghouse is convinced that its AP 600 can be built for $1,270 a kilowatt, not counting interest but including a 20 percent contingency fee.
To limit costs, the builders of nuclear plants must limit construction time. ''If we're going to be effective with nuclear power,'' said Mr. Bruschi in an interview, ''we have to demonstrate as an industry, unequivocally, that these things can be built in a reasonable amount of time.'' Westinghouse, he said, can fulfill this goal with a strategy not used since the mid-1960's: the ''turnkey'' plant. It is sold at a fixed price, so the builder bears the risk of cost overruns.
''I have been highly encouraged by conversations we've had with utilities,'' said Mr. Bruschi, ''But no single utility is going to stick its neck out. So we're willing to go forward with a turnkey plant.'' The risk might be shared, he said, among Westinghouse, an architecture and engineering firm, and other contractors.
Nuclear power opponents raise several other challenges. They question special subsidies and protections for the industry, like the Price-Anderson Act, which limits the liability of reactor operators for accidents. ''What distinguishes nuclear power in benefit to the United States, that it is deserving of such treatment?'' asked Charles Imbrecht, the chairman of the California Energy Commission.
The big reactor manufacturers, all of them divisions of larger companies, say Price-Anderson is a necessity for them to continue in the business. But Linden Blue, the vice chairman of General Atomic, said he is so convinced that his reactor could not cause damage beyond the plant boundaries that he would forswear the Price-Anderson benefits.
 
Suspect Subsidies
 Many energy experts question why the Department of Energy spends so much more to develop nuclear power than solar power or other technologies. Amory B. Lovins, a physicist and expert in electric efficiency, argues that skepticism over vendors' cost claims will persist ''until the promoters pay for that commercialization, and stop importuning the Treasury to put our money where their mouths are.'' If the nuclear companies paid all their development costs, he said, they would build no new reactors. The same funds invested in energy conservation and efficiency would save far more power, he added.
Another problem is nuclear waste. California has barred the construction of more reactors until the Federal Government demonstrates a way to dispose of waste. The Department of Energy is making little progress toward its goal of opening a repository early in the next century.
Then there are decommissioning costs, unmeasured even for plants now in operation. Also uncertain is how much of a hazard a decommissioned plant would be. As I.C. Bupp, a reactor expert at the Cambridge Energy Research Associates consulting firm, put it: ''The public expects the option to tear it down and make a baseball field. If that option isn't there, I think you're going to have one heck of a political problem.''
The industry is convinced it can meet these objections. The first new reactor, the thinking goes, will be built where others already exist, in a region with scarce coal but growing electric demand. The Southeast, including Florida, might provide a site.
Until now, the industry's greatest obstacle has been its own sorry record. But business will revive, industry executives say, when it becomes obvious that a standardized plant can be built quickly, under a licensing system that prevents challenges and changing requirements along the way.
With nuclear power in such disrepute, it may take more than just blueprints to persuade a utility to order that first new plant.As Mr. Wolfe of General Electric said, ''Someone is going to have to have faith that the system will work.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
After 30 Years, Japan Patents Chips

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
Japan granted a patent that Texas Instruments Inc. had been seeking since 1960. The patent covers the basic semiconductor chip, which the company's researchers invented in 1958. The Tokyo decision requires all Japanese chip makers to pay royalties to Texas Instruments. Japanese chip makers have about 90 percent of the Japanese chip market and 80 percent of the United States market. Texas Instruments would not comment on the money involved, but analysts estimated that the patent rights, which are valid for 12 years, could bring in a total of $2 billion. Texas Instruments shares jumped on the news after having fallen earlier in the week when the company announced a $55 million charge against earnings and the elimination of 1,500 jobs. The company has about 50,000 employees.
 
*
 American industry won a ruling that Japanese and Taiwanese makers of telecommunications equipment were guilty of selling small-business telephone systems at unfairly low prices. The International Trade Commission, an independent Federal agency, acted on a complaint by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The ruling clears the way for extra tariffs to be imposed on the foreign goods. 
 
*
 Japan's construction industry was criticized for continuing cartel-like practices, but the top American trade official said she would not urge retaliatory measures for now. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, issued a formal report required under the 1988 trade bill, which had special provisions aimed at trying to increase American access to Japan's $300-billion-a-year construction market. Mrs. Hills said abuses were continuing but there were enough signs of progress to warrant continued negotiations. The United States won its first significant victory on the issue last week. Ninety- nine Japanese contractors agreed to pay $32.6 million to settle accusations that they rigged bids on projects at American Navy bases in Japan.
 
*
 Durable-goods orders were down six-tenths of a percent in October. That was the fourth decline in six months and was seen as a sign that American industry is facing a sharp downturn. Some analysts said they were especially concerned by the revision in the September figure, which went from a gain of two-tenths of a percent to a decline of 1.1 percent . . . Consumer prices rose five-tenths of a percent in October, their largest advance since May. The October rise was a bit more than expected and resulted largely from sizable increases in the costs of housing and transportation.
 
*
 The Eastern strike crumbled, with the pilots' and the flight attendants' unions both deciding to return to work. They had walked out in early March in support of a strike by the machinists, who say they will remain off the job. Striking workers had been drifting back for some time, and they, along with newly hired workers, enabled Eastern to build back operations to about 75 percent of the pre-strike level. Eastern said strikers who return now would be put on a waiting list for jobs . . . The machinists who had been on strike at Boeing ended their 48-day walkout.
 
*
 Gold prices jumped to their highest level of 1989. Gold began the week around $395 an ounce but traded as high as $416 by week's end. The West German mark had strong gains against the dollar and other currencies. The dollar fell to near 1.80 marks, about where it was when the year began. In the summer the dollar had risen above 2 marks. Trading in stocks was light during the holiday week but hopes for lower interest rates caused prices to rise. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 22.89 points for the week, to close at 2,675.55. Bond prices had slight gains.
 
*
 A 6 percent stake in Avon has been acquired by Robert M. Bass, the Texas businessman. Avon's management was already under pressure from the disclosure earlier this month that a 6.9 percent stake was held by a group that includes Mary Kay Cosmetics. There was some speculation Mr. Bass was taking a long-term position in Avon in hopes of steering it toward a turnaround, much as he did with Walt Disney after buying into it in 1984. Avon announced that four fragrance lines - Oscar de la Renta, Uninhibited by Cher, Perry Ellis and Deneuve - would be sold to a unit of Sanofi of France for $210 million.
 
*
 Miscellanea. Time Inc. will sell its Scott, Foresman textbook publishing operation to Harper & Row for $455 million. Time had paid $520 million for the unit in late 1986 . . . Dun & Bradstreet will pay $333 million for Management Science America, a maker of business-related software. The share price of Management rose nearly 50 percent when the deal was announced . . . Great Northern Nekoosa's board rejected Georgia-Pacific's latest bid, which was raised to $3.8 billion, from $3.1 billion.

HEADLINE: The Struggle To Sell Tickets

BYLINE: By JOBETH MCDANIEL; JoBeth McDaniel is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles.By JOBETH McDANIEL

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Fred Rosen keeps a stuffed wizard on his credenza, a gift from a business associate who applauded his seemingly magical transformation of a nearly bankrupt company into one of the largest entertainment ticketing companies in the nation.
But Mr. Rosen, chairman and chief executive of Ticketmaster, based in Los Angeles, gives less credit to wizardry than to his aggressive battle plan against the New York-based Ticketron, which until recently held a solid lock on the national computerized ticketing industry.
In seven years, Mr. Rosen has built the privately held Ticketmaster to estimated annual sales of $500 million on 25 million tickets. He projects revenues of $75 million this year. The firm accomplished this largely by taking away key clients of Ticketron, the industry pioneer, which reported sales of $415 million for 1988. 
The route to Mr. Rosen's success was a computer system that, unlike Ticketron's, could provide series ticketing and sales reports to entertainment clients. And instead of taking a passive role as seller, Ticketmaster also promoted and advertised the events it sold.
While Ticketmaster snatched away clients, Ticketron was suffering from the vicissitudes of its cash-starved parent, the Control Data Corporation. ''Ticketron was a misfit within the Control Data environment,'' said Robert Gorra, senior vice president of Ticketron. ''We really needed a new system, but Control Data decided the money would be put to better use elsewhere.''
Now Ticketron may be fighting back. Mr. Gorra says his company is installing a new system with help from its new owner, the Carlyle Group, a private merchant bank in Washington. Though Carlyle Group would not comment, several entertainment-related companies are reportedly interested in participating.
Analysts say it will be difficult for Ticketron to regain its top position. ''It would take someone with an enormous amount of cash and good technology,'' said Brian Fernandez of Brean Murphy, Foster Securities Inc. in New York.
Mr. Gorra says the two rivals are virtually neck and neck, with similar sales and revenues. ''This business is a capital drain. It costs a great deal of money, but has a low margin. That's true for Ticketmaster too, no matter what they say.''
Mr. Rosen attempted to purchase Ticketron for $20 million this fall, $4 million more than the reported cost to Carlyle. Why did Ticketron refuse? ''They hate me,'' he said.
Perhaps the reason is Mr. Rosen's tenacious calls to longstanding Ticketron clients. Or what seemed to be Ticketmaster's personal war through trade media.
''I made them out to be like ghouls from 'Night of the Living Dead,' '' said Mr. Rosen, 45. ''I believe business is a war.''
Ticketron was perceived by most as invincible, from its start in 1968 when it pioneered the computerized ticketing industry, to the early 1980's, when telephone ticketing brought a host of new competitors. Given its nationwide entrenchment, most challenges had been unsuccessful.
Mr. Rosen knew little about ticketing or entertainment when he took on a short-term project as attorney for Ticketmaster in 1982. The company was based in Scottsdale, Ariz., then and was struggling to sell computerized ticketing systems to arenas.
Mr. Rosen saw the potential in the company's system if it were sold as a service. He called the Chicago investor Jay Pritzker, who owned a small stake in the company, and persuaded him to ante up $1 million to build ''the biggest ticketing company in America.''
Mr. Pritzker recalls that he was a bit nervous, but when Mr. Rosen produced other interested investors, he decided to finance it even further. ''I decided to take a gamble and let him try to run it,'' said Mr. Pritzker. ''You never know in these situations whether they're 'turnaroundable.' But this has been a good investment.''
For Mr. Rosen, who had practiced law in New York since 1972, it was the golden chance to run his own business. ''If you're an entrepreneur at heart and you want to hear your own music, you've got to find a business that is what I call 'within the cracks,' '' he said.
Antagonism to Ticketron had been building in the entertainment and sports industries. ''They had the attitude of 'We have the system: you do it our way or else,''' Mr. Rosen said. ''I knew from talking with promoters and others in the business that Ticketron was vulnerable.''
Within the first six months of operation, Ticketmaster offices were moved to Chicago. Mr. Rosen commuted from New York, and Mr. Pritzker helped seal contracts from the Chicago White Sox and Cubs and the concert promoter JAM.
The going was difficult and the money ran out quickly. Projected costs of $5 million soared to between $12 million and $13 million. Mr. Pritzker unhappily bankrolled the balance. Promoters and arena managers were skeptical, having seen too many newcomers fade away in the presence of Ticketron.
The breakthrough came with a major arena in Los Angeles, the Forum, that had been Ticketron's first fully computerized client in 1968 when it opened. Throughout the year, Mr. Rosen had made relentless calls to Lou Baumeister, its manager, pointing out his system's advantages. He also made a bid, but felt it was hopeless.
He had another late-night flight East, but after he arrived, Mr. Baumeister called to say yes, the account was his.
Another call came a few days later. Ticketron had reneged on a 60-day cancellation clause, choosing to pull its systems from the Forum in 10 days. Ticketmaster jumped in. Employees worked around the clock to install its systems within seven days.
''I thought, 'They just gave me the marketplace,' '' Mr. Rosen recalled. ''It was a signal that they thought they could muscle people.'''
Mr. Rosen soon moved the company's headquarters to Los Angeles. Within a year, Ticketmaster had nailed the biggest promoters and the biggest venues in Los Angeles, said Steve Rennie, president of Eric Chandler Management . ''They came in like a blitzkrieg. When something like that happens, it means something's wrong with the other company. With Ticketron, the main problem was the service level.'' ''Word got around about Ticketmaster,'' said Jim Michaelian, vice president of the Grand Prix Association of Long Beach. ''From our perspective, there were distinct advantages. They're marketing people as well as service people.''
By 1985, Ticketmaster was in the black, with more than 50 percent of the Los Angeles market and offices in New York, Detroit, Seattle and Indianapolis. To Mr. Rosen's surprise, Ticketron still seemed oblivious.
''They gave us a huge opportunity,'' he said. ''There's no reason why this company should be alive today. There were 18 different ways we could have been stopped.''
Mr. Gorra said Ticketron had underestimated the threat. ''That happens when you control a marketplace; you get a little lax,'' he said. ''Ticketmaster offered attractive financial arrangements to clients. They were hungry and very, very aggressive.''
Mr. Rosen said Ticketron never understood the importance of the West Coast, where so many entertainment promoters are based. ''Had we not come here, I don't think this story would be the same,'' said Mr. Rosen. ''We used this as a springboard to expand back West to East.'' Ticketmaster has built field offices and acquired local ticketing agencies across the country, for a total of 100 market areas today. Mr. Rosen figures about a third of the company's sales growth has been through acquisition.
Each property has been expanded after purchase. For example, the New York office was losing $400,000 per month on sales of $30 million when bought six years ago. Now it has $100 million in sales with profits in excess of $2 million a year, according to Mr. Rosen. Ticketmaster expanded telephone operations: 50 to 150 operators, 90 to 300 lines.
Popular music has been important to Ticketmaster's success, accounting for nearly 70 percent of its ticket business today. And though Ticketmaster's gross ticket sales jumped by almost $100 million this year, Mr. Rosen contends that overall concert sales shrunk by 30 to 35 percent. ''There were more big-name concerts, but fewer shows over all,'' he said. The capacity and speed necessary for handling the biggest shows is mind-boggling. For the Rolling Stones tour this summer, Ticketmaster in New York sold out two Shea Stadium shows - 115,000 tickets for $3 million - within an hour and a half.
Even with such numbers, Mr. Rosen says there is only enough room for one national ticketing company. ''This is the kind of business that leads itself to be an oligopoly. Except for New York and L.A., I don't know that cities can support two ticket companies. Generally one wins and one loses.''
Ticketron is far from throwing in the towel. It has solid contracts with Broadway theaters, plus baseball and concert ticketing and most national parks reservations. Mr. Gorra expects the new owners to inject vitality and a more competitive spirit by being more involved in sports and entertainment.
''If Ticketron gets more competitive, who knows,'' said Mr. Rennie. ''If Ticketmaster gets complacent and lazy and greedy, it could happen to them.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
