LENGTH: 2028 words

HEADLINE: The Big Battle Over Eyewear

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Dr. Alan H. Leventhal can remember when life was a lot easier. That was in the late 1970's, when the Federal Trade Commission said it was okay to advertise eyewear prices. Dr. Leventhal bought some lens processing equipment, advertised one-hour service for glasses and contact lenses, and waited. ''People went nutso. Our phones were ringing like crazy,'' recalled Dr. Leventhal, who owns 10 eyewear outlets in southern California.
Things are a lot harder for Dr. Leventhal now. Although he says his stores are doing $7 million in combined revenues a year, he is having to fight for those sales. He is advertising more heavily, and he is offering second pairs of glasses for $1. ''Because of the competition you have to give more away,'' Dr. Leventhal said. ''There's no question that the big chains are pulling market share.'' 
 
Money to Be Made
 Indeed, corporate America has caught on to what Dr. Leventhal recognized all along - that there is a lot of money to be made in eyeglasses. Companies as diverse as Grand Metropolitan Ltd., the United States Shoe Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company have jumped into the field, spawning chains of eyewear stores in malls, on Main Streets and in department stores. The Price Company, the country's largest wholesale buying club company, is offering eyeglasses at a ''very substantial discount'' to members at most of its 36 West Coast buying clubs, and expects to offer them at its 11 East Coast clubs within a year, according to Giles Bateman, Price's vice chairman.
The big chains have introduced specialty retailing techniques that have old-time optometrists reeling. One-hour service has become commonplace. So have cut-rate prices and ''two-for-one'' promotions. Although some stores expect customers to bring prescriptions from their eye doctors, many of the chains now have in-house optometrists or arrangements with doctors right next door.
And nearly all of the corporate-owned stores are supported by huge advertising and direct-mail campaigns. ''Doctors still think patients will find them, while we feel it is our job to seek customers,'' said David M. Browne, executive vice president of Precision LensCrafters, the U.S. Shoe subsidiary that pioneered the eyewear advertising blitz.
The eyewear market's allure is powerful. According to Jobson Publishing's 20/20 Optical Group, which tracks the opthalmic industry, eyewear is an $11 billion market. Since markups on frames and lenses can be as high as 250 percent, the potential for profits is enormous.
So is the potential for growth. The first wave of baby-boomers has hit middle age, when almost everyone needs vision correction. Moreover, glasses have become fashionable. Many people have several pairs to go with different outfits. Often, the frames sport designer names like Georgio Armani and Liz Claiborne, and designer price tags to match.
''Eyeglass stores are evolving into specialty boutiques that not only help people see better but help them look better,'' said Brian Smith, president of Cole Vision, the eyewear subsidiary of the Cole National Corporation.
 
The Dark Side
 But there is a dark side to eyewear retailing. For one thing, opening a full-service eyewear store is expensive. ''The cost of the equipment and of staff takes a big chunk out of what would normally fall to the bottom line in any other retailing business,'' said Marge Axelrad, editorial director of the 20/20 Optical Group.
For another, the market is highly fragmented - and some say oversubscribed. Jobson's 20/20 Group says that Grand Met's Pearle Inc. and U.S. Shoe's Precision LensCrafters, Nos. 1 and 2 in the industry, command about 10 percent of the market, with combined sales of $1.1 billion a year. The next 98 largest companies do a total of about $2 billion. The remaining $8 billion is split between anywhere from 25,000 to 30,000 small outlets.
''The proliferation of optical outlets in this country has far exceeded the increase in the population needing visual care,'' noted Dr. Clinton DeWolfe, president of Royal International Optical, the fifth largest eyewear chain. Dennis Telzrow, a retailing analyst with Eppler Guerin & Turner, is more blunt: ''In eyewear, this country is over-stored,'' he said.
The competition may get even worse. The F.T.C. is trying to overturn state laws that prohibit optometrists from working for corporations, from opening numerous offices, operating under trade names, or working in malls. If the F.T.C. succeeds, it will become easier for doctors to form their own chains, and for corporations to hire optometrists.
Many companies have already fallen on hard times. The Benson Optical Company, which until two years ago was owned by Revlon Inc., was slow to push eyewear as fashion or to advertise heavily. Many of its sales were siphoned away by Pearle and LensCrafters. In July, Benson filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.
Other companies bailed out before fiscal disaster struck. In 1987, Quaker Oats sold its Eyelab chain to Cole National, the third largest chain. ''The business was profitable, but we simply did not have the scale to compete as a major player,'' said Ronald Bottrell, Quaker's senior manager of corporate communications. Apparently, Cole was similarly disillusioned - it is selling Eyelab to Pearle.
The remaining players face cutthroat competition. Until recently, the chains concentrated on densely populated areas where volume warranted expensive advertising campaigns, as well as the more than $100,000 that lens processing equipment can cost. To get economies of scale, many chains set up so-called ''superopticals,'' huge stores with as many as 15,000 frames on display and manufacturing equipment in the back. Others set up satellite systems, where a central lens grinding and finishing plant makes eyeglasses for 10 or more stores that are located close enough to the plant so that they can still offer same-day service.
But nowadays, with huge cities saturated with eyewear outlets, the trend is toward ''mini-superstores,'' stores that are still several times larger than a conventional eyewear store that has glasses made off premises, but that do not approach the supermarket atmosphere of the older superopticals. And the chains are putting these stores in sparsely populated areas as well as urban centers.
Accordingly, manufacturers of lens grinding equipment are offering scaled down versions for about $40,000, within economic reach of smaller stores and even private doctors. Apparently, the equipment is being snapped up. ''Our business has grown more than 400 percent in the last five, six years, and we just see more growth ahead,'' said John Blocha, president of Tulsa, Okla.-based Coburn Optical Industries, the largest manufacturer.
 
Bleaker Future
 Private optometrists face a much bleaker future, though. The American Optometric Association, and many individual doctors, insist that the chains do not provide quality eye care, but the public does not seem to agree - the private optometrist's share of eyewear sales, which was as high as 80 percent in the early 1980's, has dropped to well below 50 percent.
Most industry experts expect that in years to come only those doctors who learn to market themselves will survive as independents. ''Optometrists are finally recognizing that they are in a profession and a business at the same time,'' said Dr. Irving Bennett, a retired Florida optometrist who is chairman of the optometric association's information and data committee. ''They are no longer just playing doctor. They are making frame displays more attractive, suggesting that people put tint in their glasses, that they buy a second pair. They are learning to play in modern business terms.''
They are also joining forces for greater marketplace clout. Dr. Bennett says eye doctors in Michigan have formed a buying group in hopes of getting volume discounts from lens manufacturers and other suppliers. And in Tracy, Minn., Dr. Jack Von Bokern, an optometrist-turned-businessman, has formed America's Doctors of Optometry Inc., a for-profit membership outfit that, for an initial fee ranging from $2,000 to $4,000 and an annual cost that comes down to about $1 per household in the doctor's practice territory, handles advertising and direct mail flyers for about 150 doctors across the country.
Dr. Von Bokern, who has given up his own practice to concentrate solely on his business, has also started a consulting service to help doctors handle the business end of their practices. ''We recognize that the chains are going to continue to erode our markets, and the only way independent doctors can fight back is to act like businessmen,'' he said.
 
Strategic Shakeout
 The chains themselves are going through a strategic shakeout. Some are concentrating on superstores, others on smaller conventional stores, yet others on leased departments. A few are going the franchise route. And each has a different marketing plan. A few examples:
* Pearle Inc., with about $599 million in sales and about 1,000 stores, has a mix of franchised and owned stores, and of superstores and conventional stores. A lot of its future growth will come from franchises because ''that is the best way to capture some of the management talent out there,'' said R. Howard Stanworth, Pearle's chief executive. Pearle's future stores are likely to be mini-superstores that are nowhere near the 10,000 square foot size of many of Pearle's larger stores. ''As the market matures there are fewer and fewer places where monster stores are going to pay,'' Mr. Stanworth said. Pearle, which has been one of the most aggressive users of ''two-for-one'' and other discounting techniques, will continue to rely heavily on price promotions.
* LensCrafters, with about 330 stores and about $489 million in sales, is ''absolutely going the mini-superstore route'' from now on, said Mr. Browne, the executive vice president. He hopes to bring customers in primarily through advertising rather than price promotions. ''The customers we are after go for quality and convenience, not just price,'' Mr. Browne said. Unlike Pearle, Lenscrafters eschews franchising. ''There's not a franchise operation going today that, unless they have some form of incredible iron clad contract and full-time audit staff, can control quality,'' Mr. Browne insisted.
* Cole Vision, which Jobson Publishing at the end of September estimated at 680 stores and $311 million in sales, is moving away from free standing stores of any size, to concentrate on leased departments in Sears, Montgomery Ward and Elder Beerman, a department store chain based in Dayton, Ohio. Mr. Smith, the president, would say only that, ''We are following a strategy that we feel will give a better return.''
Only Royal International, a Dallas-based chain of 644 stores that did $105 million in revenues in the fiscal year ended March 31, continues to ''take a stab at going in all directions,'' as Dr. DeWolfe, its president, put it. Royal owns numerous conventional stores, and operates leased departments in several Montgomery-Ward outlets. And two months ago, Royal bought New Deal, a small Baltimore chain that owned three superstores. Now Dr. DeWolfe says he is studying those stores to see whether Royal should open a few superopticals of its own. ''We are willing to stick our toe in the water and see if a shark bites it off,'' he said.

HEADLINE: A New Industry Springs Up: Europe 1992

BYLINE: By RON SCHNEIDERMAN; Ron Schneiderman is a freelance writer based in Bedminster, N.J.

 BODY:
While many American businesses are still trying to figure out how to take advantage of the 12-nation European Community's move to a single market economy in 1992, others are already profiting from it.
Indeed, ''Europe 1992'' has become a business in itself - with seminars, books, market research, legal and financial services, executive search and newsletter publishing, all designed to generate new business.
''Don't wait until 1992 to triumph in the E.C.,'' proclaims a recent advertisement by Ted Turner's CNN International that suggests using CNN to reach business travelers.
Arthur D. Little Inc. and Booz-Allen Hamilton, the management and technology consultants, have noted a sharp increase in United States companies interested in entering European markets, and have specialists ready to offer advice. Malcolm H. Ross, an Arthur D. Little vice president, was relocated last year from West Germany to San Francisco to develop his company's European Community business with the United States electronics industry. 
Prudential-Bache Securities has opened a second office in Brussels, home of the Community's headquarters, to specialize in 1992 issues. KPMG Peat Marwick helps promote its international financial services by including 1992-related topics in the New Directions in Government Contracting seminars it runs with George Mason University. The accounting firm is also co-sponsoring a series of seminars with the American Electronics Association and Adapso, the computer software and services industry association.
There are plenty of books on the new European market as well, including at least 50 published by the Washington-based European Community Information Service. And the Bureau of National Affairs in Washington is offering two reports on IBM PC-compatible diskette: Europe Without Frontiers: A Lawyer's Guide ($95) and Europe 1992 Legislation ($295).
Need help setting up a European Community-based staff? Glou International, a Needham, Mass., executive search firm, announced earlier this year that it would assist companies to ''establish a beachhead'' in the Community.
''Eighteen months ago, there wasn't any interest in 1992,'' said Stephen G. Payne, president of the PA Consulting Group's North American operation. ''Now, there is significant growth in our activities.''
A London-based concern with offices in Hightstown, N.J., PA Consulting formally identified 1992 as a ''major opportunity'' with the publication in July 1988 of the first of a bimonthly series of newsletters. At the time, PA Consulting said the 1992 program would ''underpin the development of our own European strategy.''
Since then, the firm has built up a client list that includes Quaker Oats and the Commission of European Communities itself, for which it produced a study of the regional impact of the impending single market on financial services. The firm conducts market research and executive recruitment and is advising clients on market entry strategies, product development and standards. It also runs workshops for companies that are trying to anticipate the impact of 1992 changes on their business.
PA has focused on four industry sectors - defense-aerospace, telecommunications, health care and food, but it was also hired by a group of British financial institutions to study the housing finance market in Europe. It also helped an auto manufacturer develop a strategy for entering the retail financial services market in Europe by the end of 1992.
Ernst & Young, the international accounting firm, now has 30 people dedicated to European Community issues, stationed mainly in the United States, London and Brussels. To help promote its activities and qualifications, the firm has published a 34-page booklet, Europe 1992: The Single Market. In it, the firm notes that it has been retained by the European Community for advice and to produce brochures in every Community language setting out the aims, content and legislative status of all 300 regulatory changes planned.
In Britain, Ernst & Young formed Club 1992 as a forum for British chief executives to discuss common single market issues like relations with non-Community countries. The firm is organizing similar clubs in other European countries and in Japan.
Early this year, Ernst & Young began holding so-called Euro Seminars - two-day sessions tailored for individual client companies. Six have been held so far; more are planned. The company also joined Fortune magazine in surveying more than 2,000 chief executives of major corporations in the United States, Japan, the European Community and elsewhere on their impressions of the 1992 program and their own plans to deal with the proposed changes. Then, in April, Ernst & Young began publishing a four-page newsletter focusing on 1992-related European business activities.
A Washington law firm, Crowell & Moring, has teamed up with C&M International, an international trade and business consulting firm staffed primarily by economists, and Boodle Hatfield, a London law firm, to counsel United States and European companies on 1992 issues.
In May, the three firms began co-publishing a newsletter that has grown to 44 pages. It is loaded with information on legislative and policy developments affecting European and American businesses. There are also summaries of the status of the most significant Single European Market directives, and an offer of several information services, including a document service, customized research and legislative counseling.
The newsletter seems to be having an effect. ''We have been getting calls from American companies thinking about relocating in Europe,'' said Peter Teare, a Crowell & Moring lawyer and the newsletter's editor.
Mr. Teare said the newsletter was started with 1,500 names obtained from the United States Commerce Department. Sixty percent of the recipients of the first issue asked to be kept on the mailing list. But word got around and the newsletter's circulation kept growing. It now has 1,000 subscribers in both the United States and Europe with scattered mailings in Japan, Korea and Taiwan.
Studies are also big business. For $795, DRI/McGraw-Hill will send its Executive Briefing on How to Prepare for the Single European Market. Ogilvy & Mather, the ad agency, says in an ad that it has ''jumped the gun on 1992'' with a study into its implications, and will send that, along with a checklist on what marketing and advertising people should be doing now.
Frost & Sullivan, a New York-based market research organization, has worked 1992 scenarios into several of its newest studies, and produced six specific market reports in the past year - like Food Packaging Materials Market in Europe: The Implications of 1992, and The Regulation of European Communications Markets: 1992. Many of these reports are sold out of the firm's London office. Likewise, Dataquest Ltd., the London-based arm of the San Jose, Calif., electronic industry market research firm, included 1992 as a focal point in its annual semiconductor market conference in Munich.
Seminars are a popular medium for sharing expertise. The Washington-based European Community Studies Association, a group founded in 1987 to organize workshops and seminars, dedicated its inaugural conference to the European Community. About 500 people attended, with members paying $75 and nonmembers $100.
The military publisher Jane's Information Group and the American League for Exports and Security Assistance earlier this year co-sponsored Defense Planning for Europe/1992, a one-day seminar, for a $450 fee. The International Advertising Association organized 1992 - The Challenge Worldwide. Another one-day event, Europe 1992: a Practical Approach, was sponsored by the International Protocol Officers Association.
Frost & Sullivan held a two-day seminar in New York in April that drew 170 people at $895 each. A similar event is planned in March.
For many, the effort is only beginning to pay off. ''There will be more directives coming out of the E.C. after 1992 requiring ongoing legal representation for U.S. companies doing business in Europe,'' said Mr. Teare of Crowell & Moring. Anticipating more activity, the law firm is considering opening an office in Brussels.
Ernst & Young has similar expectations. ''This is a major event for many of our clients and for us,'' said Richard Mead, who coordinates the firm's 1992-related activities in New York. ''And we don't see this effort ending in 1992.''

HEADLINE: Prospects;
The Fed's Rate Dilemma

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
The consumer price index jumped 0.5 percentage points in October, indicating a 5.9 percent annual rate of inflation. The Federal Reserve Board has said it wants to keep inflation low. But with a weakening economy, its ability to stem inflation is limited. Four economists assess inflation and the Federal Reserve's next move.
 
Francis Schott
Chief economist, Equitable Life Assurance Society. 
 The underlying inflation pressure - because of wage and cost problems - is still upward. Nevertheless, the 1990 inflation rate will be 4.5 percent, the same as in 1989.
The Fed would like to assist the economy, which is slowing, yet it has to continue fighting inflation, which at 4.5 percent is still too high. The solution to the dilemma is a very gradual easing of interest rates which will continue to 1990.
The Fed funds rate will come down another quarter percentage point to 8.25 by year-end. The prime rate will be down to at least 10 percent by year-end. During the first half of next year, the Fed funds will be 7.5 and the prime will be 9.5 or even lower.
 
Pat Choate
Economist and vice president, policy analysis, TRW Inc.
The ability of the Fed to make dramatic cuts in interest rates is severely constrained. The Federal budget deficit swirls along and there is no prospect of shrinking it before 1991. This continues to give the economy a very massive Keynesian stimulus. In addition, the continuing demand for imports is bidding up import prices and the dramatic availability of credit won't help keep inflation low.
I think the Fed will stand pat on interest rates. The Fed wants to cut inflation to zero. They will keep rates where they are, and I think that's the right thing to do. Inflation is still very troubling for the economy.
 
Leif Olsen
President, Leif Olsen Associates, an economics consulting firm.
The pickup in inflation in October's numbers isn't that significant. I fully expect that the next consumer price index will show a substantially slower rate of inflation. If you average the numbers, you can't conclude that inflation is accelerating. However, October retail sales are down 1.5 percentage points, the sharpest decline in two years, and personal consumption expenditures will be down for October as well. Throughout the year it has been difficult to achieve sales gains in durable and non-durable goods without price discounting. This indicates less inflation and slower growth.
The Fed will ease the funds rate one-fourth percent between now and early December depending on how slow the employment gains are. If we get surprisingly slow employment gains, we could also get a discount rate reduction as well. The prime rate will move when the Fed moves.
 
Lacy Hunt
Chief economist, Carroll, McEntee & McGinley Inc.
The inflation rate appears to be heading above 5 percent, perhaps up to 5.5 percent for the next year. First of all, wages are accelerating and will be given a boost by the minimum wage law. Productivity growth remains poor, meaning that the wage increases will be passed on in higher prices. Unleashing 450 million consumers behind the Iron Curtain suggests that there will be upward pressure on food prices. One of the big offsets to inflation has been oil prices, but now it appears that oil prices are headed upward. Reinforcing this is the fact that gold has risen above $400 an ounce - a 10-month high - and other commodities are going up as well.
If there is going to be a further easing in interest rates by the Fed, it has to be now. The economy will be stronger in the first part of the year. This quarter's gross national product grew by 1.4 percent. But this quarter absorbed two major natural disasters and two long strikes. Long-term interest rates will be down by one percentage point next year while growth will be at a 3 percent or better rate.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE REMAKING OF EUROPE;
The U.S. Shouldn't Abdicate Leadership

BYLINE: By JOSEPH I. LIEBERMAN; Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, is a Democrat from Connecticut.

 BODY:
The startling changes sweeping across Eastern Europe have evoked two inconsistent reactions in Washington, an exhilarating sense of historic opportunity and a debilitating sense of the limits of our resources and power.
Some see a unique chance to help shape the post-cold war world for decades to come. Others conclude that we cannot afford to be leaders anymore, so we must step back and hope it all works out for the best.
I believe that it is both premature and self-destructive for us to abdicate leadership. We must use our great resources to smooth the transition of Eastern Europe from state-controlled Communism to Western-style market economies not only because it is our moral responsibility, but also because it is an unprecedented economic opportunity, for our private and public sectors. American business stands to gain a great deal by investing in the new markets of Eastern Europe. And the Federal Government can reap a peace dividend if we no longer need to spend $150 billion a year defending Europeans from other Europeans. 
Neither private profit nor public savings are possible if the evolving democracies and economies of Eastern Europe do not survive and flourish. That's why we must ''let deeds follow words,'' as Lech Walesa says.
Congress made a good start with the Poland-Hungary aid package, which will benefit the two countries by making them eligible for programs run by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Export-Import Bank, and by encouraging the United States and other nations to reschedule Poland's debt, a move that would relieve the pressure of that country's Government.
But, as good as it is, the aid package is not enough. If we don't follow through with more immediate, imaginative and substantial assistance to all the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, we risk doing little more than putting a new tie on a corpse, to quote Mr. Walesa again.
First, the Secretary of the Treasury should encourage the International Monetary Fund to move ahead with a stabilization plan for Poland, which is a first step before it can receive aid from the international financial institutions and Western nations.
Second, the Secretary of the Treasury should authorize a bridge loan to Poland from our Exchange Stabilization Fund as soon as possible. The Solidarity economic plan is based on the assumption that its implementation will coincide with receipt of cash from the international community. But that money is months away. Strikes and riots - with uncertain results - could erupt in Poland as the coming harsh winter sets in, if more immediate assistance is not forthcoming. A bridge loan would help bolster the Polish economy until Western money arrives. And, since there is little or no history of default for a loan of this type, it should cost American taxpayers nothing at all.
Third, we need to look for ways to help Eastern Europe that are ''genius intensive.'' We should establish the economic equivalent of the Peace Corps and send volunteers with Western-style, free-market business acumen to Eastern Europe to help with the transition from Communist economics to free markets. This Eastern European Entrepreneurial Corps - perhaps operating under the auspices of the Peace Corps organization - could include everyone from young business school graduates looking for an opportunity to remake the world, to older veterans of big and small American businesses who have the practical experience in entrepreneurship and management.
Fourth, we should establish an Eastern European Foundation that would provide direct support to small and mid-sized Eastern European businesses and entrepreneurs through grants and technical assistance. The model for the foundation is the Inter-American Foundation, a public corporation that reaches out to grass-roots businesses and cooperatives in Latin America.
Fifth, we must help the nations of Eastern Europe rebuild their economic infrastructure, much as the physical infrastructure of Western Europe had to be rebuilt after World War II. Poland has no private banking system. None of the nations of Eastern Europe have fully convertible currencies. The President should establish a blue-ribbon panel to develop a long-term strategy for Eastern Europe and to help those nations develop market economies. A leader like Paul Volcker or George Shultz, should be put in charge.
Helping Eastern Europe rebuild makes good economic sense for America. But there is more than just money at stake. For four decades we have promoted the virtues of a free and open society and economy to the Communist world. Now that our moral leadership has given birth to a new order, we cannot responsibly turn our backs on our ideological progeny. We must help. And if we do, we could see one-time adversaries grow to become very good friends.

LENGTH: 1110 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
A Potpourri of Questions From Readers

BYLINE: By Deborah Rankin

 BODY:
Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.
Q.Our son will be a freshman in college next September, and we've saved $10,000 toward his tuition. The money is just sitting in a bank savings account, but we'd like to see it grow between now and then. Should we put it into the Magellan Fund, since it is doing so well? 
A. With all due deference to Fidelity's Magellan, which has a stellar 10-year record of 1,290 percent cumulative growth, the financial experts we queried say you should not be putting that money into the stock market since you are going to need it in less than a year.
''If you're going to need to draw on that money within the next three years, your guiding principle should be safety,'' said George Barbee, executive director of Price Waterhouse's Personal Financial Service in Waltham, Mass. ''You should put it in something with little or no risk of capital loss, such as bank certificates of deposit, Treasury bills or a money fund, and not aim for enormous capital appreciation. As long as you're earning a few percentage points above the inflation rate, you shouldn't worry.''
Margaret Welch, a certified financial planner and vice president with Alexandra Armstrong Advisers, a Washington financial planning firm, agreed. ''People tend to confuse the times when it's appropriate to go into risky rather than conservative investments,'' she said.
For long-term money - perhaps for your retirement - the stock market has historically offered much higher returns than C.D.'s or Treasury bills, Mrs. Welch said. If you are willing to ride out the inevitable ups and downs in the market cycle for a decade or so, the chances are that you will be able to cash out at a handsome profit.
But for money that you need so soon, you should turn to taxable money market funds, which are yielding about 8.3 percent; bank C.D.'s, yielding about 7.8 percent, or 6-month Treasury bills, also yielding about 7.8 percent.
Since you live in New York, you presumably are subject to relatively high state and local income taxes in addition to Federal tax. Treasury bills are exempt from state and local taxes. But you should also consider investing in a triple tax-free money fund that is exempt from all three levies. Fidelity's New York Free Money Market Fund, for one, is yielding about 5.4 percent.
 
Q. I understand that the Internal Revenue Service has changed the way you can report earnings from United States savings bonds. Can you explain what the change entails?
 
A. Yes, but first some background on the options that owners of E and EE bonds have regarding the tax treatment of their interest earnings. There are two ways of handling this income: you can either report it as it accrues each year, or you can wait until the bonds are redeemed or mature and report all the interest then.
Under the old rules, if you elected to report the interest annually, you had to continue to use that method until the bonds matured or were redeemed. But the I.R.S. will now allow you to change that election, and defer the reporting of interest, by filing a Form 3115 (Application for Change in Method of Accounting) with your Federal tax return for the year of change. There is one drawback though: You must use the deferred method for at least five years following the change.
''The new procedure makes it easier to switch, and is particularly beneficial for children who own savings bonds,'' said Sidney Kess, a New York tax lawyer and certified public accountant.
If your children are under age 14, they are now subject to the ''kiddie'' tax on unearned income. This means that their earnings from interest and dividends that exceed $1,000 are taxed at their parents' higher rates rather than their own lower rates. J. K. Lasser's Monthly Tax Service suggests switching those children to the deferred method if they are now reporting savings bond interest each year. ''The election will defer tax on the interest'' until they turn 14, at which point it will be taxed at their own lower rates, Lasser's said.
 
Q. Is it true that I can only claim the child-care credit if I report my baby sitter's Social Security number? She insists on being paid in cash, ''off the books,'' and I'm afraid she will refuse to give it to me.
 
A. As a result of new legislation, you will be unable to claim the credit (which is a maximum of $720 for one child and $1,440 for two or more) if your baby sitter balks. (Of course, you were required all along to pay the baby sitter on the books - and make all the necessary tax filings - in order to claim the credit legally.) The Family Support Act of 1988 requires that starting in 1989, parents who claim the dependent-care tax credit must divulge the names and taxpayer identification numbers of their baby sitters, nannies or child-care providers (only tax-exempt providers, like a licensed church nursery school, are excused from this new reporting requirement). The I.R.S. has even created a new form, W-10, that enables parents to obtain the necessary information from their care providers; however, the form is not filed with their income tax returns, but rather retained with their tax records.
If you participate in a dependent-care assistance program at work, which allows you to pay up to $5,000 in child-care expenses with pretax rather than after-tax dollars, you must also furnish your care giver's identification number; otherwise the salary that you have agreed to forgo and contribute to the assistance program will be transformed into taxable income.
In addition to cracking down on the illegal, but widespread, practice of paying care givers off the books, Congress made several other changes regarding the tax treatment of child care that take effect this year.
Practically speaking, it has abolished the practice of letting workers take advantage of both a dependent-care assistance program at work and the child-care credit; now, they must choose one or the other. If there is a choice, most parents will do better by participating in a dependent-care program rather than claiming the credit, according to Towers Perrin, a benefits consulting firm.
Another change in the law lowers the age of children whose care expenses get tax-favored treatment. Now, only care for youngsters aged 12 and under can be claimed; previously, children 14 and younger had qualified.
Finally, in order to claim a $2,000 dependency exemption, parents must obtain the Social Security number of any child age 2 or older, and report that number on their tax returns; previously, such information was required only for children who were 5 and over.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE REMAKING OF EUROPE;
Invest at Home for Influence Abroad

BYLINE: By JEFFERY MADRICK; Jeffrey Madrick is a business correspondent for NBC and publisher of IRIS, a financial newsletter.

 BODY:
The United States is acting like a poor country when it is not one. Washington sits virtually paralyzed as the world is stunned daily by events in East Europe. Paris called a conference among its European colleagues and West Germany has already announced plans to spend billions of dollars on investment in East Germany. The Japanese will not be far behind, and some conjecture they will soon be ahead. By contrast, the leaders of the country that is still by far the richest in the world - the United States - are consumed by cutting a few billion dollars of spending from a $5 trillion economy.
Largely because of the budget deficit, inaction is ''in'' in Washington. Talk to an undersecretary of Commerce, or Treasury or Education and they say something like this: ''Why do you always want to pour money into everything? Money isn't always the answer. Let's do better with what we have.'' 
Washington's leadership occasionally shrouds this attitude in loftier principles. ''We must begin to understand that we are not the only nation in the world,'' goes the running line from both Republicans and Democrats. We can no longer be responsible for every country in the world.
How did we get here? In terms of gross national product, our economy is two and a half times the size of Japan's and five times the size of Germany's. But unlike them, we have spent more than we have, and now there's no money in the bank. As a result, we don't have the wherewithal to participate in the new alignment in Eastern Europe and we are less likely to profit from its growth.
The richest nation in the world has spent too much money on the wrong things and now it is in danger of losing out in Eastern Europe. But the United States is by no means a poor country and we should not sit on the sidelines as perestroika sweeps through the world. Money still talks, in Eastern Europe, in educating our young and in rebuilding our infrastructure. Here's an economic agenda to fit the new times and ensure that we remain a world leader.
* Government ''investment'' must be separated from Government spending in the budget deficit calculations. The Gramm-Rudman law should be either revised to reflect this or abolished. We have more leeway to spend than we believe because borrowing is not bad if it is spent in ways that will produce real economic pay-offs.
* Raise income taxes. A 28 percent top tax rate is destructive. Taxes will be raised anyway by the states and cities taking the biggest hit due to lost Federal aid. If Americans understand where the money is going, they will not be averse to tax hikes.
* The military budget can be cut significantly. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has opened the door, and recent cost-cutting proposals by the Bush Administration suggest at last that some headway is being made. Military spending in a full-employment economy, when no Keynesian fiscal push is needed, drains money away from productive investment. The problems of economic dislocations - from cutting the military budget - are exaggerated, just as they were after World War II.
* Forget tax proposals intended to spur more saving, like lower capital gains rates or deductions for individual retirement accounts. They don't work. America's saving rate has been remarkably steady, without them, until recent years. The tax system should be used to spur investment.
* End tax policies that encourage borrowing. They have made leveraged buyouts and corporate takeovers very attractive, but they are uneconomic investments, much like many tax shelters once were. As a result, needed investment funds have been wasted, and interest rates have been unecessarily pushed up.
* Stop all the protectionist threats. Protectionism is the ideology of the poor.
* Get the cost of capital down, and that mostly means lower long-term interest rates. High interest rates have been the most debilitating element in the economy for more than a decade. The cost of capital is much lower in Germany and Japan than it is here and it is reflected in the ease with which they can buy Rockefeller Center or invest in East Germany.
How do you get long-term rates down without igniting inflation? That is the phantom of our particular economic opera. The above proposals will help reduce the deficit. And as far a Treasury financing goes, it should be bunched in the short end of the market.
A narrow-minded pragmatism is ruling Washington, which some interpret as wisdom. Our leaders choose their historical lessons very selectively. But for the United States to fully participate in the restructuring of Europe, we must make our economy more vital and our businesses more competitive. These are times for bold thinking, not turning away. If the United States acts like a poor nation it can turn into a self-fulfilling prophecy.

HEADLINE: ALONG FOR THE RIDE;
The Real Superpower At the Summit Will Be The Force of History

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet each other off the coast of Malta next week at one of those rare moments when you can hear the pages of history turning - a moment when the 40-year-old arrangements of the postwar world are coming to an end and demanding redefinition. But Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will not be meeting to unfurl blueprints or draw lines on maps. The future is not theirs to define, as it was for Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin at Yalta in 1945.
Those three met as winners of a war, as men in control of a world. Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, by contrast, meet as heirs to an uneasy peace whose foundations are dissolving - not through war but because individual Poles and Hungarians, East Germans and Czechs are no longer ready to accept the assumptions on which the cold war peace was based. These individual Poles, Germans, Hungarians and Czechs could not have played that role had not Mr. Gorbachev dared to unleash energies that might lift Communism from its torpor. In the longer term, many might argue, they also could not have succeeded without the steadfastness of the West. 
While 1989 will undoubtedly have its chapter in the history books, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will appear in that chapter as much witnesses to the changes taking shape as masters of them. That is not to say that when Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev meet next weekend on the Soviet cruiser Slava and the American cruiser Belknap what they discuss will not have an enormous impact on Europe. It is simply to appreciate the constraints on them both.
''I don't think either of them can help but appreciate that as much as they have set in motion the forces that are now unfolding in Eastern Europe, as much as they can influence them at the margins, it is those forces which are now in the saddle, not either of them,'' said Michael J. Sandel, a political theorist at Harvard. ''The most appropriate response now is not caution or boldness - we are beyond all that - but attentiveness and appreciation. Because when history turns this fast, what we want from statesmen are not vain attempts to control events that have a momentum of their own, but that they be alive to the possibilities that these events will leave in their wake.''
That explains why the President is preparing for this summit more with questions than answers for Mr. Gorbachev. Although Mr. Bush and his advisers and Mr. Gorbachev and his advisers have already dealt extensively with one another, they will meet in Malta almost as strangers. It is not that they have changed but that circumstances in the last six months have changed them - assigned them new roles, bequeathed them new responsibilities and invested them with new aspirations. Indeed, Bush advisers say, all of this is reflected in the four main subjects on the President's agenda.
The first item is to ask Mr. Gorbachev: Who are you today?
''The President wants to get a firsthand sense from Gorbachev as to exactly what is his domestic agenda, how he plans to allocate resources in the coming years, how he plans to solve the problems he has identified, what he sees as his own prospects for success and how much time he thinks his own people will give him,'' an Administration official said.
The President is sure to ask Mr. Gorbachev to indicate the limits of Soviet tolerance for change in Eastern Europe. For instance, must Poland, Hungary and East Germany remain full members of the Warsaw Pact?
If so, could they remain members of the Warsaw Pact and yet leave the Council of Mutual Economic Assistance, the Soviet bloc's equivalent of the European Community? Will Moscow draw tighter limits around the freedom of East Germany than, say, that of Poland or Hungary?
''There is nothing like hearing from the great man himself about these issues,'' said a State Department expert on Europe. ''What we learn about his approach to the East bloc will speak volumes about his whole approach to security. This will clearly affect our own strategy and planning.''
Mr. Bush's second concern involves what he will tell Mr. Gorbachev. The most important message, Administration officials say, will be that the Soviet Union's behavior in regional conflicts like those in El Salvador, Nicaragua and Afghanistan will greatly influence its standing with the American public and with Congress - the same Congress that would have to ratify any arms control agreements. The President will also try to set a timetable for resolving issues in the conventional arms talks and the strategic arms talks, so these treaties can be completed by or near the date of the summit scheduled for this spring.
The third item on the President's mind will be the issues he doesn't want to raise. Administration officials insist that he will avoid anything that looks like an agreement being made by the superpowers over the heads of the Europeans - anything, that is, that smacks of Yalta. He will also avoid anything - winks and nods as well as words - that could indicate that the United States would tolerate a ''Chinese solution'' to unrest in Soviet republics like the Baltics.
Last, Mr. Bush may have a few surprises tucked at the bottom of his agenda, just in case Mr. Gorbachev starts pulling rabbits out of his attache case.
''I think the President should have in his back pocket a series of steps to help the Soviets economically,'' Charles William Maynes, editor of the journal Foreign Policy, argued. ''This is not charity. It is a way of helping those in the Soviet system who are doing the right thing. That is helping ourselves. Remember: Herbert Hoover sent massive food aid to Lenin which helped to save the Russian revolution in its infancy. If Hoover could help Lenin save the revolution, surely Bush could help Gorbachev save perestroika.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Gorbachev May Seek a Bush Vote of Confidence

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IN a sense Mikhail S. Gorbachev may be seeking the impossible in his Mediterranean rendezvous with President Bush, trying to project the image of a confident leader as the Communist monolith melts in Eastern Europe.
Some analysts here say it will not be enough for him to display more of the showmanship of the great Oz. ''He must be more than reactive and show himself indispensable to this process,'' a diplomat said. 
He observed that however fresh a spirit Mr. Gorbachev sought to inspire in Communism, he hardly intended to program so great a political trauma in a single season.
''He needs this one right now,'' said another Westerner, speaking of the shipboard appointment. ''And he needs it far more than he first imagined for domestic consumption.''
The diplomat was looking beyond the meeting's basic goal of building a better personal relationship between the presidents and reassuring each other that there will be no cold war exploitation of the momentous turmoil. As important to Mr. Gorbachev, he said, is how the meeting plays to the Soviet public as another episode in the drama of Eastern Europe.
Almost lost in the graphic history of Communist subjects demonstrating by the hundreds of thousands for democracy elsewhere has been a complaint here, no bigger than a nettle at first, but increasingly defined: the issue of rescinding the Communist Party's monopoly over the nation's political, social and economic power.
 
Defending the Party
There are no throngs in the streets, but the issue is appearing more regularly on dissident agendas and has sparked some passionate defenses of the party from Mr. Gorbachev.
Using the Malta meeting somehow to define the Soviet party as clearly essential and different from the now disheveled satellite parties would be an important goal for him.
Western diplomats also sense that Mr. Gorbachev, while still admitting that the scope of Soviet economic problems is too large and internally rooted to be open to easy American aid, urgently needs a definitive signal of trust in this area from Mr. Bush.
A more positive encouragement from the President to American businesses to pursue trading with the Soviet Union would serve as a special sign that goes beyond the expected restoration of most-favored-nation trade status.
Mr. Gorbachev has made a habit of unveiling surprise initiatives as he approaches these meetings. But this time Western analysts are betting he senses that there have been enough shocks for both sides lately and that the substantive, personal trust he needs now is better courted by being unsurprising.
But the question is whether the events of Eastern Europe can be that humbling to such a kinetic, optimistic politician.
''He's been very adaptable to date,'' said one diplomat, wisely hedging all predictions about Mr. Gorbachev and the change that swirls around him.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
More and More, Prison Is America's Answer to Crime

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
OFFICIALS in California expect this week to open a new 1,000-bed maximum security prison at Pelican Bay in the northern part of the state and to open another 1,200-bed wing there soon afterward, increasing the capacity of the country's largest state prison system to 49,767 inmates.
The trouble is that the state already has 86,746 people in custody, and an additional 250 or so are added every week. Routinely operating at 175 percent of capacity, the California prisons are more overcrowded than most, putting two prisoners in one-person cells and stacking bunkbeds in gyms and day-rooms.
But most state prison systems are overcrowded, now more than ever. 
Drug crackdowns, a broadening of the offenses classified as felonies, the introduction of mandatory sentences and a tendency toward longer sentences in general are among the factors that this year raised the population of state and Federal prisons to its highest point in history, a total of 673,565 on June 30. That represented an increase of 46,004 prisoners, or 7.3 percent, since Jan. 1, a larger increase in six months than the prisons have ever experienced in an entire year.
As society grows impatient with crime and drugs, a prison industry that already consumes more than $13 billion a year is showing no sign of recession.
Experts agree that new prisons alone will never solve the problem. Some experiments are under way as alternatives to prison for less violent convicts. These include expanded halfway houses and supervised community service, sentencing guidelines that limit a term's maximum as well as its minimum, more attention to matching punishment to a particular crime's severity and electronic monitors, which enforce a prisoner's house arrest at home.
Some predict a time when the costs of imprisoning so many people will give taxpayers second thoughts. But that has not happened yet. While rejecting many initiatives last year, California voters overwhelmingly approved the fourth prison-bond referendum in recent years.
''It's been a complete sea change in the 80's,'' said Franklin Zimring, director of the Earl Warren Legal Institute at the University of California at Berkeley. ''We had declining imprisonment rates in the 60's and the early 70's. And now three-quarters of the states are at historic highs.''
Entire systems or individual prisons in more than three dozen states are operating under court orders aimed at limiting overcrowding or mitigating its impact on inmates.
In Connecticut, where 6 of 15 state prisons are under such court orders, a law requires the release of prisoners if the system operates at 110 percent of capacity for more than 30 consecutive days. Two weeks ago, with 8,760 prisoners, the system reached its 29th day of overcrowding, and officials scrambled to reduce the inmate population by a variety of means such as delaying transfers from local jails, or releasing some prisoners early, an unpopular measure. Connecticut has 23 prison construction projects under way to add 6,000 beds by mid-1992, said William E. Flower, a spokesman for the state Department of Correction. At that point Connecticut will still be 9,000 beds short, according to estimates.
The reasons for overcrowding in Connecticut and elsewhere are varied. Widespread drug use, followed by tougher enforcement, have led to more drug arrests and incarcerations.
''There's a little lag as more arrests make their way through the justice system,'' Mr. Flower said. ''But when one branch, the police, spends more on enforcement, pretty soon another has to pay more for imprisonment.'' In Connecticut, 26 percent of state prisoners are serving time for drug-related offenses.
Overall sentences are longer and so are minimum sentences, which are now often mandatory. Judges have less leeway in the sentences they impose and they grant probation much less frequently. In 1974, 15 percent of California's felony convictions resulted in prison terms, with probation and other forms of punishment accounting for the rest. Today, 35 percent of felony convictions lead to prison time.
Parole has greatly declined in political popularity, experts say, and courts are moving quickly to return parole violators to prison. Slightly more than one-third of California state prisoners are parole violators.
There are also new categories of felony, such as sexual abuse, which draw significant prison terms. And new degrees of aggravation in given offenses, such as carrying a gun in a house burglary, add mandatory extra years to a sentence.
When drunk driving is punished by incarceration, the time has usually been served in county jails. But in more states, a third drunk-driving charge becomes a felony, punishable by time in the state penitentiary. Convicts classified as habitual criminals can receive life terms in Alabama and other states for convictions otherwise punishable by shorter sentences.
And in a growing number of murder convictions, life terms without parole are emerging as a cheaper alternative to the death penalty, which entails many years of costly legal appeals. This means that more prisoners are serving longer terms, presenting new problems for administrators, guards and prison doctors unaccustomed to caring for aged inmates.
Some states are already creating geriatric wards for prisoners who require more medical care, protection from aggressive inmates, different diets and even architectural alterations to accommodate wheelchairs.
Professor Zimring links the trend toward tougher sanctions to the advent of the television age, which has made people more aware of specific crimes and how prosecutors and judges deal with them.
''The increased visibility of the justice system makes the political risks of being visibly lenient on convicts substantially higher than the risks of being ostentatiously tough,'' said Professor Zimring. ''In that sense judges and prosecutors may be in a tougher mood than society.''
There have been other times of rapid growth in prison populations - in the early 1900's, for instance, when passage of the White Slave Act in 1910, the Harrison Narcotic Act of 1914 and Prohibition after World War I led to many new convictions. But even as late as the mid-1930's, a few years after the passage of anti-gangster measures, Federal institutions held only 15,500 prisoners. This month the Federal prison population passed 52,750.
Early in American history, prisons were used only to house the accused until trial and the convicted until corporal punishment or execution was carried out. With the declining use of flogging and stocks came the American invention of the penitentiary - to encourage penitence while housing the convicted for longer terms of punishment, reflection and, ideally, rehabilitation.
''But rehabilitation of inmates is not a popular concept now,'' said Frank Hartman, executive director of the criminal justice program at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. ''When you say a third felony conviction gets you into prison for as long as you're breathing, the message is not one of hope for the future. Today's message is incapacitation: Lock 'em up.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Salvador Rebels Lose Touch, But Still Show Their Strength

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR

 BODY:
WITH something approaching awe, the rebel looked at the hotel room - a double bed, a carpet, a private bath and a tiled shower. That may be standard in any motel in the United States, but it is unfathomable luxury for most Salvadorans. ''I'm from the countryside,'' the guerrilla said. ''I've never been in San Salvador before. I've never seen wealth like this.''
The teen-age rebel was part of a band that had fought its way into a wealthy neighborhood in San Salvador, one of the few times the civil war had penetrated the tight security that shields the capital's elite. The rebels' presence illustrated their strengths in the decade-old civil war, and the teen-ager's awe at his surroundings reflected the deep divisions that have fueled the conflict. 
But his admission that he had never been in the city also illustrated a weakness of the rebels: they have failed to adapt to El Salvador's new political and demographic landscape. That weakness has kept them out of touch with many Salvadorans, and it undermined their recent offensive.
While most of El Salvador still works by an agricultural clock - up at 4 A.M., in bed by 8 P.M. - it is fast becoming an urban country. About three of five Salvadorans now live and work in metropolitan San Salvador, many having been forced off the land by the war, which has claimed 70,000 lives and displaced at least 1 in 10 people. Fewer and fewer Salvadorans share the peasant background of the guerrilla army, which is composed largely of rural teen-agers led by veteran guerrillas, many with university educations.
After almost a decade of isolation in the mountains, rebel commanders appear to have lost touch with the average city dweller. When one rebel leader returned to the capital two years ago for talks with the Government, he rode through San Salvador with his head swiveling from side to side. ''I can't believe how everything has changed,'' he told a diplomat accompanying him.
 
A Narrow View
Sometimes the rebels resemble an isolated sect, with a limited flow of information. That narrow view of the world seems to have tricked them into believing they could set off an insurrection with their latest offensive. They trucked in tons of weapons, apparently supplied by Nicaragua and Cuba. But they had more guns than volunteers, and the civilians did not rise.
More than anything, it seems, most Salvadorans are fed up with the war and see it as a continuing cycle of killing and poverty. While fighting raged in the working-class district of Soyapongo this month, workers stayed at their posts in a shoe factory caught in the crossfire. Evidently they saw steady jobs as offering a better future than revolution.
El Salvador's leading Lutheran cleric, Bishop Merdardo Gomez, last week called El Salvador a ''fertile country for revolution.'' So it appears. Poverty is endemic, repression seemingly perpetual. Luxury cars skirt potholes in streets bordering acres of shantytowns. A full-time job is a dream for almost half the population.
Yet the country remains a bastion of conservative attitudes.
Roman Catholicism has taught many that suffering is the price of a better afterlife. And there are long memories of a peasant uprising in 1932 that was put down by the slaughter of an estimated 10,000 people. If Salvadorans have learned one thing, it is to remain neutral.
 
Tactical Shifts
That is not to say the fight will soon end. While the rebels did not topple the Government this month, their offensive again showed them capable of overcoming internal divisions and countering improvements in the Salvadoran Army.
The latest offensive appears to have been one more tactical shift.
For the first time, the guerrillas brought the full force of the war into the capital, the stronghold of the oligarchy, which had been isolated from most of the fighting. And it almost caused direct United States intervention. When the rebels stormed the Hotel El Salvador, 12 Green Berets inside were trapped, and President Bush dispatched a special squad, the Delta Force, to rescue them if needed. It turned out that the team was not needed, because the rebels withdrew under an agreement with the Government.
Still, the rebels did show they hold a key to the success of President Alfredo Cristiani's ambitious plan to rebuild the economy and improve Salvadorans' lives. It is now clear that his ability to do that depends on the rebels' willingness to make peace.
Earlier this month, the rebels broke off talks with the Government on the ground that the talks had done little but show the chasm separating the two sides. The Government and the rebels have since sent members to meet with President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, who wants to mediate. But each side has also made demands intended to be rejected by the other. That has left the army preparing for another rebel attack, with prospects for renewed talks dim.
''The army and the guerrillas can both claim victory'' in this month's offensive, said Ruben Zamora, a leftist politician allied with the rebels. ''And a winner doesn't negotiate.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Reluctantly, the Military Embraces New Politics and Tighter Budgets

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BUDGET officials were working late at the Pentagon last week as the Red Army Chorus launched into its program onstage at Kennedy Center, just across the river.
In their red-trimmed uniforms, the Soviet officers began with ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' and ended with ''God Bless America.'' The performance received a standing ovation, leading one concertgoer to say that the Red Army could knock an additional $5 billion off of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's new budget by extending its tour another week.
Warming relations between Moscow and Washington, along with budget considerations, have put increasing pressure on military spending. With cuts inevitable, Mr. Cheney volunteered to wield the knife himself. 
The Defense Secretary ordered the military services to identify $180 billion in possible cuts from projected spending in the fiscal years 1992 through 1994. Advisers to Mr. Cheney said that reductions of such magnitude were likely to be the most that they would have to accept.
But even if eventual cuts are less severe than the services have been asked to plan for, Mr. Cheney's directive tacitly acknowledges that some significant cuts are nevertheless in the offing.
 
'Realistic Assumptions'
''What I've done is take a look at history - at the last five years,'' he said last Sunday on the ABC News program ''This Week.'' ''Each year, the Department has gone up with a proposal for real growth in defense spending. It never happens.''
''If you look at a realistic set of assumptions about how much money we're going to have'' in future years, he added, ''then it leads you to the conclusion that we're going to have to spend significantly less'' than current plans call for.
The Pentagon's acceptance of this budgetary reality, unwelcome though it is by some Department officials, is a breakthrough of sorts.
Over the years, the Pentagon now admits that it had made a bad habit of wishful thinking. Even while Congress was moving to trim the military budget, the Pentagon would continue to project spending increases in future years and to act as if this imaginary money would someday become real.
 
Paying a Price
The practice of continually assuming the best helped to maintain relative peace within the Pentagon. Deferring the need for tough decisions helped to limit the infighting among the services and among their various supporters on Capitol Hill.
But the Pentagon's calculated over-optimism came at a price. Realistic planning was disrupted and money was wasted. Assuming that all projected appropriations would materialize, for example, the Defense Department launched too many weapons programs. As budgets shrank, production schedules were cut back and the unit cost of a given weapon went up.
Mr. Cheney's directive to the services, while only a first step, is an effort toward changing the Pentagon's approach on budget requests.
Until now, the Bush Administration had planned on spending increases of 1 percent or 2 percent from 1992 to 1994, after the effect of inflation was discounted.
A cut of $180 billion from the White House's previously planned increases for those years - the ''worst case'' circumstance at the heart of Mr. Cheney's budget directive -would mean that military spending would shrink an average of about 5 percent annually, after inflation, Pentagon officials said.
Responding to Mr. Cheney's order, the Air Force proposed measures including the closing of 15 bases, slowing the rate of production for the B-2 bomber and scaling back the purchase of F-16 planes, officials said.
The Navy's proposals included mothballing 2 of its 14 aircraft carriers. The Army has offered plans to eliminate three active divisions and forgo the long-sought modernization of the M-1 tank.
But none of the services were eager to suggest a cancellation of any important new weapons. Civilian and military officials met on Tuesday to review the service budget cut proposals, and some of them said that it could take months before the Pentagon decided how to modify its old multiyear spending plan.
In Congress, the Pentagon's changed approach to spending plans has generally been viewed as a shrewd move by Mr. Cheney.
Representative Norman Dicks, a Washington Democrat who serves on House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, said Mr. Cheney has a better chance of maintaining control over the budget on Capitol Hill by presenting a plan that is close to what Congress is likely to approve instead of making unrealistic requests, as Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger did during the Reagan years.
But some experts also worry that the cuts are being discussed in a vacuum.
To take account of changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Pentagon officials have begun to rewrite the the strategic planning assumptions on which military spending decisions are based. The revisions, which are to be made to the Defense Planning Guidance, have not yet been completed even though the planning document was scheduled to have been finished by Oct. 1.
 
Reduced Threat
Advisers to Mr. Cheney said the task of preparing the new policy guide has been complicated by the prospect of a sharply reduced Soviet military presence in Europe as a result of the recent rapid political changes in Warsaw Pact nations. But translating the perception of a reduced threat into actual spending cuts is a complicated matter, to say the least.
As the Pentagon is beginning to discover, climbing down the budget mountain is a lot harder than going up.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Will Cuts Help the Deficit?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REDUCTIONS in military spending will not produce a pot of money for domestic programs any time soon. Nor will the cuts make it easier for President Bush and Congress to lower the budget deficit next year. The deficit problem is simply too daunting and potential Pentagon cuts too gradual to make much short-term difference. 
''We shouldn't look at this as providing us with the wherewithal to meet all our problems,'' said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist.
The President and Congress spent all this year haggling over reducing the deficit by a mere $14 billion to meet the $110 billion target required by law for fiscal year 1990, which began Oct. 1. Just before dawn Wednesday morning, Congress produced a bill of nips and tucks and gimmicks and then adjourned.
Next year, by contrast, the deficit will have to be cut by more than $40 billion to meet the $64 billion ceiling set by the law. Getting there will require deep slashes in spending, a substantial increase in taxes or a combination of the two. ''We've got a fire-breathing monster staring at us,'' said Representative Les AuCoin, an Oregon Democrat.
The Bush Administration is expected to propose cuts of no more than $10 billion in military spending, and Congress will probably not be able to up that ante by much. That is true in large part because so much of the Pentagon budget for the next year is already committed, either in long-term contracts for weapons systems or in pay and benefits for people already in the service.
Buying out contracts, closing bases or reducing troop levels - actions that could save tens, even hundreds, of billions of dollars eventually - take time to accomplish and often carry additional costs in the first year or two.
For the current fiscal year, about a third of the deficit reduction on which Congress and the President agreed was obtained by across-the-board cuts of 1 percent to 2 percent in most military and domestic programs. Another third comes from obscure tax law changes, including new taxes on cruise ship tickets. The remainder consists mostly of accounting tricks, like not counting the Postal Service's deficit. All these measures were so delicately constructed that Federal officials still could not say just what the deficit would really be in this fiscal year.
With this year's figures finally approved, the budget office is in the final stage of deciding how much money to propose for each department and agency in fiscal 1991, which begins next Oct. 1. The ''challenge'' in meeting the deficit target ''is going to be very large,'' said Richard G. Darman, the budget director. ''There's no escaping that.''
