SECTION: Section 4; Page 14, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 2061 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS AND TRENDS;
How Freud Shaped the 20th-Century Mind

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS and philosophers still debate where Sigmund Freud's theories of psychoanalysis fit into the jigsaw puzzle of disciplines studying the brain and mind.
To biologists working with brain cells and psychologists analyzing experimental data, Freud's ideas of subterranean mental forces often seem musty and arcane. Are modern men and women really fated to relive the dramas of Oedipus and Electra, psychologically murdering the parent of the same sex? Even some psychiatrists feel that their more doctrinaire colleagues in psychoanalysis are seized with an ideology not a science.
Whatever their scientific status, Freud's theories about the effects of the unconscious on behavior pervade Western culture and the humanities. To observe the 50th anniversary of his death, scholars of psychoanalysis gathered in Columbia, S.C., earlier this month for a University of South Carolina symposium on Freud's impact on such fields as psychology, literary criticism and even business administration. Here are some excerpts. 
 
AN IDEOLOGY - OR A SCIENCE?
IN its early years, psychoanalysis took on an insular existence with few connections to the outside world. Even today some analysts treat concepts like the Oedipus complex as dogmas and opposing ideas as heresies. Dr. Eugene H. Kaplan, a professor of neuropsychiatry and behavioral science at the University of South Carolina School of Medicine, said it was time for the field to hold itself to more rigorous standards.
 
What has been the impact of Freud on 20th-century thought? After 50 years we have come far enough so that we are not here to consider ''the Word.'' We're not talking about the revealed word of Sigmund Freud. And we're not here to adore or to worship or to idealize but to appreciate. And to appreciate means to savor, to critique, to discard.
I was reminded of a celebration at the time of the 100th anniversary of his birth when, I think, the title was ''The Legacy of Sigmund Freud.'' There is some passage in the Bible that says when one inherits a legacy one must then work and strive to make that legacy one's own - really to metabolize it and to absorb it. I think we're arriving at that point.
What characterizes the main theoretical developments in the last 50 years has been a decentering of the importance of the Oedipus complex. Not because the Oedipus complex isn't important but if you're starting out and the first thing you discover is the Oedipus complex, the rational way of handling that is to explain everything on the basis of the Oedipus complex.
Clearly from what we've learned about Freud's relationships and conflicts toward his own parents, he had to put emphasis on the Oedipal complex and the relationship to the father and to sidestep the relationship to the mother. Issues of relationships to the mother and the issues of narcissism are much more in the picture now. And that makes for a richer and more difficult picture. Because we have come so much further and psychoanalysis is no longer merely the institution which is the shadow of the man, what developments that have occurred do not lead anymore to heresy and schism.
What do I see for the future? Some of us have a dream that we can achieve a kind of integration. We feel that psychoanalysis has suffered almost mortally from its isolation from the university, its isolation from the other intellectual disciplines. And if it's worth saving it has to be able to stand the glare of all kinds of other study. And I think it will be lifesaving. I think there has to be an integration in which the connection is not simply to medicine and psychiatry but to the arts and the humanities. Yet I look for an integration that is not a mindless eclecticism but where there will be a development of criteria and where we can go forward with some scientific appeal. We have to have a higher court of appeal that we will all accept and it can't be simply what sounds best or who is more charismatic.
 
FROM THE MENTAL TO THE PHYSICAL
TODAY most neuroscientists are what philosophers call strict determinists. They believe that the mind is simply what the brain does and that mental life must ultimately be determined by biology and chemistry.
Some scientists and philosophers, on the other hand, argue for a mentalist approach, holding that the mind is best studied as a thing in itself with a rule book of its own.
Dr. Robert Michels, chairman of psychiatry at Cornell University Medical School in New York, said Freud took an intermediary position, considering his theories of the mind a temporary approximation until more was learned about the brain.
 
A hundred years ago, Freud gave up the laboratory study of the brain to embark on a new phase in his career: the clinical, psychological study of the mind. His initial hope was to establish a scientific psychology, one that dealt with mental phenomena - with thoughts, feelings, wishes, fears, passions -and that did so not in the loose common-sense way in which we normally think about mental phenomena but with a strict, rigorous, scientific determinism that ultimately could be linked to the emerging understanding of the brain.
Before Freud there were really two approaches to thinking about mental life and behavior. One was scientific, deterministic, with the brain controlled by the laws of physics and chemistry. The study of mental life makes sense for awhile, until we know enough about the biology of the brain to be able to make predictive statements based on our direct understanding of it -that's the view of most contemporary leaders of neurobiologic science. It was certainly Freud's view when he started out in this new field.
 
Missing Pieces
The other pre-Freudian view was common-sense psychology - totally mentalist, common-sense explanations for behavior in terms of thoughts, wishes, feelings, hopes, never in terms of synapses, neurotransmitters, cortical excitation or other brain states. It was deterministic in that it explained things in terms of cause and effect. But it was loosely rather than tightly deterministic. There were weak links and missing pieces that were explained as behavior that just couldn't be understood.
Of course, common-sense psychology essentially ignored the brain. It saw most mental phenomena as caused by other mental phenomena. Those causes could usually be understood, but some mental phenomena were inexplicable. These included dreams, parapraxis [slips of the tongue, for example] and neurotic symptoms. Mentalist determinism based on the traditional data of common-sense psychology - introspection - failed and a determinist psychology that would be strictly mentalist required new tools.
Freud's psychoanalysis offered those new tools: the concept of mental causes that could not be discovered by simple introspection. This concept allowed all mental life to be seen as mentally or psychically determined by creating this new category of causes.
For the first time, with the advent of psychoanalysis, it was no longer necessary that a scientific psychology be fundamentally a neuropsychology. Freud himself was not too enthusiastic about this. He longed for a neurological basis for his new discoveries.
 
PUTTING A CORPORATION ON THE ANALYST'S COUCH
ABRAHAM ZALEZNIK, a professor at Harvard Business School, applies psychoanalytic techniques to sick corporations. He has found that even when business leaders are reasonably healthy, their organizations can engage in self-destructive behavior. Blinded by grandiose self-images - corporate mythologies, he calls them - a company often ignores economic realities and resists change. One explanation for General Motors's loss of market share, he said, was the ''internalization of ideals, values and corporate structures and practices'' that can be traced to the company's legendary chairman, Alfred P. Sloan Jr.
 
Organizational studies on the whole have remained somewhat detached from and resistant to psychodynamic observations and interpretations. The forms organizations take are presented typically as rational responses to environmental conditions, to technology and to other extrinsic forces. Motivations of actors in organizations are considered either as intervening variables and therefore not necessarily the object of direct study or as noise in the system. . . .
People who are well placed in the power structure enjoy a protected position. There are certain narcissistic gains from belonging to the organization and being in that power position, and they are highly invested in it, and all the elements that produce cohesion, as Freud pointed out, are at work there. The people in the lower levels are very much excluded from the mythological structures that provide these narcissistic gains. The mythology includes the notion that ''the world's against us, everybody out there is our enemy, and we therefore have to pull together in order to ward off impending disasters.'' The internalization of these mythologies passes on from one group to another within the power elite but it excludes the lower-level people, who in turn feel very much left out and are vulnerable to depressive reactions.
Belief in the mythological structure and the narcissistic gain from holding those beliefs imperils the organization. The United States is in a period of decline economically. We have lost industry after industry to competition abroad, notably Japan and West Germany. General Motors is sitting in the unenviable position of having lost market share within that industry equivalent to the Chrysler Corporation, and this share will not easily be regained. Translate that into jobs lost and economic security dislocations and you have pretty much a picture of what is going on in America today. The problem stems from the fact that as these large organizations grow and persist they develop these mythological structures which the leadership believes in and passes on and acculturates new groups in, generation after generation. It prevents people from looking at reality. They do not understand the nature of the world they are living in and the changes they are undergoing. They are therefore ill prepared to lead in the direction of change.
The leadership in these organizations has to understand why myths arise and why it's important that people believe in them. But the leadership must never take them seriously and never get sucked into it themselves. They must remain highly objective and have the capacity to look at the world as it is.
 
OF READERS, WRITERS AND TEXTS
AS soon as literary critics discovered psychoanalysis, they began scrutinizing the motives of both authors and characters through the Freudian lens.
As Murray M. Schwartz, dean of arts and humanities at the University of Massachusetts, observed, some interpreters went overboard. But as the field matured, he said, Freud's ideas of unconscious forces helped illuminate the mysterious relationship between authors and readers and the way that texts can take on lives of their own.
 
In the 60's, when there was an enormous flowering of psychoanalytic thinking in the humanities, psychoanalysis was a form of appropriating literature or historical material or even personal lives, the lives of poets and writers. It was a way of possessing things. It was a way of claiming them for psychoanalysis. People went to town with psychoanalytic ideas in all kinds of literary texts. A lot of good work came from this exuberance but also a lot of psychoanalytic overkill.
In the 70's and into the 80's psychoanalysis in the humanities emerges as both an agent and an object of critical inquiry. There is also an enormous amount of writing about psychoanalysis in the humanities, and psychoanalysis becomes part of a revolution in theoretical and critical thinking. The focus is on narrative, on dialogue, on the implication of the interpreter on the interpretive process. [The critic] Geoffrey Hartman summarized these developments when he said psychoanalytic criticism is getting harder and harder to do yet more and more people are doing it.
These developments participate in the general rethinking about the nature and functions of discourse. We see increased emphasis on the relations between fact and fiction, between events and the languages we invent and use to represent events and experiences.

HEADLINE: Suppose the Town Was Promoting Insurrection

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anthony Lewis, in a column about Israel's handling of a tax strike in the West Bank Arab town of Beit Sahour (''It Can Happen There,'' Oct. 29), writes: ''Suppose the people of some small American town decided to protest Federal Government policy by withholding their taxes. The Government responded by sending in the Army. . . . Unthinkable? Of course it is, in this country. But it is happening in another: . . . Israel.''
If Beit Sahour were an Israeli town that did not pay its taxes merely to protest government policy, Mr. Lewis's comparison would have been apt. However, that is not the case. 
To give the proper context, he should have written: Suppose we were still in the pre-glasnost period and Mexico had become Communist, demanding that the United States return territories taken from it in the wake of the Mexican War: Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, Nevada and California.
Suppose also a majority of former Mexicans lived in some of these areas, who felt they were discriminated against, wished to secede from the Union and started a widespread insurrection that was supported and financed by Mexico and other Communist states in Latin America. The insurrectionists obstructed communications and access to their areas of residence and attacked civilians, the police and the National Guard with stones and Molotov cocktails; and to bring about a breakdown in governmental activity, they killed former Mexicans holding jobs with the state or Federal Governments and then began to withhold their taxes.
If Mr. Lewis had given the Beit Sahour affair this context, it would have been a constructive contribution toward understanding Israel's position. A Communist Mexico might not in itself be a threat to America, but its proximity and its Communist connections would be factors the United States could not allow itself to ignore in trying to preserve its economic and political system. To surrender former Mexican territories as a result of the insurrection would unquestionably make America more vulnerable. Thus, to send in the National Guard to put down a tax strike in Texas might not have been ''unthinkable.''
The Arab states may not be in a position to defeat Israel on the battlefield today, but their proximity, their overall military potential and the instability of their regimes are factors that Israel cannot allow itself to ignore in deciding whether or not to cede territory.
This is not to say that Israel should disregard the need for peace or not cede territory. On the contrary, there is room to believe that Israel can cede some territory and maintain self-defense capability. Such territory might be surrendered as a calculated risk in the interest of peace. Considering the high stakes, however, one should ponder the matter before condemning those Israelis who, for reasons of security, are wary of making such concessions.
And as the Arab insurrection in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip is not over rights but over territory, yielding to it can only weaken Israel's ultimate ability to achieve secure borders through negotiation. Thus to send the army into Beit Sahour to put down a tax strike as part of an insurrection is not the same as sending the army into ''some small American town'' that protested Government policy.
Reported brutalities in Beit Sahour that Mr. Lewis refers to are not to be condoned. To focus on such incidents, however, is to give the erroneous impression that Israel has become a brutal country. Israeli Army briefings stipulate restraint. The overwhelming majority of Israeli soldiers who confront the insurrectionists behave with self-control. The Israeli press regularly reports excesses, and both the army and the civil courts prosecute offenders.
 
CLINTON BAILEY
 Jerusalem, Nov. 16, 1989

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: East Europe Mostly Likes Our Life Style

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Most of the Russians and Poles I met on assignment in their countries spoke of drugs, street crime and a general breakdown of order in the West. We can attribute some of that ''knowledge'' to negative news coverage by their controlled news media, but word of mouth, via American relatives, was likely to be their main source of information. So-called Western freedom was more or less envied as a material and social life style, not usually spoken of as a political one.
Aeroflot, the Russian airline, has a ''first class'' section, and I found Soviet citizens to be extremely materialistic in their constant press to get foreign currency for access to the quality and status of foreign goods in the shops. Western products are highly prized as black market ''produce,'' but I didn't hear any talk about queueing up to register as Republicans or Democrats; that recurring theme is a bit of wishful thinking on our part. I remember that thought process from when I had a firsthand view of the two Germanys.
I was stationed in West Germany as an American serviceman at the birth of the Berlin Wall. I didn't get the feeling then that our system was envied on either side of Checkpoint Charlie. These people wanted Walkman, Izod, pop music and discos; they had little access to those before the wall came down.
Right now, they are Christmas kids with their noses pressed to the chilled windows of Freedoms R Us; let's wait and see if they go for the rest of the package.
 
BILL LEE
 New York, Nov. 14, 1989
 
The writer is an editor for Omni.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
How to Beat Prepay Charge For Air Tickets

 BODY:
More and more airlines are assessing penalties, known as prepay charges, for travelers who book an advance-purchase seat through a travel agent but get the ticket issued at the airport. There is a way to get around the penalty, which is usually about $25, but it requires a bit of planning.
Travelers who use out-of-town travel agents may find that because the agent is hundreds of miles away, the agent may not be able to get the ticket to the customer's home or office before the day of departure.
The prepay charge is not imposed by airlines when the customer books a flight directly with the airline by phone, using a credit card, and then picks up the ticket at the airport. But many travelers prefer agents - to save time, perhaps, or in hopes of getting a good deal - and then go to the airport to get the ticket. When this happens the airlines' view is that the transaction has not been completed because while the reservation has been made and payment accepted, the ticket has not been issued. The travel agent sends an electronic message called a prepaid ticket advice (P.T.A.), to the airline. To cover the cost of bookkeeping and writing a ticket, the airlines say, a prepay charge - usually $25 for a domestic flight and $30 on many foreign flights - is imposed. 
How to beat the pre-pay charge? Daniel T. Smith, a spokesman for the International Airline Passengers Association, a Dallas-based consumer group, recommends having the travel agent ship the ticket by overnight mail. Many agents have deals with couriers like Federal Express to deliver tickets for under $10. He also recommends trying to negotiate with the travel agent to absorb the cost of prepay charges. ''Particularly if you are a business, if your volume is high enough, anything is negotiable,'' Mr. Smith said.
 
Nonstop Flights To the Caymans
 Vacationers bound for the Cayman Islands in the Caribbean will be able to fly nonstop from New York for the first time starting Dec. 15. Cayman Airways, the British colony's national carrier, will fly its new Boeing 737-400's from Kennedy International Airport in New York every Friday, Saturday and Sunday at 9 A.M., arriving at Grand Cayman at 12:45 P.M. Flights to New York from Grand Cayman will be at 8:30 P.M. on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, arriving at 12:15 A.M.
In previous winters, travelers from New York had to connect with Cayman Airways, Eastern or Northwest in Miami to get to the islands.
The 14-day economy excursion fare from New York is $399 round trip. The Boeing 737-400 carries 158 passengers.
 
Informal Sales Of London Art
 Visitors to London have a new opportunity to shop for contemporary art. The work of young artists is available at what the organizers describe as reasonable prices on an irregular monthly schedule at St. Peter's Church Hall, 59A Portobello Road, London (three minutes from the Notting Hill Gate Underground station). Two organizations working together stage either cash-and-carry exhibitions of emerging artists' work (about 200 exhibits) at prices from about $80 to $320 (calculating 1 at $1.60) or art auctions at which both established and emerging artists can put their work on the block for a $16 fee. Ten percent of the proceeds from cash-and-carry sales is donated to the environmental charity ARK.
The cash-and-carry exhibits are organized by Art Events, Post Office Box 1958, Notting Hill, London W11 3PF (937 5897) and the art auctions by Griffin Contemporary Art Auctions, Post Office Box 1966, London W11 2EL (243 0192). It is worth checking on the events in advance since dates are irregular and extra shows are often organized. Starting in 1990, the aim is to have a show on the last Saturday of each month. Meanwhile, the next two are a cash-and-carry sale Dec. 2 and an auction Jan. 27. The organizers do not arrange shipping but will supply the phone number for a transport service.
 
Lighting Up At Christmas Worldwide
 Germany is the home of the Christmas tree, and every city and village in East and West Germany has one up on its central square in time for Advent. This year Advent begins Dec. 3, and the tradition may have a new poignancy because of the opening of the Berlin wall.
In Munich's Marienplatz the tree is to be decorated with electric candles and tinsel in front of the Town Hall on Friday.
In Frankfurt, the tree on the Romerberg, as the town hall is called, was installed a couple of weeks ago, but the lighting ceremony takes place on Friday, opening day of the Christmas Market.
There are four trees in Nuremberg, two on each side of the Frauen Church, the central point of the Christkindlmarkt. Their electric candles will be lighted this week.
The tree in front of Vienna's town hall, the Rathaus, is traditionally donated by one of the provinces. This year's tree is 86 feet high and 25 years old and comes from Salzkammergut. Its decorations were switched on last month. In London, the tree on Trafalgar Square will be illuminated Dec. 7. Closer to home, at Rockefeller Plaza in New York, a 70-foot Norwegian spruce, will shine with 18,000 lights beginning Dec. 4. Ceremonies start at 6 P.M. with caroling, dancing and ice skating. In Colonial Williamsburg, Va., the tree, another Norwegian spruce, won't be turned on until dusk on Dec. 24.
A lighting ceremony in Minneapolis was staged Thanksgiving Day after a parade with Dorothy Hamill as grand marshal.
In Washington, President Bush will light a 35-foot blue spruce that is permanently planted in the Elipse, the park behind the White House, at 5:50 P.M. on Dec. 14. At the same time, 50 state trees surrounding the national Christmas tree will be turned on by the President from a switch in the White House. Ceremonies begin with Willard Scott as emcee-Santa Claus. The theme: ''Families.'' Seating is on a first-come basis.
There are at least two tree lightings in Seattle. One was at Westlake Center on Nov. 24; the other is on Dec. 6 when lights are switched on around the tree at 1001 Fourth Avenue Plaza.
In Denver, the neoclassical City and County Building becomes a giant ''tree'' on Friday. About 300,000 watts will be used to illuminate multicolored floodlights lighting up the four-story building, which has a clock tower that is another four stories high.

HEADLINE: Czechoslovakia's Opulent Spas

BYLINE: By JOANNE FURIO; Joanne Furio is a writer who lives in Brooklyn.

 BODY:
For centuries, Carlsbad and Marienbad - the German names for Czechoslovakia's most famous spa towns, Karlovy Vary and Marianske Lazne - drew Europe's most prominent political and artistic figures.
Both were blessed with a wealth of mineral springs, which lured patients seeking cures as well as the healthy, and both evolved into luxurious retreats and important cultural and economic centers.
Situated in the northern, Bohemia, region, both towns are closer to today's East and West Germany than to the capital city of Prague, and throughout history have attracted a large German-speaking clientele.
Elaborate spa buildings and colonnades sprung up to surround the privileged visitor with an atmosphere of architectural splendor. Merchants set up fancy shops, hotels and restaurants. And, to keep such a group entertained, music and theater festivals were established, attracting some of the most respected performers. 
Karlovy Vary and Marianske Lazne no longer attract royalty or the wealthy, but average citizens of the Eastern Bloc.
Recognizing the towns' importance as tourist centers, the government has made an effort to maintain their historic significance by restoring many of the rich 18th- and 19th-century buildings. As a result, both towns offer some of the most luxurious accommodations for the money in Czechoslovakia. And, trying to keep up their cultural traditions, the spa towns continue to offer some of the country's best classical music performers, as well as those from other Eastern Bloc countries.
The only things a Westerner might miss on visits to these towns are foreign newspapers and magazines and a varied selection of vegetables. Although both towns have fine restaurants with an abundance of meat-based dishes, a lettuce salad is somewhat of a luxury. How the recent tumult in Eastern Europe will affect Western tourism is, at this point, anybody's guess.
Although completely different in scale and atmosphere, Karlovy Vary and Marianske Lazne have much in common.
Each is set in a valley, framed by hills of pines with a complex of walking trails and views, and an abundance of natural springs, which are thermal in Karlovy Vary.
Today, almost 90 percent of the visitors are from the Eastern Bloc, mostly from Czechoslovakia itself, whose numerous trade unions have provided its members with their own facilities, as well as East Germany and the Soviet Union. Only a handful come from England and the United States, although that, like so much else in Eastern Europe, may change.
Impressive colonnades built during the 18th or 19th centuries adorn both town centers, where visitors line up at fountains to fill porcelain mugs with the mineral waters, which they sip almost hypnotically while strolling or basking in the sun.
The mugs, designed with unusual hollow handles that act as straws, are purchased by patients before they begin their therapies.
Although the middle-aged people who visit these towns do so for curative purposes, staying an average of three weeks at the sanitariums, or spa houses, the towns do welcome those who come only as tourists, usually staying for two or three days, as well as a large number of day-trippers, who visit the towns on excursions from Prague.
But since many do come for a medical pilgrimage, the spas offer a feeling of quiet solemnity, even if their sidewalks are lined with pedestrians. For those who long for the fast-paced action of a city, these towns are not for them.
Karlovy Vary is the largest spa in the country - almost a city. (On a pocket-sized map printed by the country's official tourist office, Cedok, Marianske Lazne is not even delineated.) Karlovy Vary is said to have been discovered by Emperor Charles IV, who, in 1347, stumbled into the waters while on a hunting expedition. Later, the town achieved even greater notoriety by attracting such prominent personalities as Peter the Great, the Austrian Emperor Josef II, Beethoven, Chopin, Paganini, Richard Wagner, Freud, Tolstoy, Goethe and Gogol.
Surrounded by steep slopes that make the already majestic 19th-century buildings seem even more imposing, the spa district of Karlovy Vary conveys a comforting sense of envelopment that separates it from the gloomy urban areas surrounding it.
Karlovy Vary is centered on the River Tepla, which meanders through the town. Shops selling leather, crystal, the country's renowned folk ceramics and spa porcelain mugs line the streets on both sides of the river.
The river itself is a bit of a disappointment when not at its height. At times it resembles a stagnant pool shallow enough to allow ducks to bathe standing up, while on cool days its thermal waters at least provide an impressive display of evaporating steam.
Besides its high temperatures, ranging from 86 to 162 degrees, the waters of Karlovy Vary are known for their high levels of sulfate of soda and carbonate of soda. Because of these properties, the spas specialize in treating disorders of the gastrointestinal tract and liver.
Karlovy Vary appears to have attracted more American, West German and Arab tourists than Marianske Lazne, perhaps because it is larger, better known and older.
From the outside, those who don't stay in the spa houses might assume that they are elegant old hotels, well-maintained in their original Beaux Arts or Greek Revival style. Most of their interiors reflect such old-time opulence, as well as a kind of squeaky-clean, hospital atmosphere. This is where the doctors have their offices to diagnose and prescribe the appropriate water dosages for the patients (up to one liter a day), as well as regimens that include exercise, bathing in the waters and special diets.
Tourists can enjoy some of the perks offered by the spa houses, without making a three-week commitment. The 19th-century Grand Hotel Moskva, the most elegant complex in town, offers a sauna, massage, tanning room and small work-out room for those who seek some pampering.
Even if one doesn't seek such indulgences, the Grand Hotel is worth a visit. Completed in 1893, the hotel boasts several restaurants, stained-glass ceilings and other turn-of-the-century finery, as well as a white-and-gold rococo concert hall, where both Dvorak and Smetana, native sons, played.
Another important landmark is the casino, built in the late 19th century by the renowned Austrian design team of Helmer and Feller. Renovated in June 1988, the building houses spa facilities as well as a small casino operated by an Austrian firm.
The casino, portrayed in advertisements as a Czech Monte Carlo, is usually almost empty, with only a few West German and Arab visitors playing at the three blackjack and roulette tables on a Friday night. But it is worth seeing its elaborate period architec-ture and furnishings, including a spectacular marble staircase, 100-foot-high glass-paneled ceiling, murals depicting ancient Greeks at play and golden wood-paneled walls.
While the casino captures the feeling of Karlovy Vary past, the mood of the town today is best witnessed at its colonnades.
The Greek revival Colonnade of Czechoslovak-Soviet Friendship, conspicuously renamed after the Russian invasion of 1968, is the most traditional, allowing patrons to stroll in the shadow of Corinthian columns and potted palms or sit on white wrought-iron benches along a parklike promenade.
In contrast, the Colonnade Yuri Gagarin is a modern steel-and-glass structure with a glass-domed room containing the Vridlo spring, which shoots hot waters 50 feet into the air, and an enclosed promenade where patients line up to get their water from modern brass fountains.
Karlovy Vary is the site of an international film festival every other year, most recently last summer, which does include some lesser-known Western productions, though none that would be considered controversial, and has its own orchestra, which regularly performs works by Smetana and Dvorak in the elegant yet badly deteriorated 19th-century theater.
The town museum displays antique folk ceramics and old spa mugs, along with a roster of its famous visitors. Not far is the Museum Karl Marx, which provides a lesson in propaganda for the uninitiated.
Also worth visiting is the sedate Dvorak Park, with its Victorian gazebo, and, on the outskirts of the city, the Russian Orthodox Church of the Chief Apostles Peter and Paul, the cathedral church of Russian Orthodoxy in Czechoslovakia, which was built in 1897 and has an impressive display of antique iconography.
The town's famous Becherova, a minty herb liqueur created by the German-born Jan Becher, is worth a taste.
Farther south and west of Karlovy Vary is Marianzke Lazne, a much cozier town whose amenities can easily be absorbed in a few days.
Its parks are integrated into the town center, thanks to early 19th-century planners. The main street, the Trida Obdoraru, is lined with the principal hotels and shops, pastel-colored Beaux-Arts buildings with impressive gargoyles and classical reliefs. Across the street is a stream and a series of winding parks that work their way, like the rest of the town, up toward the main square, named after Klement Gottwald, a former head of state.
On the square, whose center is a park and fountain, is the Kavkaz Spa, once the Hotel Weimer, where the spa's most famous visitor, King Edward VII, stayed during his many visits. Since the facility serves spa patients only, visitors can just glimpse the former King's favorite resort by walking into the marble lobby, framed by a double staircase and potted palms.
Edward was also responsible for one of the town's proudest assets, its 18-hole golf course, which was opened in 1905 by the king himself. Situated just outside town, the course is the largest in the country. Adjacent to the Kavkaz Spa is the museum, which has been connected to the former vacation residence of another noted visitor, Goethe. The rooms where the poet lived have been meticulously maintained, and the building is the only one in town that hasn't been renovated. Goethe memorabilia and some of his writings decorate the rooms, as does shiny wooden furniture inlaid in the style of the period. In the modern half of the museum, the town's famous drinking mugs and images of prominent doctors and visitors, including Czar Nicholas II, Ibsen, Kipling, Mark Twain and Thomas Edison are displayed. An audio-visual museum program is available in English.
Across from the museum is the 19th-century Ascension of Mary Catholic Church, somber on the outside, with an elaborate wood-and-marble altar trimmed in gold leaf inside.
Not far from Gottwald Square is the aquatic center of town for spa patients, the Gorki Colonnade, with an elaborate glass-paned archway and Corinthian columns. At one end of the colonnade is a plain modern fountain that plays classical music at intervals.
Like Karlovy Vary, Marianske Lazne has developed a healthy agenda of entertainment to keep patients occupied. There are two movie theaters, but even if they show Western films they are usually dubbed in Czech. Its well-preserved theater and casino are better bets, offering classical music programs performed by the town's own orchestra, visiting pop performers like the Czech singer Heidi, theater and dancing to native brass bands.
Marianske Lazne has 39 mineral springs, famous for their carbon dioxide content, as well as iron, magnesium and calcium. Drinking cures are used here in conjunction with carbon-monoxide gas injections, diet and exercise regimens, to treat urinary tract and respiratory problems.
The Polyclinic treats nonspa visitors, offering drinking cures, peat applications, massage and other therapies, after a medical consultation, ''Everything,'' according to the town's slogan, ''for the health of the working people.''
 
FINDING THE WAY TO THE SPA TOWNS
 
KARLOVY VAR
 The town is about 74 miles from Prague, a one-and-a-half-hour drive. Car rental is about $100 a day. Take highway 6 west.
A two-and-a-half-hour bus ride, about $4, is preferable to the train, which, at $4.50, takes four-and-a-half hours. Plane service is also available from Prague International Airport for $12.
 
Sights
The Casino, in the Spa House (1 Vysina Imperial; 6 P.M. to 1 A.M.).
 Museum of Karlovy Vary (Dukelskych Hrdinu; Wednesday to Sunday 9 A.M. to noon and 2 to 5 P.M.). Admission 40 cents.
 Museum Karl Marx (Dukelskych Hrdinu; daily from 9 A.M. to noon). Free.
 Church of the Chief Apostles Peter and Paul (26 Petra Velikehom; April to September 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.). Free.
 
MARIANSKE LAZNE
 A 135-mile trip from Prague, reachable by following the route to Karlovy Vary, then heading south to highway 20, which turns into 24 and leads directly into the town.
Both the train and the bus cost the same ($4.50) and take the same amount of time, about three hours. Trolleys or taxis must be taken to the center of town, at the cost of about 10 cents for the former and about 25 cents for the latter, after telephoning from the station, a difficulty for those who don't speak Czech or German.
 
Sights
Museum Marianske Lazne (Gottwald Square; daily 9 A.M. to noon and 2 to 5 P.M.). Admission 40 cents.
 Casino (between Trida Rude Armady and Dusikova; gambling from 6 P.M. to 1 A.M.).
Theater Marianske Lazne (Trebizskeho; evening and weekend performances).
 
 Dining
 Most of the hotels have their own restaurants. Neither spa town has many independent restaurants.
 Foreign wines are more than double the price of fine wines from the southern, Slovak republic. Prices range from $10 to $25 for dinner for two with Slovak wine.

HEADLINE: PITTSBURGH CLEANS UP ITS ACT

BYLINE: By Vince Rause; Vince Rause is a writer living in Philadelphia.

 BODY:
BILL JOHNSON KILLS THE ENGINE OF HIS RUBYRED Mercury Astro and lets the sleek fiberglass bass boat drift along the steep northern shore of the Monongahela River, into the heart of Pittsburgh.
A stone's throw from the river's edge, morning rush-hour roars along on the Penn Lincoln Highway. A few hundred feet above Johnson's head, traffic rumbles on the deck of the Liberty Bridge. The clamor drifts down to the river: random car horns, the guttural downshift of an 18-wheeler, the pneumatic hiss from the brakes of a city bus.
Ignoring these urban distractions, Johnson draws a graphite casting rod from a locker in the boat's hull, baits his line and casts into the still water at the base of the bridge's massive pylons. In moments, the line goes taut, and Johnson jerks the rod to set the hook. Suddenly, a fat, gleaming bass explodes into view, sending up sprays of silver sparks as it tail-walks wildly across the water. 
With the shining towers of the city's corporate center rising spectacularly behind him, Johnson works his catch to the boat. ''That's a 12-, 13-inch largemouth!'' he cries, as he cuts the line and sets the big fish free. ''You think bass, you think Lake Okeechobee, Florida, or something. But here I am catching a largemouth in downtown Pittsburgh! Under the Liberty Bridge!''
It's a bittersweet moment. For years, Johnson worked in the steel mills that made Pittsburgh an industrial powerhouse and turned its three rivers - the Monongahela, Allegheny and Ohio - into running sewers. Now, he claims, he is the first licensed fishing guide on the river. The rebirth of the Monongahela and Johnson's unlikely occupation make a striking metaphor for the surprising changes this city has seen over the last decade.
IN THE LATE 70'S AND EARLY 80'S, THE STEEL INDUSTRY, Pittsburgh's economic foundation for more than a century, virtually disappeared, crippled by foreign competition and dwindling demand. More than 90,000 jobs were lost, most of them in heavy manufacturing. Regional unemployment soared to more than 14 percent, and in surrounding steel towns like Homestead, Braddock and Duquesne, nearly one of every two workers was jobless. Economic collapse seemed imminent.
But the collapse never came. Instead, in a swift and dramatic economic restructuring, the city managed to sidestep catastrophe. Today, Pittsburgh has a robust, diversified economy, with heavy industry playing only a small role, and an unemployment rate that has dipped to 5 percent - its lowest level since the peak employment years of the 70's.
At the same time, it has sustained a quality of life that gained national recognition in 1985 when Rand McNally's ''Places Rated Almanac'' named it ''America's Most Liveable City.'' (In this year's almanac, Pittsburgh slipped to third place.) None of this has come without a price. The once-thriving mill towns along the Monongahela have essentially been written off. The city's population has dropped by more than 30 percent, as many of the unemployed packed up and looked for opportunity elsewhere. The ex-steelworkers who have remained search in vain for jobs in the new Pittsburgh that offer anything like their old salaries. And for Pittburgh's blacks, few of whom reaped the rich rewards of prosperity, opportunities are even more limited.
Still, while other aging manufacturing centers in the United States struggle simply to keep their heads above water, Pittsburgh, the spiritual capital of the rust belt, can lay claim to being America's most promising post-industrial experiment.
Despite its monolithic, heavy-industry background, Pittsburgh has always had a surprisingly complex civic persona. This is a town where ''Bowling for Dollars'' was a big hit, but it is also the home of the nation's first public television station. It's a place that takes its polka seriously, but that also has produced a dazzling parade of jazz talent, including Erroll Garner, Earl Hines, Art Blakey, George Benson and Stanley Turrentine. And as Pittsburgh gropes for the image to suit its sophisticated, forward-gazing aspirations, it has chosen as its new Mayor a homey, 71-year-old grandmother named Sophie Masloff. A past President of the City Council, Masloff stepped into the Mayor's office in 1988 when the beloved Richard S. Caliguiri died before finishing his term. She won the Democratic primary last May and ran unopposed for Mayor on Nov. 7.
Masloff is a streetwise, experienced politician, but since taking over the city's reins she has projected a decidedly homespun, low-tech, old-time Pittsburgh demeanor. She told a reporter from The Philadelphia Inquirer that she didn't understand his interest in her city, since she couldn't care less about his. When interviewed for this article, she asked, with genuine puzzlement, ''Why would The New York Times be interested in me?''
Masloff has had an especially hard time sorting out the rock-and-roll celebrities who pass through town. At a press conference welcoming the Springsteen tour, she referred to The Boss as ''Bruce Bedspring.'' She told reporters, ''I didn't mean to do it. But I've never been much of a rock fan.''
In a period of wrenching change, Masloff represented a vote for both the innovative policies of Caliguiri and for the working-class, ethnic town of neighborhoods that Pittsburgh has always been. She inherits from her predecessor a city that, by a number of significant criteria, is in splendid shape. Its public schools are nationally acclaimed. The University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie-Mellon University are highly respected centers of research and scholarship. The region's 55 hospitals make the city an internationally recognized medical center. Presbyterian-University Hospital, where Dr. Thomas E. Starzl pioneered liver transplant techniques, is now the busiest transplant center in the world.
Pittsburgh boasts a thriving cultural life, with highly regarded museums of art and natural history, a world-class symphony orchestra, strong opera and ballet companies, and a profusion of smaller galleries and performing-arts companies.
Recent crime and housing statistics show that Pittsburgh may be by far the safest, most affordable city in the nation. According to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Pittsburgh's crime rate is less than half the national average for large cities. Violent crime is especially low: in 1988, only 24 murders were reported in the city; all but one were solved.
Meanwhile, a recent survey by an investors' advisory service in California found that Pittburgh's median housing price - $63,700 - was the lowest of the 25 metropolitan areas studied. More significantly, by comparing costs to income, the survey found that the city ranked second in its residents' ability to afford a home.
Perhaps most surprising to visitors is the fact that the Pittsburgh of today is clean and attractive. Cleared of industrial blight, the dramatic beauty of its natural setting - dominated by converging rivers, wooded ridges and deep hollows - has reasserted itself. One Midwestern columnist wrote that ''the waterways, the mountains, the trees, reminded me of a cross between Venice and San Francisco.'' That comment may have widened eyes, even in Pittsburgh, but it was seconded when Brendan Gill told readers of The New Yorker, ''If Pittsburgh were situated somewhere in the heart of Europe, tourists would eagerly journey hundreds of miles out of their way to visit it.''
The appeal runs deeper than scenery. Nestled in the rugged rise and fall of the local terrain are more than 80 distinct communities, each an independent village in spirit, and most united by strong ethnic ties. Naturally sequestered by rivers and ravines, these communities have retained the character of the immigrant groups that first settled here generations ago: Eastern Europeans on the South Side, Italians in Bloomfield, Poles on Polish Hill, Germans in Mount Troy and Mount Oliver, Jews in Squirrel Hill.
Neighborhood allegiances are powerful and people stay put; it's nothing remarkable to find several generations of the same family living only a few doors apart. ''There's a sense of rootedness here,'' says Morton Coleman, a professor of social work at the University of Pittsburgh.
''Pittsburgh works because we cooperate,'' says Mayor Masloff. ''The neighborhoods, the government, the universities, the corporations. I can call up the president of PPG or USX - these vast financial empires - and say, 'Look, this is what I want to do. What do you think? Let's do this.' We work together, and it gets done.''
ANYWHERE ELSE, Mayor Masloff's comments would be dismissed as Chamber of Commerce boosterism. But Pittsburgh can point to an idiosyncratic tradition of cooperation between government and industry that has physically and psychologically shaped the city for nearly two generations.
The original and most powerful example of this dates to the 1940's, when the city faced an environmental crisis even more threatening than the economic collapse of the 70's and 80's.
Thanks to the steel industry, Pittsburgh was, for much of its history, a foul and brutal place. Forests of smokestacks bristled along the rivers, towering over steaming slag heaps and grim workers' shanties. The rivers were flood-prone industrial sewers, the air stank of sulfur, and a billowing canopy of smog belched from the mills, blanketing the city so thickly that street lamps and headlights were sometimes forced on by early afternoon.
Over the years, distinguished visitors were horrified by what they saw. In the 1920's, H.L. Mencken called Pittsburgh ''a scene so . . . intolerably bleak and forlorn that it reduced the whole aspiration of man to a macabre and depressing joke.'' In the 1940's, Frank Lloyd Wright, asked by city fathers how he would improve the place, snapped, ''Abandon it.''
But Pittsburgh wasn't abandoned. Instead, in the years following World War II, the city's enormously wealthy Republican industrialists struck an alliance with its powerful New Deal Democratic machine, and launched the monumental effort that would raze and rebuild Pittsburgh. A privately funded planning commission made up of the city's top corportate leadership produced sweeping proposals for the city's rebirth. Local government turned those proposals into public policy, and the $500 million Pittsburgh renaissance began.
Tough smoke-control ordinances cleared the skies. A system of locks and dams tamed the flood-prone rivers. And a sweeping building campaign, directed by the nation's first urban redevelopment authority, leveled acre after acre of industrial slums and erected in their place a new city of grassy parks, modern towers, tree- lined boulevards and landscaped plazas.
The renaissance set the pattern for problem-solving in Pittsburgh and imparted a tough, defiant optimism in the face of adversity. ''It instilled a spirit in the people here of, 'If we can do that, we can do anything,' '' says Robert B. Pease, who was a young civil engineer at the time. Today, Pease is president of the Allegheny Conference on Community Development, as the original planning commission has come to be known. Led by a board of corporate chief executives, the group meets monthly to orchestrate the resources of the corporate community and negotiate cooperation between business and government on issues affecting the region's economic and social development.
When the steel crisis hit in the late 1970's, Pittsburgh turned once again to this network of public-private alliances. By 1982, the Allegheny Conference had convened a commission of more than 200 government, business and community representatives to develop a strategy that would move the city away from its dependence on heavy manufacturing toward a more diversified economic base. A marketing agency was formed to attract foreign and out-of-state companies to the region; a seed-money fund was created to help new enterprises get off the ground, and an information program was designed to teach local businesses the arcane art of securing Federal contracts.
One of the most ambitious aims of the restructuring campaign was to capitalize on the presence of the University of Pittsburgh, a leader in biomedical technology (both the polio vaccine and synthetic insulin were developed at Pitt), and Carnegie-Mellon University, a groundbreaker in robotics and software engineering. Planners established a series of funding sources and support programs -notably the Ben Franklin Advanced Technology Center, the Pittsburgh High Technology Council and the Foundation for Applied Science and Technology - to encourage entrepreneurs to move new technologies out of the lab and into the marketplace.
On paper at least, the city's efforts seem to have borne fruit. Between 1975 and 1987, some 101,400 jobs were created, most in education, health care and research. Advanced technology is the region's fastest-growing field. More than 900 high-tech firms operate in the metropolitan area, employing more than 60,000 workers. And there are signs that the outside world is beginning to take Pittsburgh's high-tech community seriously. In 1984, the Department of Defense agreed to locate its $103 million Software Engineering Institute in the city. In 1986, a partnership of the University of Pittsburgh, Carnegie-Mellon University and Westinghouse Electric brought one of the world's most powerful supercomputers to the city and founded the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, one of five similar centers across the country funded by the National Science Foundation. Many expect the high-tech revolution to completely restructure the city's economy. The Pittsburgh High Technology Council estimates that by the year 2000, more than 120,000 western Pennsylvanians will work in high-tech industries, making Pittsburgh arguably one of the nation's largest research and development centers.
Not everyone buys this rosy scenario, however. As the University of Pittsburgh's Morton Coleman, for one, points out, ''We were the greatest steel producers in the world. Our advantages were unique: the rivers, the raw materials, the proximity to the marketplace. But we lost those advantages. What are our advantages now? What makes us different from Columbus or Cleveland or Cincinnati or our other regional competitors? I think there are still big questions here.''
David Houston, a professor of economics at the University of Pittsburgh, dismisses the city's high-tech ambitions as ''a pipe dream.''
''There's some question whether these newly created jobs pay anywhere near as well as the jobs we lost,'' he notes. ''You know, most of those new jobs are in health care, education and business services. In those fields, there are a lot of lousy jobs.''
Bernard Bauer, former director of economic development for the Duquesne Light utility company, and now its manager of special projects, has listened to both the critics and the boosters. He insists that the region's recovery is real, if not as spectacular as some would contend. He is especially encouraged by a new $500 million expansion project at the Pittsburgh airport, which is expected to create thousands of new jobs.
Yet the region's low unemployment rate is also a matter of debate. David Houston of the University of Pittsburgh suspects that it may be statistically meaningless. ''We have one of the highest outmigration rates in the country,'' he says. ''A lot of those people, we can assume, were unemployed workers looking for opportunity elsewhere. Naturally, if your unemployed people leave, the rates go down.'' Houston's comments touch on one of the city's most surprising trends: in the last 30 years, Pittsburgh's population has dropped from just over 600,000 to about 390,000. Many younger people left in search of jobs, leaving Pittsburgh with one of the oldest populations in the country.
''Allegheny County has a higher percentage of people over 65 than any county in the nation, except for Dade County, Florida,'' says Moe Coleman - a demographic peculiarity that may help explain the popularity of Sophie Masloff.
David Houston sees no paradox in the city's drastic population loss and its low crime rate, affordable housing and other social strengths. ''All of those things are in some sense the result of weak growth or weak demand,'' he says. ''It turns out to be a virtue to miss some of the growth that places like Houston experienced. It may be an irony of modern life that managing decline gracefully may be more important than shooting for all this growth.''
EVEN THE MOST OPTIMISTIC Pittsburghers would find it difficult to deny that, whatever its successes, the city doesn't work for everybody. ''Pittsburgh is not a healthy environment for blacks,'' says Harvey Adams Jr., president of the Pittsburgh branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ''We are being destroyed here. We are an endangered species.''
''The unemployment rate in black communities is catastrophic,'' says Byrd Brown, who recently became the first black to mount a serious campaign for Mayor of Pittsburgh. ''We have areas that have been devastated by crime and drugs and the city's neglect.'' Pittsburgh has one of the highest black infant-mortality rates in the country and blacks face one of the nation's highest mortage-rejection rates.
According to Brown, racial conflict isn't obvious in Pittsburgh, in part because the black community, which makes up about 25 percent of the population, is scattered across the city in small residential pockets. ''It's not outspoken,'' he says. ''It's a very subtle thing. But it's there. When I was campaigning, everywhere I went, people were very polite and gracious. I'd give a speech in a white area and sometimes I'd get more applause than the white candidates. And I did very well in approval polls; I think I even won a couple of them. But when you check the election results, you'll see that in one white district, out of about 14,000 votes, I got 241! That statistic alone shows that no matter how subtle we are about it, we're just as racially polarized as any other city.''
''Look, I love Pittsburgh'' Brown continues, ''but if you love something, you've got to realize when it's sick. The fact of the matter is, the black community is simply not sharing in the white community's success. The disparity is truly unacceptable. And it's got to change.''
IN THE ONCE-THRIVING mill towns - the places that first put the region on the map - both black and white residents face social and economic exclusion from the new prosperity. When the steel industry collapsed, no town was hit harder than Braddock, site of the Edgar Thompson plant, Andrew Carnegie's first steel mill. In its heyday, Braddock was a thriving community; the retail district along Braddock Avenue drew shoppers from all over the county.
''Now, it looks like a miniature version of the Bronx,'' says Tony Buba, strolling past the blasted storefronts, boarded windows and crumbling brick shells that once made up the town's thriving shopping strip. ''They start to tear a building down and they run out of money. These abandoned houses, burned-out houses, buildings falling down - it looks like the aftermath of World War III.''
Buba is a film maker whose gritty, low-budget documentaries about Braddock's decline are beginning to attract international attention. He is not a detached observer. His father worked in the Edgar Thompson plant for 43 years, and except for eight years away at school, Buba has lived in Braddock all his life. He lives now with his wife in a trim white house next door to the house he grew up in, where his father, mother and grandmother still live.
Buba climbs the steps to a grand sandstone building that was Andrew Carnegie's first public library. Inside, he meets Ray Henderson, a steelworker who lost his job after 19 years in the nearby Dusquesne mill and is pursuing a degree in human services. Henderson was making $40,000 a year when the mill closed in 1984. On the streets, he found he couldn't land a job for more than minimum wage.
''I saw it coming,'' he says, ''and I thought I was mentally prepared. But you leave the mill and your mental state changes. You realize that your whole life centered around one thing - steel mills. And you have to go through this change, and you don't know how to get your feet under you, or how to get your mind in gear to think in terms other than how to make steel.
''Some of the guys I know in the mill committed suicide, some are still drunks. It's out there, you know. They can't pull their lives together, mainly because they couldn't regear themselves to the kind of town Pittsburgh has changed into.''
A few miles downriver, Bob Anderson, another laid-off millworker, stands on Homestead's main drag watching the mill come down, to be sold as scrap. ''The shift change happened right here on this corner,'' says Anderson, who now runs a food bank and support center for unemployed workers. ''From 4 to 6 o'clock you couldn't get through this intersection. There'd be traffic jams for hours. Now, it's like a ghost town. This town is broken down.''
''There are two Pittsburghs,'' says Anderson. ''There's the upscale Pittsburgh of the renaissance downtown, and there's this Pittsburgh, the Pittsburgh most people don't see. I'm not bitter about all this promotion of the new corporate image - that's good, I think they should do that. But they shouldn't turn their backs on the people who built the town.''
ON THE MONONGAHELA, Bill Johnson guns the Astro's engine and veers upriver, racing past the old factories and mill towns lining the shore, past the leveled site of the old Jones & Laughlin blast furnace on Oakland, where a new high-tech industrial park will be constructed; past the South Side, where the ongoing demolition of the J.&L. rolling mill is revealing dramatic views of the new city skyline, and past the Homestead mill, where developers have already finished a waterslide amusement park.
Johnson lost his steelworking job in May 1989. Since then, he has made ends meet by doing custodial work at a church near his home and by playing in a local rock band. But fishing is his first love, and he hopes his sport-fishing business will develop into a full-time career. ''Sometimes I miss working in the mill,'' he says. ''I miss the people and the physical work. It's a shame. Steelmaking - that's what made Pittsburgh. A lot of guys thought it would last forever.''
''But now I'm on the river,'' he says. ''And this is where I really want to be.'' It's late morning now, but a light haze still drapes the bridges and the corporate towers. Johnson glances back at the new skyline. Then, jamming the throttle and leaning into the spray, he streaks through the old steel valley toward home.
