The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 26, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4058 words

HEADLINE: PRESSURING PERDUE

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder; Barnaby J. Feder is a business reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
HENRY SPIRA WORKS FROM home, a roomy rent-controlled apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side that looks like an office first, a cat playground second, and his residence only as an afterthought. One room is dominated by word-processing equipment. A second is filled with floor-to-ceiling shelves laden with files. And in the living room, where an immense worktable stretches along one wall, the furniture consists of an old couch and two chairs covered in Naugahyde (leather is not an option here). Pictures of Siamese cats hang over the fireplace and a cat jungle gym dominates the hall. From this Spartan dwelling Spira (pronounced SPEE-ra) has run a major command post in this country's rapidly growing animal-rights movement. The burly 62- year-old ex-seaman and former high school teacher says he first became interested in animal rights in the early 1970's, after a girlfriend left him with her cat: ''I began to wonder about the appropriateness of cuddling one animal while sticking a knife and fork into another,'' recalls Spira, who since then has always had one or two cats in his house. 
At the moment, though, chickens are on Henry Spira's mind. After four years of gathering material from animal-rights activists, government agencies and newspaper clippings, he has charged Frank Perdue, the nation's most famous chicken farmer, with grossly misrepresenting the conditions under which Perdue chickens are raised and slaughtered. In a grisly full-page ad in The New York Times, Spira has challenged Perdue's claims that his chickens grow up in ''chicken heaven.'' Rather, the ad describes, among other things, poultry sheds so overcrowded that they encourage cannibalism, disease and mass hysteria; it cites the de-beaking of young chicks with a ''hot knife,'' and working conditions for humans so stressful that they force ''about 60 percent of workers to go to the nurse for pain killers and to have their hands bandaged.''
Perdue Farms, through a public relations concern, described the attack as ''vague and totally groundless.'' It said Perdue spends millions of dollars on research to minimize stress and disease in poultry and improve its chickens' housing, diet and environment. Perdue intends to ignore Spira's call for reforms.
Nonetheless, Spira is pushing ahead, scheduling meetings with other animal-rights activists in an effort to ignite a consumer boycott and working on having his newspaper ad run in other papers across the country. The campaign is, in his eyes, a bid to focus broader attention on the treatment of all farm animals. Perdue was picked as the first target, Spira says, because ''he linked his image to the idea that his chickens are well treated.'' Any reformer, Spira says, must also be an opportunist. Indeed, he acknowledges that conditions are not necessarily worse on Perdue farms than on other chicken farms in the country. ''Later, we will approach other poultry producers to see if they want to cooperate,'' Spira suggests. ''In return for a quiet life, they may want to be part of the solution.''
If a whiff of bravado can be detected in Spira's remarks, it is not surprising. In the last 10 years or so, crusaders for a wide range of causes involving the treatment of animals have successfully raised the consciousness of the American public, business and government, resulting in some dramatic reforms. Spira himself is generally credited with organizing a key victory for the animal-rights movement - a 1980 campaign attacking cosmetics companies for testing new products in the eyes of rabbits. It began with a full-page ad asking, ''How many rabbits does Revlon blind for beauty's sake?''
Since then, the animal-rights movement has grown and expanded its targets and its tactics. Hundreds of thousands of people are members of groups ranging from the armed and radical to the simply noisy. Meanwhile, business and government researchers scramble to develop new ways to test the safety of products, procedures and medicines without the use of animals.
Spira's role in these changes is the subject of frequent debate in the animal-rights movement, which has become riddled with tactical disputes and personality clashes as it has grown. Because he is best known as a moderate within the movement, where radical voices have become increasingly prominent, Spira, through the Perdue campaign, will be testing his influence and leadership within the fractious animal-rights movement.
DISCUSSION ABOUT animal rights began in the late 18th century during the debates about the rights of man. The first animal-welfare organization of note was the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which was founded in England 165 years ago. A number of animal-welfare societies later formed in the United States, including the well-organized American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, but the movement did not gather momentum until the publication of Peter Singer's ''Animal Liberation,'' in 1975, a reasoned plea for the humane treatment of animals that galvanized the animal-rights movement the way Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' published in 1962, drew activists to environmentalism.
Today, organizations regarded as the radical arm of the movement, such as People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the International Society for Animal Rights, and Trans-Species Unlimited, endorse pressure tactics ranging from demonstrations and boycotts to shareholder petitions at corporate meetings, and they produce slick, widely circulated publications. More shadowy fringe groups, such as the Animal Liberation Front, advocate attacks on laboratories and contend violence in pursuit of their goals is justified.
What the leadership of these more radical groups have in common is the desire to protect all animals from what they consider abuses by humans, and they want immediate action. These broad-based organizations may oppose a number of things simultaneously - the fur industry, circuses, hunting and animal testing - but tend to focus their resources at any one time where they feel they can make an impact. There are also hundreds of small organizations that may concentrate on single issues, such as the killing of dolphins or the U.S. Surgical Corporation's use of dogs to demonstrate surgical stapling techniques.
''On this issue, you have to be an extremist,'' says Steve Siegel, director of the New York office of Trans-Species, which led recent demonstrations that forced a researcher at the Cornell Medical Center to abandon a 14-year research project studying the impact of barbiturates on cats.
Though polls show that the vast majority of the public does not agree with Siegel, especially when it comes to using animals in medical research or forcing farmers to adopt practices that might drive up consumer prices, there is no doubt that the membership and wealth of the more extremist groups is surging. People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals alone has grown from 23,000 members in 1985 to more than 300,000. The group, based in Rockville, Md., now has an annual budget of over $6 million, and 60 full-time employees.
Spira, on the other hand, has operated on about $75,000 a year for the last two years. His major financial backers have been groups such as the Humane Society of the United States and the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals as well as wealthy individuals. Operating as a lone-wolf (he has only one employee who works on a regular, nearly full-time basis), Spira uses an ad hoc melange of doctors, medical researchers, toxicologists, advertising executives, and public relations experts. He has the advantage of flexibility over groups with large paid staffs and is freer to do things that seem useful but may not attract financial support. For instance, he spends large amounts of time quietly circulating news about alternatives to Government officials he hopes will eventually implement helpful policy changes. But the drawbacks of Spira's organizational approach are becoming apparent. He must rely on a loose-knit network of supporters, each with an individual agenda, to add weight to his cause.
The mushrooming growth of more aggressive animal-rights groups challenges the influence of more moderate organizations, such as the Humane Society of the United States and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, as well as Spira and Animal Rights International, the non-profit umbrella organization for his activities. These groups tend to focus on improving the treatment of animals but not to publicly campaign for changes, such as vegetarianism or a ban on hunting. In general, they avoid confrontational tactics such as demonstrations and boycotts.
''Most of today's activists are new people who do not even know who Spira is,'' says Siegel, of Trans-Species.
The more radical groups are not only seizing the initiative from Spira by virtue of greater resources and more visible activities, they are challenging those who see value in his tactics, which include working with companies to figure out ways to reduce the exploitation of animals in industry, willingness to compromise with companies and even to publicly applaud those half measures.
''Industry knows very well that Spira doesn't represent the animal-rights movement but they try to pretend that he does,'' said Helen Jones, president of the International Society for Animal Rights, which is based in Clarks Summit, Pa. ''He's really part of the old humane movement. We say no animals in labs. They say give them bigger cages.''
Ingrid E. Newkirk, national director of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said: ''He is hobnobbing in the halls with our enemy. Six or seven years ago, we had a lot in common. Everything he did then was putting gravel down for other people to pave roads, which was crucial. But I think Henry was deceived by the industry response. Henry was unable to cut himself loose from the mire of having become an industry mediator. The search for alternatives is a quite transparent ploy to maintain the status quo.''
But Spira also has many defenders, many of whom credit him with using the strategy that has paid off most in the long struggle. ''Henry has been absolutely right to say that at the time he began, groups had been seeking total abolition for 100 years without saving one animal,'' says Peter Singer. ''Through his work, there are millions of animals that have escaped acute pain and suffering because of the work already done on alternatives,'' he adds, referring to ways to test products without killing or maiming animals.
Frederick Davis, former president of the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, one of Spira's biggest financial backers, adds: ''There's no one like him who can talk with such credibility to either a toxicologist and or an activist. Henry's beyond knee-jerk emotionalism. He talks about parallel self-interest.''
Not that Spira's longterm goals are less revolutionary than those of the most radical animal-rights advocates. If he has his way, synthetics will one day replace leather and the fur industry will disappear. Spira readily concedes he would like to see humans become vegetarian. ''My dream is that people will come to view eating an animal as cannibalism,'' he says.
But Spira has repeatedly criticized the handful of visionary animal-rights advocates who destroy laboratories, spray paint on fur coats and threaten violence to researchers and their families.
''The people who burned flags in the antiwar movement didn't help it,'' Spira explains. He has shown no qualms about infuriating many animal-rights groups by praising companies that continue to test products on animals as long as he believes they are working to develop alternatives.
''I don't see the usefulness of pushing yourself into a corner where you are going to generate the most resistance,'' he says. ''What's interesting is what can be done. People and institutions can only move so much at one time. The task is to move people far enough that they can see the next step.''
A NATIVE OF BELGIUM, Spira immigrated to the United States with his family via Germany, England and Panama during his childhood years. He held a variety of jobs before finishing his working career as a New York City high school English teacher. During that time he was almost constantly involved in various trade-union reform efforts and civil-rights movements. ''My contribution has been to take the strategies of the human-rights movements and apply them here,'' he says.
Spira's first effort to publicize animal abuse came in 1976. Researchers at New York's American Museum of Natural History were blinding, deafening and mutilating the sex organs of cats to see how it affected their sexual performance. Spira wrote an expose in a neighborhood paper, which, along with the efforts of other activists, brought the experiments to the attention of Congress and the public. Finally, the museum was forced to scrap the program. Spira next organized lobbying to break a legislative logjam that had for 27 years prevented repeal of a New York law allowing researchers to use dogs and cats from public pounds.
''Those were victories, but we realized they were largely symbolic,'' says Spira, who noted that they affected, at most, thousands of animals in a nation that annually kills as many as 70 million, ranging from rats to primates, in research and testing, according to Government estimates. Thus, his next goal became abolition of the Draize test, named after John H. Draize, a Food and Drug Administration pharmacologist who, in the early 1940's, developed a method for categorizing the dangers to the eye of various chemicals used during World War II. His test, later adapted by the F.D.A., has been used by cosmetics and household-products companies for the last 40 years to measure how badly a product will irritate the human eye. The test uses white rabbits because their eyes do not tear, making it impossible for them to blink away whatever has been inserted in them, no matter how corrosive or blinding it may be.
The Draize test seemed to be begging for an attack. To start with, the results are subjective. What one lab assistant records as ''major irritation'' might be regarded as minor by another. In addition, scientists with no connection to the animal-rights movement had said it should be possible to find alternatives relatively easily. Finally, Draize users were vulnerable to bad publicity because the gruesome tests were being conducted in order to introduce new products that scarcely seemed essential given the thousands of cosmetics, cleaners, and similar products already available.
Spira and his allies spent most of 1979 gathering information and in fruitless private talks with Revlon. Using the Freedom of Information Act, Spira received reams of data from the Government on the number of animals used by different companies and graphic film of the distressing results for rabbits. Then he and Mark Graham, an advertising executive, went to the late Pegeen Fitzgerald, president of the Millenium Guild, a philanthropic organization involved with animal welfare, and immediately won her financial support for full-page newspaper ads. The ads were followed by demonstrations, letter-writing campaigns and eventually an international boycott.
By December 1980, Revlon announced it would offer $250,000 a year for three years for research at Rockefeller University on alternatives to the Draize test; research that is now financed by Government grants. After that, it was a simple step to persuade Avon Products, the industry leader, and other cosmetics companies to also contribute to research. In 1981, their grants led to the founding of the Center for Alternatives to Animal Testing, at the Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health in Baltimore. By last year, the center had received more than $4 million from the cosmetics industry and other businesses. Spira followed up with continual calls to companies about their research and internal programs to reduce animal usage.
''Over the years, we started seeing his point of view, and he saw our problems,'' says Janice Teal, director of product and package safety at Avon.
As the campaign against the Draize test gathered steam, Spira turned to a far more destructive test, the Lethal Dose 50. Thoughout a wide range of industries, the LD50 has long been the standard measure of how toxic the chemicals in various products are. In tests, scores, and in some cases hundreds of animals - typically rats - are destroyed in labs doing research for manufacturers ranging from toy companies to pesticide makers, to find out what concentration of various substances would kill 50 percent of the animals exposed to them. ''The issue shouldn't be how popular the animal is,'' says Spira, regarding the killing of rats. ''Rodents have feeling. They try to avoid pain. That's the reason they are used in psychology experiments.''
Often the tests are performed to satisfy labeling requirements even though it is known in advance that the substances are so toxic that warnings will be needed.
Prodded by Spira's campaign, leading toxicologists became more vocal about their long-held doubts about the test. ''There's a vanishingly small number of people who believe the LD50 provides useful information,'' says Shayne C. Gad, the G. D. Searle & Company researcher who is chairman of the Society of Toxicology Animals in Research Committee. ''Our society has said that the traditional Draize and LD50 tests are unwarranted except in special situations.''
Nevertheless, both the LD50 and Draize battles continue because companies are reluctant to abandon the tests. Companies fear that they would be exposing themselves to charges of recklessness - and massive punitive damages - if they were to abandon such tests before Federal regulators unambiguously endorse a non-animal alternative.
Government agencies are being urged by a variety of industries and some members of Congress to change regulations that encourage, and in some cases require, tests many toxicologists say are frequently unnecessary. And research on alternatives is a hot topic in toxicology circles. Five different journals have sprung up in the last six years to report on such non-animal testing techniques as work with tissue cultures and computer simulation.
To be sure, progress is too slow for many animal-rights activists. ''Habits and fixed ways of doing things, such as treating animals in laboratories as mere tools or objects, die very slowly,'' says a position paper on animal testing from People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. Animal-rights activists say that continued over-reliance on animal testing actually harms humans also by absorbing tax dollars that could be better spent on preventive medicine and research using humans who have diseases.
Scientists respond that the protesters do not understand how long it takes to prove that new test methods are reliable.
''The animal-rights people have oversimplified some very complex issues,'' says Frankie Trull, president of the National Association for Biomedical Research, a Washington-based organization defending the use of some animal testing. ''They tend to overestimate how much you can do with computer models and tissue samples.''
Computers and automated lab equipment are continually lowering the costs of the alternatives and expanding the amount of information they offer to toxicologists. In-vitro tests, as test-tube procedures are called, can provide clues at the molecular level as to why something is happening. In-vivo, or animal tests, have often done no more than demonstrate that an animal is or is not affected by a certain level of chemical exposure or treatment.
In any event, scientists say, it is often essential to test on live animals because their complicated responses, such as the reaction of the immune system to a foreign substance, cannot be duplicated by any combination of test tube procedures.
''It's not likely that a single-cell animal in a petri dish is going to tell you much about learning disabilities.'' says Theodore Farber, a former health official of the Environmental Protection Administration. Nevertheless, even though tens of millions of animals are still maimed and killed annually in research and product testing, the animal-rights movement has come far enough that, in Spira's words, ''It's no longer macho to use animals.'' Indeed, groups like the Foundation for Biomedical Research say medical research is already being hurt by restrictions put on animal use and the growing number of young researchers who dislike working with animals. In toxicology circles, the ''three R's'' stand for: reducing the number of animals used in testing, refining tests so that they are less painful, and, where possible, replacing animals altogether with other tests.
Today, scores of companies are reporting progress in reducing their reliance on animal testing. Colgate-Palmolive, which has developed a test to screen new substances on egg membranes instead of animals, reported to the United States Department of Agriculture that it used just 244 animals last year (the annual reports do not count mice and rats). The Noxell Corporation announced late last year that it would test the potential for all new cosmetics to irritate eyes on a mouse-tissue culture in a test tube instead of using rabbits' eyes, leading to a string of announcements last spring and summer from other cosmetics companies that they too were halting or suspending most or all of their rabbit tests in favor of various test tube alternatives or a policy of using previously proved formulations.
SPIRA REMAINS INVOLVED in animal-testing issues. However, by starting the chicken campaign, he is adding his voice to those who want to shift the attention of animal-rights activists and the public to the 5 billion animals of the farm sector.
''The society makes a statement that all lives are not equal by eating animals,'' says Spira. ''It's absurd in that context to think that you can eliminate laboratory tests before doing anything about farm animals.''
Spira concedes, however, that for the immediate future the best he can hope for is more-humane killing.
''Clearly, animal rights and eating animals don't mesh,'' says Spira. ''However, while it's going on you want to at least reduce pain and suffering. Once people think about it, they realize that it's not a thing under the cellophane, it's a living being.''
In addition to the nascent Perdue campaign, for example, he is backing reforms on how veal calves are fed and shipped. He would also like to see importation of an Australian experiment in which livestock are sold at electronic auctions, on computer screens, like over-the-counter securities on Wall Street, instead of forcing the animals to undergo the stress of shipment to live auctions.
''An improvement in the lives of 1 percent of farm animals would do more to reduce animal suffering than eliminating all of the testing,'' says Spira. He sees the farm campaign as more difficult than the lab campaign not because of the greater number of animals, but because of the public's attitude.
''People who eat animals don't want to read about how they got to their plate,'' Spira says. ''It's hard to do things that make consumers uncomfortable.''
Or producers. In taking on farming, Spira and animal-rights activists are dealing with opponents who have a far greater economic stake in using animals than companies that test products on them. And most are dismissive. ''Henry's much better at understanding what is achievable and what is a pipedream than most, but when it comes to farm animal production and care, he's out of his bailiwick,'' says Steven Kopperud, executive director of the Animal Industry Foundation, an educational organization based in Arlington, Va., and financed by farmers and agricultural corporations. ''We can't afford, either economically or in terms of what is best for animals, to make changes based on what makes Henry sleep poorly.''
Spira is not likely to be dissuaded by such opposition, though. He is not looking for quick victories. When asked what his epitaph should be, he ponders and suggests, ''He pushed the peanut forward.''

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: MAMMALMANIA

BYLINE: By JUDITH ADLER HENNESSEE; Judith Adler Hennessee, who often writes about the press, is the co-author, with Michael Baden, of ''Unnatural Death: Confessions of a Medical Examiner.''

 BODY:

FREEING THE WHALES
How the Media Created the World's Greatest Non-Event.
By Tom Rose.
Illustrated. 318 pp. New York:
Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group.
$18.95.
 For two weeks in October 1988, the eyes of the world were riveted on Barrow, Alaska, a frozen outpost 320 miles above the Arctic Circle, where three gray whales were trapped in a hole in the ice. The whales had stayed behind the pack to gorge on crustaceans and hadn't noticed when it was time to leave. Normally they would have drowned, as hundreds of others do every year. Their plight was a perfectly ordinary one, a routine Darwinian cruelty, and it would have gone unremarked but for one thing: the presence of a satellite dish and a television studio. 
NBC showed the first pictures. America immediately fell in love with the whales, and after that they had to be saved. The rescue of the magnificent battered creatures, struggling to survive, became the lead story on the nightly news, displacing the Presidential election campaign. By the time the rescue was over, it had cost $5.75 million and almost toppled the Government of Iceland. Japan, a whale-eating nation, thought it was a hoot, and one of its networks dispatched Tom Rose, a television news reporter and executive, to report on this bizarre American obsession.
''Freeing the Whales'' is Mr. Rose's version of the story behind the rescue. It's a detailed, somewhat stiff account (though the author does let himself go once, in a pretend moon-walking scene on the ice). Some of it reads like a PBS nature special, and it suffers from a bloated middle. But Mr. Rose has a wonderful ability to make connections, and the story he tells is funny, full of ironies and about many more things than the whales. It's about the reporters who converged on Barrow in their designer parkas (a boorish lot, arrogant and superficial, Mr. Rose thinks), who had to cope with frozen jaws and outdoor plumbing in subzero weather. It's about the Inupiat Eskimos, a people whose culture was trampled by the march of civilization and who had declined into alcoholism and idleness. And it's about self-promotion, public relations and the way so much of life has become just a matter of image.
For journalists, Barrow was a hardship post. One hundred and fifty of them descended on a town with only 80 hotel rooms. The Top of the World Hotel, a no-star establishment that did not take credit cards, got $300 a night by auctioning off rooms that were already occupied. (The previous guests were simply thrown out into the street.) Less affluent reporters paid homeowners $100 for space on cold floors. Blankets and running water were extra. A lukewarm five-minute shower cost $50. Everyone smelled. Eskimos in the transportation business were just as quick as the hoteliers to understand the economics of scarcity. The going rate for a one-way sled ride to the whales (17 miles) was $200. First-class passengers covered themselves with polar bear blankets and down sleeping bags. Economy-class reporters made do with bloodstained caribou hides and occasionally shared a sled with a dead walrus.
THE rescue effort, orchestrated by Greenpeace, brought about a collaboration between natural enemies: environmentalists and the oil industry. The two icebreakers belonging to the Coast Guard were out of commission, and the oil companies saw a public relations opportunity. They had long been lobbying to drill in the middle of a national wildlife refuge and quickly realized the value of helping to rescue the whales. However, their rescue operation foundered.
Next came another unlikely group of saviors. Eskimos wielding chain saws and small de-icers (donated by a Minneapolis company) kept the ice from freezing over the whales. These were the very same Eskimos who would have ''harvested'' the grays had the reporters and television cameras not been there to see them. The last in a long line of improbable rescuers were the Russians (invited by Greenpeace). They were delighted to be asked. For decades the West had sneered at them for being backward barbarians. Now the United States, their dearest enemy and the technological wonder of the world, was helpless, stuck without a decent icebreaker to its name. The Russians had only to cut a path through the ice and they would be transformed into instant humanitarians. Never mind that Russia is one of the four largest whale-hunting nations in the world (Norway, Iceland and Japan are the other three).
The author is ambivalent about the meaning of all this. He calls the whales' entrapment ''the world's greatest non-event'' and he faults the news media for missing the real story - Barrow and its drunken Eskimos. But he also calls the rescue ''exhilarating,'' ''the story of a lifetime, television journalism at its apex.'' Which was it? It was the sort of thing television does very well - an emotional story that doesn't need to be analyzed.
The final irony is that the rescue may well have been for nothing, that the whales may never have made it to Mexico past the polar bears, killer whales and sharks waiting for them along the Pacific coast. The whales weren't tagged, so we'll never know. It's just as well.
 
LIKE A CAT STUCK IN A TREE
 In many ways, this was the story television was created to cover. . . . It captured the imagination of millions of people in a way network executives had rarely seen. Only the immediacy of television could convey the whales' almost hypnotic allure. Somewhat the same way that a cat stuck in a tree could mobilize an entire town, three gray whales stuck in Arctic ice mobilized an entire world.
Within hours of the first NBC broadcast on Thursday, October 13, six days after the whales were first discovered, the network's New York switchboard was jammed with hundreds of calls from ordinary citizens around the country. They wanted to know how they could help. Friday morning, Greenpeace's Washington office handled hundreds more from concerned members.
The people had spoken. What started out as an ideal story for NBC to use as a ''kicker,'' a lighthearted piece used to close a news broadcast, for a brief time became almost a national obsession. . . . Just three weeks before a Presidential election, and three days after they were first reported, the stranded whales became the top story on each network newscast. Among the estimated 30 million people who watched the whales gasp for air on Sunday's evening newscasts was President Ronald Reagan. He penned a note reminding himself to ask about the whales the following morning at his daily 9:00 AM briefing with senior White House staff members. Perhaps ''helpless'' was not the best word to describe the three whales. They clearly had done something that most other creatures could not do. Nine days after discovery, the whales compelled the most powerful man on earth to action.
 
From ''Freeing the Whales.''

GRAPHIC: Two of the whales trapped in the ice off Barrow, Alaska, last year. (Agence France-Presse/Chris Wilkins)

HEADLINE: 'I REMINDED EVERYBODY OF LYNDON'

BYLINE: By KAYE NORTHCOTT; Kaye Northcott covers politics for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram.

 BODY:

THE LONE STAR
The Life of John Connally.
By James Reston Jr.
Illustrated. 691 pp. New York:
An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $25.
 On Jan. 22, 1988, John Connally, at one time among the most powerful political figures in the country and an aspirant for America's highest office, watched as his possessions were auctioned off by a Houston gallery. Having amassed $93 million in debts, he declared personal bankruptcy in July 1987. Yet rather than hiding in shame, Mr. Connally made himself the plucky symbol for his state's economic depression. ''This is not the demise of Texas, nor is this the demise of John and Nellie Connally,'' the former Texas Governor told the assembled throng. ''There are lots of places in the world we haven't seen. Lots of things we haven't done.'' 
The places he had seen and the things he had done are the subject of James Reston Jr.'s major new biography, ''The Lone Star.'' Mr. Connally's friendships with two Presidents, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon; the assassin's attack he survived while riding with John F. Kennedy in Dallas in 1963; his late-in-life switch from Democrat to Republican; his 1975 trial for accepting a $10,000 bribe from the dairy lobby, together with his acquittal; his embarrassing race for the Presidential nomination in 1980; and his recent bankruptcy - all are here in greater detail than ever before.
This rich detailing compensates to a great extent for the biographer's lack of access to Mr. Connally. The notes indicate that Mr. Reston, the author of several works of fiction and nonfiction, had only two meetings with his subject, and was barred from examining the Connally papers (which were donated to the Johnson Library in 1987 with the understanding that they would be sealed for five years). Fortunately, though the Connally perspective is missing, there were other sources on ''Big John.'' The chapter on the bribery trial, for example, is told from the point of view of Mr. Connally's accuser, Jake Jacobsen, the lobbyist for the milk producers and himself presented as a pathetic portrait of sleaze.
It is not hard to see why Mr. Connally was unwilling to confide in Mr. Reston. Here is the author's description of him as he assumed the governorship of Texas in 1963: ''He stood in his elegant boots with the wealthy over the poor, the business executive over the working man, white over black and Hispanic, the glamorous over the commonplace. In short, he symbolized Texas royalty over Texas peasantry. He was a taunting, polarizing figure, engendering feelings of intense loyalty and utter contempt, even hate.''
Much of the information for the chapters on Mr. Connally's Texas years comes from his implacable Texas-liberal Democratic foes, who were frequently the victims of his take-no-prisoner politics. Mr. Reston recounts the oft-told tale of vote fraud in L.B.J.'s 1948 race for the United States Senate, but with a new wrinkle: the possibility that Mr. Connally, who was Johnson's campaign manager, may have personally forged some of the voter signatures that appeared alphabetically in the same green ink on the registration lists of Jim Wells County in south Texas. The highly questionable votes from south Texas gave Johnson one of the most crucial victories of his career.
The author also develops a provocative theory that Mr. Connally, rather than Kennedy, was the true target of the assassin Lee Harvey Oswald in 1963. After Oswald defected to the Soviet Union, his United States Marine Corps discharge was reclassified from honorable to ''undesirable.'' According to Mr. Reston, Oswald's service in the Marines was the one significant achievement of the disturbed loner's life.
At the time of the reclassification, Mr. Connally was Kennedy's Secretary of the Navy. Oswald wrote to the fellow Texan in January 1962, appealing to him to look into the matter. But Mr. Connally, who already had resigned his post, brushed him off and routinely forwarded Oswald's letter to his successor. Mr. Reston believes that at this juncture Oswald's hatred of the United States Government became focused on Mr. Connally.
Whatever the truth, Mr. Connally survived that day in Dallas to become a national presence. Presidents Johnson and Nixon both had the highest regard for his bold, sometimes ruthless political judgment. Johnson took his best friend's advice not to run for a second Presidential term in 1968. Mr. Reston says Mr. Nixon had almost a schoolboy crush on the handsome, suave Texan, the man who told him to burn the Watergate tapes: ''Have Ziegler assemble the White House press corps in the Rose Garden, pile up all the tapes, set a match to them, and let them film the bonfire.''
Mr. Reston grapples with the question of why Mr. Connally, surely an equal of the Presidents he advised, found so little favor outside his home state. Mr. Reston embraces Johnson's criticism that Mr. Connally, who shared L.B.J.'s humble rural roots, had no compassion. ''I should have spent more time with that boy,'' Johnson complained after Mr. Connally agreed to serve as Mr. Nixon's Secretary of the Treasury. ''His problem is he likes those oak-paneled rooms too much.'' For his part, Mr. Connally attributed his humiliating defeat in the 1980 race for the Presidential nomination ($11 million spent, one Republican convention delegate won) to the fact that ''I reminded everybody of Lyndon.''
Once out of politics, Mr. Connally joined the former Texas Lieut. Gov. Ben Barnes in a Texas real estate and development partnership, and together in the early 1980's, backed by major lenders, they set out to make some big money. But the boldness that was Mr. Connally's hallmark in politics did not translate well into the business arena, and the last glimpse in this biography is of the famous wheeler-dealer seeing his furniture and keepsakes disappear into the hands of the highest bidders. Even Mr. Reston is moved by Mr. Connally's performance during the auction.
''At this moment John Connally rose to a level of nobility he had never before achieved in his lifetime,'' Mr. Reston writes. ''His fellow Texans were taking heart from his handling of the situation.'' But a few pages later the author comes back down to earth, adding, ''On no one's mind were the hundreds who had gone under less elegantly as a result of Connally's business folly or high dreams and unbridled avarice.''

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Pro Tennis Spurred by the Diversity of Its Stars

BYLINE: By DIANA NYAD; Diana Nyad worked as a broadcasterfor USA Network during the 1989 United States Open.

 BODY:

WHEN Billie Jean King thrashed
Bobby Riggs in their Houston Astrodome circus match in September of 1973, grass-roots tennis in the United States got its biggest shot in the arm to date. By 1979, 32 million people a year took to the courts for their recreation and thus racquet sales and court construction were at an all-time high. Now those enterprises are waning as people forgo their racquets (the most recent figure is 18 million United States players) for the new rush onto public golf courses.
Tennis participation may have trailed off but, as the men's and women's professional seasons wind up this month in New York, the spectator surge toward the sport has expanded significantly. There are many reasons for the popularity of the professional game. 
You can virtually watch matches from your home every weekend of the year now, and cable channels offer as many as 12 hours of live action daily during the full two weeks of the four major events, the Grand Slams. ESPN brings us the early rounds of the Australian and French Opens. HBO takes us through highlights of Wimbledon's two weeks, and the USA Network allows us to follow the United States Open from the first day of the tournament.
In part, the increased television coverage stems from the phenomenon that tennis simply lends itself to the medium better than most sports. You get to see the players' faces and bodies with such clarity that the emotional drama looms larger than life. As the tennis buff Wilt Chamberlain puts it, ''Tennis makes for great theater.''
Another factor that has allowed tennis to spill over into a larger, crossover audience is the current star status of its players. Andre Agassi is on the cover of Gentlemen's Quarterly; Michael Chang goes on ''The Tonight Show'' and discusses his dates; John McEnroe is married to the actress Tatum O'Neal. Chris Evert's social life has always been tabloid material, going back to the days of her dates with Burt Reynolds, and her marriage now to a handsome skier, Andy Mill, has the look of old-time Hollywood coupledom. These show-biz tidbits, not a player's net game, are the elements that attract someone like my mother to a sport.
And professional tennis does not suffer at the moment from the boredom created by the homogeneous talent pools of other sports. Boxing is so desperate for a black versus white bout that a George Foreman-Gerry Cooney fight has been made. Tennis showcases teen-age millionaires against middle-age gladiators. Daughters of aristocratic tycoons face girls who got their first practice sneakers from the Y.W.C.A. Lost and Found. Athletes from the Communist bloc routinely oppose players honed by the opportunities and pressures of Western capitalism.
Indeed, the expanse of international representation is another key to the healthy numbers of fans newly piqued by tennis personalities. A Soviet player, Natalya Zvereva, goes public in her fight with the Soviet Tennis Federation to keep 70 percent of her prize money. Her countryman Andrei Chesnokov openly supports her. Then when Chesnokov shows flash and grit against Ivan Lendl at the 1989 United States Open, a packed house at the Grandstand court voices its approval of his stand, and his play, by chanting, ''Da, Chesy!''
And in one of the most dramatic matches at the Open, a black from Cameroon in Africa, who was discovered by Arthur Ashe, faces an Israeli who developed in the public parks of Tel Aviv. Yannick Noah prevailed over Amos Mansdorf that day in five hard-fought sets, but that match was more than tennis. Noah and Mansdorf seemed symbols of the wide spectrum of today's pros who have had their road paved by a few mavericks.
Billie Jean King drew thousands of women to the game. Arthur Ashe has inspired phenomenal growth in tennis opportunities for blacks. Bjorn Borg set off the Swedish explosion, which affected all of Western Europe, including West Germany, where Boris Becker and Steffi Graf have become national heroes. Guillermo Vilas's appeal spawned the clubs where Gabriela Sabatini eventually learned. And there is no telling how many street-fighting types have opened their eyes to tennis because of Jimmy Connors. A middle-class kid whose father collected the turnpike tolls in Belleville, Ill., Connors has played every point of his career like it was the last punch of a 15-round spectacle.
The Open era of tennis technically began in 1968 but it has taken some 20 years for the next generation to break through the white, country club image that once limited the sport's public appeal. Previously, only an exceptional talent, like Althea Gibson, could penetrate the domain of the privileged, but today Zina Garrison leads the way for hundreds of youths from minority groups successfully coming out of public parks.
It is true that recent American success -Chang, Krickstein, Gilbert, Mayotte, Courier, Sampras - has revived fans' interest, but even more significant is the fact that so many of the young stars are first-generation Americans who bring the attention of ethnic minorities to the game.
On court, Chang, the son of Taiwanese parents, embodies the Asian value system of respect and calm. The 13-year-old sensation Jennifer Capriati is becoming as known for her fun-loving, pasta-adoring Italian dad as she is for her accurate forehands. Mary Joe Fernandez - born in the Dominican Republic and raised in Miami - has created a Latin following, especially in this country's Spanish-speaking strongholds. And Agassi's play fulfills the dream of his Armenian father, a former boxer who hung a tennis ball over his son's crib in hopes that one day Andre would be a champion at the noble game of tennis.
These names - Agassi, Connors, Garrison, Noah, Chang, Chesnokov - instantly suggest the variety of race, religion, and economic background that has brought tennis into the legitimate big leagues of sport. Professional tennis has arrived at its most diverse moment and hence at a moment of immense popularity.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 10, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 864 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
Tackling the N.F.L. Labor Impasse

BYLINE: By GERALD W. SCULLY; Gerald W. Scully is professor of economics at the University of Texas at Dallas. His most recent book is ''The Business of Major League Baseball'' published by the University of Chicago Press.

 BODY:
Union-management relations in football are the worst among the professional team sports. The two sides barely exchange civilities, much less negotiate issues.
Recently, the N.F.L. Players' Association suffered yet another defeat in this bitter battle. This time, a United States Court of Appeals ruled that the free-agency clauses of the 1982 collective bargaining contract could not be challenged as a violation of antitrust simply because current negotiations were at an impasse. 
The suit by the union was the latest in a series of contentious actions that have taken place since 1982, and especially since the failed negotiations and resulting strike in 1987. The rub - the source of the impasse - is free movement for players. The union wants unrestricted free agency for its veterans. The owners do not.
Why has this labor situation deteriorated so badly? Partly, player-owner relations are bad in the N.F.L. because the union acts more like it represents pipefitters than an association of athletes. When Ed Garvey, a Harvard-trained lawyer with strong labor movement sympathies, took over the union, he sought to structure the collective bargaining negotiations in a style reminiscent of many factory agreements. Gene Upshaw is cut from the same cloth.
Under their leadership the union in the early 1980's pushed for a fixed player share of the national TV contract that would be divided among the players by a union scale formula. Heavily weighted in the pay scale was experience or seniority. Players would be paid by job description and seniority.
This is a harebrained scheme that may work for pipefitters but has no place in football. The existing wide spread in salaries between rookies, journeymen and veteran players is a device to induce all players to perform at peak levels. Superior performance leads to the opportunity to earn a truly grand salary. Shrinking the differential pay among players reduces the incentive to play at peak levels.
Marvin Miller, the past director of the Major League Baseball Players' Association, came to the players after a long association with the United Steelworkers. Shrewdly, he left the idea of negotiated pay scales behind him. Players are a bunch of individuals who can be organized into a collective force only if the issues are important to all. Larry Fleischer represented the N.B.A. players in a similar fashion.
Aside from the militancy and traditional union approach of the N.F.L. Players' Association, the economic structure in the game is sufficiently different from baseball and basketball to make one skeptical about whether unrestricted free agency will bring the golden age of astronomical salaries. Revenues in football are socialized. About 60 percent of club revenues come from the national TV contract and are split evenly among the clubs. Ticket sales are split 60-40. In baseball, about 40 percent of the revenue comes from the sale of broadcast rights. Roughly half comes from the national TV contract and half from the sale of local rights. The gate split is 85-15. Basketball has had a much lower revenue share from TV and splits the gate, 100-0.
The implication is obvious. There is little financial incentive to win in football. Surely, there is pride in winning. However, a club that improves its finish by purchasing high-priced talent gets to keep 1/28th of the increased revenue. The remainder goes to the other 27 clubs. Moreover, in a world in which games are sold out (season tickets are the norm in football), revenues do not rise much with a winning season. While it pays to buy high-priced playing talent in baseball and basketball, this is not the case in football.
What is to be done to break the union-management impasse in the N.F.L.? There are three options. The union can call another strike. The union will lose, if it chooses this path, partly because a large fraction of the players will defect. When the expected length of your career in football is less than three years (seven in baseball and basketball), risking a third of your salary does not make a whole lot of economic sense.
Second, the union can decertify itself. Decertification would remove the labor exemption under antitrust. The 28 clubs then would have independent unions that bargain with individual owners. Players become independent contractors. As such, they would be free to initiate moves between clubs. However, I doubt that Gene Upshaw and the union staff are altruistic enough to liquidate themselves out of a job.
The third alternative is for the union to negotiate incremental improvements in the conditions of free agency (reductions in compensation for lost free agents) and build new incentives for clubs to check their overall player costs (the basketball team salary cap would work in football) or financial incentives for clubs to win. Suppose the clubs kicked in $50 million of their more than billion-dollar revenues as a prize for the winner of the Super Bowl. Such a prize would be a strong incentive to win. The demand for winning will translate into a demand for veteran free agents. Fans, players, and even owners would benefit from greater financial incentives to win in football.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Long Island City;
Ambitious Projects Delayed as Conversions Proceed

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
Two New York City agencies - the Planning Commission and the Public Development Corporation - are preparing blueprints for the brighter future that seems to be in store for Long Island City now that Citicorp has planted a striking Manhattan-style office tower there.
But as the agencies put the finish coat on reports designed to guide development in Long Island City, one major developer, Leonard Stern, chairman of the Hartz Group, has lost patience with the slow pace of the city's planning and has given up a plan for a 1.6 million-square-foot building he had hoped to put up at a major intersection at the approach to the Queensboro Bridge.
Other projects also have been put on hold, and the frenzied pace of property trading and assemblages that the Citicorp project touched off has slowed. Meanwhile, small-scale redevelopment is taking place without reference to any overall plan that may be adopted. Cunard Line, an Austrian bank and other Manhattan companies are taking blocks of space in existing buildings, many of which are former factories converted into modern office space. 
''The study will give momentum to the entire redevelopment effort in Long Island City,'' said James Schmidt, a vice president for planning, design and construction for the Public Development Corporation, referring to the agency's review of the impact of an estimated 25 million square feet in proposed commercial and residential development projects there.
''We have focused on transportation both public and vehicular, and tried to show what the effect would be on the community and the region if proposed projects were built between now and 1997.
Some of these projects include the Hunters Point district on the East River, a 68-acre proposed city, state and Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plan; any further development by Citicorp and the planned expansion at the International Design Center. There is a big push on now because officials hope to start the formal review process for the waterfront early next year.
While Mr. Schmidt's agency has focused on all of Long Island City, the Planning Department has zeroed in on a mile-long stretch of Jackson Avenue, a major commercial core of the evolving community.
Except for Citicorp at Court Square - the name for the bank's 50-story glass tower - Jackson Avenue is like much of the rest of Long Island City, a mix of industrial buildings, warehouses and factories, with a few houses and stores tucked in here and there. Most of the street is zoned for both manufacturing and commercial uses with an F.A.R. (floor-to-area ratio) development potential of five.
Because of its width, its abundant surface and subway transportation and the number of underused or vacant sites, planners feel that Jackson Avenue holds particular potential for further commercial development.
Planning Department officials said that their recomendations on rezoning and land use would be based on such issues as potential impact of development on employment, traffic and the environment.
Local business people, economic development officials and real estate professionals who were consulted in the preparation of the report said they do not expect to see the sort of blanket upzoning for Jackson Avenue that could transform the street into a corridor of high-rise office towers. Rather, these observers expect to see a study that promotes upscale development that would incorporate some of the existing industrial buildings on Jackson Avenue and the side streets.
Once completed, the report will be sent for comment to the borough president's offic, the PDC, the state's Urban Development Corporation, the Port Authority, community boards and business development organizations.
But as the city moves closer to opening the door to more development in Long Island City, some developers and other real estate professionals have expressed frustration with the pace of the review and planning process.
''Unfortunately, the risk-to-potential-reward factor is no longer in our favor,'' said Mr. Stern, chairman of the Hartz Group, a subsidiary of Hartz Development, which has built some 35 million square feet with a mix of uses in the New Jersey Meadowlands. Mr. Stern's company held an option to buy the Queens Mart site at the intersection of Northern Boulevard, Queens Boulevard and Jackson Avenue as well as a riverfront site where he wanted to build a 960-unit residential community.
''While we were going for the rezoning, the market softened and the projected costs went up,'' he said. ''For now we will concentrate on projects elsewhere.''
The owners of the waterfront site, RAK Tennis Corporation, where Hartz hoped to build apartments, will continue to pursue the development project.
The site where Mr. Stern wanted to put up an office building is five blocks from the Citicorp tower, the most visible symbol of the neighborhood's economic potential. Citicorp, which got a zoning change that let it build to an F.A.R. of 15, as well as $75 million in tax abatements, is transferring some 3,300 executives and other office employees to the office building.
The bank has the approvals for another tower of about 1.2 million square feet of space for the property it owns across 43d Street. But while a second building has been considered, Ann Roberts, a company spokesman, said there are no plans to start such a project.
Since the opening four years ago of the International Design Center, a four-building complex where a string of factories was coverted to showroom space for design and furniture companies, prices for buildings and properties have risen in Long Island City along with expectations about the future of the neighborhood. Citicorp's announcement in 1985 that it would build a front-office tower in that part of Queens pushed prices for property and buildings even further.
''Prices have stabilized,'' said Gail Roseman, an executive vice president with Sholom & Zuckerbrot, a brokerage and consulting company based in Astoria. ''But there is still a great deal of anticipation and expectations are high. One of the reasons is that Long Island City is considered by just about every major space-user looking to expand and considering places other than Manhattan.
''But unfortunately,'' she continued, ''for any company that wants brand new space sometime soon, there is nothing here yet.''
Even though it seems development is in a holding pattern, companies are coming across the river from Manhattan and some small office projects are moving forward.
Cunard, the international luxury cruise and hotel operator, expects to move 300 employees from its executive offices at 555 Fifth Avenue to a 70,000-square-foot space in the municipal garage building at Bridge Plaza early next year. The company has sublet the space from Med-Mac Properties, which has a long-term lease with the city for all of the 200,000 square feet of office space at the base of the garage.
The Cunard move, which would be the largest transfer from Manhattan after Citicorp's, will be into space intended primarily for its reservations department.
Laenderbank, an Austrian bank, recently bought a former Volunteers of America building at 43d Avenue between 23d and 24th Streets. It is renovating the five-story, 115,000-square-foot structure for computer operations and other back-office space.
Richard Zirinsky Associates, one of the largest property owners in Long Island City and the company that sold Laenderbank its building, is transforming a former tomato paste plant across Court Square from the Citicorp tower into an office building. According to Richard Zirinsky Jr., a principal in the company, the building, which has 126,000 square feet of space, will be ready for occupancy by January. Mr. Zirinsky said a lease for the entire building, at 45-18 Court Square, is pending.

HEADLINE: Union Square: Gritty Past, Bright Future

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The people who live in the vicinity of Union Square are engaged in heated debate about the future of real estate development in their neighborhood. Some equate development with progress, saying that until the last few years the area was regarded by many as having no future at all; others worry that too much development will ruin its social and architectural diversity.
Like similar debates elsewhere in New York City, it is at its most intense now that only a few major developable sites remain, on the south side of of the square and the stretch of 14th Street just east of it. This focus was sharpened nearly two years ago when Zeckendorf Towers, a 652-apartment condomium and office complex, opened on the northeast corner of Union Square East and 14th Street. It transformed the neighborhood by proving that New Yorkers would pay $300,000 to $400,000 to live in an area that, not long before, was considered all but worthless.
That success also sharpened interest in the remaining developable sites, since their disposition will determine whether the current trend toward expensive housing and shopping will continue, which local developers and the city favor, or a niche in the neighborhood's upward mobility can be found into which some low-cost apartments and maybe a community center could be fitted. 
Until the last couple of years it would have been unthinkable for anyone to worry about Union Square's becoming too slick. The park itself was a rundown, rubble-strewn smudge, a drug-dealing center where Broadway and Park Avenue South come close to meeting at 14th Street. Several nearby S.R.O.'s housed the violent and the despairing, and the big S. Klein department store buildings on the east side of the square were empty hulks. Last December, Mays, another big retail presence at the foot of the park, also was closed.
''We moved here in 1983,'' Todd Haimes, who heads the Roundabout Theater, said of his off-Broadway stage company, which rents the auditorium of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union Building, once a headquarters for Tammany Hall, off the corner of 17th Street and Union Square East. ''I distinctly remember having coffee and a bagel and seeing people openly selling drugs outside the window, and then someone tried to rob the coffee shop, and there were people screaming and jumping all over each other to get out. It was the Wild West all over again.''
Local leaders argue that Union Square and most of 14th Street is a neighborhood looking for a theme. Between Seventh and Fifth Avenues, 14th Street is a thriving - if shabby, at least on the south side - discount shopping bazaar, whose merchants were drawn to the area by the floor-through design of old loft buildings. Merchants there pay high rents of up to $125 a foot and do an annual business of $200 million dealing with lower-income shoppers who come to their stores from all over the city.
The eastward march of this shopping activity is arrested at Union Square by the empty bulk of the former Mays department store between University Place and Broadway. On the next block is a tangled, decaying collection of one-story ''taxpayer'' stores fronting the stretch between Broadway and Fourth Avenue, which becomes Park Avenue South north of 14th Street.
The blockfront is controlled by a group headed by Philip Pilevsky, who has expressed an interest in building condominiums and offices on the site but who has not yet filed any formal plans.
Much of the block between Fourth and Third is controlled by Jeffrey Glick, a developer of luxury apartments who is negotiating with the city for a city-owned parking lot that holds the key to development there.
The block between Third and Second is a stretch of rundown tenements, some boarded up, that planners believe are too narrow and shallow to attract development as retail space. The next block, of slightly better low-cost rental apartment walk-ups, connects the eastern reach of the street to the fastness of Stuyvesant Town.
The arrival of the Roundabout at Union Square was an expression of the rising real estate values - and rising rents - that eventually reached East 14th Street and Union Square. William Zeckendorf Jr., who has made his mark in recent years by beating the competition into gentrifying areas, committed $200 million in 1985 to build his development in return for the city's agreeing to allow greater densities for the project and commit itself to cleaning up Union Square Park.
The city spent $3.8 million in the first phase of refurbishing the park, completed in May 1985, which banished the drug addicts and brought back green lawns and the sound of children's laughter.
Phases two and three, to rehabilitate the pavilion at the north end of the park and to expand the park's boundaries on its west side, are now in the design review stage and no date for the work has been set.
The Union Square Community Coalition, a local citizens group, sponsors noontime concerts in the park and a greenmarket brings shoppers from around Manhattan three days a week. Over the years, five structures around the square have been landmarked to protect the ornate turn-of-the century character of the area.
A total of $20 million is scheduled to be spent rebuilding 14th Street itself, from Ninth Avenue to the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, including a complete repaving of the roadway, planting clusters of trees - an arrangement the Parks Department now prefers over stringing trees out at equal distances along the curb - and installing Bishop's Crook streetlamps of historic design.
While the city and a few big developers were doing their part, smaller initiatives by local businesses also had a great impact on the district. The lofts above West 14th Street's bustling discount stores have been converted to dwellings and office space, helping to displace the dingy, unused look that the street had in earlier years.
One of the pioneers was Ken Giddon, who opened his Rothman's men's clothing store on the corner of Park Avenue South and Union Square North in September 1986 and says he has not regretted it for a moment.
''Not being from New York I didn't have the historical background on how bad Union Square was supposed to have been,'' he said. ''I just looked and said, 'Hey, we're on a park, it's a transportation hub,' and besides, I couldn't afford the rents they wanted over nearer to Fifth Avenue.''
Down two blocks, on the east side of the square, a 40,000-square-foot Kiddie City children's toy and clothing outlet just opened on the ground floor of the ornate, cast-iron-front building that once housed Klein's Annex. And the 350,000 square feet of office space on the lower floors of in Zeckendorf Towers has been leased to Integrated Resources, the financial services company.
On the ground level of the Zeckendorf complex, A. & P. has opened the first modern supermarket that anyone can remember in the area. Also there are a new restaurant, Romeo's, a dry cleaner's, a Federal Express office and a small theater, the Vineyard, in space contributed by Mr. Zeckendorf.
The former Mays department store, owned by a partnership including Mr. Zeckendorf, is scheduled to become a vertical mall, with one of six retailers occupying each floor. So far, Pergament, the home-supplies retailer, and Marshall's, the discount clothing chain, have signaled an interest.
According to an economic survey of the area for local businesses by Robert B. Pauls, a Manhattan planning consultant, some 40,000 new white-collar jobs moved into the area between 1980 and 1987.
Zeckendorf Towers, completed a year and a half ago, has sold all but two of its condominium apartments at prices averaging $230,000, according to a spokesman, with some going for more than half a million. This means that home buyers invested $150 million in an area with a rough past but a promising future.
''Personally, I couldn't believe that people were paying that kind of money to live around here,'' said a local businessman, who refused to be named for fear of offending future customers. ''It kind of woke me up to how much things have changed around here.''
''It's well known that the best investment in this city is real estate, especially if it's in an area that's improving,'' said Adam Berwiss, an electronics engineer, who moved into a one-bedroom apartment in one of the Zeckendorf Towers a year ago. ''I think most of us are here for the same reason the other people are here - the price is right and it's a great area.''
A total of 15 new apartment buildings with more than 2,000 apartments have been or are being built within eight blocks north and south of the square, and between Seventh and First Avenues, according to the Pauls study. One of the new buildings, the Carlisle, on Union Square West, has 92 units and has been partially taken over by New York University as a student dormitory.
Suddenly, long-time residents say, the signs of gentrification are there for all to see: palmy restaurants, cleaners that charge $2 to wash and iron one shirt, women in silk suits and sneakers. The old-timers watch their new neighbors with the ambivalence of rustics watching summer people move in next door - glad to have the new money in the area but afraid that too much of it will leave no room for them.
''It's very important for us to keep the ethnic and social diversity that exists here,'' said Evelyn Strouse, a writer who has lived a block and a half from Union Square since 1981 and who is now co-chairman of the Union Square Community Coalition. ''This neighborhood has a long history of being a home to artists and workers and people of various colors and races and religions and people of very diverse incomes, and we'd like to keep them here. They give the area its punch and its charm, and anyway, we've got enough gentrified neighborhoods in this city already.''
The city's Division of Real Property indicated it wanted more gentry on 14th Street, however, when it proposed, last fall, to rezone the block between Fourth and Third Avenues to allow more apartments to be built on it. This would raise the value of a .67-acre vacant lot it owns between the Palladium disco, formerly the Academy of Music, and the former Luchow's restaurant.
Mr. Glick, president of the Glick Organization, controls the block by his ownership of the Palladium, the Luchow's building and most of the other properties. A developer of big, expensive apartment houses, he said he shares Ms. Strouse's appreciation of the district's special qualities, but left open whether he was willing to make room for them in his plans.
''I love the area,'' he said. ''It has everything. You're on the East Side, you have the subways, you're near the F.D.R. Drive and you're near the Village, it has a park - it's all connected in that one area, and I think that gives Union Square a nice, homey feeling.''
But, given the current slack in the city's residential market, Mr. Glick cautioned local residents against believing that any great new projects were just around the corner.
''It's not going to happen all at once,'' he said. ''Zeckendorf did his site, eventually I'll do mine, and after a while it will done right down to First Avenue.''
But Mr. Glick's idea of getting 14th Street ''done'' all the way to First Avenue is not what several local business and community groups have in mind, even though the developer did win friends by donating $1,500 to Ms. Strouse's group.
Where Mr. Glick and other property owners prefer to increase density and therefore financial returns, local groups like Ms. Strouse's want less density, along with assurances that lower-income people will still be able to find affordable housing in the neighborhood after redevelopment.
Two of the groups favoring this approach, the Union Square-14th Street Local Development Corporation and the Union Square-14th Street Business Improvement District, are housed and heavily supported by Consolidated Edison Company, which has headquarters on the north side of 14th Street between Irving Place and Third Avenue. Besides having an interest in protecting the area around its massive headquarters from decline, Con Ed also owns a sizable parking lot and potential development site at Third Avenue between 14th and 15th Streets.
At present, like Mr. Glick, the big utility has no plans to develop the site, said Laurie Hanson, a company spokesman.
The city originally proposed zoning the Glick block with a floor-area ratio of 10 to 12, which would permit streetwalls 125 to 150 feet high with setbacks going up over 200 feet.
''The issue around Union Square is diversity,'' said Jack Goldstein, chairman of the planning and zoning committee for Community Board 5, which takes in the park and parts of 14th Street. ''You have here, in the center of Manhattan, an area that in some way or another has managed to maintain economic and social diversity as a source of neighborhood pride. I would say that the affordable housing situation there is no worse and in some ways a little better than in the rest of the city.''
A coalition of local groups, including the Local Development Corporation and the Business Improvement District, have proposed far smaller buildings, with an F.A.R. of about 6 and a streetwall no more than 85 feet high. They would also like to save the Luchow facade and interior and include some low-cost housing. Most importantly, Ms. Strouse argued, any new building would have to be low enough to let sunlight reach the square.
''People here remember what the city tried to do with the Coliseum site, putting up a tremendous tower that would cast shadows over Central Park,'' she said, speaking of the original zoning proposal. ''It would be crazy to put something that big on the south side of the square, where the sun comes from.''
The city has since withdrawn its original proposal and is studying new options for the site.
''It's the hottest spot on 14th Street,'' said Edward Barbarini, spokesman for the Department of General Services, of the Glick block. ''We thought our proposal was a fine opportunity for the productive use of city property, but the people there were not crazy about it, so we brought it back.''

HEADLINE: Rise in Housing Costs Scrutinized

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
HOME prices in New Jersey sharply outpaced income growth in the 1980's and exacerbated a worsening housing outlook, said a study released last week.
''Housing affordability declined dramatically over large areas of the state in a relatively short period of time,'' said the report by the New Jersey Economic Policy Council, which advises Gov. Thomas H. Kean on the economy.
In real terms, home ownership became an increasingly elusive goal for low- and moderate-income families, and housing choices became sharply limited for middle- and upper-middle-income families.
''If you own your house, you're in great shape,'' said Joseph J. Seneca, chairman of the council and a professor of economics at Rutgers University. ''For first-time home buyers, housing has become more expensive.'' 
 
'Problems of Prosperity'
Mr. Seneca said the study was ''an expression of concern over what I call the problems of prosperity.''
The study also concludes that the state's population growth must begin increasing at a faster rate if it is to meet the growing demand for employees needed to continue prosperity in New Jersey.
By 1987, average housing prices ranged from $150,000 to $200,000 across the state except for the southern area encompassing Burlington County and including parts of Atlantic and Salem Counties.
In more than two-thirds of the state's towns, housing prices rose more than 70 percent from 1984 through 1987. In more than 10 percent of the state's towns, housing prices more than doubled during the four-year period. The sharpest price increases were in the northeast and central parts of the state, the report showed.
But income did not grow nearly as fast, putting home ownership out of the reach of many families.
 
Steep Increases Found
Of the 555 municipalities studied, 44 percent had housing prices grow between two and four times faster than the average income increase.
In the northeast region covering Bergen, Hudson, Passaic, Essex, Union, Morris and Sussex Counties, 70 percent of communities had housing prices increase two to four times faster than income.
In the region covering Warren, Somerset, Hunterdon and Middlesex Counties, 60 percent of communities had housing prices grow two to four times faster than income.
In 41 percent of communities in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, housing costs grew two to four times faster than income.
In the area covering Mercer, Burlington, Camden and Gloucester Counties, housing costs kept better pace with income.
About 38 percent of communities had housing prices and income grow at about the same rate, and in nearly all the other communities in that region housing prices increased at between one and two times the rate at which income grew.
 
Most Affordable Region
Housing remained most affordable in the southern region encompassing Salem, Cumberland, Atlantic and Cape May Counties, where housing costs increased at the same rate or slower than income increases in 43 out of 68 communities.
While southern New Jersey has traditionally been more affordable than the northern parts of the state, the gap between housing prices in the two areas widened between 1984 and 1987, the report found.
For example, in 1984 the average house cost $96,133 in the Bergen-Passaic-Hudson region and $97,659 in the Sussex-Morris-Essex-Union region.
At the same time, the average house cost $57,653 in the Salem-Cumberland-Atlantic-Cape May region, $60,231 in the Mercer-Burlington-Camden-Gloucester area and $86,984 in the Warren-Hunterdon-Somerset-Middlesex region. In the Monmouth-Ocean area, the average home price was $78,539 in 1984.
By 1987, however, the average house cost had risen to $185,533 in the Bergen-Passaic-Hudson region and to $178,453 in the Sussex-Morris-Essex-Union region. Likewise, large increases were found in the Warren-Hunterdon-Somerset-Middlesex region, where average prices climbed to $159,093, and in the Monmouth-Ocean region, where average prices increased to $146,692.
But average prices in the Mercer-Burlington-Camden-Gloucester area increased to only $86,817 by 1987 and increased to only $73,726 in the Salem-Cumberland-Atlantic-Cape May area.
