HEADLINE: Helping Troubled Boys Save and Study for College

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY

 BODY:
FOR Cesar Alvarez, a senior at Hastings High School, the pressure was intense.
A final draft of his paper examining the light and imagery in ''The Scarlet Letter'' wasn't going well, and Cesar needed the grade. The New York City Police Academy entrance exam loomed, and his twice-weekly commute to Queens for tutoring for the exam was helpful but time-consuming. Then there was his job pumping gas at the local Getty station.
If last May was a tough month, Cesar had seen much worse in his 19 years. But now, he says, life looks very good indeed, a turnaround that began when he came to the county five years ago. 
 
Alumnus of Job-Training Program
Cesar is an alumnus of the Children's Village, the residential treatment center here, and of a new program at the center that provides college scholarships and job training to some of the troubled boys.
Cesar Alvarez graduated from Hastings High in June and scored 90 out of 100 on the Police Academy exam. He is one of 10 Children's Village alumni who have graduated from various high schools in the New York City area and headed on to full-time jobs. Five of these boys are now in college: at Westchester County Community College, Hunter College, the University of New Haven, Sullivan County Community College and Canisius College.
The 10 boys are all scholarship participants in the five-year-old Work Appreciation for Youth program, an unusual experiment to help boys learn work ethics and job skills. While every boy at the Children's Village has the opportunity to participate in the work program, about 15 are chosen each year for the scholarship program.
With the help of anonymous donors who contributed $350,000 in start-up costs, the Work Appreciation scholarship program helps the most promising of the program's graduates work toward a college education or post-high school job training. After evaluating the results, the program's original donors recently agreed to contribute an additional $720,000.
This latest contribution will pay for more counselors, finance research efforts and provide $1,000 to each college student in the program for four years and the same amount for two years to high school graduates needing job training.
The center here is home for 314 boys with severe behavior and emotional problems. Many of the boys have had to be removed from their homes; others have been taken from the foster-care system, where they have lived all their lives.
Cesar said he came to the Children's Village voluntarily in l984, ''depressed and subject to violent mood swings.'' His mother, Rosa Manno, was unable to control him, and his father, Cesar said, is a ''career felon.''
 
A Last Resort
For 138 years, originally in Manhattan and the last 87 in Westchester, the treatment center has been the home of last resort for abused and neglected boys in the New York City area.
''These are underprivileged children, multiplied by the most extreme economic and emotional deprivation that exists anywhere,'' Nan Dale, the executive director of Children's Village, said in describing the 5- to 15-year-old boys in her care. ''They are the most troubled of the troubled kids,'' Mrs. Dale said. Reading levels are typically four to six years below the grade typical for their ages, Mrs. Dale said, adding, ''When these kids make it, it is all the more remarkable.''
Typically, students are selected for the scholarship program at age 13. Those selected must sign a contract agreeing they will save at least $300 each year until they graduate from high school. They also agree to contribute a fixed portion of their earnings to a special fund, which the donors match. The donors increase the contributions to students who have outstanding performances.
Signing the contract binds participants to regular meetings with a Children's Village counselor for five years after they leave the campus and a promise that they will get tutoring whenever it is necessary. Those who leave the program without graduating from high school forfeit all donor funds and get their own savings back only when they reach graduating age. Participants in the Work Appreciation program may work toward a maximum donor contribution of more than $4,000 for a total saving of about $7,000 when added to their own earnings.
 
71 Percent Remain in School
Of the 63 boys who were enrolled in the Work Appreciation program during the first four years, 71 percent, or 45 boys, are still in school, working part time and saving money toward further education or job training. Early surveys indicate that about half of this group are aiming toward studies after high school, most have experienced setbacks and most have avoided delinquency.
The additional $720,000 grant, the largest single contribution Children's Village has ever received, will allow the treatment center to complete a 10-year study of the achievements and difficulties of children in foster care, and the effect of the Work Appreciation scholarship program.
''There's a certain self-fulfilling prophecy just in being selected for the scholarship program,'' Mrs. Dale said. ''We tell each boy, 'You have been chosen because you are smart and the staff thinks you have a great future,' but this program communicates from beginning to end, 'You are in control of your own destiny.' ''
The message is given early on. Following the first level of basic cottage chores, performed with no pay, each new job level in the Work Appreciation program requires potential ''employees'' to apply, provide an ''employment history'' and be interviewed wearing a suit. Each boy is paid a ''salary'' and may be promoted or sometimes dismissed. Boys advance through four levels of the work program, the last consisting of community jobs off campus and unpaid internships at hospitals and other organizations. The fifth level is the scholarship program.
 
Bus Outfitted With Computers
One of the 22 work sites available at the Children's Village campus is the computer bus, a vehicle outfitted with 18 computers, three printers and a selection of software. Boys who wish to take the 14-session course aboard the bus must apply and then pay $1 for each session. Graduates of the program may then apply to become teaching assistants on the bus, which pays $1.50 a session.
The bus has started to travel throughout Westchester, beginning with a program with the Meadow Pond Elementary School after-school program in South Salem. Each Thursday afternoon, a work counselor from Children's Village accompanied by his young assistants arrives at the Meadow Pond School to instruct 15 fourth, fifth and sixth graders on the bus.
Cesar Alvarez is a typical scholarship recipient. After leaving Children's Village in 1985, he entered Bryant High School in Queens as a freshman. Although he did well the first year, in his sophomore year, Cesar conceded that he attended school only for football practice. After a few months wandering about Queens as a truant, Cesar asked to return to Children's Village. He was admitted to one of the treatment center's group homes and entered Hastings High School, from which he graduated in June.
 
Holding Down Three Jobs
While Cesar awaits the results of his final interviews for admission to the Police Academy, he is holding down three jobs, as a driver for Hastings Taxi, a gas station attendant for the Power Test station in Dobbs Ferry and a teacher's aide at the Children's Village.
He also spends 30 hours each week as an auxiliary policeman in Queens, and in September, Cesar was named Auxiliary Cop of the Month, an award for his consistent work habits.
Cesar will be leaving his job at Children's Village soon because he has just been hired by a Westchester construction company. The pay, he said, is better, and he needs the money to make payments on the red l980 Datsun he bought recently.
While he waits to hear from the Police Academy, he has plenty to keep him busy and happy, and Cesar observed: ''One thing I like about Westchester. You can find jobs so quickly. Most kids here are going to school or have their parents to rely on.''

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

 BODY:

 
SAPPHO EXHIBITION
''Imaging Sappho,'' an exhibition of 16 paintings by Ellen Evjen, attempts to evoke the spirit of a woman who is generally acknowledged to have been one of the greatest lyric poets in history. The exhibition opens tomorrow through Dec. 11 in the Exhibit Hall of the College Center at the College of New Rochelle, at Castle Place in downtown New Rochelle.
While nothing of Sappho's life or death can be confirmed as fact, she is believed to have been born in 600 B.C., probably of an aristocratic family, on the Greek island of Lesbos. Along with others of her social class, she is thought to have been banished to Sicily in her later years. In spite of her fame during her lifetime, little of her poetry is preserved intact.
Ms. Evjen has interpreted five fragments of Sappho's poetry, using wood, canvas, silk, clay and metal juxtaposed on the texts written in English and in the original Greek. The translations were made by Christos Tsiamis. 
Viewing hours are from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. weekdays and noon to 4 P.M. weekends. A reception will be held from 2 to 4 P.M. next Sunday. For more information, call 632-5300.
 
'DAY WITHOUT ART'
''A Day Without Art'' is the umbrella title for a national day of mourning Dec. 1, when more than 400 arts organizations will participate in remembering the victims of AIDS within the arts community. The date was chosen to coincide with the World Health Organization's ''AIDS Awareness Day.''
In cooperation with a campus task force on AIDS, the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase has scheduled a lecture called ''AIDS and Art: From Media to Metaphor'' at 7 P.M. Thursday. Robert Atkins, art critic and contributor to The Village Voice, will be the speaker, focusing on AIDS-related art produced during the last eight years. He will explore photojournalistic images, elegiac paintings, portraits of AIDS sufferers, conceptual works, guerrilla street art, and billboards by dozens of artists including Keith Haring, Ross Bleckner, Gretchen Bender and Masami Teraoka.
The Neuberger, the Museum of Modern Art, the Carnegie Museum and the Walker Art Center are among those nationwide that will participate by closing for the day or removing art from the galleries, by halting performances for a moment of silence, holding memorial services, or by disseminating educational material.
Admission to the talk is free.
 
THANKSGIVING COMPOST
Instead of feeding Thanksgiving dinner garbage to the disposer or the local dump, how about composting it? Carolyn Cullen, greenhouse manager at the Greenburgh Nature Center, will give a demonstration of the process using the center's own compost pile.
Believed by environmentalists to be a more efficient, economical and beneficial way to dispose of most foods, fallen leaves and garden debris, composting can be achieved in a number of ways with the deliberate or involuntary assistance of insects and micro-organisms, making use of commercial containers or an unobtrusive corner of the backyard.
The program is designed for adults and older children at 2 P.M. today, and it is free, but contributions of $2 for adults and $1 for children would be appreciated. The center is on Dromore Road off Central Avenue. Call 723-3470 for more information.
 
ST. NICHOLAS FESTIVAL
Three performances of the St. Nicholas Festival will be given in December by the Bronx Arts Ensemble and the Double Reed Band. The medley of songs and narrative tells the story of the Dutch St. Nicholas, who came to the houses of boys and girls on Dec. 6 and put candy in the wooden shoes of those who were good, but filled the shoes of naughty children with lumps of coal. In addition, his assistant, Black Piet, had been known to make off with very bad boys and girls.
''St. Nick was not exactly like Santa Claus,'' said Robert Kornfeld, who wrote the narrative. ''During the performance there are songs and stories about how he became a saint by doing good deeds for the people of Holland.'' Dec. 6 was his birthday and a day for exchanging gifts, while Dec. 25 was a traditional Christmas feast day. The Bronx Arts Ensemble originated the program 15 years ago as a Yuletide celebration appropriate to the Van Cortlandt Mansion where it was first held. It has been performed every year since.
William and Louise Scribner, directors of the ensemble and bassoonist and oboist respectively, will be joined by Mark Perchanok, oboe d'amore; Robert Ingliss, English horn; and four vocalists. Settings for the old Dutch songs and carols were arranged by Jack Gale.
Performances are at 2 P.M. Saturday in the Bartow-Pell Mansion, on Shore Road in Pelham Bay Park; and again at 4 P.M. in the Church of the Mediator, Kingsbridge Avenue at West 231st Street. The third performance is at 10:30 A.M. Dec. 7 in the McGinley Center of Fordham University's Rose Hill campus, on Southern Boulevard. All locations are in the Bronx. Admission is free but reservations should be made. Call (212) 549-1899.
 
HOLIDAY BAZAAR
An old-fashioned Christmas church bazaar first held 63 years ago will be in progress from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday at St. John's Church on Fountain Square in Larchmont.
''We get a lot of items from estates,'' said Carleen Kluss, one of the organizers. ''As parishioners pass away, their property is held by relatives until our next bazaar. One year I ended up clearing out a whole house for the family.'' Many rare books and sets of books are obtained through such bequests.
Each year a number of local antiques dealers display a selection of collectible silver, table linens and accessories that can range in price up to $400, but most other items sell for 50 cents to $75, and include gifts that children can afford to buy.
''We are noted for our own handcrafts - one of the few remaining church bazaars that makes them,'' Mrs. Kluss said. ''We have three women's guilds making 75 percent of what we sell. They start working in January.''
Among the handcrafts are unusual decorative baskets, small painted churches, all kinds of picture frames, stuffed dinosaurs covered in chintz, terrariums, knitted hats and gloves, needlepoint bridge-table covers and elaborate patchwork Christmas stockings. Aprons, decorated trees, patchwork quilts for dolls, kissing balls and toys are also created by hand, some decorated with a heart motif carrying out this year's theme - ''Christmas - Season of the Heart.''
Proceeds from sales aid such organizations as the Larchmont-Mamaroneck Community Services, the Yonkers Center for Abused Women, Hope for the Homeless and Providence House. Admission is free. For more information, call 834-2981.
 
MUSICAL CHRISTMAS CARD
''A Musical Christmas Card'' traces a period from the mid-19th century to today, when the popularity of Christmas cards grew by leaps and bounds. A selection of cards displayed one by one will be accompanied by a narrative and a selection of secular and religious music of the season. The free program, presented by ''Three for the Show,'' a group headed by Lu Gmoser, producer of the Asbury Summer Theater in Yonkers, will begin at 7:30 P.M. in the Crestwood Library, at 16 Thompson Street. Ms. Gmoser is the commentator, and her daughter-in-law, Susan Gmoser, is the vocalist, accompanied by Larry Wasserman on the piano. Call 337-1500 for more information.

HEADLINE: Restaurant Meals Going Door to Door for the Working Public

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

 BODY:
WHEN Duncan MacLaine and Charles Carafiello began Chefs' Express, a restaurant meal-delivery service, they said they thought their focus would be on food. The partners have discovered, however, that their three-month-old Hartsdale-based business fills more needs than the merely dietary.
Chefs' Express dispatches ''driving chefs'' clad in red jackets and chef's hats who deliver - and serve, if requested - meals from selected restaurants to homes and offices in the county. Customers choose from a booklet of menus and are promised hot meals within the hour if they live in central Westchester. The company, whose drivers keep in touch with the office by radio, will deliver outside central Westchester with 24 hours notice. 
Although he calls the uniforms ''silly'' and ''outrageous,'' Mr. MacLaine, who was born in Ireland, said the uniforms have ''rung a bell'' with a hard-working public in need of lightening up. ''Everybody stops you in the outfit,'' which matches the company's red delivery trucks and thermal carrying cases, he said.
 
Restaurants in the Service
Seven restaurants are included in the service. These are Livanos in White Plains; Pinocchio and Lotus King in Eastchester; Auberge Argenteuil, Hunan Manor and Epstein's Kosher Delicatessen in Hartsdale; and Marcello in Scarsdale. Desserts are also available from Sweet Cravings in Hartsdale and Brownie Square in Scarsdale. In January, 10 more restaurants are joining the list.
The delivery fee in most of southern Westchester is $7 per total order, and $10 to $25 elsewhere in the county. For an additional $15, the driver will stay an hour to serve and clean up.
Mr. MacLaine said Westchester residents were enthusiastic about the service. Many customers, he said, are two-income couples who are too tired after work to either cook or eat out.
These are often people, he observed, who have it all - and the lack of free time to prove it. They have arrived, but are too exhausted to leave again.
 
There Are 'Oops' Orders
Mr. MacLaine, an experienced res taurateur with a sociological bent, recognizes the syndrome. ''They perceive themselves to be slaves of their own success,'' he said. Chefs' Express is ''what America's about - people who will take the weight off your back.''
Work pressures lead to ''oops'' orders, Mr. MacLaine observed. He said he delivered many ''I forgot it's your birthday'' or ''I'm sorry'' dinners, noting that when the food arrived, brought hot to the table by a driving chef schooled in politeness, tensions seemed to melt. ''One woman told me this kind of thing could save her marriage,'' he added.
Andrea Taber of Scarsdale first ordered from the service when her baby sitter canceled one night. ''We were in shock when Duncan walked in in a chef's jacket and hat,'' she said. She and her husband, Kenneth, told Mr. MacLaine he could just put down the food, but ''he arranged a beautiful tray for us.''
The next time the Tabers ordered, Mr. MacLaine came again and ''seated us, lit the candles and served the wine,'' Mrs. Taber said. ''We've recommended them to all our friends.'' ''The service people are very, very nice and so pleasant on the phone,'' said Linda Grossbach of Irvington, who first ordered from the delivery service when she was nine months pregnant. After the baby's birth, the company sent champagne.
Mr. MacLaine, who is 42 years old, has owned or managed restaurants in England and the United States. The 39-year-old Mr. Carafiello is from a family that owned a restaurant in Eastchester for many years. There are 11 driving chefs, all experienced in food service. Jay Dollinger, 25, who works in the office, handles phone orders with the panach of a maitre d'hotel.
 
10 Months of Planning
The business was opened last August after 10 months of planning. Mr. MacLaine, who holds a degree in economics and marketing, said he had pondered everything from where to put the apostrophe in the company's name (''Chefs' Express'' refers to all the chefs whose food is served) to the best facsimile machine to buy for the restaurants. Each restaurant sends facsimiles of its specials to the office every day. The company also supplies restaurants with custom-designed thermal-plastic food containers.
A restaurant's menu is included in the service only after repeated visits by the partners. Mr. MacLaine noted that ''cleanliness, consistency and the quality of the personnel,'' along with the establishment's location, were the most important criteria for selection.
In turn, Chefs' Express promises to uphold each restaurant's reputation - a factor Mr. MacLaine termed ''key'' to the operation's success.
So far, restaurateurs have been impressed with the company's professionalism. M'el Eudes, who runs Auberge Argenteuil with her husband, Henri, the chef, said she liked not only ''the way the boys look'' but the fact that they knew ''what it's like to put out food.'' The drivers' behavior in hectic restaurant kitchens - where they have been instructed to wait patiently and silently for orders - reflects Mr. MacLaine's understanding that ''they'd better not come in bright and breezy - not in those outfits!''
Mrs. Eudes, who as an actress is known as M'el Dowd, said belonging to the delivery service provided ''a bit of power'' to small restaurants that could benefit from the company's advertising on cable television and elsewhere. She also disagreed with those who cautioned that a home-delivery service would take away from eat-in business.
''It's the same as a store having a mail-service catalogue,'' Mrs. Eludes said. ''It encourages people. Maybe the next day they'll feel like eating out.''
Bart Collins, the manager of Livanos, said the service enabled ''our customers to eat our food on nights when they can't get out to the restaurant.'' Chefs' Express also gives ''people who don't know us a chance to taste our food and know what we're about,'' he added.
Mr. MacLaine said he believed the ''walk-in trade'' of all the participating restaurants had increased since Chefs' Express had opened. People are willing to try unfamiliar restaurants when they are grouped with those they like, he said. The company distributes 20,000 menu booklets a month to the restaurants in the service as well as to other sites.
With satisfied home diners spreading the word to a growing clientele, Mr. MacLaine and Mr. Carafiello have begun to count their Pollo Mangiafuocos. (Breast of chicken sauteed with cherry peppers, fennel and garlic, available for $15 from Pinocchio.)
 
Lunches to Be Delivered
The company will begin delivering lunches this week and will promote the new service with a trailer sporting a huge red chef's hat adorned with a set of Mercury's wings - the Chefs' Express logo.
The partners plan to open another office in Saddle River, N.J., and are considering other metropolitan areas where the demographics - and what Mr. MacLaine called the ''back-breaking life style'' - are similar to Westchester's.
Chefs' Express also provides a one-hour grocery-delivery service and daily home delivery of items to the ill or disabled - with the same uniforms and the same fee structure.
Mr. MacLaine offered this advice for an enjoyable hot restaurant meal at home: when ordering out, set the table before the food comes.

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN AT WINDOW ROCK

BYLINE: By SANDY TOLAN; Sandy Tolan, director of Desert West News in Tucson, Ariz., writes frequently on Indian affairs. He is a regular contributor to National Public Radio.

 BODY:
UNDER THE BRILLIANT BLUE ARIZONA SKY, AN air-conditioned GMC Sierra bumps along a weed-choked wagon track near the main road to Kaibito, just south of Many Waters Lake, at the foot of the Peak Where the Wildcats Stretch. In the back seat, Peter MacDonald, the embattled leader of the Navajo nation, peers through the tinted glass window at a distant figure on horseback.
Across a valley of wild grass and sage, the horseman begins riding toward the truck, four sheepdogs racing behind him. It is Dan Chee, an 85-year-old medicine man.
Chee pulls up his horse, Sheepherder, and dismounts smoothly. Turquoise earrings stand out against his deeply lined face and neck. Wisps of white hair escape from a weathered corduroy hat. He wears a paisley shirt, brown denim pants and tennis shoes. 
The two men embrace and exchange greetings. Chee addresses MacDonald as naat'aanii, the traditional Navajo term for leader. MacDonald respectfully refers to Chee as ''uncle.''
In the warm October sun, the medicine man, keeper of the ancient ways of the Holy People, and the naat'aanii, four-time chairman of the Navajo, find themselves together in crisis.
Chee lives according to the Beauty Way of the Dine - ''the People'' - as the Navajo call themselves. Adhering to tradition, he ''walks in beauty,'' living in harmony between the four sacred Navajo mountains, under what the people call naats'eelit. The word means ''the rainbow that stretches over us and protects us.'' It also means ''sovereignty.'' But the land where he lives, the place he considers his church, is claimed by both the Navajo and Hopi tribes. If a pending Hopi lawsuit, claiming up to 3.5 million acres, succeeds in Federal court, the old medicine man could be forced from his home.
Last year, MacDonald, accompanied by reporters, helped build a new house for Chee when his mud and cedar hogan began to fall apart. The highly publicized act defied a Federal court order banning new construction on the disputed lands without written permission from the Hopi.
A grateful Chee blessed his leader with corn pollen. Now he says: ''The plants that are here, the animals that graze on these grasses, the things that are good for human beings to live on -that is what Chairman MacDonald protects. He watches over these things. That is why I love him.'' But Peter MacDonald, stripped of power by his own tribal council, charged with 107 criminal counts by a special tribal prosecutor, facing possible indictment by a Federal grand jury, is now likened to a corrupt dictator by many of his own people. The man once known as the most powerful Indian in America must now find solace in the unshakeable faith of his most traditional followers - people like Dan Chee, who see MacDonald as the keeper of naats'eelit, the guardian of sovereignty, the man who understands the old ways far better than a younger generation of Navajo leaders.
''Some ask me,'' says Chee, '' 'Why are you supporting Chairman MacDonald? He's a liar and a thief.' And I say to them, 'I know MacDonald. He has done a lot for me.' And they say, 'Suppose they put MacDonald in jail?' And I say to them, 'If they put him in jail, I will follow him to jail.' ''
FOR NEARLY 15 YEARS, PETER MACDONALD CONTROLLED the destiny of the 200,000 Navajos, America's largest Indian tribe. As tribal chairman, elected to an unprecedented four terms, he governed a reservation of 17 million acres - slightly larger than West Virginia. The land takes up much of northeastern Arizona (the Navajo seat of government is in Window Rock) and spills over into Utah and New Mexico.
In many ways, the reservation resembles an emerging third-world nation. Nearly half the people live below the poverty line. About a third are out of work. Rates of alcoholism and suicide are alarmingly high. And with a median age of 19, combined with a birth rate double the national average, economic development has become the tribe's top priority.
Across the reservation, pressures on the land increase. By tradition the Navajo are sheepherders, but there's no longer enough grazing land for everyone. Only one in six Navajo families holds a permit to graze sheep. Housing projects, once known only to urban Indians, are now common across the land. For many families, living in the traditional way has become impossible.
For a time, it looked as though Peter MacDonald might be the leader to bring his people out of poverty, underdevelopment and dependence on the Federal Government. With his deep sense of Navajo tradition, a spellbinding speaking style and a strong belief in the free-enterprise system, he came to power in 1971 amid a national surge of Indian pride, a populist Republican ready to tangle with the United States Government.
MacDonald pledged to rid the Navajo tribe of the shackles of Federal paternalism and build an independent Navajo nation free of Government interference. He promised to gain greater tribal control over coal, oil and gas reserves, assert Navajo rights to tax corporations doing business on the reservation and cut through Federal regulations hindering development on Navajo land. Always, he saved his harshest criticism for his lifelong nemesis, the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
Today, MacDonald is awash in charges of corruption and bribery. During hearings before the United States Senate last February, Navajo and non-Indian contractors testified that they gave thousands of dollars in bribes to the chairman in exchange for guaranteed work on the reservation. His son, Peter MacDonald Jr., told of attempts to cover up a scheme in which his father allegedly helped defraud the tribe of up to $7.2 million.
The irony could not be more complete. Indian leaders across the country expected the hearings to focus solely on allegations of fraud against the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Instead, they broadened out and helped bring down one of the agency's severest critics.
Less than two weeks after the Senate testimony, the Navajo Tribal Council, which MacDonald had dominated for more than three terms, relieved the chairman of his administrative duties. When MacDonald refused to leave office, he precipitated a five-month crisis in the Navajo government, culminating in a violent confrontation in late July that left two Navajos dead.
If found guilty of the bribery and corruption charges against him, MacDonald faces up to 15 years in jail and fines of up to $60,000. (As this magazine went to press, a trial date had not been set.) He has been hit with civil lawsuits in the millions of dollars, and a Federal grand jury may bring additional charges.
MacDonald calls the charges ''hogwash,'' saying others, jealous of his success, ''are spending millions of dollars in an effort to crucify me. All they want to do is silence people like me who speak out against those who are trying to erode tribal sovereignty.''
But other Navajos say Peter MacDonald, using sovereignty as a political shield and the Bureau of Indian Affairs as a bogyman, weakened tribal government while enriching himself. MacDonald, say his critics, brought about his own hard fall from power when he strayed too far from the Navajo way.
''The Navajo saying is that when you become less of a Navajo, you're going to suffer more,'' says Daniel Peaches, who managed MacDonald's first campaign for the tribal chairmanship, and recently oversaw a study to establish checks and balances in the tribal government. ''If you cease to live the way of the Navajos, you're going to become less human. You will have less moral strength.
''You will steal, you will hurt people, you're going to have no respect for the feelings of others. And I think MacDonald, by abusing the trust and the power of his office, made a big leap toward that. He took advantage of the culture of the people.''
P ETER MACDONALD was born on open range on a goatskin, in the midst of a sheep drive, in the spring of 1928. His family was moving wagons, horses and a herd of 2,000 sheep through the Four Corners area, to their home camp at Teec Nos Pos, Ariz. His parents named him Hoshkaisith: ''fierce'' or ''warrior-like,'' or, literally, ''He Who Clasps With Power.''
As young shepherds, Peter and his brothers and sisters would move the herd through the wild pastures and deep red washes near Teec Nos Pos. In the afternoons, with the sheep resting in a meadow, they would make small horses out of sticks and race them, or mold cows and wagons from the fine red clay in the washes.
Peter listened to the elders tell stories of the brutal Long Walk of the 1860's. They'd tell how Red Shirt, known to the white man as Kit Carson, forced the people to walk hundreds of miles to a prison camp in New Mexico. Peter's great-grandmother, forced to make the Long Walk as a teen-ager, would tell the stories of Red Shirt's cavalry troops: how sick Navajos, too weak to go on, were shot and left to die; how pregnant women, slow afoot, were stabbed with bayonets.
When Peter was still very young, another disaster befell the people. Off the reservation, the country was gripped by the Depression. In Navajo country, a long drought threatened the livestock. The people said the land looked tired. The Government said it was overgrazed. Officials from the Bureau of Indian Affairs came from Washington and ordered Navajo families to cut their herds drastically. Good, healthy animals, at the center of the people's economy and culture, were shot by Government range agents. The boy watched as his family's sheep were bulldozed into the earth.
He was sent to school at age 6, and given his last name by the Government teachers at Teec Nos Pos. It was at school that he began to hear that Indians were inferior. The Bureau of Indian Affairs teachers told the children to abandon their Navajo religion. They ridiculed the Navajo customs, the ceremonials, the Navajo diet of mutton stew, fry bread and blue corn meal mush. They punished the Navajo children for speaking their own language.
At age 12, Peter quit school and spent a year apprenticed to his grandfather as a medicine man. Then he sought work in the lumberyards of Dolores, Colo. It was 1941. ''Dirty Indian, lazy Indian,'' the foreman would taunt, as the boy feverishly shoveled wood pulp into a cart bound for the railroad. ''I lived through that,'' he remembers. '''You're a drunken Indian. You're a no-good Indian. You're a stinking Indian'.'' In 1944, at age 15, he joined the Marines, where he became part of an elite group known as the Navajo Code Talkers - the Pacific radio communication force that used the Navajo language in a code the Japanese could not decipher.
In boot camp at San Diego, a young private asked MacDonald if he could read a letter. He thought it was another taunt intended for the ''dumb Indian.'' He read the letter aloud. The next day, the soldier asked MacDonald to write a response. ''I always thought, up to that point, that white men were born already knowing how to write and read,'' he remembers.
''It really changed my attitude. I decided, hey, these guys don't have any secret endowment, as they said they do. They're not any better than I am. I felt very proud.'' At that point, he thought, ''I'm superior now.''
''I'll never forget that episode. Because from that day on, I never bowed down to anybody.''
After the war, MacDonald enrolled at the University of Oklahoma, earning a degree in electrical engineering in 1957. From there, he went to work for Hughes Aircraft, where he became part of a team that designed the guidance system for the Polaris nuclear missile.
Then in 1963, as the War on Poverty got under way, MacDonald came home to the reservation. Taking a leave of absence from Hughes, he was hired to direct a $900,000 annual program, the Office of Navajo Economic Opportunity (O.N.E.O.).
The Bureau of Indian Affairs wanted to manage the money. MacDonald wanted it sent directly from Washington to O.N.E.O. and its local programs. MacDonald won the bitter fight with his old enemy, and set about building a political base. As his annual budget grew to $12 million, the name Peter MacDonald became synonymous with jobs, new homes, power lines and local services.
Shortly after beginning work with O.N.E.O., MacDonald went to see Navajo government in action at the Tribal Council chambers in Window Rock. Two councilmen were engaged in heated debate. The Bureau of Indian Affairs representative, Glen Landbloom, pounded on the podium and told the councilmen to stop arguing. Then, MacDonald remembers, ''He said, 'If you guys continue to act like children, I'm going to throw every one of you out of this council chamber. I'm going to put a padlock on it. And I'm not going to let you back in until you learn to behave like adults!' ''
The councilmen stopped arguing and sat down. MacDonald was aghast.
''This Landbloom guy was treating the council like it was back in 1700! I couldn't get over it. So I said to myself, 'One of these days, it's not going to be like that.' '' MacDonald sent word to Hughes Aircraft: He wasn't coming back.
Seven years later, Peter MacDonald was elected tribal chairman. Before taking office, he met with the local Bureau of Indian Affairs official and insisted that the agency give the tribe title to the council chambers building. If not, he vowed, the council would hold its sessions outside. The tribe was given title to the building. MacDonald's assistants changed the locks.
The new chairman, presiding over his first session of the Navajo Tribal Council in 1971, fixed his gaze on the Bureau of Indian Affairs official in attendance. ''If I hear any outbursts from you or your staff,'' he warned, ''I will have our police escort you from these chambers. And you won't be let back in until you promise to behave like adults!''
Eighteen years later, sitting in the Sierra outside a hogan and corral near Black Mesa, MacDonald smiles at the memory. It's a story he has told many times. Like the tales of his early life, it has come to resemble the parables he uses with such effect when speaking to the traditional people.
PETER MACDONALD's first years in office were marked by frequent speeches pledging greater self-determination for the Navajos, new measures to assert Navajo control over reservation schools, hospitals and natural resources, and repeated trips to Washington to lobby for a greater share of the Federal budget.
''Those were the days of nation-building,'' he says.
In pursuing the seemingly contradictory goals of greater Navajo sovereignty and increased Federal support, the chairman began to forge what might be called a ''sovereign dependent nation.'' Navajo leaders explain this apparent contradiction by pointing out that the Treaty of 1868, which ended the Navajo incarceration at Fort Sumner, requires the Government to fulfill a trust responsibility for a distinct, independent people, in perpetuity.
MacDonald also began carving out a role in Republican politics. During his first term, he served on the Committee to Re-elect the President. He was scheduled to give a nominating speech for Richard Nixon at the 1972 convention in Miami. But then he began what became a legendary feud with Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona.
In 1972, Congress turned its attention to a major land dispute between the Navajo and Hopi tribes, involving 1.8 million acres claimed by both tribes. The Hopis argued that the Navajos had been encroaching on their land since the end of the incarceration at Fort Sumner. The Navajos protested that thousands of tribe members would be forced to move if the Hopis prevailed.
MacDonald met with Democratic Presidential candidate George McGovern, then chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Indian Affairs, who expressed support for the Navajo position.
Two weeks before the Republican convention, MacDonald said he might have to back McGovern for President. He was dropped from the list of speakers. ''Goldwater was infuriated,'' says Jerry Kammer, author of ''The Second Long Walk,'' a highly acclaimed book about the Navajo-Hopi conflict. ''He had arranged this, and here's MacDonald suddenly flirting with Nixon's opponent.''
Near the end of MacDonald's first term, Senator Goldwater gave his support to the Hopi side, now expressed in pending legislation, in the long-brewing land dispute. MacDonald fought back, enlisting the help of the AFL-CIO as Washington lobbyists against the bill.
But with Goldwater solidly behind the Hopi tribe, the law passed in late 1974. It authorized one of the largest forced relocations in North American history, involving some 7,000 Navajos so far. The gulf between MacDonald and Goldwater deepened.
''There's no question MacDonald's strategy backfired,'' says Kammer. ''It spelled tragedy for thousands of traditional Navajo people. And it set the stage for more trouble for MacDonald.''
In 1976, a year after MacDonald began his second term, Federal officials began looking into tribal operations. At Goldwater's request, the General Accounting Office began an audit of tribal finances. Late in the year, a Federal grand jury indicted MacDonald. He was charged with filing false travel vouchers in connection with an agreement to erect power lines on the reservation.
MacDonald, represented by F. Lee Bailey, repeatedly charged that the prosecution was a political vendetta by Goldwater. Others shared his suspicions. Ken Fields, one of the prosecutors in the 1976 case, now says: ''I was extremely uncomfortable about that. I've always wondered if we'' - the prosecutors -''were dupes.'' The Federal judge found so little evidence to convict MacDonald that he issued a directed verdict of acquittal. (Repeated attempts to reach Goldwater for comment were unsuccessful.) For the chairman, the incident became an important political weapon in his lifelong fight against the Government. It may have helped him win election to a third term in 1978. But he says the incident left him deeply bitter. ''When that happened to me in 1976,'' he says, ''I lost complete faith in the American justice system.''
IN JULY 1987, ON A warm afternoon in Window Rock, a confidential source slipped a two-page, typewritten memo to Betty Reid, a newspaper reporter. It was seven months into Peter MacDonald's fourth term.
Reid had been covering the reservation since graduating from journalism school at the University of Colorado in Boulder in 1985. She was part of a team of Navajo reporters who worked on the first Indian-run daily paper in the country, The Navajo Times Today.
She'd covered the 1986 election campaign between MacDonald and Peterson Zah, the reformer who had defeated MacDonald four years earlier amid frequent charges of greed, cronyism and corruption.
Reid had heard MacDonald's many promises in the 1986 campaign: a house for every Navajo veteran, a guaranteed college scholarship for every high school graduate, a minimum of 1,000 new jobs per year. These promises of hope, unbelievable to many Navajos, were often presented as moving parables, in Navajo, to the traditional people.
''It was just amazing,'' remembers Reid, who was raised in the traditional community of Bodaway, in the western part of the Navajo reservation. ''People hung on his every word. He has this gift. If you listen to him speak in Navajo, it's incredible.'' Zah, perceived by his critics as well-meaning but ineffective, lost to MacDonald by less than a percentage point.
Reid had covered MacDonald's lavish fourth inauguration, watching as a string of white limousines cruised by, as the police snipers, perched atop grandstands at the tribal fairgrounds, surveyed the crowd. Navajo critics who had long ridiculed ''Big Mac'' (a former vice chairman was called ''Quarter Pounder'') now began to deride MacDonald's ''imperial chairmanship,'' comparing him to Ferdinand Marcos and Manuel Noriega.
Reid had also been part of the exodus from the Navajo Times five weeks after the inauguration, when MacDonald shut down the vigorously independent paper and dismissed its employees. Now, five months later, she was working for the Gallup Independent.
By the summer of 1987, it was common for Betty Reid to receive notes and tips. She had a lot of sources close to the chairman. She also knew many people who, over the years, had developed grave doubts about him.
The note came from one of these people. It was about Big Boquillas, a 491,000-acre ranch west of Flagstaff that the tribe had agreed to purchase for $33.4 million a few weeks earlier. According to the memo, the timing of the transaction was peculiar. It took place at 9:55 A.M. on July 9. At 9:50 that same morning, someone else had bought the ranch for only $26.2 million. That was a difference of $7.2 million in five minutes. On July 23, Reid called the Coconino County assessor's office. The facts checked out. She sat down to write. The lead story in the July 24 edition of the Gallup Independent announced the opening of the long-awaited Navajo Nation Economic Summit, which MacDonald hoped would initiate an unprecedented era of development. Sponsored by MacDonald and United States Senators Pete Domenici and Dennis DeConcini, the two-day meeting would be attended by five senators, four congressmen, three governors, the head of the Bureau of Indian Afairs, tribal officials, and executives from major corporations. President Reagan was to deliver a special message by videotape.
The same day, in a single column beside the summit story, the Independent ran a short piece under Betty Reid's byline about a ranch purchase. To many out-of-town journalists covering the summit, the article seemed of little importance. But for MacDonald, standing before prominent political leaders, government officials, chief executive officers and the national press, this was the moment when things began to unravel.
In the coming months, as new revelations came to light, the Big Boquillas Ranch controversy - immediately dubbed ''Bo-Gate'' - became the main topic of conversation in Window Rock.
Navajos soon learned that Byron (Bud) Brown, who, along with an associate named Tom Tracy, had sold the ranch to the tribe, was a close friend of Peter MacDonald's. It was reported that Ninibah Cahn, director of the tribe's Office of Navajo Land Administration, had ordered tribal appraisers to inflate the price of the land from between $50 and $63 an acre to $68 an acre, the final purchase price. The sale also appeared to have gone forward with a speed that bewildered tribal officials.
''I kept thinking, 'What's the big rush?' '' remembers Stanley M. Pollack, an attorney in the tribe's justice department.
Pollack, a graduate of the University of Colorado Law School, had been hired by the tribe during the Zah administration to work on energy and water law. On the afternoon of May 22, 1987, he was summoned to Ninibah Cahn's office and told to review the contract for the purchase of the Big Boquillas Ranch. It was a complex document; Pollack felt the process shouldn't be rushed.
In the evening, MacDonald called. ''What's the problem?'' the chairman asked irritably. It was a complicated purchase, Pollack explained. But MacDonald was growing impatient. ''You know what I want!'' Pollack remembers hearing him say. MacDonald's impatience may have been fueled by the presence of Bud Brown and Tom Tracy in Window Rock, where the two men were waiting for a $500,000 nonrefundable down payment.
Around 10 P.M., after an uncomfortable Pollack prepared an option agreement to buy the ranch, Brown and Tracy got their money. If allegations are true, MacDonald had just helped the two men flip the ranch for a profit of $7.2 million.
It didn't take long for the shock waves from ''Bo-Gate'' to reach Washington. In early 1988, a special Senate committee had been organized to consider holding hearings on the Federal Government's relation with Indian tribes. The primary impetus for the hearings was an October 1987 series in The Arizona Republic that had detailed extensive fraud involving the Bureau of Indian Affairs and energy companies.
But by the fall of 1988, a major focus of the investigation had shifted to Peter MacDonald's problems. The committee received authorization to monitor the chairman's activities with a surveillance van and telephone taps.
Some staff members were furious. Four members of the energy team quit in protest over the changed focus of the probe. ''It was the Big Easy,'' says one veteran of Congressional investigations familiar with the Senate probe. ''The chief counsel was only interested in a big hit. This was Watergate in Indian country. The media were all primed. But it overshadowed everything else. And it only made the Indians look corrupt.''
On Feb. 7, Peter MacDonald became national front-page news, as contractors at the Senate hearings described in detail the cash and gifts they had given him in exchange for work on the reservation: Free limousine service at MacDonald's 1987 inauguration; a private jet flight to the graduation of his daughter at Harvard; all-expense trips to Hawaii and Las Vegas; and stacks of $100 bills, which the chairman allegedly stuffed in his pocket.
Bud Brown, who became an undercover informant for the committee in exchange for immunity, described an agreement to pay the chairman between $500,000 and $750,000 from the profits in the Big Boquillas Ranch deal. (At the time, MacDonald had allegedly received a BMW and cash, for a total value of about $125,000.) The committee heard extensive sections of an undercover tape, made by Brown, of a ploy to cover up the agreement through the perjured testimony of Brown and the chairman's son, Peter MacDonald Jr., known as Rocky.
Testifying under immunity, Rocky described the cover-up plan to the committee. He said his father used a code word whenever he wanted another payment from Brown.
''What was that code word?'' Ken Ballen, the committee's chief counsel, asked Rocky, as Senator DeConcini and others looked on.
'' 'Golf balls,' '' Rocky responded. ''A golf ball was approximately $1,000.''
Later, Ballen asked the chairman's son why he had chosen to participate in the cover-up.
''Because I love my father,'' he told the committee.
''THEY USED MY OWN baby against me, my people,'' MacDonald said in a speech broadcast in Navajo to his traditional supporters across the reservation.
''They said they were going to investigate the B.I.A. . . . and yet they lied. Instead they have been investigating me. The reports of the conspiracy - they are lies, my people. This you should remember.''
It was less than a week after the Senate testimony. After word spread that MacDonald's own son had testified against him, support for the chairman began dwindling to a hard core of traditional people. In Window Rock, former supporters of MacDonald were calling for his resignation. Opponents of the chairman began demonstrating outside the council chambers, holding golf balls aloft. Later, they wore buttons on their lapels that read: ''Mutton Yes! Golf Balls No!''
In a confidential Valentine's Day memo to the Tribal Council, Navajo Attorney General Michael P. Upshaw concluded that the Big Boquillas Ranch purchase represented a ''major fraud.'' In danger, he warned, was ''the sovereignty of the Navajo nation.''
The week after the hearings, the 88-member tribal council, once under the tight rule of the chairman, split into two factions. Supporters of each faction gathered in the road outside the chairman's office. Heated words flew back and forth.
Daniel Peaches, the tribe's deputy director of legislative affairs, recalls walking into the chairman's office. He looked outside at the demonstrators. ''What if they get into a fight?'' he asked. ''If you allow people to hurt each other, then you've lost control of this whole thing.''
MacDonald looked up from his desk. ''And he says to me,'' Peaches recalls, '' 'So be it. Let them fight. Let them hurt each other.'
''At that point,'' Peaches says, ''I figured he's more interested in himself than the welfare of his own people.''
AT 8:50 P.M. ON FEB. 17, 1989, after four days of bitter dispute in the council chambers, a 49-member majority of the Navajo Tribal Council placed Peter MacDonald on administrative leave. It was a vote of monumental importance for a council the chairman had dominated during nearly all of his 14 years in office.
But MacDonald refused to accept the council's decision. His stand touched off five months of dispute that put the tribal government to its greatest test of independence since the early 1920's, when the Bureau of Indian Affairs first formed the Tribal Council as a means of approving oil and gas leases.
In March, an interim chairman and vice chairman were appointed by a deeply divided council. The council then split into two factions. MacDonald's supporters believed the government had been stolen from them, arguing that there was no provision in the tribal code for removing the chairman by less than a two-thirds vote. (The tribe has no constitution.) They occupied the lavish office suites he had once had redecorated at a cost of $700,000 and filled with heavy wooden furniture (critics referred to the offices as the Mahogany Palace). From there, on MacDonald's instructions, they issued tribal mandates. An interim government issued opposing decrees from its spartan offices nearby.
On April 18, after a tense scene outside the chairman's office, the Area Director for the Bureau of Indian Affairs, James H. Stevens, considered calling in Federal police from Albuquerque. ''The situation was moving so quickly that it might be best to take over the station,'' he wrote in a chronological record for that date.
On May 24, MacDonald's supporters were forcibly removed from the chairman's offices by tribal police. For the next two months, Window Rock was calm.
On July 20, however, after several days of delivering fiery speeches across the reservation, Peter MacDonald wrote a memo to his former chief of police, ordering him to ''reassume the position of Chief of the Navajo Police,'' and to ''assist with the orderly restoration . . . of the Navajo Government.''
Supporters of the fallen chairman gathered at the tribe's administration and finance building. Some, claiming they had been roughed up during the eviction from the chairman's offices, carried baseball bats and two-by-twos for ''protection.'' When a Navajo policeman arrived, they tied him up and took his gun. More police came. The crowd broke into groups of 10 to 15 people. ''They were hitting the police with sticks,'' remembers Marley Shebala, a Navajo reporter with the Farmington (N.M.) Daily Times. ''The crowd was in a frenzy.''
Police drew their weapons and held them aloft. Undeterred, the MacDonald supporters advanced. Someone - no one can say for certain who - fired a shot. Then the police began firing. A moment later, two supporters of Peter MacDonald lay dying.
SINCE THEIR ARRIVAL in the American Southwest centuries ago, Navajos have demonstrated an astonishing resilience. They survived war, hunger, incarceration, livestock reduction and forced relocation. They incorporated sheep and horses from the Spaniards, becoming expert weavers in the process. From the Pueblos, they learned pottery-making; later, from the Mexicans, they learned silversmithing. In this century, Navajos have taken to pickup trucks, blue jeans, satellite dishes and majority-rule government while staying rooted in ceremony and a strong sense of identity.
At his best, some time ago, Peter MacDonald personified this Navajo culture in transition. He combined deep roots in the culture, and an ability to incorporate the modern world in a keenly Navajo way. He used his gifts to inspire his people with a new sense of pride and helped make them a political force to be reckoned with.
Today, driving across the reservation, trying to rally support from his traditional followers, MacDonald thinks about his legacy. ''I look at some shopping center or some tribal building or some paved road, and I think about how that wasn't here before, when I returned to the reservation,'' he muses. ''I wonder if the people know that. I wonder if they even realize what it was like in 1963.''
At Dan Chee's new house, the house built in part by Peter MacDonald, the front door faces east, in the traditional Navajo way. It looks out upon a vast open valley cut only by a dirt road. On a hill beyond the road, the medicine man still grazes a few cattle and sheep.
To the north, just out of sight, a railroad brings coal from a big strip mine at Black Mesa to a power plant on Lake Powell. From there, transmission lines stretch from huge towers across the reservation, bypassing Navajo hogans on their way to Phoenix, Las Vegas and Southern California.
Some afternoons, Chee hikes a steep incline to the top of the Peak Where the Wildcats Stretch. There, he prays for the people's government to be whole again, for the dispute over his land to end, and for his way of life to continue.
''I always think, what words and thoughts do we use to make it right again,'' Chee says in soft, low Navajo tones. ''We have men and women, children and grandchildren. We want good for them. We want good food, sheep, cattle, horses and employment. We want to live our dreams. Instead, everyone is worried about what's going to happen next.''

HEADLINE: A Look at Fuji's Expanding U.S. Role

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: RYE

 BODY:
WHEN Osamu Inoue was an undergraduate majoring in business administration at Kobe University in Japan, he set his sights on a career that would take him beyond the borders of Japan into international markets.
''I very much wanted to travel and see something of the rest of the world,'' he said, ''so I felt I was very fortunate when I graduated to get a job in the export division of Fuji Film.''
That was 32 years ago, when Fuji first entered the North American market. A year-and-a-half ago, Mr. Inoue, became head of Fuji Photo Film U.S.A., which is based in Elmsford. And this month he delivered his first talk - ''Fuji, U.S.A.: An American Company With a Japanese Name'' - to members of the World Trade Club of Westchester at a luncheon meeting at the Rye Town Hilton. 
The World Trade Club is the international trade forum of the Westchester County Association, a business group.
For Mr. Inoue, who is called Sam by friends and acquaintances, his promotion to the post of Fuji's top executive in the United States brought his second tour here.
 
Steps Up the Ladder
He began working in the United States in 1964 at Fuji U.S.A., marketing industrial products. In 1971 he returned to Japan and has held various positions there and in West Germany. He was made general manager of Fuji's Dusseldorf operations in 1979, a post he held until 1984, when he returned to Japan as manager of the export sales division for consumer products.
''I am very glad to be back in the U.S.A. getting reacquainted with the many friends I met here,'' he said. ''What is especially gratifying is that when I left the United States in 1971, Fuji U.S.A. was a small company with perhaps two dozen employees. Now we have about 850 employees and many branch offices in the United States and we are still growing.''
Fuji U.S.A., Mr. Inoue explained, is the United States subsidiary of Fuji Photo Film Company of Tokyo, the second-largest manufacturer of photo-sensitized materials in the world, outranked only by Kodak. Its products are sold in more than 120 countries. Last year Fuji had worldwide sales of $6.9 billion, with two-thirds of sales made in Japan.
''It is important to note, especially in these days of concern about the balance of trade and the openness of Japanese markets to American products,'' Mr. Inoue said, ''that our American competitor does significant business in Japan. In the industries in which we compete, the markets are truly open, and free and fair competition benefits consumers and end-users of our products. The competition drives innovation while curbing inflation.''
Until recently, Mr. Inoue said, almost all of Fuji's products were developed and manufactured in Japan. But Fuji recently established manufacturing operations within the markets its serves.
This year, he said, Fuji's first U.S. factory, in Greenwood, S.C., began producing pre-sensitized plates used in offset printing. And in a joint partnership with the BASF Corporation, Fuji U.S.A. recently began manufacturing floppy disks in a factory in Bedford, Mass.
In addition, Fuji U.S.A. has acquired the worldwide manufacturing and sales operations of Olin Hunt, which includes manufacturing and sales plants in the United States.
 
Local Benefits Cited
''All our American factories employ American workers, use American machinery and raw materials and contribute to the local economy and communities we are in,'' Mr. Inoue emphasized, adding that in each country outside Japan almost all Fuji employees were local citizens.
''For example,'' he said, ''in Elmsford we have almost 180 people and only 20 are Japanese. In keeping with Fuji's philosophy, the heads of all our marketing divisions and almost all of our support departments are American. When the factory in South Carolina is fully operational, it will employ more than 140 Americans and seven Japanese.''
Since the job of Fuji U.S.A. is primarily to market Fuji products to American consumers and businesses, Mr. Inoue noted, advertising and promotion is handled by American firms, geared to the local market.
Fuji began its United States operations in 1955 by selling industrial products through American distributors. In 1965 Fuji Photo Film was incorporated in New York State and by the early 1970's, Mr. Inoue said, ''we began marketing some of our products, including color film, directly. Separate divisions were formed to market each product.''
 
Move to County Discussed
In 1986, the company moved from its original headquarters in the Empire State Building in Manhattan to Elmsford.
''We made the move to Westchester for the same reasons other companies move out of Manhattan,'' said Thomas H. Shay, director of corporate communications at Fuji U.S.A. ''We needed more room to expand and Westchester was an easier commute for most of our employees. We also felt the county was a better place to recruit the type of high-level employees we'd need in the future.''
When asked if working for the American subsidiary of a Japanese company differed from working for an American employer, Mr. Shay, who has spent 18 years with Fuji, grew thoughtful.
''Salaries and benefits are competitive with those of every other company,'' he said, ''but most of the two dozen original American employees who started when I started with Fuji are still on the job. The Japanese nationals that come here are rotated in and out, but there is almost no turnover in the American staff. The reason, I think, is that we feel valued. We all feel that we've played an important part in the growth of the organization and we have a real interest in it. There's a sense of pride.''
 
Role of Japanese Workers
At the Elmsford headquarters, Japanese employees primarily act as marketing or technical coordinators, relaying information between American employees and their counterparts in Japan, Mr. Inoue said.
''Our marketing programs are designed in America for Americans by Americans,'' he said, ''but I believe our success is largely due to our ability to continue to offer American consumers new high-quality products.''
''Fuji's big growth spurt in the U.S. came after we sponsored the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics,'' Mr. Shay noted. ''The Olympics really put us on the map. As the official film of the Games, Fuji caught the attention of millions of people for the first time.''
In Westchester, Mr. Shay said, Fuji helps sponsor concert and museum programs and supports dozens of local civic and charitable organizations. ''We had felt a warm welcome in Westchester and we want to do our best to repay the kindness,'' Mr. Inoue said.
''We try to demonstrate that Fuji U.S.A. is truly an American company,'' he said. ''Not only will 1,500 American employees be working for various Fuji subsidies in the U.S., but we also support other American jobs through advertising and the magazines and the networks where we place our ads, and at so many other places along the channels of distribution.''
Mr. Inoue and his wife, Takako, live in Harrison. They are parents of two grown sons: one works in Japan and the other in West Germany.

LENGTH: 1569 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q & A: LIEUT. COL. DAVID R. WALLACE;
'They're Sold on Patriotism'

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DAVID R. WALLACE of New Haven, a lieutenant colonel in the Army and a Vietnam combat pilot decorated seven times for heroism, has had a new challenge for the past year, as the Army's chief recruiter in Connecticut.
Lieut. Col. Wallace has just reached the halfway mark in his two-year assignment as the Recruiting Battalion Commander for Connecticut and western Massachusetts, and in that time the number of recruits increased to 1,800 from 1,260. The percentage of high school graduates at the top of their class who join the Army also increased, the colonel said. And his region is now 26th in recruitment out of 55 regions nationally, up from last place a year ago.
In an interview at his office in New Haven, Lieut. Col. Wallace talked about the problems of recruiting in Connecticut. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q. Has the image of the armed forces changed? 
A. Absolutely. Our low point was probably during the latter parts, or just after, the war in Vietnam. We came back to an Army that was demoralized. No one wanted to come into it. From that low point, we started building, step by step, first at the officer corps, and then to our senior noncommissioned officers, and finally down to our enlisted personnel.
We set very high standards, particularly starting about 1980, which was our turning point. In 1980, about 54 percent of our soldiers were in the lower mental categories. By lower mental categories, I mean someone who on a test where the top score is 100 scores 27 or below. We now have that down to about 4 percent, sometimes 7 percent.
The other thing is, only about half the kids in the early 1980's had a high school diploma. Today, 91, 92, 93 percent of our kids have a diploma. We are getting the winners in our society. A young man or woman who drops out of high school, even in school there is competition, and that's one more gate they didn't go through. We have more enlisted soldiers today with four years of college, or a degree, than we have enlisted soldiers without a high school diploma.
Q. How has your first year gone?
A. For the first time in the battalion's 14 years, in 1989 we not only met our mission, but we met our mission in every category all across the boards. We were one of about only 10 battalions in the country to do that. It was a good feeling. There are 55 battalions, and I can tell you that the entire Army Recruiting Command met its goal in fiscal year 1989. Obviously, some are doing better than others.
Since January, for what we call the quality market, we've been No. 1 in the country. We are graded on the number of quality recruits we put into the service, as opposed to volume. We could open up our doors today, and in two days' time fill every vacancy we have. But for either physical or moral or mental reasons we just can't use them.
Q. Why has Connecticut been such a tough recruiting environment traditionally?
A. I think it stems from two things. Patriotism here is just as good as where I come from in Arkansas. But there's low unemployment. When only 2.9 percent of the population is unemployed, you don't have that hunger to get out. So the recruiting force has to be more, I hesitate to use the word aggressive, but we have to get out and let people see what we have to offer. The other thing is salaries here are pretty good. We'll be more of a golden handcuff.
Q. Why have you been successful as a recruiter?
A. I have serving with me the best noncommissioned officers in the country, and I have delegated to them the responsibility and authority to do their job. I'm one guy, and I'm from Arkansas and I'm not real smart, but I've got a bunch of smart guys working for me. And if you sit around and listen to those 200 guys come up with good ideas, and get a bunch of them together once in a while and let those good ideas bubble up, and then implement those - that's what we've been doing, and that's what's been working.
There's a stereotype of one guy giving out all the orders and maybe not knowing what's going on, but I've never been in that environment. You know the book ''The One-Minute Manager?'' That's the kind of guy I've worked for all my life.
Q. What types of goals do you have to meet as a recruiter?
A. We have about five or six different categories. One is a total number. The bulk of them will score in the upper half on the mental tests. Roughly 50 to 60 percent of my overall mission will be males in the upper mental categories. Probably 10 to 15 percent of my mission will be the upper mental categories of females. We get more female mission here than some of the other battalions because we seem to do real well here.
The rest of the mission falls into the mental categories that are kind of middle of the road. We have no lower mental category mission. In fact, the entire country was just cut off last month. I could not put a non-high school graduate in.
Q. As a recruiter, what would you think about mandatory military service for all teen-agers, as is required in some countries?
A. We have, for most of the history of our country, had a volunteer Army. The draft we always talk about is really, when you look at a long period of time, only been in place for a very short period of time. I personally think we're better off having people volunteer to serve their country. We're a free society, and we're probably freer than any society that's been around this old world for a long time. I don't think we should do anything to infringe on that freedom.
Q. Do you expect much of an impact after the recent announcements of defense cutbacks in the Soviet Union because the threat of war with the United States is at a 45-year low?
A. It's too soon to tell. But I will say, I think it's great. The guys who want peace the worst are the soldiers who went to combat. I don't ever want to go to war again. One was enough for a lifetime. I don't ever want my son or my daughter to go to war. I think it's great the way it's going, and I hope it keeps going.
Q. Do recruits today favor active duty over the reserves?
A. Active is most favored because of the packages we offer, but a strong second is the reserve program. A lot of women in their first year of college are interested in medical training, so they spend one summer going through basic training, and then they have a part-time job. In October, we set a record for the number of reserves put in in a single month out of this office.
Q. Do you get a lot of young people who think of the service as the start of a career?
A. I don't think you identify who a career soldier is until his or her third or fourth year. When I came in I wasn't sure I was going to be a career soldier. What we're seeing mostly are young men and young women who are looking for ways to improve their life. The typical high school graduate goes into a service industry, such as fast food. After a year or two years, they take a look at that and wonder where they're headed.
We can offer a young man or woman $25,200 for college, or we can repay their student loans. We can give them up to an $8,000 bonus. We're one of the few services that can guarantee you in writing a specific job. I can promise Mike Jones that he will be a military policeman.
The other person we see, interestingly enough, are people who are affluent. These people look at the $25,000 we offer for college, and they really don't need it. We get more Airborne Rangers out of that group of kids than anywhere else in the country. They're sold on patriotism, and the fact that they will have a challenge to meet for three years.
Q. High school enrollments have been dropping since the mid-1970s, and are expected to drop for the next few years as well. What does that mean to recruiters?
A. We have been fighting the declining market now for the last five years, and we're winning it. We're winning it not because we're superstars, but because we've got packages we can offer people that are attractive. I think the declining market problem has just about bottomed out.
Q. What recruiting techniques work best in an affluent, low-unemployment area like Connecticut?
A. Getting out and talking to people. You go everywhere you can. There are three types of prospecting we do; telecommunications, get on the phone and call them; go out and meet them face to face, out in the malls and the schools, and the third kind is referrals. Now referrals are the best kind. If you're a good recruiter and you have a satisfied customer, he'll bring more people to you.
Q. Has your budget for recruiting been increasing to help you meet the special challenges of recruiting during prosperity?
A. It's gone down. What it costs me today to put a young man in the service is about $2,200. Twelve years ago, it cost $1,900, so if you play inflation in, we're working with a lot less. But the difference is 12 years ago, who wanted to go in. Now, our image has turned around.
Q. What are the most popular choices of careers for teen-agers signing up these days?
A. The career choices don't center around jobs so much, such as M.P.s or infantrymen, as they do around vocational training. You see a lot of young people interested in medical training, in mechanics, aviation, truck maintenance, which directly leads to a career after two or three years in the service. Communications, and the high technology areas are popular, and language training.

GRAPHIC: Photo of David R. Wallace
