HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Tale of Two Yuris: For Soviet Ambassador, These Are the Best of Times

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Yuri Vladimirovich Dubinin calls himself ''a popularizer of perestroika,'' a salesman of the new Soviet thinking that brings Red Army watches to Bloomingdale's and blasts holes in the Berlin Wall.
With real political debate in Moscow, a Solidarity-led Government in Poland, huge demonstrations in Czechoslovakia, the promise of free elections in Hungary and the opening of the border between the Germanys, there has never been a more promising time to be the Soviet Ambassador to Washington.
''It's very exciting,'' Mr. Dubinin says of changes in Soviet attitudes and their effects on his life - so exciting that his words tumble out, disclosing both his zest for the job and his uncertain command of English:
''The feelings of a diplomat is that perestroika opened new horizons for our diplomatic activity. Absolutely. And how to say, the most important part, the essence of the diplomatic activity - contacts, understanding and cooperation with other countries. It's luck just to be involved.'' 
Mr. Dubinin got off to a rough start in Washington, sometimes boring former Secretary of State George P. Shultz and irritiating his successor, James A. Baker 3d. But he has undergone a remarkable personality change. Yesterday's gray-faced apparatchik is today's bon vivant.
 
'A Different Person Today'
''Whoever he was yesterday, he's obviously a different person today,'' says Max M. Kampelman, the former chief United States arms negotiator who sat on the other side of the table from Mr. Dubinin's delegation at Madrid. ''But the key is that his Government's policies are different today. He is and always was a faithful servant of his Government. Faithful, that's the word to describe him.''
It is hard to believe that this Yuri V. Dubinin, Washington's most sought-after Socialist socialite, is the same Yuri V. Dubinin who, in 1980, as the Soviet Ambassador to Spain, stalled for two months at a 35-nation preparatory conference on human rights and security issues in Madrid.
In those pre-perestroika days, Mr. Dubinin was so secretive that comrades from other Warsaw Pact countries had to turn to their NATO counterparts for assessments of the private parts of the negotiations. The Spaniards considered expelling him because of K.G.B. meddling in the Canary Islands. His hard-line positions and his hairdo earned him the description ''A Molotov with a pompadour.''
It is a function of both the times and Mr. Dubinin's personality that he now spends as much time buttonholing businessmen, eyeballing farms and factories across America and mingling with the rich and the royal in black tie or tails as he spends reporting on the nuances of superpower politics. Indeed, the 59-year-old envoy seems more comfortable with his new roles than with the old ones.
When he talks about joint ventures or cultural exchanges, Mr. Dubinin is effusive. But when the subject turns substantive, he proves that he is very much a product of Andrei A. Gromyko's school of diplomacy. The cardinal rule of the late Foreign Minister and President was to give away nothing and put the other side on the defensive.
 
Limited Latitude
Mr. Dubinin's interpretation of the significance of the scheduled summit meeting off the island of Malta in early December illustrates both his extreme caution and the limitations of his diplomatic latitude.
''You see, there are a lot of speculations around this meeting,'' he said. ''And on one side, I would say that all kind of speculations is just a manifestation of interest. It's a positive aspect. Sometimes this kind of speculations could be damageable also, because, you see, it could be speculations that could raise too much expectations, too much hopes, too much projects and after that it could be a kind of disappointment.''
Mr. Dubinin came to Washington in May 1986 as an obscure career diplomat who had specialized in Western Europe, spoke little English and had not set foot on American soil until he was appointed Moscow's top representative at the United Nations two months earlier. He stood in the shadow of Anatoly F. Dobrinin, his predecessor, whose 24 years as the Soviet Ambassador made him the most formidable diplomatic presence on the Potomac and Moscow's top specialist on American affairs.
Mr. Dobrynin was brilliant, daring and shrewd; Mr. Dubinin is smooth, cautious and nice. He lacks the access and the insight of his predecessor, who knew six Presidents and nine Secretaries of State and had a direct line into the Politburo. But he enjoys the advantage of a better relationship between Moscow and Washington.
''The nature of the job has become much easier and more pleasant and he is thriving,'' said John C. Whitehead, the former Deputy Secretary of State, who knows Mr. Dubinin well. ''In the social and economic world, he is acting like a normal ambassador from an important country.''
 
He Compensates for Gaps
In the world of geopolitics, however, Mr. Dubinin still has a lot to learn. To help compensate for gaps in his understanding of issues, he relies on highly sophisticated specialists who are encouraged to court the news media and address research organizations on matters of substance while he presses the flesh and works the drawing rooms.
''I don't have any complex of inferiority, not because of my experience, but because I came here - how to say - carried by a new policy,'' he said when asked about his predecessor.
Trained as a linguist, with perfect French and excellent Spanish, at first Mr. Dubinin fooled his American audiences into thinking he knew more English than he did by memorizing answers to anticipated questions in advance. Determined to be a player, he haphazardly took lessons from two American tutors and pushed himself to speak English in every social setting.
He and his wife of 36 years, Liana, have thrown open the doors of the once-formidable Soviet Embassy and transformed the mirrored and chandeliered receiving room into a regular meeting place for glasnost glitterati.
He welcomed an Iowa businessman who delivered a 50-by-13-foot congratulatory greeting card for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and held a joint news conference with Russian bears and tiger cubs when the Moscow Circus came to town. He struggled with a hand puppet named Khryusha the Piglet in a performance by Mister Rogers, the star of children's television, and presented Mitch Snyder, the Washington advocate for the homeless, with $5,000 and an elaborate samovar after Mr. Gorbachev denounced homelessness in America at the 1987 Washington summit talks.
 
Large Portions of Perestroika
''I would use an American expression to describe him - he is a person who can think big,'' says Boris Malakhov, the embassy's press spokesman.
Every event is served up with a large portion of perestroika and the economic, social and opportunities it provides.
He called his recent party for Debbye Turner, the marimba-playing Miss America, and Yulia Sukhanova, the first Soviet beauty queen in half a century, a ''kind of Soviet-American summit'' for beauties. The good-will visit of a Soviet missile cruiser to Norfolk last July became ''a clear, tangible manifestation of the new spirit'' and the signing of two Soviet hockey players by the New Jersey Devils opened ''new avenues in a spirit of cooperation.''
Mr. Dubinin's style fits nicely into Mr. Gorbachev's vision of restructuring in the Soviet economy. The Ambassador has pressed for joint ventures to generate the currency needed to make the ruble convertible on the world market. To help put more chickens into Soviet pots, he organized a tour for Soviet experts to study poultry production at the Perdue Farms operations in Virginia and Maryland. After the Armenian earthquake, which killed 25,000 people and left 500,000 homeless last December, Mr. Dubinin appeared on television, gave speeches, wrote letters, solicited businessmen and was a co-host for a Carnegie Hall concert to raise money for the victims.
Unlike his predecessor, who preferred to jawbone over scotch in the parlors of the capital, Mr. Dubinin pops up in unexpected places. He took the Mayor of Moscow to a Washington cabaret to watch a performance by the singer Mel Torme, who is of Russian Jewish descent. When French peasants and workers stormed the barricades with red flags in a Kennedy Center performance of ''Les Miserables,'' Mr. Dubinin startled some in the audience when he jumped out of his seat and cheered.
 
Travels Around the Country
In three years, he has visited 27 states, touring an international auto show in Detroit, the Chicago Board of Trade, an Iowa corn farm, the largest supermarket in the Giant Food Inc. chain and the Walt Disney Company's Epcot Center in Florida.
''I have visited more military bases in the United States than in the Soviet Union,'' he said. ''To be more honest, I have visited no military bases in the Soviet Union.''
Mr. Dubinin got off to a bad start in Washington. He antagonized State Department officials, from Mr. Shultz on down, with relentless requests for high-level meetings on inconsequential subjects. ''He was like Federal Express,'' said one State Department official who has dealt with him extensively. ''He would get a letter and was always trying to deliver it immediately.'' Mr. Dubinin is still so persistent that some senior Administration officials say they will make themselves unavailable when he comes calling on many routine matters.
Mr. Dubinin also finds it impossible to amplify official Soviet positions or improvise in meetings with American officials, even though Administration officials believe that he has a close relationship with his boss, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. His reticence has left the impression that he is not privy to high-level decisions the way Mr. Dobrynin was.
Instead, said one State Department official: ''He'll go fishing. He'll deliver a message on Afghanistan and then ask you your opinion of a non-aligned conference in Zimbabwe.''
 
Not 'a Brilliant Philosophe'
To compensate for what some Bush Administration officials characterize as Mr. Dubinin's problems of perception and lack of influence, the State Department increasingly relies on Jack Matlock, the United States Ambassador to Moscow, to get Washington's points across to the Kremlin.
''O.K., nobody is now saying that he's a brilliant philosophe or Gorbachev's right-hand man,'' says Dimitri K. Simes, a Soviet expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. ''But he is what he appears to be: a highly competent professional diplomat who shows loyalty to his Government's agenda and pursues the party line.''
Mr. Dubinin uses his sense of humor, with varying degrees of success, to disguise the fact that he is more a faithful messenger than a creative thinker. In response to a protest by Mr. Baker after Honduran authorities intercepted a truckload of Soviet-bloc weapons on the way from Nicaragua to El Salvador last month, Mr. Dubinin delivered an urgent message from Mr. Shevardnadze.
After Mr. Baker read the rough English translation, he was unable to contain his anger. He coldly told the Ambassador that the message included nothing new and added that he was ''deeply disappointed'' in the Soviet response. Undaunted, Mr. Dubinin paused a moment and handed him the Russian text. ''Maybe you will read it better in the Russian,'' he said. Mr. Baker was not amused.

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: Hope Is Seen for Poor of 7-State Delta

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
In many ways geography has wrought a common destiny for much of the lower Mississippi River delta as the centuries-old rhythm of flooding and receding waters made the agricultural bottomland fertile, attracting farmers and thousands of laborers to work the land.
But as agriculture became mechanized, jobs disappeared. Nothing has replaced most of them, leaving the region in the grip of some of the worst poverty in the nation.
Yet until the past year, no one looked at the region's problems as a whole. Instead, the seven states in the region fought the high levels of unemployment, poverty, infant mortality, substandard housing and illiteracy in their own way. But they generally found that the problems were too vast to deal with alone. 
The Lower Mississippi Delta Development Commission, created by Congress about a year ago, is now seeking to change that with the first-ever plan to fight the problems on a regional scale. The plan is due to be completed by next May.
 
'A Common History'
''We see a common history,'' said Wilbur Hawkins, executive director of the commission, ''an atmosphere which created an aristocracy and a colonial-type economy, but no middle class.''
The region, which extends from Cairo, Ill., where the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers meet, to the Gulf of Mexico, covers 214 counties in Illinois, Kentucky, Missouri, Arkansas, Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana.
Over the past four months the commission has been holding hearings throughout the region. On Nov. 30, it will hold a hearing in Greenville, Miss., on developing tourism in the region.
But the commission's chances of success remain blurred.
For one thing, while modeled on past Federal efforts to deal with regional problems, like the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Appalachian Regional Commission, the delta commission is working without the huge infusions of Federal money that breathed life into the earlier efforts. And although it has the support of the Governors of all seven states, it has yet to get noticeable support from the White House.
''We just don't have the band leaders that the A.R.C. and the T.V.A. had,'' said Lee Troutwine, Kentucky's Commissioner of Local Government, who serves as his state's representative to the delta commission as well as to the two older regional groups.
 
Depth of Problems
In an interim report released last month, the commission reported that nearly 21 percent of the 8.3 million people in the region live in poverty, as against 12.4 percent nationally. The most deeply affected are the 30 percent of the population who are black. More than half the blacks in the region have incomes below the national poverty level.
Unemployment rates in the region average more than 8 percent, as against the national rate of 5.2 percent. But some counties have unemployment rates of more than four times the national average. And while the region's per capita income of $10,192 a year is 75 percent of the national average of $13,577, 137 of the counties had average incomes that dipped to 62 percent of the national average, or less.
''The Delta's economic, social and cultural structure of life has often reinforced tensions between ethnic groups and worsened the economic subjugation of African-Americans,'' the report said, adding that changes in recent years had failed to eradicate the legacy of this history.
Both Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the commission chairman, and Mr. Hawkins said the panel does not see itself as simply trying to open a floodgate of Federal financing to the region, which already receives more than $17 billion annually in welfare, Medicaid, veterans and other benefits to individuals. Nor do they see their task as developing a ''laundry list of new Federal programs'' or becoming a cheerleader for larger farm subsidies.
 
Targeted Programs
Instead, they said, they hope to focus on a number of targeted, self-help and state financed efforts that, with a small amount of additional Federal help, can be repeated regionwide or made more productive.
They also hope to modify existing Federal policies that work against the region. Those policies, Mr. Hawkins said, include limits on Medicaid payments for services that can be delivered at lower cost in densely populated urban areas than in rural areas.
''Why does this exist?'' Mr. Hawkins asked. ''It exists because no one from the region was there to scream about it or ask tough questions.''
The commission, in its interim report, also emphasized the potential of building on the region's agricultural base to establish industrial jobs for the unemployed. Mr. Hawkins said that might include food processing jobs, like flash freezing, distilling and packaging the agricultural products.
Currently, most of the delta's agricultural products are processed outside the region.
''We would like to identify five alternative crops that have this capacity for growing and processing here in the region, just as we now do with catfish,'' Mr. Hawkins said. Catfish grown in the region supply nearby plants that employ thousands of people to do filleting, processing and packaging.
 
'Involvement at All Levels'
''When we talk of these spinoff industries and jobs,'' Mr. Hawkins said, ''we are talking about significant involvement at all levels for minorities. That kind of thinking just wasn't going on some years ago.''
The makeup of the commission is proving to be both an asset and a small drawback. In addition to Mr. Clinton, its nine members include Gov. Ray Mabus of Mississippi as vice chairman, Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana, gubernatorial appointees from the other four states and two Presidential appointees, all of whom are white males.
''This is not the delta,'' said Jimmie Wilson, an Arkansas lawyer who is president of National Association for the Advancement of Colored People chapter in Helena, referring to the commission's makeup. ''The delta is largely female and African-American. I'm not surprised, just disappointed.''
Representative Mike Espy, the Mississippi Democrat who was a main sponsor of the bill creating the panel - and who is black - said he was also disappointed in the makeup of the commission. It has hurt the panel's credibility, he said. But he added that having Governors on the commission has given a higher profile to its work. ''It means they are willing to put their integrity and reputations on the line, and that's fine,'' he said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1615 words

HEADLINE: It's All Untrue: Lendl Spurns The Lendl Myth

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn.

 BODY:
It hardly comes as a surprise that the house Ivan Lendl lives in is made of stone, great slabs of gray and beige stone, and is protected from the rest of the world by two fences: a natural baffle of hemlocks backed up by a no-nonsense span of chain link. Protecting himself - on the job with a dentist's drill of a forehand, at leisure with a battery of sarcasm that passes for cocktail-hour banter, at home with a meticulously trained quartet of brainy German shepherds - has long been a top concern of the world's top tennis player.
After a life spent in a furious pursuit of mental and physical invincibility, it would not make much sense to leave any inch of himself vulnerable. And besides, said Lendl, who at age 29 has begun to soften some of the hard edges of the blueprint he lives by, nobody would believe him if he did.
 
He's Heard It All
''You hear it all about me,'' Lendl said. ''That I only sleep two hours a night, I don't like food, I train like a machine, I have killer dogs, I hold a grudge against Michael Chang because he beat me in the French Open, I am an unhappy guy, I am too driven of a guy.'' 
Lendl is still most efficient in situations that do not demand an excess of affability, such as a five-set match where pride and a six-figure payoff are at stake. But he has a ready rebuttal for the amateur anthropologists who continually accuse him of impersonating a robot.
''Hey, I wish I only needed two hours of sleep,'' he said. ''I had turkey and potatoes and brownies for Thanksgiving; I train five to seven hours a day, not so different from anybody's workday, and unless you are mice, my dogs won't kill you. And why should I hold a grudge against Michael Chang just because he beat me? I've beaten more guys than have beaten me.''
''If they all hold grudges, that's too funny,'' added Lendl, whose sense of humor is decidedly not mainstream.
This week Lendl will be getting serious against his prime rival, Boris Becker, the Wimbledon and United States Open champion and defending Masters champion. The pair will meet when the Masters opens tomorrow at Madison Square Garden.
Lendl said he was not worried by intimations from Becker's camp that the West German, who earned two grand slam titles this year, should be ranked No. 1 in the world instead of Lendl, the computer's pick.
 
Wimbledon on His Mind
''You don't have to massage my ego by saying I'm No. 1,'' the five-time Masters champion said.
But at the moment, he conceded, ''I am worried a little about the Masters, a lot about the Australian - and a lot more about Wimbledon, which is my one goal left.''
''But first I must get to this clinic on time,'' Lendl said as he guided his sensible suburban Range Rover toward the Trumbull Racquet Club and the yearly benefit he attends for the Big Brothers/Big Sisters Program.
Lendl does not use his cars like flying carpets anymore; age has brought more wariness (the accident that caused the demise of his old Porsche happened at 35 miles an hour instead of his customary 100). And, in another sign of maturity, he has committed his time, his fame and his shiny new smile to a bushel of worthy causes.
 
Eat and Run
For more than two hours inside the chilly club, Lendl traded strokes with awed schoolchildren and stood obediently at net as the procession of local movers and shakers who spent sponsorship dollars for the event took their turn at practicing their country club smash on him.
Then, his responsibilities in order, he jumped back into the Rover, stuffed a restorative banana into his mouth, and sped away toward the highlight of his day, a Hartford Whalers game.
A hockey buff who wears an autographed Mike Liut jersey whenever he tends goal for charity, Lendl is a friend of the Whalers' owner, Richard Gordon, the developer who has had a Trumpian impact on Hartford's skyline and who last year assumed control of Hartford's only professional sports team.
Gordon added Lendl to the club's board of directors, which tickled Lendl, and in the not too distant future the two will travel to Czechoslovakia in hopes of extricating the hockey prodigy Robert Holik.
 
A Favor to the Sport
Success in that endeavor, Lendl said, would be nothing short of a profound public service to hockey lovers like himself, not to mention a coup for Holik, who in Lendl's judgment is bound to excel as an athlete with more certainty here than there.
''In the early days of our friendship, he once told me that part of being Czech was the feeling that you cannot excel,'' Lendl's former agent, Jerry Solomon of ProServ, said of him. ''And he said he wasn't going to let that happen to him.''
Although Solomon's business relationship with Lendl concluded in a $7 million breach-of-contract lawsuit that provoked a $25 million countersuit from Lendl (the matter was settled out of court after an eight-month battle), Solomon remains intrigued by Lendl's determination to succeed.
''He's not a guy who allows for any margin of error,'' Solomon said. ''He's obsessed or driven to achieve at a standard that in his mind is a level above what anybody else has done. His system has worked for him, and he believes it would work for anybody. But in reality you have to have a very specific personality for it.
''I can remember when we'd have guys come back from practicing with him for a week before a tournament, guys who were tennis professionals themselves, and they'd say, 'If that's what it takes to be No. 1 in the world, then I don't want to be No. 1 in the world.' ''
 
Likes Life Here
A quiet friend to the Reagan and Bush administrations, Lendl has repeatedly gone on record with a social philosophy that sounds as if it had been lifted from a tattered propaganda poster for the American dream.
Anybody, Lendl has said, can make it in the United States if he just sets his sights on a goal and works for it -just look at Lendl. He has said that people do not seem to know how good they have it here.
Anyone with doubts, Lendl said, should take a field trip to Czechoslovakia, where, despite the unraveling of the Communist Government, a development Lendl approves of, the meager economy defies even the ablest entrepreneurs.
''Life is so good over here, especially in my position now; life is like a dream,'' said Lendl, who was allowed to take up residence here in Greenwich when he was 20 and ranked sixth in the world. The defection of his countrywoman Martina Navratilova in 1975, Lendl explained, paved his path for a smooth absorption into the capitalist system he embraces.
''I really owe a lot to her,'' said Lendl, who was never forced to undergo the emotional upheaval of defection.
 
Concedes Single-Mindedness
''I basically did everything in my life so that I could become the best tennis player,'' he said. ''And that happened to be the same thing as trying to live the best possible life, and living in America was part of that. I believe neither Martina nor I would have become No. 1 if we'd stayed in Czechoslovakia.''
But now he is here for good. He has accumulated more than $14 million on the tennis court, added millions more from endorsements and investments made possible because of his celebrity on and off the court, and is, in his own words, ''a happy person not because of the money, but it helps.''
In the spring of 1992, Lendl expects to relinquish his shopworn green card for United States citizenship. By then, he and his wife, Samantha, who is now pregnant, will have a toddler to raise in their mansion of choice. Current contenders are his 20-room Georgian in Greenwich, with its United States Open tennis court cloned in the side yard, the 45-acre Conyers Farm nearby, or the 800-acre gentleman's estate in Connecticut's rustic foothills.
Lendl followed up his six-year courtship of Samantha Frankel, whom he met through the former player Wojtek Fibak when she was 14, with a whirlwind wedding last September. Married in their home on a Friday, they honeymooned that night at a rural inn in Connecticut, went to a Whalers game Saturday, and flew to Europe on Sunday to keep on track with his tournament schedule.
 
Respects His Idiosyncracies
But Frankel, like everyone permitted into Lendl's inner sanctum, defers to his need for planning and order on all fronts. She does not attempt to advise him on his tennis, and she gets away from it all with her own hobby, horseback riding.
Lendl, acquisitive and competitive by nature, has not ventured into that arena. ''I don't like horses,'' he explained, ''because I'm afraid of them.''
Lendl did not like children much, either, but with impending fatherhood, he has adjusted.
''When I was 18, 19, somebody with little kids around drove me bananas 100 percent of the time,'' he said. ''Five years later, I'd like it one day, they'd drive me bananas the next. Now 99 percent of the days, I like it.'' What Lendl envisions for his future is, for the first time, two lives.
''It's going to be something new to split myself between career and family,'' he said. ''My goal in tennis is to win Wimbledon, because I haven't done it, and after that it's to win every tournament, of course. But next year I'm 30, and the time is coming when I'll quit. Wimbledon is not nearly as important as the life I have.''
 
Looking Out for No. 1

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
The Twilight of 'America's Century'

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
''America's Century,'' Lewis H. Lapham's dour and dire view of the decline of American power and confidence over the last 100 years, comes to its gloomy conclusion tonight with a litany of events that have shaken the nation's sense of itself.
With the support of a few like-minded journalists and think-tankists, Mr. Lapham probes traumas like the loss of the war in Vietnam, the economic competition from Japan and West Germany, the Iranian hostage crisis, the killing of United States marines by terrorists in Lebanon and the Iran-contra revelations. He arrives at a diagnosis of terminal malaise.
The six-part series, which ends tonight at 8 P.M. on Channel 31 and at 10 P.M. on Channel 13, is as close to a personal essay as television has given. If you tuned into the earlier programs, you know by now that Mr. Lapham, the editor of Harper's Magazine, sees American history in this century as a compound of pretensions to power, affectations of ideology, and a naive idealism about the workings of the world and the motives and interests of the United States itself. And so the nation has plunged from triumph to disarray. 
Much of tonight's hour, produced by Peter Bate, is given to the Presidencies of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, and Mr. Lapham and his cohort really give it to them. Mr. Carter is presented, not without sympathy, as a feckless leader, altogether out of his depth in Washington. Even as he was trying to incorporate ideals of human rights into foreign policy, he is shown toasting the Shah of Iran: ''We don't fear the future when we have friends like this great country.'' The Administration, by this account, was totally unprepared for the advent of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Mr. Carter's response to the taking of American hostages in 1979 is written off as ''weak, indecisive, sentimental.''
The treatment of Mr. Carter is kindness itself compared with the treatment of Mr. Reagan, who is credited here with having accomplished the ''Hollywoodization of politics.'' Mr. Lapham, who can seem supercilious even when he means to be pleasant, lets loose his scorn for the former President for upholding ''the sanctity of myth against the heresy of fact.'' He is blunter about Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, whom he calls ''a treacherous and lying agent of the national security state.''
It is that state, represented most formidably by the Pentagon, that Mr. Lapham and most of his guests, who are not very helpfully identified but speak mainly from the left, see as the Great Satan. President Eisenhower's warning against the power of the military-industrial complex is hauled out as a prophecy come true. The Pentagon and the defense industry are pictured as clinging to past threats and future profits, while present threats and opportunities go unmet. Instead of working with other nations to safeguard the environment and help the impoverished, Washington, in the Laphamian view, is frozen in its obsession with military power.
At the very end, Mr. Lapham, who delivers his messages while strolling among international sites and sights like a figure out of Henry James, turns slightly upbeat, offering the possibility that the hopes of the American people will prevail over the ambitions of the American state. Given all that has gone before, this seems like pro forma condescension toward the People. It runs smack against the strong current of the series.
But you don't have to buy Mr. Lapham's entire stock of goods to be stimulated by this effort to provoke thought, concern, debate. And whatever one's reservations about the quality of the history offered by ''America's Century'' and the opinions advanced with such assurance, at the very least - and it is not so little - they are phrased with an elegance not common to television.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Japanese companies are negotiating to acquire one of the last American makers of the highly sophisticated equipment used to etch circuits on chips. Such a deal would leave the United States almost wholly dependent on Japan for the chief tools used to produce future generations of computer chips. Nikon, part of the Mitsubishi Group, is viewed as the leading bidder for Perkin-Elmer's semiconductor equipment. [Page A1.] 
OPEC continues to scramble for an agreement on production quotas, but the dispute among its 13 members is not expected to have a strong effect on world oil prices. And some OPEC ministers are leaning to the view that quotas are no longer necessary for OPEC members, since only a few of them have the physical ability or oil reserves to respond to rising world demand. [D1.]
The hulking Lenin Steelworks in Poland symbolizes another set of yearnings and challenges: to transform the fossilized hulks of a burdensome Communist economy to more efficient market-oriented enterprises. [D1.]
J. R. D. Tata is stepping aside as head of one of India's industrial giants, but he remains concerned about his corporation's public image and its financial well-being, developed over three decades in which Mr. Tata has dominated Indian industry and influenced political leaders by the force of his convictions and his insistence on quality and professionalism. [D4.]
 
 
 
The Economy
Orders for American machine tools dropped 32.3 percent in October from the September level, largely because the auto industry cut back its orders, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said. Machine-tool orders totaled $205 million in October, compared with $302.6 million in September. The October total was 21.8 percent lower than that of October 1988. [D1.]
The Chicago Board of Trade says it plans to tighten circuit breakers for its stock index futures contract on the Major Market Index, in another move to reduce stock market volatility. [D6.]
 
The Media Business
The publisher of Cable Guide plans to challenge TV Guide and local newspapers in providing a weekly road map to the ever-expanding landscape of television. [D8.]
GTG Entertainment has yet to come up with a hit program, and last week its ''USA Today on TV'' was canceled. [D8.]
University Press of America distributes many books for small publishers that lack warehouses or marketing skills. [D8.]
Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein is grappling with a problem faced by many small agencies: because they have created their reputations in cities outside the advertising centers of New York and Chicago, they have found it difficult to attract the attention of big-budget clients. Ad Scene. [D8.]
Hank Seiden says he is very happy with his contract with Ketchum Advertising. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D9.]

The prime lending rate is likely to be lowered by half a percentage point this week, some credit market analysts and economists said. Credit Markets. [D1.]
The courts lean heavily toward defendants in product liability cases, two professors have concluded. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [D2.]
Bank of New England lent $1.5 million to Lifeline Heatlh Care just days after the S.E.C. halted trading in Lifeline's shares. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Small Companies Going Global

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Small American companies, which already account for a fifth of United States exports, are increasingly taking the next step to becoming global businesses: they are setting up operations overseas, not just shipping their goods abroad.
A decade ago, such an evolution was unthinkable at most small companies. Overseas operations were the domain of the Fortune 500 corporations, while small companies kept production close to home. And even now, the small manufacturer - the sort of company that employs 200 people in a one-story factory in an industrial park - is expanding abroad reluctantly.
''A lot of small companies are forced into the international marketplace just to stay alive,'' said Kenneth S. Flamm, a Brookings Institution economist. 
 
Smaller First Moves
Today, some smaller companies are building factories in foreign markets, but most are making less costly moves at first, like arranging joint ventures, partnerships and licensing agreements in Western Europe, Japan and elsewhere. The globalization of small business underscores corporate America's belief that in the future most companies, even small ones, must compete internationally to be successful.
A foreign presence can increase sales and give companies access to new technology and marketing ideas. The experience helps them to fend off competition at home from second-tier foreign rivals that have jumped into the United States market in recent years. And with the economy slowing sharply in the United States, smaller companies, often particularly susceptible to downturns, are looking to faster-growing overseas markets.
Since the mid-1980's, thousands of small manufacturers have gone into exporting. Small companies account for more than 20 percent of the nation's total annual exports, according to several studies. The United States has more than 150,000 small manufacturers, companies with fewer than 400 employees and less than $70 million in annual revenues, the National Association of Manufacturers reports.
 
Exporting Seen as Not Enough
Still, small companies are now concluding that exporting alone is not enough, according to executives and Government and trade group officials.
''You can't sell very much abroad without switching to production overseas,'' said Michael Plumley, chief executive of the Plumley Companies, an auto-parts maker in Paris, Tenn.
Like other small-company executives, Mr. Plumley contends that operating overseas is essential to stay competitive in the domestic market. ''It's the best way to gain experience in new products and manufacturing techniques,'' he said.
But when manufacturers switch to overseas production, the nation's income from exports declines, making the trade deficit more difficult to resolve. And as long-term survival for small manufacturers depends more and more on establishing overseas operations, the pinch on this crucial sector of the economy will intensify, business executives say.
''The pressure is to become a much bigger company fast in order to compete globally,'' said Harry E. Featherstone, chief executive of the Will-Burt Company, an Ohio concern with $22 million in annual revenues that makes truck parts and mobile radio-transmission towers. ''Will-Burt will either become much bigger or sell out to a big company, or we won't be around.''
Recent events at three small companies illustrate what is happening:
* Plumley's main product is auto engine hoses to connect radiators and air-conditioners. For a while, the family-owned company, with about $50 million in annual sales, tried to export directly to European customers. But each required a different metal coupling or fitting - of a type that Plumley did not sell at home. So Plumley now ships bare hose in bulk to a German-based partner, Aeroquip Trinova, which makes the metal fixtures and handles sales. ''We don't have the money for our own European factory or distributorship,'' Mr. Plumley said, ''but 10 years down the road, that's the way we'll have to go.''
* Avid Technologies of Burlington, Mass., is trying to sell simultaneously in Europe, Japan and the United States a new $80,000 computer system that edits film and videotape, using Avid's proprietary software. Lacking money for such ambitious marketing, Avid relies on foreign distributors who keep up to 40 percent of the revenue. William Warner, Avid's president, said that was the price of gaining a quick foothold abroad. Without one, foreign companies will have room to introduce similar systems and then invade Avid's American market. ''By being successful, you create a big billboard that says, 'This market exists and here's how to address it,' '' Mr. Warner said.
* Rather than continue to export its mobile radio towers, Will-Burt is negotiating to make them in Ireland, with a partner that would provide the factory and sales force - and keep a big chunk of the profit. Why do this? Well, Will-Burt cannot yet afford its own factory, but having a European operation is essential, Mr. Featherstone said. For one thing, it gets the company inside the European Community, safe from trade barriers that might appear once a unified market is created in 1992. Even more important, if the dollar were to rise in value, Will-Burt could sell its Irish-made towers in the United States for less than towers made in Ohio.
 
Protecting the Home Market
Such a strategy would protect Will-Burt from foreign companies that might try to export towers to the United States during a strong-dollar period. ''You can't protect your home market unless you are also in the fray overseas,'' said William Archey, international vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. ''If your first experience with foreign competitors is right here at home, you might not survive.''
Will-Burt's first experience with foreign competitors, in fact, almost cost the company its main business, manufacturing truck and tractor components, Mr. Featherstone said. As the dollar rose in value in the mid-1980's, Caterpillar Inc. canceled a $1 million contract for items like cab doors and engine compartments and switched to lower-priced Belgian and Brazilian suppliers.
''We realized then that we were operating in a worldwide market,'' said Mr. Featherstone, whose company had never had any foreign dealings. By cutting costs in Ohio and going to China for some castings and to Indonesia for some welded parts, Will-Burt was able to win back Caterpillar, as well as business lost at Mack Truck. Currently it is bidding to supply parts to Volvo in Europe.
Many of the small companies now operating abroad are niche manufacturers, making specialized products whose sales often rise more quickly abroad than at home. For example, the Kiva Container Corporation of Phoenix produces containers made of corrugated plastic - the material used in the post office's letter-sorting containers. Kiva's containers are used for computer boards and chips, and to ship fish packed in ice.
''Getting Americans to buy plastic corrugated containers instead of cardboard ones is very difficult,'' said Ruth Stafford, Kiva's vice president. ''The Europeans are much quicker to switch to new products.''
Whatever the explanation, Kiva's overseas sales now represent 10 percent of the company's $5 million in annual revenue, up from zero a few years ago. And Kiva is making a barter arrangement with a British company, Team Tool Ltd. Team Tool will distribute Kiva's containers in Europe while Kiva will distribute the British company's die-cutting equipment in the United States.
''Eventually, we'll manufacture containers in Europe; that's more practical than shipping them from here,'' Mrs. Stafford said.
At the outset, Kiva's manufacturing operation would probably be a joint venture - owned by Kiva and perhaps Team Tool.
As a first step, most small companies today rely on joint ventures, partnerships and licensing agreements. (Foreign licensees pay royalties to American companies for the right to make their products abroad.) Indeed, licensing fees and royalties collected by American companies from abroad are running this year at an annual rate of $12 billion, compared with $6.2 billion in 1979 and $5.3 billion in 1983, the Commerce Department reported.
But joint ventures and partnerships can be hazardous, executives say. ''Often the foreign partner prefers to expand sales of its own products, not those of its American partner,'' said Stephen Cooney, director of international investment at the National Association of Manufacturers.
 
Problems of Partnerships
And sometimes the American partner in the joint venture becomes less than enthusiastic. That happened to Sonicraft Inc., a Chicago manufacturer of airport communications devices used in bad-weather landings.
With few new airports being built in the United States, Sonicraft, which has $30 million in annual revenue, sought overseas sales through a venture with the Teli Corporation of Sweden, which makes a different type of airport communications gear.
''We wanted to Americanize their gear and, in exchange, they would sell our product through their distribution network in 65 countries,'' said Jerry T. Jones, Sonicraft's chairman.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Cut Expected In Prime Rate This Week

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The prime lending rate, which most commercial banks have held at 10.5 percent since late July, is likely to be lowered by half a percentage point this week, some credit market analysts and economists said.
The way for a cut in the prime was paved last week when the Federal Reserve Board signaled that it had eased the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market by about a quarter of a percentage point, to 8.25 percent. A drop in the prime would lower costs for a wide range of borrowers, ''I think the Fed would like the prime to come down, and it may happen today,'' said Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and money market economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''A move in the funds rate from 9 percent to 8.5 percent earlier this year didn't generate a cut in the prime rate, and I think that is one of the reasons they eased policy again last week. I think they are concerned that households are going to go on a buying strike.'' 
 
'Further Confirmation' Sought
Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh, observed that ''banks may want further confirmation that the Fed has indeed lowered the funds rate to 8.25 percent.''
''There is a lot of pressure on bank earnings, which intensifies the pressure to linger at 10.50 percent,'' he said. ''But the Fed wants interest rates, including the prime, to move lower.''
Banks have been reluctant to lower the prime rate because other important financing costs, like three-month Eurodollar deposit rates, have lagged the declines in the funds rate. Generally, banks like to maintain a difference, or ''spread,'' of 1.50 to 2 percentage points between their own cost of funds and the prime.
After the dip in the funds rate late last week, three-month Eurodollar deposits were offered at a rate of 8 5/ 16 percent.
Aside from small and medium-sized businesses, an array of consumers have loans with charges tied to changes in the prime.
 
Affecting Consumer Confidence
With Christmas scarcely a month away, a cut in the prime could provide an additional lift to consumer psychology, which remains high even though spending has been sluggish lately.
''Consumer confidence has held up pretty well, but there is no doubt the Fed wants to create a favorable backdrop going into the Christmas season,'' said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
Nevertheless, a lower prime rate would not in and of itself lead to a further rally in the credit markets.
''At this stage the market has limited upside potential,'' said Leonard J. Santow, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''The Fed's most recent move is already reflected in current prices. Further improvement won't come until we get a chance to see additional new information.''
By late Friday the Treasury's 8 1/8 bonds of 2019 were offered at a price to yield 7.86 percent, down only slightly from a yield of 7.93 percent on Nov. 17. Yields on two-year notes had dipped to 7.63 percent by the end of last week, down from 7.76 percent on Nov. 17.
 
New Data Due
Given the Fed's current bias to postpone the battle against inflation to help stave off a recession, analysts said another cut in the funds rate, to 8 percent, is possible before the end of the year if data show that the economy remains weak.
Reports due early this week will not offer much new evidence on the economy, but traders are likely to pay close attention to data in the November survey of the nation's purchasing managers that is due Friday.
Few if any analysts are willing to project publicly what will be shown by the survey, which provides the first glimpse of how the economy fared in the month just ended. In October, the results of the survey showed that business conditions had improved slightly from September levels.
Aside from the economic reports, which also include the Commerce Department's first revision of third-quarter growth figures, the week's credit market activity will be highlighted by the sale of $10 billion of new two-year Treasury notes tomorrow and $8 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday.
Aside from weekly bill auctions, the note sales next week ''pretty much wind up the Treasury's activity for the year,'' Mr. Santow said.
With the Treasury absent from the market, he said, ''dealers will use that opportunity to lighten up their positions, and provide the opportunity for corporations and municipalities to price some issues.''
This week's corporate debt calendar is fairly light, and there is at least some statistical evidence to suggest that the heavy Treasury financings that have taken place this month have persuaded corporate treasurers to stay away from the new-issue market despite the fall in interest rates.
Through last Friday, $22.68 billion worth of corporate non-convertible debt issues had been priced during November, according to data from IDD Information Services. During the comparable period last year, the figure was $25.89 billion.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Is Optimistic On American Economy

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The United States can avoid both a recession and excessive inflation next year, so long as the Federal Reserve keeps an even grip on credit, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says in a report to be released on Monday.
But the O.E.C.D. said the American economy would remain dogged by the trade and budget deficits, which may stay stubbornly high in coming years.
The research group, which is sponsored by 24 countries, said in its latest review of the United States economy that price rises may be fanned by too-rapid cuts in interest rates. 
 
Below Previous Forecast
Despite this caution, the O.E.C.D.'s latest inflation and growth forecasts are more optimistic than its projections last June. It foresees inflation in the United States at just less than 5 percent in 1990. Previously, the O.E.C.D. expected it to be 5.25 percent. It is expected to average 4.2 percent in the second half of 1989.
The gross national product should grow 2.5 percent next year, the same as in the second half of 1989. Last June, the O.E.C.D. predicted growth of 2.25 percent in 1990 after 2 percent in the second half of this year.
But the O.E.C.D. cautioned that the trade deficit showed little sign of narrowing after sharp improvements in the last two years, with imports expected to outpace American exports. The 1990 trade deficit is seen at $105 billion, little changed from this year's $107 billion.
 
Watched by Markets
Financial markets closely watch the United States' overseas trade performance to determine if the dollar will be pushed lower to make American exports more competitive.
The O.E.C.D. also said that a failure to meet lower budget deficit targets would add to trade and current account problems. Fiscal measures are needed to dampen consumer spending and reduce the budget deficit, it added. And the organization recommended ending current tax distortions that discourage private savings.
''If effective action is not taken to meet the budget targets, the trade and current account deficits could well remain above $100 billion over the next five years,'' it said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Magazine Planned To Challenge TV Guide

BYLINE: By ALBERT SCARDINO

 BODY:
The publisher of the monthly Cable Guide plans to challenge the 30-year dominance of TV Guide and local newspapers in providing a weekly roadmap to the ever-expanding landscape of television.
TV Times, a weekly television listings magazine, will appear Feb. 3 in San Diego and Huntington, Calif. Its publisher, TVSM Inc., expects it to spread to other markets and hopes it will eventually reach a paid circulation of two million.
By sharing revenues with cable system operators and by simplifying listings, TVSM is trying to overcome the obstacles that other publishers, including Time Inc., have faced in assaulting TV Guide's market. 
 
Simplified Listing Format
TV Times will provide a subscriber with the current listings for each of the channels on a particular system - and only on that system - for about $3 a month. The format will eliminate the complex grids and multiple-system listings provided by daily newspapers and other publications, which usually try to provide information for most of the cable systems reached by local broadcasters.
The magazine will also include articles about television personalities and programs, as well as advertising.
The introduction of TV Times comes more than six years after Time Inc. lost about $50 million on TV-Cable Week magazine, its unsuccessful challenge to the industry giant, TV Guide. Time closed TV Cable Week after only about six months of publication.
Robert Cohen, a magazine consultant, said TVSM's longstanding relationship with independent cable operators may give TV Times the edge it needs to succeed where TV-Cable Week failed.
Many cable systems already distribute the Cable Guide, which has a circulation of almost eight million.
''If the cable operators are willing to play the game, the market might decide that it needs another listing book after all,'' Mr. Cohen said.
 
Reliance on Operators
TV Times will rely on the cable operators for a range of services. The operators will be asked to supply both programming information and subscriber lists, helping TVSM to hold down the initial promotional costs.
The cable companies will also bill for subscriptions on the monthly statements that they already send to their customers, another powerful advantage over competing publications, which rely on sales at newsstands and through annual mail subscriptions. Those who sign up for TV Times and do not pay may find their cable service disconnected.
In return for their services to TV Times, the cable operators will receive a share of the advertising and circulation revenues, said Mark Edmiston, chairman of TVSM.
Mr. Edmiston said many cable operators believed that more cable subscribers would sign up for premium channels if they knew what programs would appear on them. He said the magazine's simplified listings might encourage its readers to add those channels.
With special pay services added to the basic monthly subscription price, many cable subscribers now spend $40 a month or more.
 
'Hopelessly Complicated'
''The average cable system will be up to more than 50 channels by the late 1990's,'' Mr. Edmiston said. ''When you have several systems in a given metropolitan area, it can get hopelessly complicated to read a guide that tries to cover all of them.''
The area reached by New York City's broadcast stations, for instance, now includes more than 100 cable systems, and no two of them use the same numbering system.
Mr. Edmiston asserts that videocassette recorders and remote control devices have shifted the balance of power in the fight for audience share. ''The viewer can control what he watches far more than ever before, but unless he knows what his system offers, he can't decide what to watch,'' Mr. Edmiston said.
Joseph W. Cece, publisher of TV Guide, agrees that television viewing has increasingly become defined by cable system rather than by local network affiliations. But TV Guide, America's largest magazine (circulation 15.8 million), is reacting to the cable phenomenon, too.
 
About 6,000 Cable Systems
''We have already introduced several editions where the programs are listed by the cable channels they appear on rather than by the broadcast channel,'' Mr. Cece said. ''But there are about 6,000 cable systems in the country, and you can't provide a different edition for each one.''
To start the magazine, TVSM has added 30 editorial staff members -half of them in New York and half at the company's headquarters in Horsham, Pa. - to the 130 already with the company. Mr. Edmiston said TV Times would grow system by system.
TV Guide will introduce its cable-oriented guide in the same markets in December.
''When TV-Cable Week came out, TV Guide spent as much defending against it as Time spent trying to launch it,'' Mr. Edmiston said. ''But only about 20 percent of our monthly subscribers also read TV Guide, and that's what we expect from the weekly. They can't do what we are going to do economically.''

HEADLINE: De Lorean Wins a Round

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Lawyers for John Z. De Lorean, whose Belfast-based car company went bankrupt in 1982, won a High Court order on Friday setting aside an earlier court order against him for more than $51 million.
Judge Peter Gibson overturned a July 1987 court order that allowed legal documents in the case to be served on De Lorean at his home in New Jersey, which is outside the jurisdiction of the English courts. 
''It follows that all subsequent orders made against Mr. De Lorean will fall away,'' Judge Gibson said.
The ruling is the latest in a dispute between the liquidators of the DSQ Property Company, incorporated in Northern Ireland and formerly called De Lorean Motor Cars Ltd., and Mr. De Lorean.
Unstated damages had been claimed against Mr. De Lorean, who was accused of conspiracy, deceit and breach of fiduciary duty, Judge Gibson said. In June 1988, the High Court entered judgment against Mr. De Lorean ordering him to pay more than $51 million.
Judge Gibson said Mr. De Lorean took no part in the English proceedings until this year, when DSQ sought to enforce the judgment in the United States.
On July 10, Mr. De Lorean asked the High Court to set aside the order.
DSQ, which was ordered to pay Mr. De Lorean's legal costs, was allowed to appeal Judge Gibson's ruling, which was suspended pending the appeal.
Mr. De Lorean, a former executive with the General Motors Corporation, set up his plant in Belfast in 1978, employing more than 2,600 workers at its peak.
The British Government, hoping to ease high unemployment in the city, lost $140 million in the venture when the gull-wing sports cars found few buyers.

HEADLINE: U.S. Issues Protest to Soviets On Arms to Salvador Rebels

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The United States has told the Soviet Union that it holds Moscow indirectly responsible for what the State Department described today as the recent ''outrageous'' attempt by Nicaragua to ship advanced Soviet-made weapons to the leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.
The Soviet Embassy in Washington was also told that this arms shipment was a ''dangerous escalation'' in the Salvadoran conflict and a clear violation of explicit Soviet promises to the United States to get Nicaragua and Cuba to halt such activities. The issue would be brought up when President Bush meets with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev this weekend, Bush Administration officials said. 
''The President will tell Gorbachev that the introduction of surface-to-air weapons in the guerrilla war in El Salvador is a dangerous escalation of a conflict, contrary to high-level Soviet assurances,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. ''It is an example of old thinking. The President will press the Soviets to take action to insure that their allies cease this outrageous behavior.''
Analysts said the Administration wants to do all that it can to publicize Nicaraguan shipments of Soviet-made arms to El Salvador to create international pressure on the Sandinista Government in Managua to live up to its promises to other regional leaders not to support insurgencies in neighboring countries.
 
U.S. Accepted Soviet Assurances
For the last 10 months, the Bush Administration has been accepting assurances by the Soviet Union that it was cutting off its arms deliveries to Central America and exerting pressure on Nicaragua and Cuba not export their Marxist revolutions to neighboring countries.
Only hours after a two-engine Cessna aircraft, purportedly making an arms run to Salvadoran rebels from Nicaragua, crashed Saturday in southeastern El Salvador with 24 Soviet-made SAM-7 surface-to-air missiles and one American Redeye missile on board, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called the State Department from his home in Houston and ordered that the Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, be summoned and handed a formal protest.
Administration officials doubt that the Soviets are actually encouraging Nicaragua to make arms shipments. But they argue that if Moscow can use its leverage to help bring down repressive Communist leaders in East Germany and Czechoslovakia, it can stop Nicaragua from sending Soviet-made missiles to Salvadoran rebels.
 
Questioning Soviet Priorities
A senior Administration official said Mr. Dubinin was told that Nicaragua and Cuba could not provide military assistance to the Salvadoran guerrillas were it not for the fact that the Soviet Union was providing these two countries together with between $6 billion and $7 billion a year.
''Therefore,'' the Administration officials reportedly told the Soviet diplomat, ''we hold you responsible.''
The official said that Mr. Dubinin was also told that it is difficult for the United States to take Moscow's appeals for economic assistance from the West seriously as long as the Soviet Union can afford to continue pouring money into Nicaragua and Cuba.
The Soviet envoy reportedly was also told that the United States has gone out of its way not to exploit the changes in Eastern Europe in ways that might undermine Soviet security, but that the Soviets are not reciprocating in Central America.

HEADLINE: Oakland Journal;
Where More Than A Highway Collapsed

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 27

 BODY:
Each time the wrecking ball pounds the concrete remains of the Nimitz Freeway, the streets of West Oakland vibrate and the residents of the neighborhood shudder anew.
The aftershocks of the Oct. 17 earthquake have subsided in many parts of the Bay Area. But here in the poorest pocket of Oakland, where 42 people died in the collapse of the double-deck roadway, there will be no peace or forgetting for years to come.
Demolition is three-quarters complete, after a month of round-the-clock jackhammers, but there will be dust and detours well into the 1990's as the Nimitz is rebuilt. 
And this week seismic testing is supposed to begin here, with engineers rocking one standing block of the highway to determine why the mile-and-a-quarter section fell, and how best to reinforce similar structures against future jolts.
''Not much we can do about it but accept it or move,'' said Joseph Perkins, whose decrepit Victorian house is next to the test area.
This is a neighborhood with more than its share of boarded-up or burned-out buildings, where men pass the afternoon drinking from bottles sheathed in brown paper. Front porches sag and paint peels from the private houses. The housing projects are grim cinder-block bunkers.
By virtually any index, West Oakland is the harshest of this city's neighborhoods, with the highest rates of unemployment, infant mortality and welfare. Huey P. Newton, founder of the Black Panther Party, was murdered just a block from the Nimitz last summer in a drug-related shooting, a common occurrence here.
Since the quake, there are new indignities. A neighborhood school was turned into a temporary morgue and for weeks the streets stank of death. Scores of homes were damaged beyond repair, swelling the ranks of the homeless. Local people do not hold much hope for employment related to the highway, since few belong to construction unions.
For a time the area was overrun by reporters, including network anchors who incongruously set up shop in white stretch limousines. For a while, residents were hospitable, offering cornbread, coffee and the use of their telephones. Now many are bitter, asking for money before they will talk. ''Can you help a guy with a buck?'' asked Wendell Price. ''We're so bad off around here.''
Local leaders note that the poor of West Oakland do not have the luxury of resettling during the chaos, which is wearing them down. ''They cannot get away to put their life in order or forget,'' said the Rev. Walter H. Brown, pastor of the Taylor Memorial United Methodist Church.
These leaders hope to galvanize the community against rebuilding the Nimitz in its original route, which bisects the neighborhood, leaving one portion of West Oakland isolated.
''No one thought of the social pathology of this,'' said Edward J. Blakely, chairman of the city planning department at the University of California at Berkeley. ''But a section of this city atrophied and died.''
Oakland has a black mayor, and there are many members of minorities on the City Council and Alameda County Board of Supervisors. The power structure was very different when the Nimitz was built in the 1950's. ''People of color were not represented,'' Mr. Brown said. ''No one was paying attention at any level of government.''
Now, local leaders say, the state is listening. The Department of Transportation has agreed to review proposals for alternative routes.
Decisions about the Nimitz could resonate in the 1990 mayoral and council elections here. Candidates are expected to walk a fine line, courting votes in West Oakland without stalling reconstruction of a truck route that serves the Port of Oakland and is essential to the city's precarious economy.
For the first month after the quake, the state was less than sensitive to the residents, who live side by side with freight yards and machine shops. Until mid-November, they endured 24-hour demolition, which was then scaled back, stilling the jackhammers at night.
''The noise just came through the house, like it was made of paper,'' said Cynthia Talbert, who lives in a project next to the site. ''The kids were so tired they didn't want to go to school. Now that they cooled it down, it's not as bad. But each time the ball hits, it sure brings back memories.''

HEADLINE: Long-Secret History of C.I.A. Sheds Light on Battles Over Authority

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The State Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the military hampered the Central Intelligence Agency in its infancy by bickering about authority, according to a long-secret history of the agency's early years.
The 1,000-page narrative, written in 1953 by the agency's first historian, Arthur B. Darling, is the first C.I.A. document to be declassified and transferred to the National Archives for release to the public under the agency's historical review program.
A copy of the history was delivered to President Bush last Wednesday by William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, and Don W. Wilson, Archivist of the United States. 
Mr. Webster said other agency records would be declassified and transferred to the Archives.
 
Note Cautions Readers
The declassified version of the history was accompanied by a note from the C.I.A.'s history staff cautioning readers that Mr. Darling, a former professor of history at Yale, had ''a definite and sometimes controversial point of view.''
''Darling blames the State Department, the F.B.I., and what he terms the military establishment - especially the heads of the military intelligence services - for much of the hardship which the early C.I.A. (and its predecessor, the Central Intelligence Group) endured,'' the note says.
The history staff also said that Allen Dulles, who became Director of Central Intelligence in 1953, reportedly ''did not concur with Darling's conclusions'' and restricted access to the history.
Mr. Darling was the agency's historian from 1952 to 1954. He died in 1971.
He wrote that sniping by the military departments began as soon as the Office of Strategic Services, forerunner of the C.I.A., was established by President Roosevelt in World War II.
Brig. Gen. John Magruder, deputy director of the O.S.S., told Mr. Darling that career military officers ''lowered their horns'' against the economists, geographers, historians and scientists recruited for the C.I.A. Mr. Darling conceded in his history that the military might have been justified in withholding information because the O.S.S. ''deserved part of its reputation for being a sieve.''
 
The Issue of Security
However, he quotes the O.S.S. chief, Gen. William J. Donovan, as saying that it was the military men who were the ''leaky boys.''
In any event, Mr. Darling wrote, ''They are reluctant to this moment in 1953 to give a central civilian agency intelligence which exposes their capabilities in war.''
''The result,'' he continued, ''has been interference with the flow of raw materials essential to the realistic estimates which should go to the makers of diplomatic policy and military strategy.''
On Nov. 18, 1944, with World War II less than a year from its end, General Donovan urged President Roosevelt to turn the O.S.S. into a permanent central intelligence system. But, Mr. Darling wrote, the F.B.I., the military, the State Department and other agencies were hostile to that idea.
On Sept. 20, 1945, President Harry S. Truman disbanded the O.S.S. and ordered the State Department to develop a postwar intelligence network. On Jan. 24, 1946, Truman issued a directive creating the Central Intelligence Group, which was prohibited from interfering with ''internal security functions.''
In 1947 the Central Intelligence Group became the Central Intelligence Agency, as part of the same law that merged the War and Navy Departments into the new Department of Defense.

LENGTH: 1470 words

HEADLINE: Pressure Grows for Cuts in Intelligence Spending

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Senior Pentagon officials' decision to consider substantial cuts in the military budget over the next few years has intensified pressure on intelligence agencies to take an equal share of the reductions.
Although the issue has not yet been directly joined, Administration officials and members of Congress say the battle lines are already forming between those who view a diminishing Soviet threat as a reason for reducing intelligence spending and those who believe that more extensive intelligence information will be needed to keep abreast of rapidly changing developments abroad.
''In my recent conversations with senior intelligence officials, many have been privately concerned that the United States intelligence community will have to take a 'proportional hit' -that is, be reduced by the same percentage the defense budget is being cut,'' said Kenneth E. deGraffenreid, former head of intelligence programs in the Reagan White House. ''There is no question that many in the Office of Management and Budget and the money side of the Defense Department intend to go that way.''
Current and former officials said the budget pressures would likely prompt a reassessment of whether to shift money now spent on monitoring Soviet military movements in Eastern Europe to regions and topics that historically accorded less emphasis. 
American officials said it was possible to achieve savings on intelligence operations in Europe as the NATO nations pulled back from their posture of preparing for an all-out war in Central Europe. The United States spends billions on eavesdropping and satellite photography to collect intelligence on Soviet and Warsaw Pact forces.
 
Spending Is Buried in Budget
Intelligence spending is not publicly disclosed; it is hidden in the Pentagon budget by overstating the amount of money needed for various military programs. Government officials said it represents less than 10 percent of the $300 billion Pentagon total.
Because their financing is part of the Pentagon budget, any effort to exempt intelligence programs from cuts will mean greater reductions in military programs.
Intelligence spending grew as much as four times as fast as the Pentagon's overall budget in the early years of the Reagan Administration. And in the past five years as the Pentagon budget has actually declined once inflation is accounted for, intelligence spending has continued to grow at a modest rate.
In recent weeks the military services, at the request of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, have identified $180 billion in possible cuts in spending for 1992-94.
Officials said the prospect of tightening, or even flat budgets, could force some hard choices for the intelligence chiefs, causing them to define more carefully what is truly needed by the President and his aides.
One Government official summarized the predicament this way:
''If you've had an intelligence requirement that says, 'I want to be prepared to go to war on a moment's notice; I want to know when this Soviet commander turns on his radar within seconds,' the question is: In a peacetime environment do you need to collect and report that information on daily basis?''
 
Senator Sees New Soviet Threat
Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said through a spokesman, ''Now is not the time to reduce the intelligence budget; it's just the opposite.''
Senator Boren says that as the Soviet Union cuts military spending, it will put greater emphasis on the theft of Western technololgy, his spokesman said, and this will increase the pressure on counterintelligence agencies. Senator Boren also contended that the anticipated signing of new arms control treaties will place costly requirements on the intelligence agencies for verification.
In the House, the intelligence panel's chairman, Representative Anthony C. Beilenson, Democrat of California, said that if present trends continue in Europe, he foresees a slow, steady decline in intelligence spending over the next few years.
''One could argue that the intelligence budgets should be cut more carefully and slowly than defense,'' Mr. Beilenson said. ''But if we continue to believe the Soviet threat is diminishing, then I think the intelligence budget will be cut into over the years to come.''
At best, Administration officials said, the intelligence agencies can plan on flat budgets while they are being asked for better reporting on trends in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union, Central America, China and the economic powers of the Pacific Basin.
The agencies are also being pushed to develop better capabilities for supporting the war on drugs, and some consumers of intelligence - including President Bush - have complained about a lack of solid reporting from human sources.
Administration officials said no decisions had been made on the intelligence budgets, and one official said, ''This is not the sort of thing that is going to happen over one year; it's something that will develop over five years.''
 
Separate Budget Is Considered
The uncertainty has prompted some Administration officials to consider -and one prominent former intelligence officer to advocate - the idea of separating the intelligence budget from the Pentagon's, thus allowing Congress for the first time to vote on a publicly announced total figure for intelligence.
''My worry is that as we start a new cycle of draw-down in the Pentagon, we will once again incrementally take a slice off intelligence,'' said Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. ''There is much less hazard in letting people know how much money we spend on intelligence then in letting the cuts get made almost accidentially.''
Admiral Inman said history shows that the intelligence agencies suffered lasting damage in periods of reduced Pentagon spending. As a former director of Naval Intelligence and head of the National Security Agency, Admiral Inman traced the pattern of intelligence spending as it grew through the 1950's, was altered by the Vietnam War and sharply reduced in the 1970's.
After World War II, he said, Government leaders concluded that ''never again should we be so ill-informed about the outside world.'' This meant better intelligence than simply counting an opponent's military forces.
The intention, Admiral Inman said, was to create a ''classified Encyclopedia Brittanica'' of the world's countries. Financing for the Central Intelligence Agency rose steadily throughout the 1950's, hitting a peak in 1958. It stayed flat from 1958 to 1964, when he said a decision was made to move analysts on other subjects to work on the Vietnam War.
''We gave up on analytical efforts judged not to be problems, beginning in the Western Hemisphere and then to Europe, Africa and later Asia,'' Admiral Inman said.
 
Embassy Shrinkage Cuts Data
In 1967, as a way of improving the nation's trade balance, the Johnson Administration cut the number of people in American embassies, a move that Admiral Inman said reduced intelligence collection.
In 1971, he said, costly new technology was discovered that greatly expanded the potential of overhead surveillance. Nixon Administration officials decided to buy it and absorb the cost by cutting manpower from other technical areas.
As President Richard M. Nixon withdrew American forces from Vietnam and began reducing the Pentagon budget, ''all those cuts went straight across the intelligence budget,'' the admiral said.
In 1973, when the intelligence agencies failed to predict the 1973 war between Israel and Egypt, William Clements, Deputy Secretary of Defense, ordered a 25 percent reduction in intelligence agencies under direct Pentagon control, which included the National Security Agency but not the C.I.A.
By the end of the 1970's, he Admiral Inman said, intelligence employment was down 40 percent from the level of 1958.
When new issues arose in the 1980's, like strife in Central America or terrorism, American intelligence was not effectively covering countries involved. ''We would see things, and couldn't tell what they meant,'' the admiral said. ''We didn't know what the norm was.'' To correct the problem, President Reagan ordered large increases in intelligence spending, starting ''a slow process to begin covering not just the Soviet Union,'' Admiral Inman said. ''The buildup has been broad-based, including human intelligence, clandestine collection and overt collection as well as broad increases in the analytical side.
''It was possible largely because the executive branch was prepared to let intelligence budgets grow at a faster rate than the rest of the defense budget and because of bipartisan support on the intelligence committees and enough support on the armed services committees.''
