HEADLINE: Democracy Speaks in India

 BODY:
What most distinguishes a democracy is the people's right to reject those in power. In India, the world's largest democracy and the third world's most durable, voters have done just that, denying a majority to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party. They gave no clear mandate to any single political force but everywhere vented their anger at incumbents for corruption, inequality, religious discord and a variety of local failures. 
Forming a coherent, effective new government is certain to be a challenging task. But the challenge is a constructive one, thanks to India's continued faith in democratic change.
Mr. Gandhi, political heir to his mother, Indira Gandhi, and his grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru, could yet survive, but only as a coalition leader, and only with greatly diminished power. It's a mighty fall, for which Mr. Gandhi can blame only himself.
In 1984, buoyed by sympathy over his mother's assassination, Mr. Gandhi led his Congress Party to a huge triumph. He promised clean government, economic liberalization and secularism. But he concentrated real power in his personal entourage, weakening the party and tempting corruption. He achieved solid economic gains, but these disproportionately benefited an urban elite. Relations with India's two strongest neighbors, China and Pakistan, began to improve. But a huge defense buildup and clumsy power plays against Sri Lanka and Nepal gave India the reputation of a regional bully.
The opposition ranges all the way from Communist to Hindu fundamentalist. Its leading force is a center-right coalition headed by Vishwanath Pratap Singh, a former Finance Minister. Most worrisome are the strong gains of the fundamentalist Bharatiya Janata Party. Its drive to rebuild a Hindu temple on a site sacred to both Hindus and Muslims has already cost more than 300 lives. Political violence during the five-day voting period cost at least 100 more, making this India's deadliest election.
American interests are best served by a democratic, peaceful India. Those goals would be equally well served by Mr. Gandhi or Mr. Singh or any other likely prime minister - provided that the fundamentalists don't impose divisive policies as the price of needed political support. Nor do the major parties differ much over bilateral issues like nuclear proliferation and Afghanistan, although the fundamentalists favor nuclear arms production. Voters sensibly rejected crude last-ditch efforts by the Congress Party to paint the opposition as American pawns.
In too many countries, dictators cite poverty, corruption and social diversity as excuses to avoid elections. In India, those ills spur democratic electoral change. That example deserves praise, and emulation.

HEADLINE: How Japanese Undercut U.S. Companies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Trade Law's Tangled Web,'' Peter Passell's Nov. 8 Economic Scene column, omits or confuses important facts to reach tangled conclusions about the anticircumvention provision in United States antidumping law.
He correctly points out that Japanese forklift truck manufacturers were found by the Commerce Department to be dumping their products in the United States market, in some instances at half the fair market value - and in the process damaging the United States industry. The remedy for this offense under both international and United States law is for the manufacturer to adjust prices to eliminate the dumping or pay additional antidumping duties to the United States Treasury. 
Certain Japanese companies decided to do neither. Instead, they sought to evade the duties by shipping parts from Japan (and, in some cases, Mexico, Indonesia or Turkey) and assembling them in the United States. Mr. Passell does not mention that in the two quarters after the final antidumping order was issued, imports of complete forklifts subject to duty were 52 percent less than for the same two quarters in the previous year, while imports of Japanese forklift parts, which would evade the duty, increased by 403 percent.
The value of forklift parts imports jumped from $16.8 million between July and December 1987 to $84.2 million between July and December 1988.
Mr. Passell's concern that enforcement of the trade laws will lead to less Japanese investment in the United States is misplaced. Certainly, the flood of parts imports does nothing to help the United States economy, nor does it represent any real investment in the productive facilities of this country.
Further, one questions whether Mr. Passell relied on unbiased sources for his statement that the United States-made part of the Japanese forklifts assembled in this country ''reportedly exceeds 20 percent.'' Does that figure represent investment in the United States or the profit, selling and other expenses that any importer would experience?
Unless the anticircumvention law is enforced rigorously, Japanese forklift truck producers will have little incentive to invest in productive facilities in the United States. Indeed, Mr. Passell's approach to enforcement -or more aptly, nonenforcement - of the anticircumvention provision of the law will not only lead to less investment in the United States, but it will also result in undermining fair trade laws and increase protectionist approaches to our trade problems. This is a result that Congress clearly did not, and Mr. Passell should not, want.
 
PAUL C. ROSENTHAL
Washington, Nov. 14, 1989
 The writer is counsel to the Hyster Company, maker of forklift trucks.

HEADLINE: Too Soon to Slash Defense

BYLINE: By Caspar W. Weinberger; Caspar W. Weinberger was Secretary of Defense from 1981 to 1987.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Is anybody listening out there?
The Secretary of Defense, appearing on a national television program, is told by reporters that Congress will probably require even deeper budgetary cuts than the 12.6 percent reduction that has been imposed since fiscal 1987. He is also told that the Air Force's response to the Secretary's request for ideas about how to meet such deep reductions has already been leaked to the press. 
The Secretary responds that he has indeed been told by Congressional leaders that they will insist on deep cuts, perhaps totaling $180 billion in the next few years. He agrees that the risk of a Soviet attack against the West is lower than in many years. Then he is asked if he has changed his belief that Mikhail Gorbachev is likely to be driven out of power soon. No, he replies, he still thinks that is right.
The Secretary never said he wanted these deep cuts; he never said it is safe to make them, and it is clear he has not ''ordered'' them.
Nonetheless, the next day, the press reports that the Secretary wants to cut $180 billion from defense in three years (Associated Press); five years (USA Today); six years (The Wall Street Journal); three years beginning in 1992 (The New York Times).
I never heard Secretary Dick Cheney say he ''wanted to cut'' any amount. While the ''likelihood of all-out conflict between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R.'' is indeed lower than ever, as he said, it is largely because of the total failure of Communism and Socialism as an economic system and the military strength we regained from 1981 to 1988. All these welcome changes we are seeing in the Warsaw Pact countries are neither irreversible nor cause for concluding that the West and NATO can reduce their military strength now.
Less than six months ago, China, under Deng Xiaoping, was ''irreversibly'' launched on the road to free market economics and more democracy, or so most people believed and hoped. One afternoon in Tiananmen Square reversed all that. We all hope it will change back someday. But it is certainly clear that the Soviets did not reduce their military forces on the China border on the ground that there was less of a threat because of apparently ''irreversible'' changes in China.
But Congress, having already made major cuts in President Bush's requests for defense funding for fiscal 1990, now insists on much deeper cuts for the next several years. These cuts will hurt all the military services, cast doubt on the future success of the all-volunteer program, reduce our readiness and cast aside many of the elements of our regained strength. And all of this because of some pleasing rhetoric and some clear demonstrations that people who have been forced to live under Communism hate it as much as always.
There has been no evidence yet that Mr. Gorbachev, if he is sincere, can last. And there is no question whatever that if Mr. Gorbachev or his successor wants to use force and repression, the Soviet Union, with its huge military might not yet meaningfully reduced, will continue to be the biggest threat to peace and freedom.
Under these circumstances, cutting the heart out of our defenses for the next several years is roughly like canceling all your fire insurance because you did not have a fire last year.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.

 BODY:
In many ways, the beginning sessions of Bill Granville's Granville Academy resemble an introductory class in business administration, with the emphasis on accounting. Indeed, the class is held in a large lecture room at Rider College here, in the glistening new business administration building.
''A woman owns a car worth $1,500,'' the instructor said. ''So what is that?'' ''An asset,'' several in the class answered. ''Why is it an asset?'' ''Because she owns it!'' ''But she owes $750. What is that? ''A liability.'' ''Why?'' ''Because she owes it!'' ''So what's the owner's equity and how do you arrive at it?'' 
''Seven hundred and fifty dollars, by subtracting liabilities from assets.''
The lesson is rudimentary, but grows more complex, easing into balance sheets, ''a snapshot of where you are financially at a particular moment in time,'' and on to gross and net profits, sales and operating expenses, other overhead and the like.
The instructor, Joseph S. Marrow, is the accounting supervisor for the marketing division of British Petroleum in Keasbey. He is teaching the class because he is an old friend of the founder of the five-year-old academy, William Granville Jr., who is also an oil executive, vice president of a division of the Mobil Corporation in New York City. Mr. Marrow, who is 42 years old, entered the oil business because of Mr. Granville, 48.
 
Mr. Marrow met
Mr. Granville in Trenton, in the inner city, where Bill Granville, called just Bro' in those days, led a gang, the Whips East Trenton Trotters. Bro' was good with his fists. The Whips wore blue-and-yellow jackets with a snake on the back. They fought, stole and used a fair amount of dope.
''I saw a man who was very angry in those days,'' said Mr. Marrow, who also saw a transformation in Mr. Granville. ''Someone who was looking to prove himself as a man. That was the impression you had - a man who was tough.''
That was a long time ago. William Granville did well in math, found out that he was smart and earned a cum laude degree in mathematics from Delaware State College, which also recently awarded him an honorary doctorate in humane letters. He started climbing the corporate ladder, but he has not forgotten.
The students at the Granville Academy are black teen-agers, 13 to 15 in this class, and they are mostly from the inner-city areas of Trenton. ''They don't think of black businessmen and investors at this level,'' Mr. Granville said. ''To them, the inner city is it, and success in business in the inner city means owning a barbershop or a beverage store. Business does not mean planning, economics and corporate structure. It isn't a negative image they have. It's a non-image.'' Mr. Granville's academy meets two evenings a month at Rider or the Princeton Theological Seminary. The surroundings are intended to defeat a ''ghetto mentality.''
The ad hoc four-year program enrolls 20 to 30 students a year. The academy has had four graduates, all of whom went to college in business disciplines.
The students - recruited through churches, schools and word of mouth - enroll for different reasons. Coltrane Stansbury, 14, said the academy offered ''long-term benefits, communication skills and learning to deal with people in the realm of business.''
Marwan Malloy, 13, said she wanted to know ''the fundamentals of business.'' Camille Roberts, also 13, said that she wanted to be a doctor, but that ''I also sort of want to have my own business, too.''
The president of Rider, Frank N. Elliott, was so impressed with the academy that he arranged for up to eight scholarships, worth $15,000 a year, for its graduates.
After attending a class on insurance, he said, ''I can truthfully say that my daughters,'' who are both college graduates, ''are not nearly as sophisticated about insurance as these 8th-to-12th graders.''
Mr. Granville suggested that the successful executive might provide an alternative role model to the ''other entrepreneur,'' the inner-city drug dealer. ''The dope dealer has income, bags of cash and gold chains,'' he said. ''The investor has property, marketable securities and is on his way to a better life.''
A 15-year-old in the class said that he sold marijuana when he was ''in the seventh grade'' and made $100 to $150 a week, but that he then thought about his situation.
''I just looked around and saw more and more people getting arrested, more people falling off, dying,'' he said. ''I just started thinking about it.''

HEADLINE: Historic House May Get New Life at Last

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
In the more than 200 years that it has stood on the East River waterfront, the home of Capt. Joseph Rose has endured few periods as trying as the last decade, while New York City officials have tried and tried and tried again to salvage what has become little more than a brick shell.
But there may be new hope for the four-story Captain Rose House at 273 Water Street, which is the third-oldest building in Manhattan, with one of the raciest histories of any of New York's structural antiquities.
It has been auctioned for $325,000 to two Manhattan real-estate investors, Edmond Ohebshalom and Eli Sakhai. Mr. Ohebshalom said they hope to renovate it with a ground-floor store and offices above.
Under terms set by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which controls the house, they cannot complete the purchase until their plans are approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The house, between Peck Slip and Dover Street, is within the South Street Seaport Historic District. The building must be rehabilitated and cannot be enlarged. 
 
Looking New, Feeling Old
''The key is to make this building look new but feel old,'' said the city's Housing Commissioner, Abraham Biderman. He said builders were ''daunted'' by the challenge of retaining the small structure's historic character while making it functional and economically attractive for the contemporary market.
Although the house is in a state of near ruin, some of its facade - the second floor in particular - is a handsome testament to 18th-century building crafts, with Flemish-bond brickwork and splayed brownstone lintels and even some wooden window frames that are presumed to be original.
But from the street, the sky can be seen through the fourth-floor windows. Alarmingly large cracks run through the exterior walls. The interior is badly charred and appears to be close to collapse.
It is not known exactly when Captain Rose built his house, which is 25 feet wide and originally was two stories and an attic, but it was standing in the 1780's. In Manhattan, only St. Paul's Chapel on lower Broadway and the Morris-Jumel Mansion uptown predate it.
 
Brig Moored Nearby
At the time of its construction, before land was filled, the Rose property was on the riverfront and the captain kept his brig, Industry, moored behind his house. When he was not in New York, Captain Rose sailed as far as the Bay of Honduras, trading in sugar, mahogany, indigo, rice and tobacco.
In the late 18th and early 19th centuries, the house was an apothecary shop, rooming house, hotel and brothel. Its most notorious incarnation was as Kit Burns's Sportsman's Hall, a saloon that kept its patrons entertained by staging bloody fights among dogs or between dogs and rats. In 1869, it was converted into a ''home for fallen women.''
More conventionally in the 20th century, the building was a loft and storehouse. In 1904, after a fire in the upper floors, it was expanded to four stories. It was abandoned by 1976, when squatters started a fire which consumed the roof and caused severe interior damage.
City officials took the building from its owner in 1976 for failure to pay taxes. In 1983, the housing agency tried to dispose of the house under a 30-year lease to a development team that included the architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle, specialists in restoration work. But that arrangement fell apart. A second attempt in 1985 failed.
 
A Love for South Street Area
Commissioner Biderman said housing officials finally determined that leasing the building would not work but selling it might, ''as long as we could maintain restrictions so that the building could retain its historic context.''
''Obviously, it would be more financially attractive to a buyer,'' Mr. Biderman said. ''That's why we got someone to bite this time.''
Mr. Ohebshalom said he became aware of the Rose house while looking through a catalogue of city properties for a Sept. 27 auction. He was attracted to the property, he said, because of his love for the South Street area. There were no other bidders, and $325,000 was the minimum price.
This would be the first major construction project Mr. Ohebshalom has undertaken, although he described himself as being ''in the real-estate business for the past five years.'' He said Mr. Sakhai was also involved in real estate.
Mr. Ohebshalom said a housing official ''gave me some hope that it will be much easier to do'' than it appears. But, he conceded, ''when you look at the building, you get scared.''

HEADLINE: Martha Wallace, 61; Business Consultant Led Big Foundation

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Martha Redfield Wallace, a management consultant who was a director of many corporations, died of a heart attack Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old. She was the founder in 1983 of a consulting business, Redfield Associates, which helped to raise money for many causes. Its headquarters were in River House at 435 East 52d Street. 
From 1967 to 1982, she was executive director of the Henry Luce Foundation and a member of the foundation's board. For four years before joining the foundation, she worked for Time Inc. as a researcher and as assistant director of corporate development.
Mrs. Wallace had been a director of Bristol-Myers until it agreed to merge with Squibb this year. She had also been a director of the Chemical Bank and continued to serve on the board of American Express and the surveillance committee of the New York Stock Exchange. She was a director of the exchange from 1977 until 1983.
 
On Rhodes Scholar Panel
She served on the Williams College board from 1974 to 1986, then becoming a trustee emeritus. She was a director of the American Judicature Society and its board chairman from 1981 to 1983. She was a trustee of the New York Racing Association and a former director of the Legal Aid Society.
She was chairman of the Rhodes Scholar selection committee from 1983 to 1986 and a director of the Citizens Crime Commission in Manhattan. From 1972 to 1982, she was a director of the Council on Foreign Relations and since 1980 she had been a member of the American Council on Germany, a private group concerned with United States-German relations.
Mrs. Wallace, who was born in Omaha, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Wellesley College. She received a master's degree from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, where she was an instructor and assistant to the dean in the School of Economics.
She was an economist with the State Department from 1951 to 1953, and before joining Time, she worked for RCA and International Business Machines.
Her marriage to Donald L. Wallace, a lawyer, ended in divorce in the late 1970's.
She is survived by a sister, Janice Redfield Roach of Omaha.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 5; Science Desk

LENGTH: 2096 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Counts o Computer Edge In the Race for Advanced TV

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
DESPITE a slow start by the United States in the race to build television sets with razor-sharp pictures, a growing group of scientists and engineers say there is hope for a comeback. Indeed, some believe conditions are ripe for America to vault over the international competition in a field seen as vital to economic success in the 1990's and beyond.
''We've got a tremendous opportunity to leapfrog limited technology and really develop a television of the future,'' said Dr. W. Russell Neuman, director of communications research at the media laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
''It would be a big mistake to write off the field,'' agreed Dr. Dimitris Anastassiou, a professor of electrical engineering at Columbia University who recently helped organize a technical symposium on high-definition television. 
Experts say the main reason for hope is that the Japanese and Europeans, by virtue of an early lead, have locked themselves into a type of technology that may become antiquated. That technology is based on analog signals, which mimic the scenes and sounds observed by a camera and render these, in all their variations, as continuous electronic waves. The future of television, these experts say, increasingly lies in the direction of digital processing, the same technique computers use and is an area of great American strength. Digital signals turn the complexity of the real world into a code based on the numbers 0 and 1, or, in electrical terms, plus and minus. The code can be manipulated to process or transmit volumes of information with great accuracy.
''We have a hope because this country is so good in computers,'' said Dr. Arun N. Netravali, director of the computing systems research laboratory at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories.
Pessimists say the race is already nearly lost, and that even if the United States came up with an innovative design for a high-definition television, few companies would be able to make HDTV's now. They note that Zenith is the last large American company still in the television business.
The race for high-definition television is considered important by some experts because the technology may represent more than a path to sparkling images and sound as good as that on compact disks. Some experts see it creating a wide variety of new products, including video systems for education, industry, medical imaging and the military. Moreover, the technology is so demanding electronically, requiring scores of advanced new computer chips, that it is seen as a new driving force for the semiconductor industry, potentially providing even greater demand than computers do.
''The companies and countries that control the development of HDTV will have a huge lead in the coming competition for leadership in the electronics world,'' Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the House subcommittee on telecommunications, recently said in opening a hearing on high-definition television. Other experts disagree, saying the importance of the field has been exaggerated.
 
A 20-Year Japanese Quest
Japan has long led the fledgling field, having embarked on HDTV research 20 years ago and investing an estimated $1 billion. European governments and companies over the past five years have spent about $200 million. Spending in the United States is estimated to be less than $100 million.
But both Europe and Japan have based their efforts on the development of analog systems that use wave-like transmission signals. These signals can easily be disrupted by static. Moreover, they are broadcast by satellites (Japan has one in orbit and Europe will soon) and are therefore not available to regular television viewers. Satellite transmissions aimed at a small geographic area or nation are relatively easy to accomplish. But experts say they cannot rival the economic advantages of terrestrial broadcasting that allows local programing and local advertising.
In contrast, the United States is focusing on the creation of what experts believe is a more egalitarian and economically promising system that could be broadcast over regular television channels. Moreover, there is growing enthusiasm about doing it with digital signals, which could dramatically cut distortion.
Several of the 20 or so American systems now under development are partly based on digital transmission, and American scientists at schools like Columbia and M.I.T. are racing to see how far digital technology can go in the search for the perfect television picture.
''As far as transmitting over the air, we're already way ahead of Europe and Japan,'' said William F. Schreiber, director of M.I.T.'s advanced television research program. ''They simply haven't addressed the problem seriously.'' But some other experts note that Europe and Japan have begun work on tackling the challenge of terrestrial broadcasting, instead of by satellite. >gfcrossline>More Detail in More Lines The basic goal of high-definition television is to increase the number of lines in a television picture, thus sharpening it. Today's television pictures in America and Japan are composed of 525 scanning lines, while those in Europe have 625. More scanning lines provide more details in the image on the screen. HDTV proposals call for various numbers of lines: 787, 1,050, 1,125, or 1,250.
The challenge is not just making high-quality picture tubes. It also is devising a way to process and transmit all the extra information that is needed to animate the added scanning lines.
Last year, the Federal Communications Commission ruled that new American HDTV systems would not be allowed to make the nation's existing 160 million TV sets obsolete. That means broadcasters must give viewers the standard signal and, if they choose, the new HDTV signal for those who have special TV sets to receive it. In addition, the F.C.C. ruled that HDTV broadcasters must operate in the same wavelength range as older sets because the electromagnetic spectrum was considered too crowded to appropriate a new area.
In technical terms, the challenge is to squeeze the 30 megahertz of signal band width needed for high-definition television into the band of 6 megahertz for each channel that normal broadcasting uses. Some experts have likened the process to squeezing an elephant into a bathtub.
The solution is signal compression. It relies heavily on digital processing, which breaks the analog signals from a camera into digital pulses that are sliced, diced and rearranged with incredible precision.
In a technique known as conditional replenishment, a series of images is digitally analyzed and only new features are transmitted, such as those that show an object moving. The static background is sent only once. Another technique reduces the data flow even further by taking into account the fact that the human eye perceives fewer details on a moving object than a stationary one.
''If you have a lot of motion, you don't send as much information,'' said Wayne C. Luplow, executive director of electronic systems research at the Zenith Corp., which is developing an HDTV system.
 
Elimination of Noise
Both Europe and Japan do some of this kind of digital signal compression. But then they switch back to analog signals for transmission to television sets, since that was the accepted approach when they started their work. In contrast, American scientists are working to extend the digital process all the way to the receiving TV set.
The advantage of digital transmission is error reduction. Electronic flaws, called noise, that invade an analog signal are sometimes nearly impossible to differentiate from the signal itself. But since a digital signal is made up of a string of simple pulses, noise stands out and is easily removed. In its place a computer can generate a corrected pulse after making a quick assessment of nearby pulses.
For instance, a black dot of interference could be replaced with a correct red dot of color, based on a survey indicating most nearby dots were red. Similar techniques of digital transmission are how deep-space probes send back stunning photos like those Voyager 2 recently radioed from Neptune.
''Digital communication by definition has higher fidelity,'' said Dr. Neuman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
In addition, by going directly from digital processing to digital transmission, rather than switching back to analog, ''You skip a step of processing, which improves performance and makes it more cost effective,'' said John I. Taylor, a Zenith spokesman.
The problem is that digital transmission is still only experimental. Researchers have tried over-the-air digital radio broadcasts, but are just starting to tackle the challenges of of over-the-air digital television.
Zenith, which recently decided to sell its personal computer business and focus on high-definition television instead, is one of the pioneers of digital transmission of HDTV. Its proposed signal is a hybrid, part analog and part digital. The digital portion includes low-frequency video, the pulses that keep receivers synchronized with transmitters, and the audio signal for high-quality stereo sound. The analog signal contains high-frequency video information, which helps make up the picture.
 
Less Power Means More Channels
An important advantage of this approach, Zenith says, is a vast reduction in the amount of power needed for the broadcasting transmitter, since the low-frequency part of the analog signal that has been eliminated is also the power-hungry part. Zenith's HDTV signal, it says, uses less than 0.2 percent of the power needed for regular transmissions.
This power reduction, in turn, allows Zenith's HDTV signal to use the channels that usually are empty in crowded city television markets. Because analog signals are so strong, they can be broadcast only by skipping channels between them so they do not interfere with each other. For instance, a city with several stations might have channels 3, 5, 7 and 9 in use. But the low-power Zenith signal can be broadcast in the taboo channels in between without causing interference.
Scientists say proposals like Zenith's are but the first step on the digital highway, and that the transmission journey might be complete in the next 5 to 10 years.
''Over the air, if you can receive it, digital will have the advantage of being perfect,'' said Dr. Anastassiou of Columbia University. He noted that there are a host of challenges, and potential solutions, to the goal.
It will be at least two years before the Federal Communications Commission decides on standards for over-the-air HDTV broadcasts. Some options under study would make it easier to extend the digital range; others would make it harder.
Some scientists say a better digital route is through a national network of glass fibers that connect homes. Such fibers can carry enormous amounts of digital information in the form of laser-light pulses, transmitting not only digital HDTV signals to American homes, but also other types of information, including high-speed computer data.
''We want to make this the superhighway of the future,'' Jules A. Bellisio, a fiber enthusiast at Bell Communications Research in Redbank, N.J., told the recent HDTV symposium at Columbia.
 
Adding Computers for 'Smart' TV
Finally, scientists say, the advent of digital television will aid the merging of computers and television, with the prospect of a rush of combined uses. Smart TV's, for instance, could automatically scan the digital airwaves for shows of interest, recording them when certain key words were present.
Several scientists and engineers warned that American HDTV would materialize only if there was steady Federal financial support for the field. Most direct in his comments was Dr. Neuman of M.I.T., who said, ''The lack of leadership in the Bush Administration may blow it.''
Dr. Netravali of A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories, in Murray Hill, N.J., echoed the need for a strong initiative, saying, ''If we take no action, obviously we won't have anything in this country.''
On the other hand, some experts say, HDTV development could prove so successful in the United States that it would be exported to the countries now considered the leaders.
''There's a lot of interest in Japan and Europe for terrestrial broadcast systems,'' said Mr. Luplow of Zenith. ''We think that when there is a terrestrial standard in the United States, it may be adopted in those countries as well.''

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

 
International
Ford's Halewood plant, outside Liverpool, is a striking example of how much British business has been transformed during the 1980's. Cooperation has replaced conflict on the shop floor, and productivity has soared. Since 1980, Halewood's car production has jumped more than 40 percent while the payroll has been trimmed by a third, mainly through retirement. [Page A1.] 
The Soviet Union and the 12-nation European Community agreed on a 10-year trade pact that would ease quotas for Soviet goods and increase technical cooperation. [D1.]
In a striking example of commercial glasnost, the Soviet enterprise that makes jet fighters has teamed up with Gulfstream to try to build a supersonic jet for business executives. But the project faces some formidable obstacles. [D1.]
Small investors reacted angrily after Daiwa confirmed a newspaper report indicating that it had made good the losses of several large institutional customers. [D2.]
 
The Economy
The nation's Big Three auto makers suffered serious sales declines in mid-November, while Japanese auto makers posted sharp gains. Over all, sales of domestically produced cars slumped 6.1 percent and light-truck sales dropped 1.7 percent. G.M. car sales were off 13 percent, Ford's sales were off 11.5 percent and Chrysler's sales were off 11.9 percent. [D1.]
A growing group of scientists and engineers say the U.S. has a good chance to vault over the international competition in high-definition television because it is not locked into a technology that may become out of date. [C1.]
 
Companies
Deutsche Bank agreed to buy Morgan Grenfell, one of Britain's biggest merchant banks, in a friendly deal that values Grenfell at $1.48 billion. [D1.]
Hewlett-Packard will announce a set of programs to allow people in a company to work together electronically even if they use different types of computers and different brands of software. [D6.]
Lone Star intends to sell several businesses, real estate and interests in some of its joint ventures. The move is viewed as a response to declining earnings in recent quarters. [D4.]
Shares of Perkin-Elmer rose $1.125, to $23.375, in the wake of a report that Nikon is considering buying the company's semiconductor equipment manufacturing operations. [D4.]
Columbia Savings and Loan is pulling out of a deal to provide an additional $51.4 million to buy Western Union securities, in a move that could damage Western Union's attempts to revive itself. [D5.]
 
Markets
The Federal Reserve Board signaled that it had not eased monetary policy last week, as had been commonly thought. As a result, prices of Treasury securities sagged and short-term interest rates rose sharply. [D1.]
Stocks advanced, despite falling back from early highs after a slump in the bond market. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.42 points, to 2,694.97. [D8.] Sales sold short and not yet traded rose 2.8 percent rise in the four weeks ended Nov. 15, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported. [D8.]
Gold prices plummeted amid heavy profit-taking by speculators. [D18.] The dollar fell sharply against most currencies. [D18.]

More than $100 million in account transfers proved that while some clients are willing to overlook the past, others steadfastly stick to tradition. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D1.]

HEADLINE: U.S.-Soviet Makers Plan Supersonic Business Jet

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
In a striking example of commercial glasnost, a Soviet state enterprise that made the planes that bombed Afghanistan has joined an American company to build the ultimate capitalist status symbol: a supersonic jet for business executives.
The project is still in its early stages and faces formidable obstacles, including environmental concerns and worries about exporting sensitive technology. Some skeptics say the proposed plane will never be built.
''The whole idea is preposterous,'' said Richard N. Perle, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington and a former Under Secretary of Defense. ''There would be immense licensing problems.'' 
He said export controls were unlikely to be relaxed to allow the free flow of technology between the countries.
But East bloc and aerospace experts say it signifies the Soviet Union's hunger for hard currency, Western technology and new uses for its historically military-oriented aerospace industry, now that the Kremlin is cutting military spending.
Sukhoi, a company best known for building the Su-25, a jet used in the war in Afghanistan, has teamed up with the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation best known for building high-priced private jets used by top executives who want an edge on the corporate battlefield.
Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British aerospace manufacturer, has been signed up to design the engine for the plane with a Soviet company, Lyulka. The plane would tentatively carry 15 to 20 passengers, fly at speeds of about 1,500 miles an hour and cost $50 million - twice the price on the most expensive corporate jet on the market today.
The proposed plane, according to Allen E. Paulson, the president of Gulfstream, would have the range to fly the booming trans-Pacific market for corporate travel, especially from the United States to Japan. The only civilian supersonic plane flying today is the British-French Concorde, which took more than five years to develop and does not have trans-Pacific range.
After months of meetings between Sukhoi and Gulfstream engineers, the final designs are scheduled to be approved within weeks. It would be the first joint civil aviation project between the countries.
Sukhoi, which would handle most of the development work, valued at the equivalent of $1 billion, has said in meetings with Gulfstream that it can have a prototype flying in three years and begin production in five.
''What the Soviets have to offer is manufacturing muscle,'' said Donald Fink, the editor of Aviation Week and Space Technology, a trade magazine. ''You have, if not a marriage made in heaven, a logical meld.''
While the aerodynamics of Soviet aircraft are nearly on par with that of Western planes, they lag slightly in engine technology and cockpit electronics. And a previous Soviet attempt at building a supersonic civilian aircraft ended in disaster. The plane, the Tupelov Tu-144, crashed at the Paris Air Show in 1973, killing several crew members. The plane never entered passenger service.
The cuts in Soviet military spending, intended to decline by 14.2 percent through 1991, are behind Moscow's push into civilian aircraft for export. Other sectors of the Soviet defense industry also diversifying. Missile plants, for example, have begun making outdoor barbecue grills, while aircraft manufacturers are building baby strollers.
''The Soviet defense industry is under enormous pressure to go civilian and equally enormous pressure to come up with hard currencies,'' said Marshall I. Goldman, the associate director of the Russian Research Center at Harvard University.
The Soviets' aviation export agency, Aviaexport, has already expanded its presence and now has 55 offices worldwide. It hopes to increase its export sales by 50 percent, to nearly $4 billion, by 1995, calculated at the official exchange rate for the ruble. But until now, virtually all of those sales have been to East bloc nations and to some third world countries.
To stimulate interest and possibly sales in Western markets, the Soviets are now showing their airplanes abroad, making dramatic appearances at air shows last summer in Oshkosh, Wis., and Abbottsford, British Columbia. And Ilyushin and Tupelov, the two primary manufacturers of airliners, are developing longer-range, more fuel-efficient jets that they hope to sell to Western airlines.
''It's of prime importance for these companies to start finding new products,'' said Dmitri Beskurnikov, the principal counselor for the state Foreign Economic Commission in Moscow. ''One of the ways of easing the conversion process is to invite foreign partners.''
Mikhail P. Simonov, Sukhoi's chief, has said that his goal is to transform the primarily military-oriented company to one that is half civilian.
Mr. Paulson of Gulfstream first heard of Sukhoi's plans in an article published last spring in Aviation Week and Space Technology. Mr. Paulson and Mr. Simonov then met for several hours in June at the Paris Air Show, the industry's premier event. By the next morning, they had signed an agreement to study the design of a supersonic coprorate jet.
 
Concerns Abound
The current project faces many hurdles, not the least of which is the public concern about the noise from supersonic jets. Civilian planes are prohibited from flying faster than Mach 1, or about 700 miles an hour, over the United States. But Mr. Paulson said the plane could be designed to have a lower, more acceptable sonic boom.
While Gulfstream's planes have advanced electronics and other systems that could have military applications, Mr. Paulson said that it was the United States that was most likely to gain in the technology transfer.
Another obstacle is the plane's price. At $50 million, the jet would cost more than twice Gulfstream's G-IV, which is considered the ultimate corporate chariot. ''It's a great concept from a technology standpoint, but I'm not sure the market is big enough to warrant the development costs,'' said Angelo Fiataruolo, the president of Premier Aircraft, an aircraft brokerage in Westport, Conn.
Upon reconsideration, some Soviet analysts say, Moscow may eventually abandon the project, given its huge risks.
''I don't think the Soviets are in a position, considering the state of the economy, to stick their neck out on a project that no Western company, even a consortium, would consider doing,'' said Jan Vanous, the research director for Planecon, a Washington consulting company that specializes in the Eastern bloc and Soviet economies.
Gulfstream, Mr. Paulson said, so far has invested a nominal amount of money into the project.
NASA, along with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, recently completed a study on building a commercial supersonic plane that would seat about 200 people. While NASA concluded that a market existed for such a plane, industry analysts said that such an extensive project would need to be developed by an international consortium and might require government money.

HEADLINE: Domestic Car Sales Show Drop

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The nation's Big Three auto makers suffered serious sales declines in mid-November, while the so-called Japanese transplants posted sharp gains on far fewer sales. Over all, sales of domestically produced cars slumped 6.1 percent, and light-truck sales dropped 1.7 percent, not quite so dismal a trend as during the early part of the month.
The Big Three and five Japanese auto makers operating American plants sold 149,381 cars from Nov. 11 to 20, down from 159,082 a year ago, for a seasonally adjusted annual rate of about 6.2 million.
Analysts said the sales report indicated that the automotive industry remained soft, and they agreed that while production cuts were likely, they were not sure how they would be accomplished. 
 
Scattered Shutdowns Seen
Ron Glantz of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said he was looking for scattered shutdowns, a few weeks at a time, during the next couple of months.
Jack Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody in New York said he was hearing rumors of an industrywide extension of the traditional Christmas vacation, that starts just before the holiday and ends just after New Year's.
From an investment perspective, Mr. Kirnan said an industrywide shutdown was bullish because ''it dramatizes to the Fed the need for continued lower interest rates.'' He added: ''It dramatizes to the union the need for sanity in the bargaining for the next contract. And it will help improve the resale values of cars and trucks,'' which are hurt when companies overproduce and then use incentives to clear inventories.
Indeed, the prices of all three stocks rose on the New York Stock Exchange today. The Ford Motor Company added $1.125 to close at $45.375; the General Motors Corporation gained 87.5 cents to close at $43.875, and the Chrysler Corporation rose 75 cents to close at $20.25.
G.M. car sales in mid-November were off 13 percent, to 66,338, Ford's sales were off 11.5 percent, to 41,963, and Chrysler's car sales were off 11.9 percent, to 20,187.
Nissan Motor Corporation sales for the period jumped 19.5 percent, to 2,329; the Honda Motor Corporation's car sales rose 29.7 percent, 10,714; the Mazda Motor Corporation's car sales rose 44.9 percent, to 978, and the Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales rose almost threefold to 5,882, compared with a year ago. The Mitsubishi Motor Corporation, in its first full year of United States production, sold 990 cars produced in this country. The five Japanese auto makers producing in North America together sell about as many domestically built cars as Chrysler.
Light-truck sales declined to 98,878, from 100,643 a year ago, with Ford acccounting for the entire decline; it had a 14.8 percent drop from a year earlier, while G.M., Chrysler and Nissan all posted increases.
Tom Houston, a Chrysler spokesman, commenting on increased truck sales, said, ''It's about time something turned up.'' He credited financial incentives for trucks and recent increases in dealers' advertising outlays for the gain.
A Ford spokesman, referring to Chrylser's truck gain, said the No. 3 auto maker ''obviously is trying to buy some market share.'' He added, ''Chrysler is the only company with incentives on full-size pickup trucks.''
 
Domestic Truck Sales Down
For the first 20 days of the month, domestic car sales were down 15.3 percent, and domestic truck sales were down 8.8 percent. Sales of minivans and utility vehicles, which are used as personal transportation, are included in truck sales.
''This is progress, but nothing to get excited about,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. ''The first 10 days of the month must have been an aberration, but still, these are not good numbers at all.''
G.M. plants in Doraville, Ga., and Fairfax, Kan., and Chrysler plants in Toledo, Ohio, and Detroit will be closed this week to help reduce inventories. Ford will shut its Dearborn, Mich., plant for a week starting Dec. 4 and keep its Lorain, Ohio, plant shut until Dec. 11, also to reduce inventories.
Charles Brady, auto analyst for Oppenheimer & Company in New York, said no clear sales trend had emerged. The soft sales of October and November are understandable in light of the strong incentives at the end of the summer and the sharp price increases for 1990 models, he said, but how long the downtrend continues depends on the strength of the overall economy and consumer psychology.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 19.42 Despite Bond Market Slump

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks advanced yesterday despite falling back from early highs after a slump in the bond market.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.42 points, to 2,694.97, as 883 issues rose and 612 fell on the New York Stock Exchange.
Revived hopes for lower interest rates pushed the Dow up steadily in the morning, to about a 27-point gain at 10:30 A.M. Shortly before noon, however, stock prices began to retreat in reaction to the Federal Reserve Board's signal that it would further drain funds from the banking system, a sign that it is not easing credit.
''Hopes for a quick prime rate reduction were dashed early as the Fed drained liquidity,'' said Joseph H. Barthel, director of investor strategy at Hopper Soliday & Company in Philadelphia. ''While the Dow ignored this apparent change in the direction of short-term interest rates, the broad market underperformed badly, with the Value Line index being up only the equivalent of 6 points on the Dow.'' 30-Year Bond at 7.90% Mr. Barthel noted that by late in the day, bond prices were near their lows for the day, with the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue off nearly half a point to yield 7.90 percent. The Federal funds rate was up to 8.5 percent. 
''The Fed's apparent move toward higher interest rates might have something to do with an attempt to stem recent dollar weakness,'' Mr. Barthel said.
Volume on the Big Board expanded to a moderate 149.4 million shares from Friday's 86.3 million shares, the second-lowest turnover the year.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.64 points, to 345.61, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 0.84, to 191.13.
 
Chevron Advances 3 1/4, to 68 1/4
Among individual issues, Chevron rose 3 1/4, to 68 1/4, in active trading. The company said it had created an employee stock ownership plan under which it would borrow about a billion dollars and use the money to buy back newly issued Chevron stock, representing 5 percent of its currently outstanding 342 million shares.
Pennzoil, which is regarded as Chevron's most likely suitor, also advanced, adding 1 1/2, to 80 3/8.
Perkin-Elmer rose 1 1/8, to 23 3/8. The Nikon Corporation of Japan is considered a likely bidder for Perkin-Elmer's semiconductor equipment operations, which it put up for sale in April, but there has been trouble completing a deal, analysts said.
Lone Star Industries gained 1, to 21 7/8, despite announcing it would take a charge of $250 million in the fourth quarter for a restructuring program. Lone Star also said the charge would prevent payment of future dividends on its common stock under its present loan agreements.
 
Cray Research Up 1 3/4, to 34 1/2
Cray Research rose 1 3/4, to 34 1/2. Rick Martin, an analyst with Prudential-Bache, reiterated a buy recommendation on the supercomputer maker's stock, citing an improved earnings outlook.
Texas Utilities, in an apparent dividend-capture play, was the most active Big Board stock, rising 1/2, to 35 1/2, on a volume of more than 11 million shares. The stock goes ex dividend today.
Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric rose 1 1/4, to 61 3/8; Exxon gained a point, to 46 7/8; Philip Morris was unchanged at 41 1/2; Texaco was unchanged at 53 7/8; I.B.M. dropped a point, to 99 3/8; A.T.&T. slipped 5/8, to 43 1/8, and Unisys was off 3/4, to 15 1/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 0.90, to 374.04, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.46, to 456.17.

HEADLINE: Trade Zones Are Criticized

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Foreign trade zones, which are supposed to create jobs in the United States by increasing exports, are instead bringing in more imports, mostly auto parts, according to a Congressional report released today.
The report by the House Government Operations Committee said 89 percent of all shipments through the zones now come into the United States and only 11 percent go out.
Duty-free zones at United States ports were approved in 1934 to create jobs and promote exports, re-exports and transshipment of goods.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Profit Taking by Speculators Sends Gold Prices Plunging

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices plummeted yesterday amid heavy profit taking by speculators as the market broke a five-day run-up that had pushed the metal to its highest levels in almost a year.
On other commodity markets, cotton futures plunged the permitted daily limit and soybeans were down sharply.
Gold futures settled $5 to $6.10 lower on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for delivery in December down $5.20 at $414.10 an ounce. The expiring November contract fell $5, to $413.90. Silver fell 18.7 cents to 20.7 cents, with December settling at $5.693 an ounce. 
 
Steepest Drop Since Aug. 4
Yesterday's selloff was the steepest daily decline in gold prices since Aug. 4 and the most significant drop since the market began climbing sharply about six weeks ago from levels near $360 an ounce.
Analysts said gold had been due for a correction after climbing so hard so fast, and many remained bullish.
''The trend remains intact,'' said James Steel, a metals analyst with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. in New York.
But they said gold could easily fall a bit further before resuming its climb, which has been based largely on investment buying stemming from the uncertain economic outlook, the volatile stock market and worries about the rapid rate of political change in Eastern Europe.
There were no solidly bearish developments yesterday to prompt the gold selloff, so observers concluded that the selling reflected profit taking by players who had ridden the market up since mid-October.
''I don't think we're finished yet with the rally in gold or silver,'' said Jack Barbanel, managing director of First Global Asset Management Inc. in Princeton, N.J. ''It's healthy for the market not to overextend itself.''
Most cotton futures prices fell the daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange in a sell-off inspired almost entirely by technical sell signals in the absence of fresh supply-and-demand news.
The trigger was the March contract's drop below the September low of 72.20 cents early in the session, said Ernest Simon, a cotton analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
''When it came close to it, frantic, panicky selling developed,'' he said.
The wheat market closed narrowly mixed, with support stemming from Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter's statement that France's sale of 1.3 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union was ''an encouraging sign'' that the Soviets were back in the market for wheat.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Expectations Of Changes in Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against most major foreign currencies yesterday. Traders apparently are expecting a decline in interest rates in the United States in response to a slowing economy, although action by the Federal Reserve in the credit markets yesterday suggested rates may not decline as quickly as some may expect.
The Fed, which took the first steps earlier this year to ease credit as the economy began to slow, signaled apparent approval for further easing last week but indicated yesterday that it had not yet approved a rate decline. 
The dollar was also weakened, however, by the expectation among currency traders that interest rates will rise in West Germany because of the continuing political changes in Eastern Europe, said Earl Johnson, a vice president for foreign exchange at Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. ''The psychology is definitely bearish for the dollar and bullish for the mark,'' he added.
 
Decline Against the Mark
A nation's currency tends to follow the direction of its interest rates. Lower American rates make the dollar less attractive, while higher West German yields make the mark a better investment. Against the West German currency yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.7890 marks, down from 1.8010 late Friday.
The dollar's downward trend is expected to remain in place in the next few weeks unless the Government issues new statistics indicating strength in the economy, Mr. Johnson said. Traders will be scrutinizing several economic reports this week, including third-quarter gross national product figures and personal income, construction spending and the index of leading indicators for October.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing of 143.35 Japanese yen from 143.80 at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 143.40 yen, but in New York, it fell to 143.195 from Friday's 143.60.
The dollar gained against the British pound, as sterling fell to $1.5605, from $1.5635 late Friday in London, and to $1.5585, from $1.5625 late Friday in New York.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6040 Swiss francs, down from 1.6095; 6.1100 French francs, down from 6.1415; 1.16665 Canadian dollars, down from 1.6725, and 1,320.75 Italian lire, down from 1,326.75.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Management Of Facilities a Growth Area

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
FACILITIES management has become a fast-growing profession, so much so that 8,000 specialists belong to the International Facility Management Association, formed in 1980 with headquarters in Houston.
Its president, Robert J. Gross, who is 43 years old, is a vice president of the First Pennsylvania Bank, in charge of its faciliites. ''Take the word facility away from facility management and substitute assets,'' he explained. ''We are a resource for executive management.'' 
''If the bank adds staff we are concerned about expenses as well as space requirements,'' he said. Space often constitutes the second-largest operating expense after salaries.
''I joined 17 years ago at a time the bank was using people without formal training to handle branch expansion,'' he said. ''In fact, there was little training available. Our facilities management department grew from that.'' He has a bachelor's degree from Temple University in architecture.
Mr. Gross heads a staff of 24 people, including six in design and construction, three in real estate, two in planning and four general administrators. Each unit is headed by an assistant vice president, while outside concerns do much of the maintenance work under contract.
''One way my operation differs from a manufacturing company is that the bulk of my space is office and customer-contact space,'' he said. Involved with furniture, lighting, acoustics, environmental issues, occupancy expenses, design and construction, he also busies himself with long-range planning. ''I work closely, too, with management information systems people.'' he added.
''We try to eliminate surprises,'' he said. ''Our weekends sometimes are not a lot of fun.'' Often his department must check artwork, nameplates, telephone systems and other items at new bank branches.
''I think an undergraduate major in facilities management and a master of business administration degree would be a fine background,'' he added.
Training is still scarce, available at fewer than two dozen colleges. Cornell University, a pioneer in the field, offers graduate and undergraduate degrees. Iona College offers a bachelor of science degree as does North Dakota State University and Brigham Young University. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has several courses and holds an annual conference.
Arthur P. Hahn, facility operations manager for the space and defense sector of TRW Inc., heads a staff of 400 people of which about 300 are in operations and maintenance.
Mr. Hahn, who majored in architecture, joined the Air Force after college and it sent him to Oklahoma State University for a master's degree in architectural engineering. ''I spent more than 23 years in the Air Force, doing facilities management,'' he said. After retiring as a colonel he joined TRW.
''It's a good career - one of the last unexplored areas, without many books for guidance and few courses,'' he added. ''So many facilities can be improved. The thing that strikes me is that every day is different.''
Mr. Hahn might receive a call about a broken air-conditioning system or trash not being picked up. Sometimes questions are technical as in the case of the engineer who asked for the longitude and latitude of a plant.
''I had to research that,'' he said. ''Then I might get a call about the need to plan for a new building.'' His responsibiliites include environmental and heating and ventilating problems, among others.
Cost containment is important, he said, ''Our electric bill in the space and defense unit alone is $25 million a year.''
Christine H. Neldon, who is 36 years old, heads facility management at four offices for the accounting and consulting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company, in Atlanta; Birmingham, Ala.; Jacksonville, Fla., and Chattanooga, Tenn. ''I majored in marketing,'' she said, adding that in her 17 years with the firm she has held many administrative jobs, in personnel, training and telecommunications.
She has ''a lean operation,'' with two professional assistants. ''We lease space,'' she explained, so that when a plumber or electrician is needed she telephones the landlord's office.
Her areas include long-range planning, design, construction and renovation, office furnishings and real estate procurement. ''For that I might talk to our real estate partners,'' she said, explaining that often she can find professional help within the firm.
''Today many companies are contracting out some facilities management,'' she said, noting that new service firms have been ''sprouting up.'' However, others have increased inside facilities staffs. ''It's purely a matter of economics,'' she added.
At the International Facility Management Association, she said, about 75 percent of the members are professionals while 25 percent, called affiliates, work for outside service companies. ''You see people go back and forth between them,'' she commented, and she recalled a funny situation: ''One day the chairman of a company discovered ants crawling in his office. The question is can an outside consultant react fast enough.''

HEADLINE: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
The life and death of Preston (Little Man) Simmons, a 14-year-old marijuana peddler who was shot and killed last Thursday, is a story that has become dismally familiar in his part of the world.
When he was executed in the courtyard of his housing project in the Bronx, he became one of almost 140 homicide victims aged 18 or under in New York City this year. For the last three years, about 10 percent of the city's homicide victims have been in that age group, many of them killed in drug-related incidents, according to police officials.
That the case of Preston Simmons is so commonplace is what gives it special weight. His existence at the Castle Hill Houses, a sprawling public housing complex in the East Bronx, was typical of life in the underclass. And the legacy of despair he left behind provides little hope of a better life for the next generation. 
Like Preston's mother and grandmother, his girlfriend will become a teen-age mother next month when she is due to deliver his child. The girlfriend, 17-year-old Denise Butler, doubts that her child's life will be much different from that of Preston, a personable youngster who made his spending money by selling $5 bags of marijuana.
''If he's still living around here,'' Miss Butler said of her expected child, ''I guess he'll be selling drugs, will be forced to sell drugs, or will have a lot of bad habits.''
The police have yet to make an arrest in Preston's case, but contend they have good leads. Although police officials are reluctant to declare the killing a drug hit, Preston's family and friends believe he was killed because he threatened to break with his marijuana supplier and set up a competing operation.
Although the man identified as Preston's supplier is not suspected as the gunman, he has been questioned at length by the police, said Sgt. William T. Kivlehan, a detective at the 43d Precinct in the Bronx. The man, who was at the site of the killing when it occurred, has a record of drug arrests.
Preston was killed at about 8:15 P.M. while walking from his girlfriend's apartment at 580 Castle Hill Avenue to his family's apartment a block away at 2120 Randall Avenue. He encountered the drug supplier and, while talking to him, was approached by a group of at least four men.
One of them pulled a 9-millimeter automatic pistol from his waist and shot Preston twice, once in the head and once in the body, and then shot him nine more times as he fell to the snow. ''This kid was full of holes,'' said Vincent Pizzo, chief of detectives for the housing police.
Preston's friends said he sensed the danger in the drug trade, although he thought it came more from the police than from his counterparts in commerce. It was a risk he thought worth taking.
''I guess he did it for the reason all the young dudes do it,'' said Anthony Butler, the brother of Preston's girlfriend and one of Preston's best friends. ''He was too young to get a job and it was some quick little change in his pocket.''
 
Fear of Venturing Out
Although residents of Castle Hill are accustomed to bloodshed, they were taken aback by Preston's death because of the coldness of the killing, particularly given the victim's age and his low position in the drug hierarchy.
The incident has made children and elderly people afraid to leave their apartments and has encouraged community leaders to philosophize about the spiraling cycle of poverty and drugs that seems to pull each generation's youth farther away from hope.
''There is a growing fear that the drug cancer is metastasizing and it's really impacting on the young children,'' said Zalreth P. McCreath, the director of the Randall Early Learning Center, a few yards from the site of the shooting. ''It's clear that the whole family unit has broken down and what's caused it seems to be drugs.''
In Preston's case, it is hard to know whether drugs were the cause or the effect.
 
From Shelter to Project
Preston was the fourth of Ruth Simmons's seven children, who range in age from 18 years to 15 months. An eighth child died as an infant.
Ms. Simmons dropped out of high school in 11th grade, when she first got pregnant. Preston's father, Ms. Simmons said, was an abusive drug user who wandered in and out of her life, often entering through a smashed window or door.
During the two years that they lived together, he regularly beat her and the children, Ms. Simmons said. Eventually, Ms. Simmons got a protective court order prohibiting the man from seeing his children.
Ms. Simmons and her family spent a number of years crowded into her mother's two-bedroom apartment. They moved into a shelter in Queens in the summer of 1988 before moving into their four-bedroom apartment at Castle Hill 15 months ago.
Unemployed for the last six years, Ms. Simmons has received a welfare check since 1969 when she first became pregnant. She gets a check for $235.55 every two weeks, which is supplemented by a $371 monthly check for one of her sons, who has a mental disability. She pays $266 a month in rent at Castle Hill.
 
Gunfire Is Commonplace
About one-fourth of the 2,025 families living at Castle Hill are on full welfare, saidVal Coleman, a spokesman for the New York City Housing Authority. The average family income at the 14-building complex is $11,022. More than 7,000 people live there now, with almost half of them under the age of 21.
The project is a complex of 12-story buildings clustered around playgrounds and courtyards. Most of the apartments are spacious, but the elevators smell of urine and the tile hallways are marred with graffiti.
Residents report that the project is overrun with crack dealers. Gunfire from roofs and windows has become commonplace and there have been four homicides this year.
 
Life Is Cheap
One killing took place only a month and a half before Preston's death, when 17-year-old Jamal Graham was shot twice with a .32-caliber automatic. Police have labeled the killing a territorial drug dispute and have charged a 20-year-old man from another housing project in the shooting.
''People are dying over jackets, drugs, money, even the way you look at people,'' said Crystal McNeill, a 17-year-old Castle Hill resident who knew both Preston and Jamal. ''For $5, they'll shoot you in your head.''
Before the emergence of crack, Castle Hill was a relatively quiet place, said Anthony Butler, who is 24. He remembers when his mother would plant a beach chair in the grass in the late afternoon and spend much of the evening there.
Now the Butlers, like many residents, spend most of their time locked in their seventh-floor apartment, watching music videos, preparing meals, and peering through grime-stained windows at a view of the Empire State Building framed between two other Castle Hill high-rises.
Because Preston Simmons was a broad-shouldered and self-reliant youth, he had been called ''Little Man'' since childhood. He was friendly and outgoing, often playing the role of the family clown. He also was susceptible to peer pressure, according to his sister, Natasha.
His was a life devoid of positive role models or heroes, said his mother and friends. After learning some elementary karate moves from a friend, he lined the walls of his bedroom with magazine pictures of Ninja warriors.
Because he was hyperactive, Preston was enrolled in a special education class at Intermediate School 174. His teacher, Norman A. Washington, described Preston as an average student who rarely skipped school, who did his homework, and who showed respect for authority. ''He seemed to have a good self image,'' Mr. Washington said. ''He had an elastic ego. He didn't get hurt easily.''
Preston began selling marijuana after meeting his supplier last summer, according to friends and family members. Along with several other boys working for the same man, he stationed himself in a playground near the spot where he was killed.
On a good day, he would sell 20 to 30 bags for $5 each and would keep $1.50 for each bag sold, Anthony and Denise Butler said. Occasionally he would keep some marijuana for his own use, but his sister and friends said he preferred a Heineken beer to a joint.
Ms. Simmons said she was not aware of her son's drug dealing.
 
Keeping Up With 'the Styles'
Preston spent his money on food and gifts for Denise, and for pricey clothing and shoes. ''Young people like to keep up with the styles and it's expensive to keep up,'' said Mr. Butler. ''These are low-income projects here and your parents can't get you everything the other kids have.''
Since Preston's death, both his family and Denise's family have found special meaning in the coming birth of Denise's baby. They seem unfazed by the prospect of another generation of fatherless children living a life of destitution and danger.
''Little Man is gone but he's left something behind,'' Ms. Simmons said. ''We hope it's a boy so he can keep his name. We loved Little Man a lot. Since he's not here any longer we all will have something to remember him by.''
