HEADLINE: Oil, a Foundation of Alaska, Works to Rebuild Its Image

BYLINE: By RICHARD MAUER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Nov. 28

 BODY:
For four days last month, the State of Alaska refused to allow an oil tanker to discharge her cargo at a refinery 100 miles south of here in Kenai. In a state that owes its prosperity and indeed its existence in large part to oil, the event was a jarring one.
But it symbolized a shift in the psychology of Alaska and its citizens, a new skepticism shaking an old faith in the virtues of oil.
But the keepers of the old faith have shown in word and deed that they do not accept the change as inevitable or irreversible. With some public opinion polls showing a renewal of good feelings toward the oil industry as memories of last spring's disastrous spill fade, the oil companies have aggressively joined the fight for the trust of Alaskans. 
Oil brought Alaska its statehood and later its low taxes, schools, roads, theaters, jobs, a vibrant economy and an annual dividend check of more than $800 for each citizen.
Lobbyists who campaigned against raising taxes on oil production and regulating its development found allies among residents who were the industry's beneficiaries. Over the years, the arguments of the industry resounded among Alaska's ''boomers,'' that vocal segment of the population for whom development assumed the significance of a spiritual quest.
Historians here say that changes in Alaska's boom mentality were apparent even before March 24, when the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil. But they say the environmental disaster wrought by the spill was an event that has shifted politics and, more fundamentally, the way Alaskans think about their environment and how industry should be allowed to operate in it.
''Oil is now suspected,'' said Stephen Haycox, a professor of state history at the University of Alaska in Anchorage. ''Before, there was trust in oil - grudging trust, willing trust, but guarded. It's much more than guarded now. I think it's resentful.''
This new skepticism was evident last month when the state's Department of Environmental Conservation refused to allow the tanker Sansinena II, owned by the Unocal Corporation, to discharge her cargo. The ship lay at anchor in Cook Inlet south of here while her owners scrambled to provide the state with an acceptable plan for cleaning up oil spills.
 
A Change in Enforcement
Ships lacking such plans are nothing new. Most of the 15 tanker companies active in the Valdez trade, including Exxon Shipping Company, had no plans in place before March 24.
But enforcing the longstanding law requiring cleanup plans is a change. Two weeks before the Kenai-bound tanker was forced to anchor, the state notified all the companies that pick up oil at Valdez that they must have contingency plans by Nov. 13 or be barred. All the companies have since filed the plans.
''I see the Cook Inlet situation as being indicative of change in Alaska that parallels change nationally,'' said Dennis Kelso, Alaska's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation. ''I think Alaskans are going to want to have the deciding vote in what kind of risk they accept, whether from tanker traffic in Cook Inlet or exposure to waste materials on the Kenai Peninsula from drilling waste, or other sources.''
Mr. Kelso's agency and the Coast Guard, have been criticized by those who saw failure to protect the state against a spill and to make sure industry could clean up a spill. Mr. Kelso, in turn, has said the State Legislature has consistently failed to provide the money his agency needed.
 
'What a Betrayal'
Claus-M. Naske, the author of the standard text on Alaska history and a professor of history at the University of Alaska in Fairbanks, says the March spill changed attitudes, perhaps forever.
''What a disaster, what a betrayal of the Alaskan people, what a failure of Alaska State Government and the Legislature,'' he said. ''But the upside of it was that it finally broke the power of the unholy 11 in the State Senate.'' The majority in the 20-member Senate has effectively blocked higher oil taxes and regulation for most of a decade.
That coalition collapsed in the months after the spill, when oil-production taxes were raised, more money was appropriated for the environmental agency and even the most ardent backers of industry backed tougher standards.
Oil's singular place in Alaska had much to do with breaking the hold that the canned-salmon industry and its legendary lobbyist, W. C. Arnold, had on the territorial Senate before Alaska joined the union in 1959. The canneries, based in Seattle, fought statehood, fearing new taxes and a loss of access to the fishing grounds. Until the mid-1950's, when oil was discovered on the Kenai Peninsula 80 miles south of Anchorage, the canneries had been persuading Congress that Alaska would remain an economic burden, demanding ever greater Federal subsidies if it became a state. Epitome of Capitalism? Although public opinion polls over the years have shown that an overwhelming majority of Alaskans had ''positive'' feelings about the oil industry, Professor Haycox ascribed those sentiments to admiration of achievement, not to a deeply rooted affection of the type found in oil states like Texas.
''It's not so much a love affair with oil, because there isn't much drilling for oil up here by wildcatters, and there's not that much direct investment in oil,'' Mr. Haycox said. ''I think people saw oil in the most heroic of terms, betting the company and investing all of the resources in an economic gamble, so that if the gamble fails, the company is wiped out. It's sort of the epitome of Western capitalist success.''
But in teaching his class on Alaska's living history, Mr. Naske has invited some of the older generation of boomers to lecture - and has found that his students see them as ''quaint'' relics from a bygone era.
 
Different Perceptions on Attitudes
The two poll takers who monitor Alaskan opinion agree that attitudes changed sharply with the spill, but they dispute how long the effect will last.
David Dittman, whose clients include Atlantic Richfield, the state's second-biggest oil producer, said the percentage of people who believe oil has been a positive force has rebounded to within about five percentage points of the pre-spill level. ''There really hasn't been much of a change that is long-lasting,'' Mr. Dittman said. But Marc Hellenthal, who does not work for the major oil companies, said the popularity of oil remained relatively low. He said a poll he took in late summer for the Alaska Federation of Natives showed a that higher percentage of the state liked environmental organizations than the oil industry.
Mr. Hellenthal said his research does not provide many clues on how lasting the changes will be. But he recalled that the industry has begun a new advertising campaign after months of silence over the summer. Whose Dream Is Sung? Last month, Atlantic Richfield began televising a commercial that intersperses shots of oil developments with farmers, rugged loggers, and a boy riding a horse on a beach. The song in the background extolling ''the Alaska Dream'' is so catchy that people have written for sheet music.
The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the manager of the pipeline and the Valdez terminal and industry's first line of defense against a spill in Prince William Sound, is preparing a series of newspaper advertisements it hopes will restore some of its credibility.
And changes in Alyeska's management appear to be having results. Riki Ott of Cordova District Fishermen United, a biologist who is one of Alyeska's long-time critics, says that Alyeska's new manager for environmental issues, Mike Williams, has been so friendly and open that he has disarmed some opposition.
Last week the state's biggest and most influential oilfield-service companies, Veco International, took another step toward insuring a platform for its views when it announced it was buying The Anchorage Times. The Times, a privately owned afternoon daily that was once the state's dominant newspaper, has been steadily losing circulation to its morning rival, The Anchorage Daily News, and is widely believed to have been in danger of closing.
 
One Man's Newspaper
Robert Atwood, The Times publisher for more than 50 years, has been unabashed in his support for the oil industry; he has owned oil leases himself on the Kenai Peninsula. At a recent press conference, Mr. Atwood said he believed a newspaper ''should be an integral part of a community, not a separate entity sitting on the sidelines at a tennis match.''
Veco was the prime contractor in the billion-dollar oil spill cleanup. Its majority owner, Bill Allen, said he planned to invigorate The Times but not change its outlook.
Recovering some measure of political influence is important for the industry. The new taxes and regulations passed after the spill are expected to cost it more than $2 billion over the next two decades. As a result, ''the investment attraction of Alaska has dimmed perceptively for the industry,'' said Benjamin M. Rice Jr., an analyst with the Brown Brothers Harriman investment company.
Mr. Hellenthal said Arco's commercials are a masterly attempt to regain some of the lost influence. ''It's classical conditioning,'' he said. ''It's got a nice warm feeling, and then they pair it with oil.''

HEADLINE: Prominent Rightist Slain in El Salvador

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, one of this country's most prominent right-wing politicians, was shot to death today outside a fast-food restaurant here.
The former justice, Francisco Jose Guerrero, 64 years old, was shot in the throat at 9:40 A.M. by four gunmen on foot as he rode on a downtown street with two bodyguards in his Volvo, spokesmen for the armed forces said.
No one immediately took responsibility for the killing. But the logic of political violence in El Salvador made the most likely assassins leftist guerrillas, who had tried to kill him seven years ago. 
 
One Attacker Reported Slain
The police said one attacker was killed by Mr. Guerrero's bodyguards. The assailant, who the police said was an urban guerrilla, appeared to be in his late 20's and was dressed in civilian clothes.
There was also circumstantial evidence indicating that left-wing insurgents killed Mr. Guerrero, who was the president of the legislature from 1962 to 1968 and the Foreign Minister from 1968 to 1971. While a member of the Supreme Court, he was the architect of an important ruling that blocked an investigation into the 1980 assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador.
In an interview earlier this year, Joaquin Villalobos, the top rebel commander, said guerrillas had killed Roberto Garcia Alvarado, the attorney general, because of his role in blocking the inquiry into the murder, which has repeatedly been linked to the governing party.
Mr. Guerrero, a conservative landowner known as Chachi, was an unsuccessful presidential candidate in 1984 for the National Conciliation Party, a group closely linked to the armed forces, which had ruled this country for a quarter of a century before a 1979 coup by junior officers bent on change. Political violence that erupted that year between leftist and rightist groups has grown into a civil war that has killed about 70,000 people. Backed by the C.I.A. Mr. Guerrero, who had served as a behind-the-scenes adviser to the United States Embassy, was secretly supported in his presidential campaign by the United States Central Intelligence Agency in an attempt to split rightist votes and insure that the candidate favored by Washington, Jose Napoleon Duarte of the Christian Democrats, triumphed over Roberto d'Aubuisson, an extreme rightist who was considered politically unacceptable to the American Congress.
Moderate critics often pointed to Mr. Guerrero as one of the men most responsible for blocking social, political and economic change.
Mr. Guerrero represented the 14 families that formed the nation's oligarchy and other large landowners who thwarted efforts in the mid-1970's to break up the country's tight concentration of property owners.
Mr. Guerrero's party and its historical allies in the armed forces have often been accused of stealing the 1972 election from Mr. Duarte. The controversy over that vote, which provoked widespread feeling that it was impossible to change the society through peaceful methods, went a long way to set the stage for the political violence that followed.
Mr. Guerrero's term on the Supreme Court had ended earlier this year, and he was no longer a member of the Government's inner circle. But in recent weeks, Mr. Guerrero's party had formed an alliance with the governing party to enact legislation that gives the army and the Government sweeping power to suppress dissent.
 
Earlier Killings
The killing of Mr. Guerrero followed several attacks on the homes and families of senior army officers. In addition, during the last year the rebels have killed several political leaders linked with extreme rightists.
The rebel attacks have already brought retaliation. The security forces, which are linked to the death squads that slaughtered almost anyone who dared organize or even criticize in the early 1980's, have cracked down on church groups and religious organizations.
 
Ortega Won't Comment on Plane
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 28 (Reuters) - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has declined to comment on accusations that Nicaragua sent antiaircraft missiles to Salvadoran rebels.
''The problem here is not of denying or accepting charges,'' Mr. Ortega told reporters Monday. ''I am not on trial. We are facing a political problem promoted by the United States.''
Mr. Ortega made his remarks while being questioned about Salvadoran charges that a light aircraft that crashed in El Salvador on Saturday had taken off from Nicaragua with weapons for the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Europeans Ask U.S. Not to Reach Understanding on Troop Cuts Yet

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Western European defense ministers asked the Bush Administration today not to reach any understandings about American and Soviet troop cuts when President Bush meets this weekend with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
The European concerns were expressed to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during a closed-door meeting at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's headquarters here and in private individual meetings between Mr. Cheney and NATO defense ministers.
''The message of the Europeans is don't do unilateral things,'' said a Western European defense official. ''Be cautious. Don't be hasty.'' ''In the back of our mind, we remember Reykjavik,'' the official said, referring to the summit meeting between President Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev during which the two leaders came close to an agreement on drastic cuts in ballistic missiles before the talks collapsed over American plans for a space-based anti-missile defense. 
 
U.S.-Soviet Understanding Feared
Even though the Bush Administration has repeatedly said it will not try to strike an arms control agreement at the summit meeting off Malta on Saturday and Sunday, British, West German and other Western European defense officials have been concerned that Washington plans to use the summit in a subtler fashion to lay the groundwork for further troop cuts.
Bush Administration officials have said, for example, that Mr. Bush may engage in ''philosophical'' or ''conceptual'' discussions with the Mr. Gorbachev about lower troop levels in Europe. American officials say publicly that this is in keeping with Mr. Bush's desire to have a wide-ranging discussion with Mr. Gorbachev about the implications of change in Eastern Europe. Some West European officials fear, however, that the ''philosophical'' discussions will be a cover to explore an informal superpower understanding about future cuts without prior consultation with NATO.
The European worries have been aggravated by reports that the Pentagon is already considering troop cuts in Europe to alleviate severe pressures on the military budget, and by recent comments by Mr. Cheney. En route to the NATO meeting here, Mr. Cheney publicly encouraged Moscow to go beyond the cuts contemplated in the emerging East-West pact to cut conventional arms, suggesting that the United States would reciprocate after consulting with its allies.
 
Adding Fuel to the Fire
A statement on Monday by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, that the two leaders would hold discussions on ''arms control and military force structure'' added fuel to the fire.
Mr. Cheney sought to ease European concerns here today by reaffirming Administration pledges that Mr. Bush would not present detailed proposals for troop cuts, and by saying the United States planned to maintain a sizable military presence in Europe for the foreseeable future.
But a Western European official who attended the closed-door meeting today said differences between Mr. Cheney's approach on conventional arms and that of some Western Europeans were apparent in several areas.
Mr. Cheney, for example, is reported to have spelled out a faster timetable for carrying out a agreement to reduce conventional arms than did some Western Europeans. The West German Defense Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, is reported to have said it would take five to seven years to carry out such an agreement - an estimate based on the large quantities of equipment to be destroyed under the accord and by the difficulties that Moscow is likely to encounter in discharging a large number of troops into the civilian economy.
Mr. Cheney, however, is reported to have said that he thought such an agreement could be carried out in two or three years.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
An Outline of German History

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:

1815 After the Congress of Vienna redrew the map of Europe with the defeat of Napoleon, the main German states grouped themselves into a loose association of 39 kingdoms, duchies, principalities and free cities known as the German Confederation. It was dominated by Prussia and Austria.
 
1834 The states formed a German Customs Union with free trade, which brought economic growth. With Austria staying aloof from the union, Prussia eventually emerged as the dominant German power. 
 
1866 After defeating Austria in the Seven Weeks' War and driving it out of the confederation, Prussia created a North German federation north of the Main River.
 
1871 Otto von Bismarck, chancellor in the new federation, used the patriotic fervor aroused by Prussia's defeat of France in the Franco-Prussian War to persuade the southern states to join the North German federation. The Second German Empire, with King William I of Prussia as Emperor and Bismarck as its ''Iron Chancellor,'' was proclaimed Jan. 18, 1871, at Versailles, near Paris. It embraced four kingdoms, five grand duchies, 12 duchies and principalities, and the three Hanseatic free cities.
 
1918 The new Reich, which initially stretched along the whole Baltic coast as far as Memel in present-day Soviet Lithuania, did not survive Germany's defeat in World War I. The Weimar Republic, proclaimed in 1919, adopted a federal structure with a central government far stronger than in imperial times.
 
1933 The instability of the Weimar Republic opened the way for the rise of Hitler and his totalitarian Nazi ideology stressing nationalism, anti-Communism and anti-Semitism that led to the Holocaust in which millions of Jews and others were killed. Under the Third Reich, Hitler's aggressive expansionism led to the outbreak of World War II.
 
1945 After the defeat of Hitler, modern East and West Germany grew out of the postwar occupation zones of the four victorious Allies -Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. Their borders, although universally recognized, have never been formally laid down in a peace treaty.

HEADLINE: Aging Baths In Brighton Face Demise

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
These days Jose Ruiz eyes his neighbor across the street, an aging recreational complex sprawled over 15 acres of Brooklyn's Brighton Beach waterfront, and can hardly wait for it to die.
A $275 million condominium project is planned for the site and is expected to bring at least 5,000 new higher-income residents to the area. Mr. Ruiz, the owner of J & I Grocery and Deli at 3212 Coney Island Avenue, figures that would mean a 15 to 20 percent rise in his business. He says he plans to invest $12,000 on two new display cases, add more products and give his store a facelift.
''Once they start building over there I'll start renovating over here,'' he said yesterday. ''I want my store to look good too.'' 
 
'Can't Stop Progress'
The aging recreational complex he wants to see torn down is the Brighton Beach Baths, which has been around since 1919 -the Miami Beach of Brooklyn before there was a Miami Beach. The complex, with 25 paddle-tennis courts and 3 swimming pools, its tiny zinc-roofed cabanas and Beach-Nut Bugle newspaper, its dancing classes and duplicate bridge, has been in decline for years, its members dying off or moving into nursing homes.
''I don't feel too good about it, but what am I going to do?,'' said Al Stone, 82, a club member since 1931 and one of about 20 members using the club yesterday afternoon. ''Can't stop progress. I got my share.''
Steve Alschuler, a spokesman for the developers, said the club was doomed even if the project was not planned. ''The baths are going to close no matter what,'' he said. ''It's not a feasible enterprise anymore.'' But its anachronistic charm has many defenders, and even neighbors who do not remember the heyday of the baths, when the club had 14,000 members instead of 2,000, feel the condominium project set to replace it is too dense and intrusive for the last remaining bit of local shorefront.
The New York City Planning Commission is scheduled to hold a public hearing on the project today at 10 A.M. at City Hall.
The proposal before the seven-member commission is a revised, scaled-down version of one first proposed in 1986. It envisions two 23-story buildings, two 25-story buildings and one 29-story building for a total of 1,730 apartments ranging in size from studios to three-bedroom units.
The project, to be built by Alexander Muss & Sons, who have owned the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club since 1980, would also include doctors' offices, commercial space and a health club.
The apartments would sell for $125,000 to $275,000. Nina Mazur, who is 28 years old and a Brighton Beach resident for eight years, said she fears the changes that so excite Mr. Ruiz. She lives in a $600-a-month studio apartment with her husband and 2-month-old daughter. The couple have been looking for bigger quarters but find everything too expensive.
If the project goes through, she said, ''prices, rent, everything would go up.''
Residents have other concerns. Jean Kreiling of the Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach and Manhattan Beach, a group of neighbors who oppose the project, said the new units could bring as many as 7,000 new residents into the area without an accompanying increase in resources. The development would provide 1,856 new parking spaces, for example, but Ms. Kreiling said that was hardly adequate for households that often have two cars.
 
Won't Make It Better
Edith Zuloff, another resident, said she worries more about a deeper change in the character of the neighborhood that she has called home for the last 14 years.
''The only things Brighton has going for it is the beach, the boardwalk and the air,'' she said. ''This is not going to make it better.''
Under the 1986 plan, the project would have had six towers from 24 to 44 stories tall occupying a total of 2.8 million square feet. The new plan is 27 percent smaller, but the developers still need zoning changes that would allow them to change the site from commercial to residential and from a density of 300 units to the proposed 1,730. The site is bordered by Coney Island Avenue, Brighton Beach Avenue and Seacoast Terrace.
Both the developers and the project's supporters say the condominiums would ease a housing shortage and blend with other high-rise buildings in the area. Two of these, the 20-story and 18-story buildings next to the beach club, were also owned by Alexander Muss & Sons before becoming co-ops. The late Alexander Muss's son, Stephen, is the owner of the Fontainbleau Hilton in Miami Beach.
 
'What We're Looking For'
Community Board 13 approved the project in a 30-to-4 vote. The community district manager, Herbert Eisenberg, said the project was needed because economic development in the area was soft, there was too little housing and the local economy was stagnant.
''It keeps some of our kids from going,'' he said. ''My 26-year-old son is moving out of the area. He could afford better housing but can't find any. There are people who could afford it, and that's what we're looking for.''
But Ms. Kreiling said: ''This is New York City's recreational playland and you shouldn't block off the shore with high-rises. We think it's an outrageous zoning request for a waterfront site.''
If the Planning Commission approves it, the project then goes to the city's Board of Estimate for a hearing and a vote. Construction is expected to take five years.

HEADLINE: 2 U.S. Towers At Foley Sq. Will Avoid Review Steps

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Worried that full public review might seriously delay or even derail their plan to build two large civic buildings in lower Manhattan, the Federal Government and New York City have agreed to sidestep that process.
Under legislation signed this month by President Bush, the Government would condemn the two city-owned sites on which the new buildings are to rise, rather than acquire them through a voluntary transfer by the city. The condemnation would be ''friendly,'' not contested or protested by the city.
In that way, the project, a Federal courthouse and a Federal-municipal office building, would not have to go through the city's uniform land-use review procedure, known as Ulurp, which involves the local Community Board, the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate. 
 
Announced Two Years Ago
Nor would the plan be affected by changes to the land-use review process that are called for by the recently approved revisions to the City Charter.
''All the parties agreed that only friendly condemnation would make it happen,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. He has been impatient with the slow progress of the $500 million project, which was announced two years ago and had appeared to be foundering. ''We have basically knocked a year, year and a half, off the process by doing it this way,'' said Deputy Mayor Robert Esnard.
''Without condemnation, we would not have a certainty of any building being built there,'' said William J. Diamond, regional administrator of the Federal General Services Administration, which is overseeing the project. ''We would not know what would happen in Ulurp. More importantly, we were very afraid that with the charter's being a new one, no one knows exactly how it will work.''
Now, he said, ''there is no chance that a municipally driven process is going to destroy'' the project, which he described as the largest civilian development currently being undertaken by the Federal Government. He said he expected the buildings to be completed in ''the second Bush Administration.''
The two towers, on either side of Foley Square, would be built by one or more developers and purchased by the Government on a 30-year installment plan. Together, they would contain more than 1.5 million square feet, or one and a half times the size of the Chrysler Building. The Government said it did not expect that either tower would be more than 30 stories tall.
 
Compensation From Developers
One tower would be directly behind the New York County Courthouse at 60 Centre Street, between Worth and Pearl Streets. In its 740,000 square feet would be more than 40 Federal courtrooms, judges' chambers and space for court clerks, marshals, probation offices and the United States Attorney.
The other tower would be at 290 Broadway, between Duane and Reade Streets. It would have 400,000 square feet for Federal offices and 400,000 square feet for city offices.
The sites are now used mostly for parking.
Under the original terms, the city was to have conveyed the land to the Federal Government in return for a credit on the rent for office space in the new building on Broadway. Under the new agreement, the land would be condemned under eminent domain and the city would be compensated not by the Federal Government, but by the developers. The value of the land has not been established.
''While there is a condemnation, we are working with the city and, as best as we can, with community groups,'' Mr. Diamond said. ''It doesn't mean we're throwing out environmental concerns. We're not using condemnation to massively build a site that we couldn't otherwise. And it's not being used to avoid zoning.''
 
Plea From Community Board
Indeed, Mr. Diamond said, the size of the planned courthouse had been reduced, from 800,000 square feet. He added that the Government was ''committed to working with the city to improve Foley Square.''
Community Board 1 has objected to bypassing the review. Its chairman, James A. Stratton, wrote to Mr. Diamond that the board ''considers its participation in the Ulurp process one of its most important and significant functions'' and that it is ''not prepared to waive this opportunity to review and speak out on these two new buildings.''
The president of the Municipal Art Society, Kent L. Barwick, said the existing Jacob K. Javits Federal Building at 26 Federal Plaza, long criticized as being too large and having a brutal architectural style, was a troubling indication of what the Government would do if left unchecked.
''There is nothing in the past performance of the Federal Government at Foley Square to give anybody any confidence that the results will be anything less than disastrous,'' Mr. Barwick said. ''Nobody can blame anyone for wanting to avoid Ulurp. But the last people you'd want to see in charge of alterations to the Civic Center are the Federal Government.''

HEADLINE: Small College Shifts Focus To Minorities and the 90's

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 28

 BODY:
Working in a factory alongside his father was an option that Luis Rivera of Passaic always had but never wanted. His dream was to go to college, learn all he could about computers, work for a big corporation and, someday, own the business.
Now, with the help of a full scholarship and a special program at Bloomfield College intended to help minority students enter the state's post-industrial work force, Mr. Rivera is taking the first steps toward his goal.
''I plan to live up to the dream,'' the 17-year-old said. 
Long shut out of New Jersey's economic mainstream, Hispanic and black workers were hired in record numbers during the 1980's and will make up a growing portion of the labor force in the next decade, recent Federal statistics show.
 
'Missed Opportunities'
But analysts say that unless more young people like Mr. Rivera receive the substantially higher level of education and training needed to hold a job in today's sophisticated information-handling economy, New Jersey and the metropolitan region might not have enough workers.
''With all the achievements of the 1980's, the decade was also a period of missed opportunities,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in the Federal Department of Labor.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said that New Jersey created more than 750,000 jobs, most in business services or retail trade, during the 1980's. But in the same period it lost 133,000 factory positions that traditionally had been filled by people with few or no professional skills. The 1980 census found that 34 percent of black workers and 52 percent of Hispanic workers had not finished high school.
Mr. Ehrenhalt said it was that lack of education that kept many more minority workers from taking advantage of the state's economic boom and will continue to hamper them in the 1990's.
 
Change in Emphasis
Capitalizing on the pending demand for workers will take special education initiatives and a renewed effort on the part of government, business and schools to integrate minorities into the job market, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Such efforts are under way here at Bloomfield College, a 121-year-old liberal arts institution that over the last few years has been reorganized to help financially and academically disadvantaged minority students prepare for the work place of the future.
''If we turn our backs on the thousands and thousands of students whose S.A.T. test scores fall below 800, we turn our backs on the students upon which the future of New Jersey rests,'' said Dr. John F. Noonan, the president of Bloomfield College for the last three years.
 
Transforming the School
The college's location makes it a suitable site for an experiment in minority education. It is a mile and half north of Newark and not far from other large urban areas like East Orange and Irvington, and many of its students come from those cities. About half of the institution's 1,600 full- and part-time students are members of minorities, the highest percentage of any of the state's 16 independent colleges and universities.
Scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test range from a minimum of 400 to a high of 1,600.
When he arrived from Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., in 1986, Dr. Noonan set in motion the transformation of Bloomfield from a traditional liberal arts school with a sharply declining enrollment to what he calls a multi-cultural contemporary institution serving the surrounding population.
The most direct way of helping those students was to help them find work in New Jersey's new economy, which may need as many as 100,000 more workers by 1995.
 
A Lot of Hiring
The tight labor market has been building. According to recent Federal statistics, the number of New Jersey residents in the labor force rose by 437,000 between 1979 and the first nine months of 1989, far less than the 750,000 new jobs that were created. Immigrants from other states and nations filled the remaining jobs.
The shortage led businesses to hire minority-group members at a rate greater than ever before. Black and Hispanic workers constituted 44 percent of the 437,000 people who joined the labor force. As a result, the unemployment rate for black and Hispanic workers was halved during the 1980's, dropping to the current rate of 6.9 percent. But that rate remains twice as high as the 3.5 percent rate for white workers. In 1979, it was roughly the same - the unemployment rate for minorities was double that of whites.
The jobs these minority-group members took were not limited to low-paying positions at McDonald's, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. But Federal statistics show that 34 percent of white workers in New Jersey are employed in managerial, professional or technical jobs, compared with 19 percent of black workers and 19 percent of Hispanic workers.
Last year, Bloomfield College received a $1.8 million challenge grant from the state to establish an extensive program to attract black and Hispanic students who might otherwise not have even considered going to college.
 
Studying Leadership
The program establishes an executive-in-residence, who this year is Cyrus R. Holley, chief operating officer of Englehard Industries. It also includes a four-year leadership development program, in which select students, including Mr. Rivera, receive help as they study leadership styles and skills they will need in business.
Along with courses in his major, computer information systems, Mr. Rivera attends special leadership seminars. In his second year he will be assigned a mentor, an off-campus volunteer already working in the computer field. The third year he will spend up to 20 hours a week working as an intern in a business. He will also attend leadership seminars with Dr. Noonan. In his senior year he will become a mentor for a freshman.
Sometimes it takes more than financial aid and seminars. For Isabel Londono of Newark, who emigrated from Colombia in 1983, it also took an on-campus job, a flexible class schedule and long hours learning English.
''It was all very hard, very difficult,'' said Ms. Londono, who is 46 and the mother of twin teen-age boys who live with her in a Newark housing project.
Last May she graduated with honors with a degree in business administration.
Bloomfield College's new emphasis on job training and technical skills has raised questions about the mission of an institution of higher learning. There is concern that entrance standards might be lowered too far, and that too much attention might be paid to the needs of the work place at the expense of subjects like history and literature.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Luis Rivera and Isabel Londono who attend a special program for minorities at Bloomfield (N.J.) College. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases Drive Is Off To Better Start Than in 1988

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign for 1989-1990 opened on Sunday, and $1,303,381.21 has been collected. That is a substantial increase over the $1,168,040 that had been collected by the same time last year.
''Getting off to so impressive a start is particularly heartwarming at this time of great need,'' the president of the fund, Fred M. Hechinger, said yesterday. ''I hope that it will encourage donors old and new to make this year's drive the most successful ever.'' 
Of the total, $993,726.10, was from estates and trusts. The balance, $309,655.11, was from individuals and organizations, including the Starr Foundation, which donated $150,000, and the Mary J. Hutchins Foundation, which gave $55,000.
Even taking inflation into account, the proceeds of the three-day-old campaign dwarf the total of $3,630.88 that was collected in 1912. That was when Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of The New York Times, started the campaign after a chance encounter with a beggar.
 
From an Original Donor
One of the 117 original donors, Elizabeth L. Weiler of Manhattan, sent a $100 gift this year, carrying on a lifelong tradition.
''The time has come again,'' she wrote in a letter accompanying her contribution. ''I have done this since the very first year that you initiated this fund and hope to continue for a good number of years. I am now in my 85th year and look forward to a few more to enjoy life's blessings.''
Arthur D. Tenenholtz of Brooklyn, who wrote a check for $40 to the fund on Thanksgiving Day, said: ''At this time of year I receive many solitications from New York's cultural institutions. As worthy as those institutions may be, their letters remind me of The Times's Neediest Cases Fund, which never sends me solicitations.''
Some ties between cultural organizations and the fund do exist, as exemplified by $75 sent in September by di Cagno Inc., a new theater company. ''The enclosed check is from the proceeds of our theatrical production of Harold Pinter's 'The Collection,' '' the president of the troupe, Charles di Cagno, wrote.
The play ran in June at the Kittredge Club for Women on East 39th Street. ''We had a small budget, and we made some profit,'' Mr. di Cagno said yesterday. ''So we forwarded a small check. I would have preferred to send more. I have given to the fund before, and I was prompted by the sight of the homeless to do something this year.''
 
Collected so far $1,303,381.21

HEADLINE: OPEC Sets New Policy On Quotas

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided tonight to revise its quota system in a fundamental way that would give Persian Gulf oil producers a firm grip on prices and production in the next decade.
It also agreed to raise its overall production ceiling to 22 million barrels a day for the first six months of next year, from the present widely ignored ceiling of 20.5 million barrels.
OPEC's strict adherence to its new and higher quotas is doubtful since its 13 member nations are believed to be producing more than 23 million barrels a day. Indeed, the United Arab Emirates immediately said it would not accept its quota and would continue to overproduce.
 
'A Different Future'
''This meeting was somewhat insignificant in its immediate results, but we have set the first step for a different future,'' said one senior Iranian official who asked not to be identified. 
The new system will give Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Iraq, the Emirates and eventually Iran the final say over OPEC policies for years to come.
''After 1991 it is possible that people who will be managing the market will be three or four countries within the oil business,'' said Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, Kuwait's oil minister.
While Iran and Iraq are still technically at war, they have observed a truce in the last year and they seem to tacitly agree on demanding a larger share of OPEC production in cooperation with their Persian Gulf neighbors.
 
Dominance in Market
The new system means that as world demand for oil rises, those OPEC nations that possess the largest reserves will take what they please of the growing market and, consequently, set the price of oil as it serves their interests.
News of the OPEC agreement was interpreted on Wall Street as a sign that the price of oil would rise, increasing the value of the inventories of major oil companies. The stock prices of most oil companies were higher in brisk trading. But in the commodity markets, oil prices fell, and analysts there said there was a broad expectation of continued overproduction by OPEC members. [In New York, the chairman of the Phillips Petroleum Company, C. J. Silas, said in a briefing for reporters that he thought the OPEC agreement ''might give some strength to the market.'' He added that he was pleasantly surprised, explaining, ''I thought they might agree to nothing.'' [Mr. Silas added that the price of West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude, had averaged $18.50 for this year, and that the international market was such that the price would probably not be much higher for 1990.] Some OPEC countries, like Indonesia, have for the first time recognized their limited ability to produce more oil from their poor reserves, giving the green light to those with enormous reserves, like Kuwait, to fill the void.
 
Output Tied to 'Reality'
''The sensitive thing about this agreement is that it links production for the first time to the reality of oil reserves and the ability to produce it instead of a blanket right to have a larger share for political reasons,'' a senior Arab oil minister who asked not to be identified said in an interview.
Sheik Sabah of Kuwait, echoing a widespread judgment by a number of oil analysts and other oil ministers, said at a news conference tonight at the end of the OPEC meeting that ''the quota issue will lose its relevance in the 90's.''
In raising its ceiling by 1.5 million barrels, OPEC gave a third of the increase to Kuwait, which has been arguing for more than a year that OPEC countries that possess large oil reserves must have a bigger share of oil producion.
Under the accord, Kuwait's share of production went up to 1.5 million barrels a day. In September, OPEC assigned to Kuwait a quota of 1.2 million barrels a day, which Kuwait refused to acknowledge as binding.
 
Emirates Firm on Quota
The Emirates, which has been producing nearly two million barrels a day, twice its present quota, did not participate in the OPEC accord. In rejecting the assigned quota, its officials said they continued to believe that their country must receive a substantially higher share of oil production in OPEC in order to rejoin the quota system they have boycotted for more than two years.
Some OPEC members received proportional increases in their quotas. Others, like Indonesia, whose ability to produce oil is shrinking, received a smaller share. Algeria and Ecuador are other OPEC members whose capacity is believed to be near the saturation point.
Some countries that received proportional increases based on an old and increasingly defunct percentage system are not expected to be able to produce the oil, leaving room for those that can to fill the void.
Other countries that are able to produce more oil but are expected to face financial or physical constraints in doing so over the next few years are Libya, Qatar and Iran.
 
Iran Investment Lags
Iran is expected to join Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the Emirates and Iraq in being able to sharply increase production if it makes substantial investments in its oil operations. It has not been able to do that because of a lack of hard currency after war losses in the eight-year conflict with Iraq.
While OPEC's strict adherence to its new quotas is doubtful, virtually all OPEC officials here agreed to develop new methods to deal with their perennial disputes over market shares.
Of the Emirates, Sheik Sabah of Kuwait said, ''We hope as demand increases that we will get them back into the fold.'' That reflected a widespread belief within OPEC that it will increase its share of the world oil market to about half in the next decade, from its current one-third share. Such growth would create enough room within the group to accommodate the competing demands of major producers.
Some oil analysts argued that although in the long run OPEC might be right about its optimistic view of the rising oil demand, it might be rushing too fast to increase its production.
''There is a euphoria in OPEC about the recent price rise they have seen over the past year, but Western economies and Asian economies are slowing down and OPEC may be putting too much oil in the system with this latest agreement,'' said Joseph Story, president of Gulf Consulting Services of Washington, who was observing this meeting. ''I think demand will drop in the spring and this may come as a big shock to them.''
 
Steady Increase Since 1986
Oil prices and demand have risen steadily since 1986. OPEC prices have risen by an average of $6 a barrel over the last year alone, but many analysts said that while this trend might resume eventually as demand for oil continued to grow, it might slow in the coming year.
Nordine Ait-Laoussine, an Algerian oil expert who was an OPEC official for his country, said demand for OPEC oil in the first quarter of 1990 might not exceed 21.5 million barrels a day, while the group will be pumping at least 22 million barrels, plus another million barrels from the Emirates.
''It is an invitation for oil prices to come down,'' Mr. Ait-Laoussine added, ''because this is the first time in years that OPEC is fixing its ceiling of production above, not below, market demand.''
But the OPEC agreement worked out today has a built-in clause that suggests the calling of another meeting if prices drop substantially below the ''reference minimum price of $18 a barrel,'' according to the organization's final communique issued here tonight.
 
Strong Winter Demand Seen
Several ministers said, however, that they believed winter demand for oil would be strong enough to sustain current prices. Furthermore, they added, a number of other independent oil producers, notably the Soviet Union, were experiencing financial, political and physical constraints on their production that might create room for any excess OPEC production.
One key minister said the economic problems of the Soviet Union and the Eastern European bloc were becoming so severe that the average total exports of the Communist bloc countries of about 2.5 million barrels of oil a day might be substantially cut this year.
Some countries within OPEC are not expected to be able to produce their full allocation of oil under the accord either. Bahman Karbassioun, a former OPEC economist and independent consultant, said Algeria, for instance, would not be able to produce 50,000 barrels of the 827,000 barrels a day it had been allocated.
 
Doubt on Output Abilities
He also noted that Indonesia would not be able to produce 100,000 barrels a day of its new larger share of 1,374,000 barrels a day. Libya will also be unable, in Mr. Karbassioun's view, to pump all the 1,233,000 barrels a day it has been allocated, and Iran may have a shortfall of 140,000 barrels in its allocation of 3,140,000 barrels a day.
''Even if there is an overproduction by some, others will recognize they are hitting their maximum capacity and underproduce their quotas,'' Hisham M. Nazer, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said in an interview.
Abdallah Bassondan, a senior Saudi economist with his country's OPEC delegation, said: ''The nice thing about this agreement is that it is putting OPEC's capacity to the test. Some countries are about to find out that they may be unable to produce their new quotas. Then we will have a new ball game.''

HEADLINE: Hard Choices for Arms Makers

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Spending cuts being contemplated by the Pentagon for the 1990's could bring profound changes in the weapons business.
The cuts could reshape an industry in which the Pentagon and Congress have historically kept open certain weapons factories and laboratories even when they are no longer needed, simply to preserve jobs and hedge against any future war. Instead, some contractors now face years of shrinking profits and a growing likelihood of being forced out of businesses like airplane making and shipbuilding, where the military's reduced needs could be met by fewer companies.
Analysts, Government officials and industry executives also say that some of the biggest contractors would pursue a host of survival strategies, including taking on more work historically done by subcontractors or deliberately underbidding on programs just to keep engineers and production lines busy until the day, if it comes, that the arms business turns up again. A few could become takeover targets as Wall Street drives down their stock prices. Some could explore diversification more heavily into nonmilitary fields. 
 
Cutback Seen as a Catalyst
''Our biggest task is the restructuring of the defense industrial base,'' said Robert B. Costello, a former Under Secretary of Defense for acquisitions in the Reagan and Bush Administrations who is now with the Hudson Institute, a research organization. A Pentagon cutback would be ''a catalyst that will focus attention on the issue and allow us to put together concise, coherent policies to best use our capabilities for the benefit of the nation.''
Many experts say widespread spending cuts would also result in increased calls for the Government to take a more active, if yet undefined, role in making sure that companies vital to national security are not forced out of business, that important personnel and vital technologies find a home and that research projects in promising fields continue to be financed.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has asked the armed forces to formulate budgets that would allow a decline in Pentagon spending for the 1991 fiscal year and cuts totaling as much as $180 billion over the three years beginning in 1992, which represents an annual drop averaging 5 percent after accounting for inflation. His request reflected warming relations with the Soviet Union, the political changes in Eastern Europe and the pressure to bring down the budget deficit. The Administration had previously proposed increases of 1 or 2 percent after inflation over those years.
''In the 1990's, we are finally going to have to face the issue of what kind of defense industry we want,'' said Thomas L. McNaugher, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
 
Muddling Along
The weapons industry has been headed toward leaner times since the Reagan Administration's arms buildup reached a peak in 1986, although most companies have managed to muddle along for the last few years, finishing out programs started earlier in the decade.
Even now, few companies have taken radical steps to cope with the likelihood of rapidly declining Pentagon spending, saying it is too soon to predict what impact any budget cuts will have on their programs. Some industry executives say their companies will do just fine without any big strategic changes.
''When you take into account budget deficits, arms control negotiations and Gorby mania, this is something we've been anticipating for a long time,'' said David Wheaton, corporate vice president for program development and planning at the General Dynamics Corporation.
 
Some Losers, Some Winners
The cuts would still hurt though. Smaller Pentagon budgets would put the most pressure on the the builders of expensive aircraft and ships. Further cuts could hasten the demise of the Grumman Corporation on Long Island as a leading aircraft producer, analysts said. Other companies like the Lockheed Corporation would also face struggles to keep producing planes.
There would be some winners as well as losers. Because the armed services would not be able to afford new planes and ships, they would probably turn more frequently to makers of some sophisticated electronics systems that could upgrade and modernize their existing fleets. Most big contractors have expanded their electronics businesses in recent years, especially those like Lockheed and the Rockwell International Corporation that have seen rapid declines in their aircraft business.
Similarly, makers of satellites and other surveillance equipment are expected to do well. Wall Street has particularly high hopes for a company in Dallas called E-Systems Inc. that makes surveillance gear used for arms control verification.
 
Political Factors
While the weeding out of the industry's weaker or excess players has begun in recent years, it has been significantly slowed by political realities.
For example, Congress has continued to finance production of Grumman's F-14 fighter plane even after the Navy asked that the program be ended. The reason was Congressional reluctance to end all major aircraft production at Grumman, the largest employer on Long Island and a repository of knowledge about the design and manufacture of carrier-based fighter planes.
Other companies have already left portions of the business, either by design or because of lack of new business. Rockwell, which built the B-1B bomber earlier in the decade, now has no major military aircraft-production programs. The company is concentrating instead on its commercial businesses and those military-related businesses that show some growth prospects, mostly in satellites and electronics.
 
Adding to Costs per Unit
Even those companies that have and continue to receive big production contracts will suffer as programs are stretched out or scaled back in an attempt to save money. While generally preferable to outright cancellation from the contractor's point of view, stretchouts almost always make production less efficient, increase the per-unit cost of the system and reduce profit margins.
The Northrop Corporation has invested more than $1 billion in developing technical expertise and capacity to build the 132 B-2 bombers the Air Force wants at a rate of 24 to 36 a year. But now the B-2 program seems certain to be scaled back and stretched out. The B-2's per-plane price of $530 million will probably rise, because Northrop will not master the manufacturing process as quickly as it had planned. Northrop's profit margins will suffer, the company's debt load will remain higher than planned and large amounts of space, machinery and skilled personnel will be underutilized.
Faced with a declining military market, most companies, predictably enough, are studying the possibility of diversifying into other businesses. But that route has not been successful for those contractors who have tried it in the past - Rockwell, for example, never learned to make good televisions or refrigerators when it tried a decade ago - and few companies have the financial strength to make an acquisition or start an entirely new business anyway.
 
A Variety of Strategies
Still, said Robert Paulson, a director at the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, prime contractors will pursue a variety of strategies to survive. Some will deliberately underbid on the few contracts available, just to insure that they stay in the business, doing so on the assumption that the Government will later help by giving them more money. Other prime contractors will take on more work historically done by subcontractors, or will farm less work out to subcontractors by making more parts in-house.
Companies are increasingly likely to pursue joint ventures with foreign partners that can supply technologies, designs and access to their home markets. Lockheed recently announced that it would license the design for a jet trainer from Aermacchi S.p.A. of Italy that it will propose for use as the Air Force's next generation of trainers.
As the financial pressures mount, some companies could attract takeover offers. Analysts say Grumman, Northrop and Lockheed are the most logical targets, because all have relatively weak stock prices that would allow an acquirer to purchase their technical expertise at bargain prices. The Boeing Company, which is financially strong because of its booming commercial aircraft business, is one potential acquirer, though it has made no moves in that direction.
''There's no question that budget cuts will force a more rapid consolidation in almost all the subsectors of the weapons industry,'' said William B. Burnett, a vice president at Charles River Associates, an economic consulting firm. ''The question is to what extent the Department of Defense will participate in the consolidation and make sure that valuable defense assets don't just go floating away in the wind.''
 
Fears for Smaller Companies
Much of the concern is focused on the lower tiers of the industry, generally smaller companies that supply prime contractors with sophisticated technology or components. Without a Government effort to protect such companies, many officials say, the nation will increasingly face situations like that in which a unit of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation that makes tools to produce advanced computer chips is likely to be sold to the Nikon Corporation of Japan because efforts to find an American buyer have failed. A sale to Nikon would leave the United States almost wholly dependent on a foreign nation for the production of chips that have widespread military as well as commercial applications.
Some analysts think the Pentagon should decide which contractors ought to survive and should direct contracts toward those companies to insure a smaller but healthier industry. Others think the Pentagon should provide more seed money to private industry, much as the Government is trying to do in backing Sematech, the industry consortium that is working to improve the nation's competitiveness in computer chips.
Mr. McNaugher of Brookings said the Government should finance more research and development without necessarily planning to build the weapons systems that might result.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Shifting Spending To Public Works

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE upheaval in Eastern Europe, with its greater openness to the West, means to many Americans that the United States no longer needs a huge military establishment. The Bush Administration, in fact, is beginning to shrink the $300 billion military budget. But if billions of dollars are diverted from military spending over the next decade, how should the money be spent?
To many people, the answer is that the money should not be spent at all: It should be used to balance the Federal budget and thus revive the economy. If the Government no longer has to borrow so much to finance the deficit, this argument goes, then interest rates will decline. The lower rates will encourage corporations to build new factories and buy machinery on credit. This robust capital spending increases productivity, lowers costs and helps to make exports boom. 
''If we could get $100 billion a year out of defense spending, that would bring long-term interest rates down toward their levels in the 1960's,'' said Charles L. Schultze, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. Adjusted for inflation, interest rates averaged 2 percent in the 1960's.
But popular as it is, the goal of reducing the budget deficit runs into a conflicting economic theory. No matter how low interest rates are, companies will not invest in a big way if they cannot hire properly educated workers for their new factories, if they lose money trying to ship goods on rundown highways and if they have to put up with costly irritations like congested airports, or inadequate water and waste disposal systems.
Private investment, in sum, requires an adequate infrastructure, many economists contend. Reflecting this view, Robert Heilbroner, the economic historian, says, ''The single most productive use that we can make of a $100 billion annual reduction in the defense budget is to rebuild the nation's infrastructure.''
Few economists oppose public works spending. Mr. Schultze, for example, says $20 billion of the $100 billion in military budget savings - if that much is actually cut - might go to the infrastructure. But giving it priority over reducing the budget deficit assumes that refurbished public works will generate so much new wealth that a $150 billion annual deficit won't be hard to finance.
The most frequently cited research into infrastructure spending has been done by David Aschauer, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. He concludes that for every $1 invested in ''core infrastructure'' - streets and highways, water and sewer systems, airports and mass transit - corporations invest 25 cents in plant and equipment, over the long run.
By comparison, Mr. Aschauer says, the private sector would increase capital spending by only 7 or 8 cents for every dollar's reduction in the military budget, absent an offsetting public works outlay. Compounding the problem, the ratio of public works to private capital stock has fallen from a peak of 54 percent in 1964 to just over 40 percent today, Mr. Aschauer said.
Other studies - and the research is still skimpy - support the view that a Government dollar spent on the infrastructure gets more mileage than it does in the military sector. Zvi Griliches, a Harvard economist, for example, found that civilian research into, say, more efficient auto engines, results in three times more growth in the nation's productivity rate than the same amounts spent on developing weapons, such as ballistic missiles.
There are some caveats, of course. Gordon Adams, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, for example, agrees that public works spending adds to the nation's wealth, but only if the spending is managed properly. The rebuilt highways, for example, must be thick enough to bear the weight of tractor-trailer trucks.
Then there is the short-term problem. The 1970's were another period of cutbacks in military spending, and when the low point was reached in 1976, Pentagon outlays generated only 1.9 million jobs in the private sector, compared with 3.1 million today, according to Richard P. Oliver, a Labor Department economist. ''If you cut one-third of the defense spending in the next decade, one-third of the jobs may be lost,'' he said.
That process is already under way. The General Electric Company, for instance, plans by 1992 to eliminate 10,000 jobs, or 20 percent of the work force, in its aerospace division, mostly devoted to military work. But that does not faze unions. ''The defense industry is turning to offshore procurement and to labor-saving technology,'' said Richard Greenwood, an official of the International Association of Machinists, which represents many military equipment workers. ''The civilian sector is a better bet to generate more jobs in the future.''

HEADLINE: Trade Gap a Bit Wider As Export Growth Lags

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit, after improving for six months, deteriorated slightly, to $27.75 billion, in the third quarter, reflecting flat exports and the nation's appetite for imported goods.
Analysts do not expect much improvement in the near future. Imports may drop somewhat because of a slowing United States economy, they say, but exports also are likely to fall because of a strong dollar and moderating economies overseas. 
The Commerce Department said today that the gap between imports and United States exports edged up by seven-tenths of 1 percent in the July-September quarter, from $27.55 billion in the second quarter. The April-June deficit was the narrowest since a $27.7 billion imbalance in the first quarter of 1985.
 
Records in Five Quarters
Imports rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to a record $119.3 billion, while exports rose only two-tenths of 1 percent, to a record $91.6 billion. Both imports and exports have reached record levels in each of the last five quarters.
But analysts worry that exports, which sustained much of the nation's economy last year, will remain unchanged in the months ahead. ''The trade report substantiates what we've already seen,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. ''Export growth simply has flattened out after booming previously and is a major source of the wave of weakness rippling through the United States economy, particularly the manufacturing sector.''
A stronger dollar makes American goods more expensive and thus less competitive overseas, while making imported goods cheaper and thus more attractive to buyers in the United States.
 
Increase in Oil Imports
Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said the trade deficit would be aggravated by the high level of oil imports.
The Commerce Department said the average number of barrels imported daily increased by 8.5 percent in the third quarter, to 8.65 million barrels, the highest level since the third quarter of 1977. But despite the increase, oil imports showed a July-September numerical decrease of 1 percent because of lower prices. The average price per barrel fell to $16.85, from $18.46.
Non-oil imports rose five-tenths of 1 percent, to $106 billion, led by consumer goods, including clothing and household goods. Imports of industrial supplies and materials fell, while both capital goods and automotive products were virtually unchanged.
 
Bolstered by Capital Goods
Non-farm exports increased by 2 percent, to a record $81.8 billion. The sector was bolstered by shipments of capital goods, including aircraft and parts to Western Europe, Japan and newly industrialized countries in Asia.
For the first nine months of the year, the overall deficit was running at an annual rate of $111.6 billion, down 12.3 percent from the $127.2 billion trade deficit registered in all of 1988.
Today's report on merchandise trade, which is calculated on a balance-of-payments basis, is slightly different from the Commerce Department's monthly merchandise trade reports because it excludes United States military sales to foreign governments and makes other minor adjustments in the monthly figures.

HEADLINE: U.S. Awards Computer Contract

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The Thinking Machines Corporation said today that it had received a $12 million contract from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to develop the first supercomputer capable of speeds of a trillion operations a second, the level of computer performance researchers believe will be necessary to solve the most difficult scientific problems.
Thinking Machines is a computer maker based in Cambridge, Mass., that has designed its supercomputer around thousands of small processors that work in parallel. This approach differs from the route taken by such traditional supercomputer companies as the Cray Research Corporation, which build computers based on only a few processors and concentrate on making each processor as fast as possible. 
A computer capable of a trillion operations a second has recently become the Holy Grail of the supercomputing industry after a Government panel reported that such performance would be necessary to solve 20 ''grand challenges '' - the thorniest scientific problems. These include creating models of the earth's weather patterns that would enable much more sophisticated long-range forecasting.
 
Speedier Operations
Such computing power would enable operations to be performed as much as 500 times more quickly than on existing supercomputers, which reach speeds of several billion operations a second.
The Thinking Machines contract comes at a time when the Pentagon research agency has been embroiled in a controversy over what the Government's role should be in supporting research that would help United States high-technology industries compete against Japanese and European companies.
In recent years, Darpa, as the agency is known, has been the Government coordinator of efforts to enhance national competitiveness in semiconductors, high-definition television and computing. But in recent weeks there have been indications that some of President Bush's advisers believe that the Government's role in such efforts should be restricted.
The supercomputer business has also become more risky recently. This year two major American efforts to design supercomputers, by ETA Systems, a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, and Evans & Sutherland, a start-up venture, have each announced a withdrawal from the field.
And Cray, the world's leading maker of supercomputers, split into two companies this year because it could not meet the costs of all of its development efforts.
At a news conference here, several of the agency's executives said Darpa's financing role in the supercomputing field did not raise broader industrial policy issues.
''Darpa has a clear mission to avoid technology surprises,'' said Stephen Squires, the chief scientist of Darpa's information technology office. He said Darpa was currently supporting a number of private and university efforts in new supercomputing technologies.
 
Japanese Deal Likely
More than 40 Thinking Machines computers, known as Connection Machines, have been sold to private and government agencies as well as to Europe, The company said it would announce its first sale to Japan soon.
Thinking Machines is controversial in the supercomputing business. ''We can't find any real progress in harnessing the power of thousands of processors,'' said Neil Davenport, the president of the Cray Computer Corporation, a spinoff of Cray Research that was founded by Seymour Cray earlier this year.
Mr. Davenport said he believed that such parallel computers were only useful on a limited class of scientific and engineering problems.
The Thinking Machines CM-2 computer uses 64,000 processors. The new machine, which will not be ready until the mid-1990's, will have as many as a million processors and will cost as much as $80 million to develop, said Danny Hillis, the company's co-founder and chief scientist.

HEADLINE: Boskin Sees Lower Rates

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he expected interest rates to fall a bit further, spurring increased consumer demand for durable goods.
''It's likely there will be a little bit further fall,'' Mr. Boskin said at the Agriculture Department's 1990 outlook conference. 
Economists have grown confused in recent days by the actions of the Federal Reserve, and interest rates in the credit markets have moved erratically this week.
Mr. Boskin said that recent sluggishness in the economy could be attributed partly to higher interest rates earlier this year and that, as rates continued to fall, the economy would pick up.
He also said the Government on Wednesday would probably revise upward the 2.5 percent third-quarter gross national product figures it reported previously.
He said the Administration was forecasting long-term economic growth of 3 percent after inflation.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 7.04 as Light Trading Continues

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above 2,700, after languishing in a slightly higher range throughout most of the session.
''The Dow's close of 2,702.01, was at a critical market area,'' said Robert B. Ritter, the chief technical analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company in New York. ''Stock prices advanced despite investor confusion primarily resulting from conflicting monetary policy moves by the Federal Reseve Board.''
Mr. Ritter said that while the outlook for interest rates and the economy were dominating the market, the forthcoming summit meeting between President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was attracting widening interest and helping lift stocks. 
''A better definition of the 'peace dividend' might develop from these discussions and have a major impact on the stock market,'' he added.
 
Gains 26.46 So Far
The Dow gained 7.04 points yesterday, bringing the week's gain so far to 26.46 points.
Volume continued to be light, with investors still cautious over the course of interest rates. A total of 153.8 million shares changed hands yesterday, up from 149.4 million the day before, as the 848 advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered the 647 declining ones.
The broader market yesterday was noticeably weaker than the blue-chip sector. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks edged up only 0.16 of a point, to 345.77, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index tacked on 0.21 to close at 191.34.
Oil stocks helped bolster the blue-chip sector after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries increased the output quotas of its members. Exxon jumped 1 point, to 47 7/8; Mobil added 5/8, to 58 3/4; Phillips Petroleum gained 3/4, to 23 3/8, and Texaco rose 7/8, to 54 3/4.
 
Chevron Most Active
Chevron was the most active Big Board stock, slipping 1/2, to 67 3/4, on a volume of nearly 3.7 million shares. Traders said that Chevron, based in San Francisco, also attracted interest because on Monday it created an employee stock ownership plan that will hold $1 billion worth of its shares.
Much of yesterday's action came in merger-related stocks.
On the American Stock Exchange, Ambrit rose 5/8, or 38.5 percent, to 2 1/4, making it the Amex's biggest percentage gainer. The ice cream maker, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., said it had agreed to a new exchange ratio in its proposed merger with Empire of Carolina Inc. under which each Ambrit common share would be exchanged for three-tenths of a share of Empire.
In over-the-counter trading, McCaw Cellular Communications jumped 1 1/2, to 37 1/2. The company, with headquarters in Kirkland, Wash., offered to make its offer for Lin Broadcasting more attractive if the New York-based Lin would agree to a friendly merger.
 
Polaroid Off $1.25
Earnings reports and projections continued to move some equities.
Polaroid slipped 1 1/4, to 45 3/4. The company, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it had lowered its earnings projections for 1989 and 1990.
Litton Industries slipped 3/8, to 77 1/8, after reporting that earnings for its first fiscal quarter that ended on Oct. 31 were unchanged at $43.6 million.
Other active stocks included General Electric, up 3/8, to 61 3/4; Philip Morris, unchanged at 41 1/2; McDonald's, off 1/8, to 32 7/8; Smithkline Beecham, up 1/4, to 39 1/4, and American Express up 5/8, to 35 3/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index rose 1.06 points, to 375.10, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index advanced 0.49, to 456.66.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Energy Prices Fall Sharply In Wake of OPEC Accord

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Energy prices declined sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders reacted to news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had reached a production agreement that would raise the group's output ceiling to 22 million barrels a day and maintain a target price of $18 a barrel.
Futures prices of precious metals were mixed in active trading on New York's Commodity Exchange, and grain and soybean prices rose.
The OPEC agremeent, reached at a meeting in Vienna, ''had a few more leaks in terms of quota discipline'' than was desired by the market. said Robert Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. 
''The agreement was signed with the recognition that the United Arab Emirates would continue to overproduce,'' he added, predicting that Kuwait would also continue to surpass its quota. The United Arab Emirates and Kuwait have each been producing two million barrels a day. or double their current quotas.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 29 cents to 43 cents lower, with January at $19.25 cents a barrel; heating oil was 0.61 cent to 0.94 cent lower, with December at 60.31 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.80 cent to 1.36 cents higher, with December at 49.53 cents a gallon.
 
Gold Prices Mixed
Gold settled from 50 cents higher to 60 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in December down 60 cents at $413.50 an ounce; the expiring November contract settled at $413.40, off 50 cents. Silver was 2 cents to 6 cents higher, with December at $5.695 an ounce.
Gold prices continued Monday's slide in early trading, but regained some losses as speculators began to hunt for bargains.
''Gold continues to be bought by speculators,'' said Peter Cardillo, an analyst at Josephthal & Company in New York. ''Basically, there still is a sense of fear about the strength of the economy.''
Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher on the Chicago Board of Trade despite the lack of news to influence trading. Soybean futures rose as traders reacted to a sense that the market was oversold in the wake of Monday's selloff of soybean futures on slack export sales and bearish technical signals.
Soybeans also received support from the Malaysian palm oil market, where futures were higher Monday after last week's weakness, analysts said.
