HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Lower On Interest-Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was generally lower yesterday as concerns about interest rates continued to dominate the foreign exchange markets.
Analysts said the dollar moved higher in early trading after the Federal Reserve signaled on Monday that it was not lowering interest rates. When interest rates fall in the United States, dollar-denominated securities and the dollar itself become less attractive to investors.
The dollar had fallen in recent sessions amid expectations that the Fed would lower interest rates. But Monday's developments ''caused a momentary hesitation in the market'' and traders began buying dollars early in yesterday's session to shore up their positions, said Robert Ryan, senior foreign exchange trader with the Bank of New York.
In late trading, the dollar resumed its slide because of continuing expectations that interest rates would rise overseas, particularly in West Germany, making foreign currencies more valuable, said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc.
 
Strength of West German Mark
The West German mark has been strong against most currencies since East Germany opened the Berlin wall on Nov. 9, raising expectations that West German industry would benefit from the new opening to the East and that the Bundesbank would raise West German interest rates.
The mark suffered from some profit taking yesterday but still closed higher. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7770 marks, from 1.7890 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5880 Swiss francs, down from 1.6040; 6.0710 French francs, down from 6.1100; 1,312.75 Italian lire, down from 1,320.75, and 1.16645 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16665.
The dollar also declined against the British pound, which cost $1.5670 in New York, compared with $1.5585 late Monday. And it was basically unchanged against the Japanese yen, at 143.20 yen.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
McCaw Offers to Sweeten Its Bid for Lin

BYLINE: By GREGORY A. ROBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said today that it would make its offer for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation more attractive, if the New York-based cellular telephone company would accept a friendly transaction. Lin, trying to fight off McCaw's advances, has agreed to merge with the BellSouth Corporation.
Craig O. McCaw, chairman of the nation's largest cellular telephone company, in a letter to Lin's board of directors dated Monday, said that Lin shareholders would be given more favorable tax treatment, although the revised deal ''would mirror the economics of our present proposal.'' His letter was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
A spokesman for Lin, the nation's seventh-largest cellular company, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
Lin's shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $120.25, in the over-the-counter market. McCaw rose $1.50, to $37.50.
 
Increased McCaw Offer
Last week, McCaw raised its offer for Lin to $150 a share for 22.5 million Lin shares, or 46 percent. With the 10 percent it already owns, it would thus have control. The earlier offer was $125 a share for 22 million shares.
Lin has said that it will review the sweetened bid and respond at an appropriate time.
Under McCaw's complex new proposal, Lin would issue new common stock, and McCaw would buy 46.1 million of those shares directly from Lin for $3.37 billion, or $73.21 a share. Then, Lin would buy $425 million of McCaw class A common stock and distribute to shareholders $69.19 in cash and $8.71 in McCaw stock for each remaining Lin share.
McCaw said this distribution would be treated partly as a dividend, partly as a return of capital and partly as capital gains. Over all, this would result in lower taxes than the previous deal.
Following the transaction, McCaw said it would control 52 percent of Lin's outstanding shares.
BellSouth, the giant telephone concern, has argued that its offer is still superior to the new McCaw bid.
BellSouth has offered a cash dividend of $42 a share plus stock in BellSouth's television and cellular companies. Lin has scheduled a shareholders meeting to consider the merger on Jan. 12, and McCaw contends its offer should also be put to the shareholders.
In general, however, analysts discounted the significance of the latest McCaw proposal.

HEADLINE: Visions of Europe; The View From Moscow - a special report:
Clamor in the East;
Gorbachev's Hope for Future: 'A Common European Home'

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 29

 BODY:
When it comes to the future of Europe, no one accuses President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of lacking vision.
The Soviet leader's vision - he calls it ''a common European home'' - is in some respects utopian. It has been shaped in large part by the tumult of events beyond the Kremlin's control, including economic desperation at home and explosive popular aspirations in Eastern Europe.
From the time Mr. Gorbachev first broached the ''common home'' notion on a visit to France in 1985, it has been regarded in the West as more a speechwriter's conceit than a basis for serious discussion.
 
Taking a Closer Look
But as Mr. Gorbachev and President Bush prepare to survey together the wreckage of the postwar order in Europe, both Soviet and Western specialists have begun to look more seriously at the Soviet leader's vision of what might replace it. 
In interviews conducted as successive spasms of democracy struck Eastern Europe, Soviet officials and scholars and Western diplomats here said the West had not yet grasped the magnitude of what Mr. Gorbachev wants in Europe, of the overall vision toward which he would like to maneuver Mr. Bush in their meeting this week.
In effect, what Mr. Gorbachev seeks is a huge exchange, in which Moscow surrenders its costly ambitions of expansionism - at least beyond its postwar borders.
 
Admission to the Club
In return, Moscow wants admission to the club of Western industrial countries, bringing with it technology and a period of calm in which to focus on the problem that really threatens Soviet security: an economy that cannot compete in the world or satisfy the growing wants of its own people.
''The common European home means decomposition of the empire, in our own interest,'' said Andranik Migranyan, an analyst at one of the most influential research groups, the Institute for the Economy of the World Socialist System.
''In the end, it means the return to a single European civilization,'' said Fyodor M. Burlatsky, chairman of the human rights panel of the parliamentary committee on foreign relations.
As Mr. Burlatsky suggests, this Europe is not so much a geographical concept as a cultural one - it means Western civilization, including the United States.
What follows is a rough floor plan, based on these interviews and Mr. Gorbachev's own comments, of the Soviet leader's European home.
 
Freedom of Choice, Even With Capitalists
The first and most startling feature of this new Europe is the breakup of the Communist bloc.
''Of course, there is still a bloc of Eastern European states, in which the Soviet Union is clearly the most formidable partner,'' said a Western European diplomat. ''But it is no longer uniformly Communist, and it seems even Communist parties within those countries are not bound by Moscow.''
Although Soviet officials do not like to advertise it, they agree that the freedom of Eastern European countries to run their own affairs includes the right to reject Communism altogether, to adopt multiparty democracies and market economies and even to call themselves capitalists.
''Once you've determined the principle of freedom of choice, I don't see how any limit can be set,'' said a Foreign Ministry official, interviewed on the condition he not be named. ''You cannot say 'This is socialism; this line you cannot cross.' ''
 
How Quick the Pace: It's Dominoes Away
Mr. Gorbachev has been increasingly categorical about a policy of noninterference in the internal affairs of his allies, and has backed up his words by accepting - even applauding - the dislodging of Communist regimes in Poland and Hungary.
''One can argue about the degree to which Gorbachev had a choice, and about his motives,'' said a Western diplomat. ''But it is hard to make the case any longer that he doesn't mean it.''
This diplomat speculates that if Mr. Gorbachev had any lingering qualms about a hands-off policy, they were erased this year as he watched the horrified reaction to China's suppression of its democracy movement, and the bitter domestic backlash after troops killed demonstrators in Soviet Georgia.
At the same time, Soviet officials and Western diplomats generally agree that Mr. Gorbachev had not engineered the tumbling of Eastern Europe's dominoes, nor foreseen the pace and sequence of events.
He has, rather, played the role of catalyst, both publicly, by opening a vigorous debate of Communism's failures at home, and privately, by making it clear Moscow would not intervene to prop up old regimes.
''A signal may be either indirect or indirect,'' Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, observed the other day when asked to describe Moscow's role in Eastern Europe. ''We are not waving a conductor's baton.''
 
All the Party's Horses And All of Its Men
Perhaps the best metaphor for Mr. Gorbachev's approach to his restive allies is the opening of the Berlin wall.
Just as East Germany opened its borders to slow the headlong defection of its citizens - by assuring them they could wait a while, size up the changes at home, and leave whenever they wanted - Mr. Gorbachev's policy is to open the bloc in hopes that the members will remain together voluntarily.
So far the more independent voices in Eastern Europe have been careful to pledge their allegiance to the Warsaw Pact and to the postwar boundaries of Europe - and not only because they worry how Moscow would respond if a country bolted from the pact.
''Now the Governments in Poland and Hungary have changed,'' said Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the former chief of the armed forces general staff and now an adviser to Mr. Gorbachev in the Soviet legislature. ''There are non-Communists at the heads of the governments. But the state interests of Poland and Hungary have remained the same, to a significant degree.''
''First of all, there's the stability of the territory and state boundaries,'' he continued. ''Second, there are the economic interests of the states. After all, they've been linked for many decades. That is why the military-political alliance remains.''
 
Staying Together, For Old Time's Sake 
The next stage, already under way, is a transformation of the eastern military and economic alliances - the Warsaw Pact and the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.
While Soviets once talked of disbanding NATO and the Warsaw Pact simultaneously - a bluff the West did not take seriously - they now tend to agree that it is better to preserve the alliances for the foreseeable future, since on its own each country might be tempted to renew historical disputes with its neighbors.
In Mr. Gorbachev's vision, the military alliances that now face off across a central European front will evolve into political alliances, in which the military role has withered.
Beginning with a meeting of Warsaw Pact leaders in Bucharest, Rumania, last July, where the group for the first time declared a policy of noninterference in its members' internal affairs, the Eastern alliance has begun to take on some trappings of a more political, NATO-style fraternity.
According to Western and Soviet specialists, the Soviet side has signaled that it will accept changes in the Warsaw Pact Constitution that would ban use of troops in internal affairs, declare that the pact does not include promoting Communism, and make membership more equal and voluntary.
''The pact will dissolve, that seems irreversible,'' said a Polish journalist who visited Moscow last week with Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Poland's new non-Communist Prime Minister. ''So why waste our energy pushing it? The only thing we have to do is avoid posing a threat to the Soviet Union, and we are not that stupid.''
In the Soviet vision, the remaking of the pacts would include a rollback of military forces on both sides.
''The state interests of both alliances still remain, and the contradictions remain,'' Marshal Akhromeyev said. ''And a certain quantity of arms and armed forces will remain. But what matters is that it be such a quantity which would not permit the country to start a war, even if it wanted to.''
Mr. Akhromeyev and Mr. Gorbachev publicly insist these reductions must be mutual, worked out at the conventional arms talks under way in Vienna between the 16 NATO allies and the 7 members of the Warsaw Pact.
But among the Soviet researchers, some theorists now argue openly for more dramatic, one-sided moves.
 
To Have Troops Or Not to Have Troops
Vladimir N. Chernega, vice rector of the diplomatic academy of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, suggests that the Soviet Union could withdraw its troops entirely from Eastern Europe without demanding that America match it.
''If the Governments of Eastern Europe want it, we must withdraw our troops from their territory,'' he said, stressing that this was a personal opinion. ''We can do this even unilaterally. As for American troops - I would leave that up to the Western European Governments. I know that some circles in Western Europe feel their security is greater with American troops. It's an understandable position. Let them have it.''
''We have a historical chance now and we have to make the most of it,'' he said. ''In this context, a certain presence of Americans troops - a limited presence - poses no danger.''
Like Mr. Gorbachev's own series of announced military budget cuts ''the pact will dissolve, that seems irreversible,'' said a Polish journalist who visited Moscow last week with Tadeusz Mazowiecki, Poland's new non-Communist Prime Minister. ''So why waste our energy pushing it? The only thing we have to do is avoid posing a threat to the Soviet Union, and we are not that stupid.''
''For us, this is not just reducing military spending and reallocating resources to civilian purposes,'' Mr. Chernega noted. ''It is a matter of structural reorganization of our whole economy. Forty percent of our machine-tool industry and 75 percent of our spending on science go to the military. This is no basis for a normal economy.''
 
Is Finlandization Coming to the East?
Ultimately, after the withering of military confrontation, some Soviet analysts expect that some of the Soviet allies will become neutral-but-careful neighbors like Finland.
On his visit to Helsinki in October, Mr. Gorbachev hailed Finland as a model neighbor. Mr. Migranyan predicts that Finlandization of the Eastern bloc will come more quickly than anyone in the West anticipates.
Mr. Burlatsky, a legislator close to the leadership, is more cautious, but he says neutrality is entirely possible.
''If Austria can be neutral, then why not Hungary?'' he said. ''But that's in the future, after radical structural changes in the two blocs.''
If the Warsaw Pact is being revamped, the Eastern economic alliance seems to be quickly coming apart, as budding market economies like Hungary and Poland find it harder to coexist with the older, planned economies.
The more market-minded members of the alliance, including the Soviet Union, are aggressivly seeking to open new relationships with the European Community, and with individual Western countries.
But the Eastern European countries are so bound together by common backwardness and mutual trade dependencies, that economic integration with the West may prove more difficult than reducing military confrontation.
''There is an asymmetry between the disintegration of Eastern Europe and the growing integration of Western Europe,'' Mr. Burlatsky said, noting the Western European countries' planned 1992 market consolidation.
''It seems there is a danger of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union turning into an economic appendage of the West, a supplier of raw materials,'' he said. ''That would create political problems, because a great superpower such as the Soviet Union will not feel comfortable in such a role.''
Mr. Burlatsky argues for ''a common market on the entire European continent,'' but he predicts a difficult decade or two before that is possible.
 
Wooing the Money And Then Some More
In the meantime, Mr. Gorbachev seems to accept, even welcome the flow of Western credits, guarantees and investment to Eastern European countries. Although he warns against ''exporting capitalism,'' he realizes that Western capital relieves him of an unbearable economic burden, and that hopes that it will help Eastern Europe become a bridge by which the Soviet Union can reach Western technology and markets.
Some portions of Mr. Gorbachev's design remain deliberately unfinished.
One is Germany. The Soviets are uneasy about the potential clout of a reunified Germany, and they are reluctant to be seen undermining the authority of their allies in East Berlin.
But some Soviet analysts say privately they are not alarmed about some new arrangement short of complete reunification, with security guarantees to reassure the neighbors.
And Soviet officials say they do not rule out reunification in the future, after ''overcoming the division of Europe,'' as the Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said today.
 
Whither the Baltics? A Gray Area for Soviets
Another gray area in the blueprint is the fate of the Baltic republics, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which yearn to rejoin Europe as independent states. Moscow is willing to concede these republics greater autonomy and closer economic links with the West, but balks at complete independence.
So far, most Western governments seem to accept this as Mr. Gorbachev's domestic problem, and they have not pressed him on behalf of the Baltics. But the three republics are pushing ahead without foreign encouragement.
The overriding question about Mr. Gorbachev's vision is how widely it is shared within the Soviet power structure. Clearly there are conservatives here who chafe at the retrenchment of Soviet power and the flouting of Communist verities, but they are understandable quiet about it.
Mr. Migranyan, for one, contends that the collapse of territorial ambitions has now very nearly reached the point where it would be impossible to reverse even if Mr. Gorbachev were replaced by a conservative.
''Even the most conservative government here will have to accept the changes in Eastern Europe,'' he said. ''It would cost too much to reverse them.''
Future articles will include the views from Washington and Western Europe.

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
Bush Hoping to Use Malta Talks to Speed Strategic Arms Pact

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
President Bush wants his meeting this weekend with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to speed up talks on reducing long-range nuclear weapons, possibly by giving negotiators a timetable for dealing with the remaining obstacles to a treaty before the next Soviet-American summit meeting in 1990, senior officials said today.
Making it clear that the meeting will not merely be the ''feet on the table'' get-together that Mr. Bush first advertised, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today outlined an ambitious agenda for Mr. Bush's first summit talks with Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Baker hinted that the two leaders might reach some understanding, even if they do not take specific action, on lowering barriers to trade between the Soviet Union and the West, including the American restrictions on granting Moscow the most-favored-nation trading status it has long sought.
 
Will Protest Arms Shipments
Saying the Administration is ''interested in exploring the opportunities for mutual advantage across the board in our relations,'' Mr. Baker highlighted only one area of fundamental dispute. He said Mr. Bush would strongly protest to Mr. Gorbachev about the shipment of Soviet arms to Moscow's ''Brezhnevite clients in Central America, Afghanistan, Cambodia and Ethiopia.'' 
Mr. Baker called the shipments ''a cold-war relic'' and said arms shipments to Nicaragua and the leftist rebels in El Salvador have continued through Cuba despite repeated assurances that Moscow would use its influence to stop them.
''All I can gather is that either the Nicaraguans are lying to the Soviet Union or the Soviet Union is lying to us,'' Mr. Baker said at a White House news conference. ''We prefer to believe it's the former.''
 
Linkage Not Specified
''Soviet behavior in Central America remains the biggest obstacle to an across-the-board improvement in United States-Soviet relations,'' Mr. Baker said. But he stopped short of saying that Mr. Bush would tie the issue to progress in other areas during his talks with Mr. Gorbachev this weekend.
Another senior Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States thought Mr. Gorbachev might propose a ''trade-off'' under which the Soviet Union would agree to end arms shipments to Central America if the United States stopped support for the Afghan rebels. Mr. Bush would reject such an approach, the official said.
Mr. Baker said Central America is part of a five-part agenda that Mr. Bush is bringing to the Malta talks. The other parts are Eastern Europe, arms control, Soviet political reforms and the Soviet economy, he said.
Mr. Baker said Mr. Bush will want to discuss ''what preparations we might make to accelerate further progress'' in arms control.
The other senior official said Mr. Bush wants to put ''some more political impetus behind'' the Geneva negotiations on long-range nuclear weapons.
The Malta meeting, he said, could help by ''setting out a timetable designed to have covered the major outstanding issues by the time of the summit,'' which is to be held in the United States next year. The two sides are still apart on some key verification issues, as well as on American development of a space-based anti-missile shield.
On conventional armed forces in Europe, the official said, ''both sides are likely to agree to push hard and try to get an agreement next year.'' Beyond that, he said, ''it would be logical that there would be a general discussion about what's next.''
 
Sea-Launched Missiles
Mr. Gorbachev has indicated that he also wants to discuss nuclear weapons deployed at sea, the senior official said. Mr. Bush is prepared to talk about the issue, but will not negotiate toward an agreement, the official said.
On Eastern Europe, Mr. Baker said the President, who spoke by telephone today with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany as part of a round of consultations with European allies, plans to tell Mr. Gorbachev that ''continued change and reform is the only path to long-term legitimacy and stability'' in the area. He will also say that ''any attempts to forcibly intervene and prevent continued reform will be extremely destabilizing and dangerous,'' Mr. Baker said.
Senior Administration officials said Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev were likely to discuss German reunification in broad terms and not set forth a timetable.
Mr. Baker said the United States would like the process to be gradual and sets no conditions. But Mr. Baker said the United States does not want a neutral unified Germany and believes that Germany should continue to be aligned with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Community.
 
Soviet Human Rights
Mr. Baker said the President was eager to use the summit meeting ''to hear about the steps Mr. Gorbachev may be planning to institutionalize the rule of law and to guarantee human rights in the Soviet Union.''
Administration officials said the Soviets have made it clear that trade issues are at the top of their agenda, and some of these questions have been tied by the United States to Soviet domestic policies.
The Soviets, American officials said, hoped to win Mr. Bush's backing for a waiver of the 1974 Jackson-Vanik Amendment, which says that Communist countries may not receive favorable tariff treatment or credits from the United States until they permit free emigration.
And, Mr. Gorbachev is hoping to win Mr. Bush's endorsement for observer status, and eventual membership, for Moscow in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Question of Waiving Requirement
Mr. Baker said Mr. Bush would discuss both issues in detail with Mr. Gorbachev, but declined to say whether the Malta meeting could produce an agreement to waive the Jackson-Vanik barriers. Mr. Baker noted that the Supreme Soviet was not able to pass new emigration laws in time for the meeting.
''We need that legislation before we can actually waive Jackson-Vanik,'' he said. But he added, ''That's not to say, I don't think, that the General Secretary might not be in a position to give some assurances, if he felt it advisable to do so, with respect to when that legislation might be passed.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Staff Told To Take Refuge In San Salvador

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 29

 BODY:
In the face of a new rebel attack here in the capital, the United States Embassy today urged its officers, contract employees and dependent families to leave their homes for safer quarters on embassy property. It also offered to grant special leaves to diplomatic personnel who wished to leave the country.
The request, broadcast over a special embassy radio network, came a few hours after leftist guerrillas slipped into wealthy neighborhoods on the west and south of the capital. Their attacks provoked fierce new fighting, trapping residents, knocking out power to the headquarters of the Salvadoran armed forces and destroying the house of a senior American diplomat. 
 
Fighting Continues in Capital
Heavy fighting continued through the day in the Escalon and San Francisco neighborhoods, but tapered off to sniper fire in the San Benito and Ciudad Delgado sections.
About 400 to 500 American Embassy personnel, contract workers and dependents are thought to be in San Salvador. Those who do not leave the country will be given floor space in the embassy and the Agency for International Development buildings.
United States officials said today that no Americans were killed or injured in the fighting, but that some Americans remained trapped within the rebel-held zone.
French diplomats said that an undetermined number of French citizens were trapped in a house that was seized by the guerrillas at the city's northwest edge and that negotiations were under way to free them. Guerrillas were also said to have entered offices belonging to the Japanese Embassy, but its employees were believed to have escaped unharmed.
In view of such attacks, the United Nations also ordered all but a handful of its international personnel in San Salvador to leave the country until the situation has stabilized.
American Embassy spokesmen here declined to comment on the identity of the diplomat whose residence was attacked. But diplomats familiar with the embassy staff said the high-walled house, which was still smoldering today under a layer of charred debris and spent shells, belonged to a senior American intelligence officer. And neighbors said they believed the man had been rescued after the attack began by troops who arrived in a column of tanks and armored troop carriers.
American officials said the house of the embassy's security officer was also among those attacked, but that he, too, had been rescued by Salvadoran troops.
 
'We Are Not Evacuating'
Officials at the embassy, which was closed today as a standard precaution during heavy fighting, played down the announcement and refused to describe it as an evacuation. They emphasized that it was a voluntary measure for diplomats who felt themselves to be in danger.
''We are lowering our profile,'' an embassy spokesman said. ''We are not evacuating. It seems obvious that with the fighting in neighborhoods where we all live, this would be a good time to leave.''
But embassy personnel said the message was delivered to them with the manner of an order rather than an offer. And the announcement appeared certain to deepen the atmosphere of uncertainty and tension that has prevailed here since the beginning of the guerrilla offensive on Nov. 11.
American officials have repeatedly emphasized their confidence in the Salvadoran Government's ability to control the fighting, which until last week was limited largely to the city's working-class suburbs. But official expressions of optimism by the Salvadoran authorities have repeatedly been upstaged by new guerrilla attacks.
The first important aftershock in the offensive came last week when guerrillas attacked the elegant neighborhood of Escalon, on the northwest side of the capital, trapping 12 American Green Berets and other foreigners in a luxury hotel during a one-day standoff.
The most recent fighting began on Monday when guerrilla columns returned to attack positions that they had earlier abandoned on the north of the city. The renewed offensive quickly gained momentum on Tuesday night as guerrilla units again seized strategic points in Escalon and extended their attack to the western neighborhood of San Benito and the southern district of San Francisco.
The number of guerrillas involved in the most recent attacks is believed to be only a fraction of the 2,000 who took part in the broader offensive earlier this month. But the psychological effect of bringing the offensive to wealthier districts, which had remained virtually untouched by the 10-year civil war, has been great. And it has been dramatically increased by the selectivity of the guerrillas' recent attacks, which today appeared in some cases to be focused directly on the country's American community.
The overall American presence here includes thousands of people in official and unofficial capacities.
The number of American military trainers who live here and advise the Salvadoran armed forces is limited by Congress to 55. But military officials here say that that number is augmented by those Americans assigned to the embassy as military attaches and by the continuing rotation of special evaluation and exercise teams, bringing the number of military personnel in the country to anaverage of 125.
Although Americans live throughout the country and the capital region, the majority live in its western neighborhoods, many of which were attacked last night.

HEADLINE: Boa Vista Journal;
This Is El Dorado? Gold and Death in the Jungle

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOA VISTA, Brazil, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The streets of this jungle city may not be paved with gold, but Albert Dunbar Beckers finds it worthwhile to sweep the sidewalks.
Every morning, Mr. Beckers, a spry 62-year-old native of Guyana, is out, broom in hand, to sweep in front of the gold-buying shops on Gold Street.
''On a good day, I can get two or three grams,'' he said, referring to the flecks of gold dust lifted by the wind from shops patronized by rough-cut miners coming in from the gold camps for provisions and a night on the town. ''It's just like the Yukon, just like California.'' 
Younger men - 50,000 at last count - seek their El Dorados in a nearby chunk of Amazon jungle the size of Portugal. Panning gravel and water-blasting mud, they are following one of Brazil's biggest gold rushes of the 1980's. #400 Killed in a Year Brazil became the world's sixth-largest gold producer in the 1980's, behind South Africa, the Soviet Union, the United States, Canada and Australia. Today, Brazil produces about 100 tons of gold a year, triple the production at the start of the decade.
Here in Roraima, a territory that is scheduled to achieve full statehood next year, claim jumping, gunfights and plane crashes in the rain forest are the currency of the day.
The newspaper Critica captured the spirit of Boa Vista today with a banner headline: ''Eight dead in firefight in Roraima gold camp.''
Since the gold rush started in earnest about a year ago, more than 400 miners have died in gunfights or in plane crashes. In a frontier where many people are known only by their nicknames, most burials amount to litle more than a few words from a priest and a circle of friends standing at graveside, hats in hand.
Last January, during the dry season, overworked bush planes were crashing at the rate of one a day. That month, air traffic become so thick -7,995 takeoffs and landings - that the local civil aviation director announced that Boa Vista airport was Brazil's busiest.
In the last two years, commercial flights from Manaus, the nearest major city, have increased from one a week to four. The number of buses plying the 400-mile route has tripled.
The fact that the gold rush is taking place on traditional lands of the Yanomami Indians, South America's largest unassimilated tribe, does not disturb the gold seekers.
''The opening of the Brazilian frontier is just like the American pioneers, with covered wagons, fighting Indians,'' said Athos Vieira, an ebullient gold and diamond mine operator, piloting his Dodge toward a dirt airstrip behind the Jockey Club, the city's racetrack. ''We don't have horses, we have airplanes.''
 
Keeping the Planes Flying
The improvised airstrip captured the single-minded pursuit of gold that has gripped the territory. Without the formalities of flight plans, radar or mechanical inspections, small planes took off and landed at the rate of one every five minutes. Under a flapping blue tarpaulin, grease-stained mechanics - earning more than they could in a Sao Paulo automobile factory - labored to keep aging Pipers and Cessnas airworthy.
''There are 126 strips out there, and a new one opening every day,'' said Valdeni Lopes de Oliveira, a pilot who goes by the name Baby Onion. Aeronautical maps of Roraima show only three officially designated airstrips.
One of the Amazon air jockeys is an American nuclear physics professor who found he could make 10 times as much money flying here than he could teaching in Sao Paulo, 2,500 miles to the South.
Miners and pilots also say they are are tired of outsiders who complain about the decimation of the Indians. ''The U.S. gave us the example,'' Baby Onion said as he dug into a $5 plate of beef and rice at the airport. ''I've seen all those movies on television of cowboys and Indians.''
Jose Teixeira Peixoto, president of the Roraima Goldminers Union, elaborated a homespun conspiracy theory that is popular here.
''Multinationals, foreigners and the Vatican'' are behind the international fuss over the Indians, said Mr. Peixoto. All three groups want the gold and are using the Indian issue to block the miners, he said.
If Mr. Peixoto had a telephone, he would need to go no further than the 1990 Roraima telephone book to find the legal explanation for the dispute over the Yanomami land. Reprinting Brazil's 1988 Constitution, the telephone book contains on page 18 a key clause: ''Mining of mineral resources in indigenous lands can take place only with the authorization of the National Congress.''
At the state house, Marcelo Couto Chagas, the Governor's chief of staff, said, ''That's something very Brazilian - tying to stop natural economic forces with laws.''

LENGTH: 536 words

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
Rumania Getting an Unfamiliar Cold Shoulder in the West

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Having been treated with sympathy by Western Governments over most of the last two decades, Rumania's hard-line Communist Government seems both surprised and confused to find itself suddenly under attack from the West for its human rights record.
Although many in the West charge that rights abuses have grown in recent years, puzzled Rumanian officials argue that little has changed here since the days when President Nicolae Ceausescu was a welcome guest in Washington, London and Paris.
The West's view of the Ceausescu leadership, however, appears to have been changed less by developments here than by events beyond Rumania's borders - with this country's increased isolation coming almost as a side effect. 
Today, with just a hint of embarrassment, Western diplomats concede that while a Stalinist-style Government intolerant of internal dissent was always in power here, Rumania was courted until the early 1980's as a Communist country of Eastern Europe that maintained a foreign policy independent of the Soviet Union.
Most dramatically, it denounced the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. But it also maintained diplomatic relations with Israel after the Middle East war of 1967 and, in the same year, it became the first East bloc country to recognize West Germany.
 
How It Won Friends
Further, Rumania acted as an intermediary between the United States and China in the early 1970's and between Israel and Egypt in the late 1970's. It won the gratitude of the United States when, in 1984, alone among East bloc countries, it ignored the Soviet boycott and participated in the Los Angeles Olympic Games.
The West responded by treating Mr. Ceausescu with some deference. President Richard M. Nixon visited Bucharest in 1969, while Mr. Ceausescu came to Washington in 1973, 1975 and 1978. In 1980, the Rumanian leader was received by both Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France, and as recently as 1983, George Bush came here as Vice President to acknowledge, in the words of officials at the time, ''the continued independence of Rumanian foreign policy.''
But since then, first as relations between Moscow and Washington improved, and more recently as East European Communist leaderships started to crumble, Mr. Ceausescu's maverick stance appears to have lost its usefulness to the West. In turn, Western Governments have begun distancing themselves from Bucharest.
During a visit here in October 1988, the former Deputy Secretary of State, John C. Whitehead, for the first time publicly expressed American concern about human rights here. Then, last February, Rumania rejected the trade benefits of most-favored-nation treatment by the United States after learning that this was about to be revoked by Congress.
Rumania's isolation in the East bloc also continues because it is considered a Stalinist regime that refuses to contemplate political or economic liberalization.
Today, the Ceausescu Government must look as far away as China, North Korea and Cuba for understanding. After a visit by a high-level Cuban delegation here last week, it was disclosed that President Fidel Castro would visit Bucharest in January.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 813 words

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
Gorbachev, Visiting Italy, Urges Talks on Naval Arms

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Striding triumphantly through Rome on his first state visit, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev criticized the West today for not discussing naval arms control, and proposed talks on American and Soviet naval bases in the Mediterranean.
Mr. Gorbachev also said the rapid shifts under way in Eastern Europe should be accompanied by changes in Western attitudes that would help usher in a new age of peace.
''The cold war has ended, or is ending, not because there are victors and vanquished but because there is neither one nor the other,'' he told his Italian hosts at a banquet tonight in the 16th-century Quirinal Palace. ''Therefore it is perfectly possible to avoid a period of 'cold peace' and to proceed with greater courage toward a period of peace for human history.'' 
 
Talk on Naval Weapons Possible
The Soviet leader's mention of the Mediterranean, a point of obvious sensitivity for Italy, raised the possibility that he might pursue naval arms control - something that NATO has resisted - when he meets with President Bush off Malta this weekend.
Mr. Gorbachev offered no specifics in his wide-ranging speech tonight. But he proposed discussions with the United States and Italy, and possibly also within the United Nations Security Council, on whether permanent American and Soviet naval bases are really needed in the Mediterranean. ''During the cold war some justifications could be found for this,'' he said. ''Now, the situation has changed.''
Naval forces must be considered as part of the overall disarmament process, he said, adding that NATO's reluctance on this matter ''can only arouse concern'' and ''can put in doubt, even in danger, much that has been accomplished in recent times.''
Mr. Gorbachev also talked at length about his attempts to restructure Soviet society and, in more general terms, the fast-paced political developments in Eastern Europe. The Soviet Union, he suggested, has no intention of interfering with the changes that are taking place.
''Real politics deal with real issues,'' he said. ''Therefore, it is necessary that the principles of noninterference and free choice are strictly observed.''
 
Meeting With the Pope
The visit here is Mr. Gorbachev's first trip to the West since the explosions of change began this fall in Eastern Europe. It is his sole opportunity to experience Western reaction first-hand before his seaborne meetings with Mr. Bush. Before he leaves on Friday, he will also meet at the Vatican with Pope John Paul II - the first encounter between a Pope and a Kremlin leader.
Security was tight across Rome, with sharpshooters posted atop many of the city's ornate palaces and monuments. But it was clear that this capital was as captivated with Mr. Gorbachev as have been other major European cities he has visited.
Hoping for a glimpse as Mr. Gorbachev passed, several thousand people lined downtown streets. The Soviet leader stopped to shake hands before ducking inside the Colosseum for 10 minutes of sightseeing.
The crowds were perhaps not as demonstrative as those who had lionized him on visits to Paris and Bonn. But for Rome, which greets virtually all visitors with studied insouciance, the reception amounted to unbridled enthusiasm.
 
Likened to Kennedy
''He's the Kennedy of the 90's,'' several people said. Giovanni Civica, a building superintendent, summed up the feelings of many Italians when he said of the Soviet leader: ''He has finally given Europe a new face, the face it should have, and he has done it all by himself. He has managed to upstage America, and this takes both courage and risk.''
As dusk settled, Mr. Gorbachev stopped briefly for coffee at a cafe on the Pincio hill, which offers a breathtaking view of the city and is a place that has been frequented over the decades by Benito Mussolini, King Farouk and Chiang Kai-shek. ''We thought we would have serious talks in Italy and a warm welcome from Italians,'' the visitor from Moscow told reporters. ''My expectation was not only right but we have begun a very serious dialogue.''
 
Talks With Italian Leaders
The Soviet leader's plans for political and economic restructuring took up much of his separate conversations with Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and President Francesco Cossiga, who hosted tonight's banquet and praised Mr. Gorbachev for ''bold realism and farsighted resolve.''
This trip is also about money, and business contracts and Government agreements are scheduled to be signed that would set in motion an estimated $3 billion worth of Italian commercial enterprises in the Soviet Union.
It is understandable, and welcome, that Western countries would want to help Mr. Gorbachev succeed by giving his economy a much needed hand, the Soviet President said tonight, but he cautioned that ''all the riches of the West cannot replace that which we must do ourselves.''

HEADLINE: Collapse of Lincoln Savings Leaves Scars for Rich, Poor and the Faithful

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Much has been made of the $2 billion that it will cost taxpayers to bail out Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. But for the people who were persuaded to invest their life savings in now-worthless securities, the cost is emotional as well as financial.
Many of them live in the retirement communities of California, where Lincoln was based, and when they look at the bright orange bond certificates of the American Continental Corporation, Lincoln's parent company, they feel duped, incensed and embarrassed.
''I am supposed to be retired,'' said Morris W. Rubenacker, a 68-year-old former contractor who put $75,000 into high-yield American Continental bonds. ''But now upon looking back, I'd call myself retarded for buying those things.'' 
 
Hungry for Cash
From 1987 to 1989, as American Continental was growing increasingly cash hungry to cover losses in development projects and land purchases, Lincoln customers say they were called at home by branch managers, told that their insured certificates of deposit were coming due and asked whether they would like to invest in higher yielding bonds that paid a monthly interest rate. And in the branch offices, tellers urged the bonds upon them.
Many of the 23,000 people who bought more than $200 million in American Continental bonds at the 29 Lincoln branches in California say they were told by smiling and bright-faced young bank officials that the instruments were either insured by the Government or the next thing to it, and that they were assured right up until the Government took over Lincoln last April that their investments were absolutely safe.
American Continental was in the Fortune 500, they were told, and Lincoln would support its parent company in any crisis.
But some of the victims are now saying that the Government should make good on their losses as well, citing the fact that Mr. Keating was permitted to sell the bonds on bank premises. Others are seeking damages from Mr. Keating himself, in class action suits.
 
Lincoln's Ailing Parent
Both the Federal and California governments are conducting criminal investigations into the legality of the sales, asking such questions as whether unlicensed bank employees were selling the bonds, whether illegal bonuses were paid to the best salesmen and whether Lincoln concealed the true financial condition of its parent company.
What follows are four case studies, chosen to illustrate the cross section of investors - from the rich to those of modest means - who once trusted Mr. Keating and other Lincoln officials.
 
The Truck Driver
'Bigger and Better' Turns to Nothing
Kenneth Ludwig had been banking with the Lincoln Savings branch in Santa Ana, Calif., for 24 years. Mr. Ludwig, a truck driver for the Prudential Overall Supply Company, a uniform cleaning outfit, had to retire at the age of 59 because of a back injury.
But he had managed to save almost $45,000, and had invested it in federally insured certificates of deposit at Lincoln. When he went in to renew them last year, the tellers asked if he wanted an investment that paid ''bigger and better interest.''
 
'How Safe Can It Get?'
Mr. Ludwig was introduced to a young man named Peterson, he said, ''a real nice guy - I think he was an honest guy - who told me he had gotten his father into this deal for $3,000.''
''He said, 'How safe can it get?' '' Mr. Ludwig recalled. '' 'A.C.C. is the parent organization of Lincoln. There is no risk whatsoever. Lincoln is there to protect A.C.C. and you know Lincoln is under the F.S.L.I.C.' '' The reference was to the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which insures deposits up to $100,000.
Convinced, Mr. Ludwig proceeded to invest $30,000 in the A.C.C. bonds, and received monthly interest checks of $286. But in April 1989, when Lincoln was taken over by the Government, he found out that the bonds had become worthless and that he had lost two-thirds of his life savings.
''I can't believe I have done it,'' Mr. Ludwig said. ''It's humiliating. I have been working for 25 years and could not have imagined that I could have done such a stupid thing.''
He added that with the $30,000 loss, his plans to move with his 72-year-old wife, Loraine, into a retirement community have had to be scrapped and their monthly income has now been reduced by one-third to around $900.
Mr. Ludwig saves his harshest words for Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democrat who along with four other Senators met with regulators on behalf of Mr. Keating. The five, who are under investigation in the Senate, received a total of $1.4 million in contributions from Mr. Keating and his associates, with Mr. Cranston receiving almost $1 million of that amount.
After voting for Senator Cranston, Mr. Ludwig promises not to vote for him again. ''We counted on him,'' he said. ''I really thought the guy was a good guy and always stood up for the little man. I think he should be impeached.''
 
The Stockbroker
Riding a Wave Up; Then the Plunge
Not all those who suffered losses from the collapse of Lincoln Savings were members of the working- or middle-classes. Some very large investors bet their fortunes on Mr. Keating and now regret it.
James D. Mussio, a 47-year-old broker for Queen City Securities in Cincinnati, says he lost half a million dollars on his investments in American Continental securities and that customers of his firm have lost almost $5 million.
For Mr. Mussio and Queen City, the loss is particularly bitter because his firm aggressively sold both American Continental common stock and other now-worthless securities, and now has clients suing.
''Not only have I lost money and my clients have lost money, but can you imagine what it is like the next time I call a client with another idea,'' Mr. Mussio said. ''They're not too quick to listen.''
 
Believing in Auditors
Mr. Mussio complains bitterly about the public accounting firms that gave their seal of approval to the financial statements of American Continental in 1985, 1986 and 1987. In saying that the profits that American Continental reported accurately reflected the true financial condition of Lincoln and its parent company, Mr. Mussio argues, the accounting firms betrayed their obligation to shareholders and the public. There was little he could have done, he insists, to detect the troubles at Lincoln apart from having insider knowledge.
''The C.P.A.'s are supposed to be the Bible, the Gospel as to the condition of a company,'' he said. ''They are the ones who say the numbers are accurate. How else are you supposed to be able to judge a company? If you can't believe in the auditors, what can you believe in? Then nothing is good.''
He added that during the years in which he was selling Lincoln stock and bonds, he attended shareholder meetings, met frequently with management officials in Phoenix, and was in personal touch with Mr. Keating, who repeatedly told him how well the company was doing.
''A lot of people in Cincinnati trusted Keating and rode his wave up and down,'' Mr. Mussio said.
 
The Construction Worker
'A Little Mistake' And a Life's Savings
Rene Hugo Heimann, a 49-year-old construction worker who lives in Ceritos, Calif., lost $48,000 from buying American Continental bonds in his local office of Lincoln Savings. But unlike Mr. Ludwig's case, the money was Mr. Heimann's entire savings.
Mr. Heimann, a Bolivian-born naturalized American whose family fled Nazi Germany, had sold his home and took the proceeds in October 1987 to the Lincoln branch in Ceritos to invest in insured certificates of deposit. A Lincoln teller advised him to look into American Continental bonds.
''I was told that the bank backed up the bonds 100 percent,'' Mr. Heimann said. ''They showed me a list of 30 companies that Continental owned and told me that if anything happens I would get my money back.'' He twice went to Lincoln officials when he heard there might be trouble with American Continental bonds, he said, but was told the reports were ''a misprint in the paper, and that as proof of the company's health they had just bought another hotel in Phoenix.''
While he could retire from his job within three years, after putting in 25 years of work, that is now impossible.
''The Senators say they made a little mistake,'' Mr. Heimann said, referring to the five lawmakers who are being investigated by the Senate Ethics Committee. ''I make a little mistake at work and I am gone,''
 
The Nuns
Embarrassment And Prayers
The swath of investment enthusiasm generated by Mr. Keating also reached inside the walls of the Sisters of Charity, a Roman Catholic order of nuns based in Cincinnati.
According to one official of the order, who asked not to be identified, an investment of $440,000 from the order's retirement money, which has to support 900 sisters throughout the country, was made in the mid-1980's by the order, at the recommendation of a group of local business advisers.
''We're not very happy with the situation,'' the official said. ''We're praying everything works out.''
One local businessman, familiar with the investment, said that the $440,000 did not represent a major portion of the order's resources, and was within investment guidelines.
He added that officials of the order were mainly embarrassed by its involvement with Mr. Keating, and have wanted to keep it quiet.
''The point is not that some little sister got taken by Charlie Keating,'' said one investment expert, who asked not to be identified.

HEADLINE: Help the Homeless Off the Street; New Calcutta: An occasional series.;
For the Homeless: New Old Hotels

 BODY:
The soft real estate market that darkens New York City's economic future opens a bright window of opportunity for New York State and City governments seeking ways to develop more housing for the homeless mentally ill.
In the early 1980's, demand for high-priced housing prompted developers to buy and tear down many old single-room-occupancy hotels. The Koch administration smiled on the phenomenon at first: the squalid S.R.O.'s, offering cheap rooms to the poorest of the poor, provided little in municipal taxes. Replacing them with glossy high-rises improved neighborhoods and city revenues. 
But as the homeless problem grew in the mid-1980's, second thoughts set in. Turning $200-a-month rooms into $200,000 condos spruced up neighborhoods but left former residents of the cheap rooms with nowhere to go. The most fragile were the mentally ill, no longer welcome at upstate hospitals.
In 1987, belatedly realizing the importance of the S.R.O.'s, the Koch administration clamped a moratorium on conversions. But owners of the buildings sued, and last July the state Court of Appeals threw out the moratorium. This week the Supreme Court refused to review that ruling.
That leaves S.R.O. owners once again free to sell. But not many are likely to do so right away because the city's real estate market has cooled. Moreover, in some cases, other state and city laws may complicate quick conversion to apartments. This opens the way for enterprising mental health officials to buy some of the buildings, keeping them in business as supported S.R.O.'s, offering services, as well as housing, for the mentally ill homeless. The few such residences now operating in the city not only provide better housing than the city's shelters; they do so at about half the cost.
Several hundred old S.R.O. buildings may be available. At current depressed prices, they could be purchased and renovated for the same cost, $50,000 per room, of putting up a new building.
Renovation is far preferable to new construction. A new building usually requires a planning and siting process that may include confrontations and even lawsuits with angry neighbors. That's less likely with the purchase of an existing S.R.O. To the neighbors, a renovated building run by competent nonprofit managers and staffed by mental health workers would be a welcome improvement over a squalid flophouse.
There is already some money in the state budget for community housing of the mentally ill, and legislators are studying ways to provide more.
The quiet real estate market, and the opportunity it creates for developing supported S.R.O.'s, extends the potential value of those state dollars. Albany, facing a season of austerity, can't afford anything less than a good deal. For the homeless mentally ill - and for all New Yorkers worried about the city's decline into a New Calcutta - S.R.O. purchases are the best deal in sight.

HEADLINE: Topics of the Times;
The I.R.A., You Say?

 BODY:
For several months rumors have circulated in Britain and the U.S. that McDonald's, the fast-food chain, has given financial support to the Irish Republican Army through Noraid, the I.R.A.'s North American fund-raising group. McDonald's itself couldn't figure where the implausible charge came from, and denied it flatly at every opportunity. But the rumor, and the mystery, persisted.
Now The Economist of London has tracked it down. One of its sleuths discovered that, some time back, on a financial talk show carried by the Cable News Network, McDonald's was cited for its generosity in contributing to employees' Individual Retirement Accounts - commonly called I.R.A.'s on this side of the Atlantic. But CNN can be viewed overseas now, via satellite, and in Britain I.R.A. means something else entirely.
Mystery solved. Rumor quashed. But not the cautionary question: Is the world really ready for modern telecommunications?

HEADLINE: Just What Does Congress Do to Merit a Raise?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Proponents of the House of Representatives voting itself a 33 percent pay increase argued that the increase would attract bright new talent (news report, Nov. 17). They overlooked the 95 percent rate of incumbent return. Even off-again, on-again drug users boast a lower rate of recidivism. 
Nowhere in the private sector do salaries in the $89,000 range boast perquisites of nearly $30,000 in value. In corporate America, such a Tuesday-to-Thursday club as Congress is would soon find itself unemployed. Keeping campaign contributions on retirement far exceeds the benefits of even the most generous corporate golden parachute. Where in the private sector do pensions match those in government?
Surrendering honorariums rather than contributions from political action committees, which always favor incumbents, demonstrates how likely it is that bright new talent will be attracted and how welcome they'd be to the senior leadership.
Why not peg Congressional salaries to the median American wage earner's salary? Nothing would be more likely to provide insight into the financial problems of the ordinary American, that Congress is elected to serve. We'd know too that our representatives run out of a desire to provide benefits, not receive them. If Congress believes judges and top Federal employees need raises to prevent their departure to private industry, let Congress provide those raises, but forgo its own. Let's not forget that private industry considers merit before bestowing raises.
Even with salaries at the median American level, our elected representatives would fare considerably better than most with their perquisites of office: staff allowances, offices in Washington and in constitutent districts, assigned free parking at the Capitol and the airport, franking privileges, more recesses than the average American kindergartener and a variety and regularity of travel that has added a word to the language: junket.
 
JEROME GILLMAN
 Shady, N.Y., Nov. 17, 1989

HEADLINE: Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Economic Watch article on the costs of limiting the emissions of carbon dioxide (front page, Nov. 19) raises troublesome issues. The extent to which society chooses to spend money slowing greenhouse gas emissions or adapting to inevitable climatic impacts does depend partly on the costs and benefits of the different actions. But traditional cost-benefit studies, such as the ones you cite, are an unsatisfactory basis for guiding such decisions. 
The true costs to society of global climatic changes are unknown, and they are unlikely ever to be accurately determined. We are not likely to know the full range of global consequences until climatic changes are upon us because of the difficulties of accurately modeling the climate. More important, many of the probable effects, such as the extinction of species, the loss of natural ecosystems and long-term human health effects, simply cannot be put into classic economic terms. Even calculating the costs to society of the more obvious effects, such as a rise in sea level, is fraught with computational pitfalls, methodological complications and controversial assumptions. Economic analysis simply ignores these issues, leading to the fallacy that what can be most easily counted is what really counts.
Equally disturbing, however, the costs of climatic impacts and the costs of reducing emissions will be unequally distributed. Many of the worst impacts of climatic change are likely to fall on poorer, developing countries without the resources to adapt to the changes. But the costs of prevention will fall on the industrialized countries responsible for the vast majority of the emissions. Thus the richer countries responsible for the problem may prefer to delay action on limiting emissions, while poor countries that cannot build sea walls or develop irrigation systems to save their agricultural production will be forced to suffer the consequences.
Finally, many studies suggest that some actions to slow the rate of climate change are economical and could be taken today, such as improving our energy efficiency to the level of Japan's, or eliminating chlorofluorocarbons that contribute to the destruction of the ozone layer and to the greenhouse effect. Such actions should be considered prudent and inexpensive, preferable to taking no action and suffering the consequences. Waiting until imperfect traditional cost-benefit studies are done means waiting until climatic changes are upon us.
 
PETER H. GLEICK
Berkeley, Calif., Nov. 19, 1989
 The writer directs the global environment program of the Pacific Institute for Studies in Development, Environment and Security.

HEADLINE: Bush 'Talking Points' at Malta

BYLINE: By Richard Perle; Richard Perle was Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When President Bush sits down with Mikhail Gorbachev on Saturday, he will have in his briefcase a set of ''talking points'' from his top advisers suggesting what issues to raise and how to raise them. Here are proposed talking points that could help him seize the initiative from Mr. Gorbachev:
We continue to be concerned by your willingness to pour vast sums into military forces. Military spending is draining the Soviet economy, threatening your perestroika program and creating unecessary and most unwelcome tension between us.
We are particularly troubled by your continuing support for some of the world's most repressive and violent regimes: North Korea, Afghanistan, Nicaragua, Cuba, Vietnam. In Afghanistan, you spend $250 million a month to prop up a regime that cannot gain popular support. It is Moscow that ultimately is at the end of the supply line reaching the guerrillas in El Salvador. This must stop. 
There is a great deal of discussion in the West about how we might help your program to reform the economy. The best thing I can do for you is remind you of how much of your national wealth is devoted to military spending and conflicts abroad. (Note to President Bush: Since financial assistance for the Soviet Union would rightly infuriate many Americans, this approach will head off criticism at home.) We have made a good start toward the goal of sharply reducing conventional and nuclear weapons, but we could go further.
We should be prepared to reduce strategic nuclear forces below the levels originally proposed by President Reagan to Leonid Brezhnev. Since those negotiations got under way, the number of weapons that would be allowed under a strategic arms treaty has actually increased. Surely, we can do better today. If you are prepared to agree in principle to even deeper reductions in strategic weapons, I propose that we state in our communique that our negotiators in Geneva will be instructed to explore further reductions. We are also prepared to consider deeper cuts in conventional forces. Our proposals in Vienna call for sharp reductions in armor, artillery, aircraft and personnel. But why not reduce forces by, say, 20 percent beyond what is now under discussion? We both need relief from unnecessary military spending. Here's a way to accomplish that without risk to security on either side. If you agree, the communique could reflect our desire to move in this direction.
We have been watching with great interest as events have unfolded in Eastern Europe. I want you to know that we approve of the process of change taking place there. We have always believed in self-determination for the people of Eastern Europe and we are pleased that you appear to have accepted this principle. The people of Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Czechoslovakia are demanding freedom. They should have it. They are demanding new leadership. They should have that, too. And, finally, they are demanding a new political and economic system. This too must be allowed.
I want to assure you that we have no desire, no intention, to exploit in any way the changes in Eastern Europe. We do not see the rejection of socialism as an opening to threaten Soviet security.
You should understand that the people of Eastern Europe believe socialism has failed them. That is their judgment to make. If they wish to establish free markets along with free political institutions, that is their right. I trust that when you were quoted as warning against the ''export of capitalism,'' you did not mean the Soviet Union would seek to interfere with the free choice of the countries concerned. We would view with grave concern any action to block their choice.
As you know, the Jackson-Vanik amendment denies most-favored-nation status to nations that deny their citizens the right and opportunity to emigrate freely. I have the authority to waive that restriction but only if I have received assurances that doing so will lead to substantially freer emigration. If you are prepared to give me those assurances, I would ask for a waiver under the amendment's conditions.

LENGTH: 1144 words

HEADLINE: THE TALK OF FORT DRUM;
Boom Times for Army Base and Its Region

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: FORT DRUM, N.Y., Nov. 29

 BODY:
On 2,000 bleak acres here in northern New York, the Army has opened a computerized firing range to hone the skills of 21st-century warriors. At a time of glasnost, the opening of the Berlin wall and talk of troop cutbacks in Europe, an M-60 tank demonstrating at the range's dedication on Tuesday fired at mock Soviet tanks and plastic soldiers called ''Ivans.''
The firing-range paradox - ''the way things are going, we'll be shooting with them, not at them,'' said Staff Sgt. Rafael Alvarez, the M-60's commander - is just one of many byproducts of the Army buildup at Fort Drum that began in 1985, when the 10th Mountain Division was reactivated.
In bringing 11,000 soldiers to the sleepy World War II-era base, the division has also brought monumental changes to one of the state's most depressed regions, flooding the area with jobs and people, causing a crisis of homelessness next to a housing boom. 
The newly completed $5 million firing range, which took almost 12 years to plan and build in the northern reaches of this 107,000-acre Army reservation, is the latest manifestation of the military side of the boom. It is a vast shooting gallery in which remote-controlled tank targets, complete with the smoke and sound of simulated muzzle flashes that pop up from behind hills. Other tank targets speed along hidden rail cars at more than 20 miles an hour.
''It helps us prepare for real live combat,'' said Sergeant Alvarez, whose tank gave the firing demonstration to a group of visiting military officials.
And then there are the Ivans, as soldiers have nicknamed the 60 plastic head-and-torso infantry targets in green overcoats and caps with the red Soviet star. Even the most dedicated soldiers concede that new designs may be in order.
 
Incomes on the Rise
The boom at Fort Drum has set off an economic, social and physical transformation in this region between the Adirondacks and the St. Lawrence River, known as the North Country.
The Army has built 4,000 new houses and apartments, on the post and as far as 30 miles away, for the 25,000 soldiers and their families. Private developers are building nearly 6,000 more.
The rapid demand for housing has rejuvenated the region's construction industry and triggered a demand for workers in service industries. The unemployment rate, which topped 20 percent five years ago, now hovers around 6 percent.
Per-capita income in Jefferson County has jumped to $13,338 from $10,252. Shoppers who once had to drive 75 miles to Syracuse to visit a mall now have the 95-store Salmon Run Mall with its choice of eight movies.
The signs of growth are everywhere. Housing developments have gobbled up hundreds of acres of farmland. Fast-food restaurants have sprouted practically overnight along Arsenal Street, a main thoroughfare in Watertown, the region's largest community, with nearly 30,000 people.
The Watertown Daily Times added a Sunday edition three years ago, and the paper's advertising volume is up 20 percent since the base's expansion. The hamlet of Great Bend is moving its post office out of a trailer and into a brand-new building.
''We're eons better off than where we were,'' said Terrence L. Roche, executive director of the Fort Drum Steering Council, an organization of local elected officials and civic leaders charged with helping to plan growth for the region.
That is a difficult task, since virtually none of the villages, towns and counties had zoning master plans. Under the review of newly hired planners, roads are being widened, sewer lines extended and water mains built.
The expansion at Fort Drum, also a training site for Army Reserve and National Guard Units from throughout the Northeast, has brought social changes to a region with a minority population of less than 1 percent. The A.&P. in Watertown now carries a wide assortment of ethnic foods, like smoked ham hocks.
One out of four soldiers is black, but the racial tension that many residents feared with the division's arrival has been replaced with acceptance. Black, Hispanic and Asian-American soldiers are volunteer firefighters, Little League coaches and church leaders.
''Our whole community is broadened and improved,'' said John B. Johnson Jr., managing editor of The Daily Times.
 
The New Homeless
Overnight success for some has meant overnight hardships for others. The demand for housing has sent rents and the price of new houses soaring, displacing many longtime residents on fixed incomes or with low-paying, entry-level jobs. Rents for a two-bedroom apartment, for example, have increased to $375 a month from $207 a month in 1984, modest by New York City standards but hefty in this market.
''We never had a homeless problem before,'' said Robert C. Dorr, housing coordinator for Jefferson County.
Right now, the county is housing 137 people in shelters or motels, compared with 30 a year ago.
''I'm as low as I've ever been,'' said Michelle, a 25-year-old Watertown resident who was evicted from her apartment in July. She has been staying at one of two shelters operated by the Community Action Planning Council, a group that helps the poor.
The rapid expansion has spawned other problems. The number of reported crimes in Watertown, mainly thefts and assaults, increased to 1,530 in 1988 from 1,186 in 1985, said Police Chief Michael J. Hennegan.
''We're definitely going through growing pains,'' said Carmen Bocciolatt, executive director of the Community Action Planning Council.
 
Flowers on the Graves
In the northwestern corner of the reservation, in a small clearing off of Fort Drum Road marked by two large pine trees, seven tombstones stand.
They are the burial markers of seven prisoners of war - one German and six Italians - who died during their internment during World War II at what was then known as Pine Camp.
The tiny cemetery is a forgotten reminder to many people here that Fort Drum onced had nearly 1,500 P.O.W.'s.
Lois Welser, however, has not forgotten. She remembers when the prisoners were here and remembers when she first heard about the little cemetary overgrown with brush at the edge of the woods.
''I thought they deserved better than a cemetary full of weeds,'' said Mrs. Welser, who lives two miles down the road.
So for 16 years, until 1973, Mrs. Welser cut the grass around the tombstones and laid flowers on the graves once a month. She badgered Army officials for the addresses of the soldiers' relatives. She reached all but one family and for years exchanged small gifts and cards at Easter, Christmas or whenever the mood struck her.
Mrs. Welser, who is now 65, eventually passed her caretaking duties on to the son of Italian immigrants. The Army now tends to the graves, and the letters from Germany and Italy are fewer. But Mrs. Welser doesn't forget. ''It'll always have a special place in my thoughts.''

Most private analysts predicted a sharply weaker performance in the final three months of the year and the first quarter of 1990. A few even said they feared that the nation's longest peacetime expansion, which enters its eighth year in December, could be in jeopardy.[Page D1.]

The people who invested in now-worthless securities offered by Lincoln Savings and Loan are paying a price that is emotional as well as financial. [A22.]
 
COMPANIES
 
In a decisive step toward ending the two-year bankruptcy of Public Service of New Hampshire, all major parties in the process have agreed to a plan filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the utility to be acquired by Northeast Utilities. [D1.]
 
Seven potential bidders have expressed interest in buying a large percentage of the Shearson Lehman Hutton stock held by the American Express Company, Wall Street sources said. [D5.]

Attempts to bring Japanese investors into a Bloomingdale's buyout continue, with several new twists. Marvin Traub, the store's chairman, called talks in Tokyo ''serious and constructive.'' [D17.]
 
Freeport-McMoran will sell a third of its $3.8 billion in assets to concentrate on recent discoveries of sulfur off the shore of Louisiana and copper in Indonesia. [D4.]
 
Fiat is prepared to offer about $780 million for 51 percent of the car division of Sweden's Saab-Scania. [D4.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Business and labor representatives called on the White House to assign the ''highest priority'' to streamlining export controls, warning that if the U.S. does not move rapidly enough, Europeans will buy fewer American high technology products and cut American companies out of cooperative research projects. Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading, and dealers said an auction of $8 billion worth of five-year Treasury notes went as anticipated, with prices rising significantly. [D17.] Yields of money market mutual funds were mixed for a third consecutive week, increasing slightly for tax-exempt funds and falling for taxable funds. [D8.]

The dollar turned in a mixed performance as the mark continued to dominate the foreign exchange markets. [D18.] Gold prices fell sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York. [D18.]
