HEADLINE: White House Won't Back Chip Subsidy

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
The White House's science adviser said today that the Administration does not endorse an advisory committee's recommendation to provide Federal subsidies to rebuild the nation's semiconductor and consumer electronics industries.
''The money for direct Government subsidies to somehow reverse the situation by brute force is not now available, and it is unlikely ever to be available,'' the adviser, D. Allan Bromley, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee.
''Even if such funding were available,'' he said, ''it is unlikely that such an approach would work.''
 
Aid to Consortium
But Dr. Bromley also denied reports that the Bush Administration may seek to slash Federal support for Sematech, an industry-government consortium working to develop advanced computer chips. 
''I personally am completely unaware of any move to reduce support for Sematech,'' he said.
Dr. Bromley said, however, that the Administration does not endorse the recommendation in the recent report by the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors that Government financing for Sematech be substantially increased from its current level of $100 million a year. That amount is matched by another $100 million from American companies.
Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat and the subcommittee's chairman, said he was ''concerned over recent reports of attempts by Administration officials to drastically reduce or eliminate funding for a number of existing programs, such as Sematech.''
Those reports emerged earlier this month when four lawmakers, in a letter sent to President Bush, said they had learned of classified and unclassified documents that called for cutting programs financed by the Defense Advanced Researched Projects Agency. The programs believed under jeopardy included Sematech.
The other Pentagon-financed programs facing cutbacks, according to the letter and comments by Senator Bingaman today, include manufacturing technology to develop robots and other computer-assisted equipment; high-definition computer displays, which involves an advanced technology that provides a much sharper television picture, and X-ray lithography, a technique used for producing powerful semiconductor chips.
Senator Bingaman said the Defense Department ''has an appropriate role in supporting research in long-term, high-risk, high-potential technologies.''
Dr. Bromley, director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, testified that he shares the concerns about American leadership in semiconductors expressed in the recent report by the advisory committee, which was created in Congress's trade bill last year.
 
'Corrective Actions'
''In many ways, what has and is happening to the semiconductor industry is a paradigm for what could happen to other U.S. industries, such as the computer and telecommunications industries, unless corrective actions are taken in the immediate future,'' he said.
Dr. Bromley and Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher are two officials in the Administration who have been generally thought to favor Federal programs that will strengthen United States industrial competitiveness. The White House officials who reportedly support a Government pullback from financing high-technology initiatives include Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
The comments today by Dr. Bromley are the closest the Administration has come to responding to the reports that it is planning to cut support for high-technology companies that are trying to compete with Japanese and European rivals.
 
Panel's Recommendations
The semiconductor advisory committee recommended that Sematech's financing be increased immediately by $100 million a year, split evenly between industry and Government. It said an additional $800 million will be required over the next three years.
But Dr. Bromley said the Bush Administration does not endorse ''major increases in Federal funding levels for Sematech.''
He also said the Administration opposes creation of a publicly supported corporation to rebuild the consumer electronics industry in the United States.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate In Quarter Put at 2.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew at a moderate rate of 2.7 percent in the July-September quarter, slightly higher than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.
But most private analysts predicted a sharply weaker performance in the final three months of the year and the first quarter of 1990. A few even said they feared that the nation's longest peacetime expansion, which enters its eighth year in December, could be in jeopardy.
''We should enjoy these numbers because the chances are we're not going to see their like anytime soon,'' said Robert Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company. 
 
Administration's Reaction
The White House was generally pleased with today's report. ''We always like to see increase in growth,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the Presidential spokesman. ''And this report is relatively good news in that sense.''
The Commerce Department had estimated last month that the gross national product, the broadest measure of economic health, grew at a 2.5 percent rate in the third quarter, matching the growth in the April-June quarter.
The revision was attributed mostly to a better-than-anticipated trade performance. The September trade deficit, which was the smallest monthly gap in five years, had not been reported when the original G.N.P. estimate was made.
Today's report said exports climbed at an annual rate of 1.6 percent in the third quarter, compared with the Commerce Department's initial estimate that there had been no change. Imports grew 9.5 percent, compared with the 15.1 percent jump in the initial report.
Analysts, however, are pessimistic about trade, believing that the strength in the dollar will stall a further narrowing of the deficit.
 
Spending Remains Brisk
Today's revised report also reflected stronger consumer spending than previously estimated: It rose at a brisk annual rate of 6.2 percent, the strongest since the first quarter of 1988, compared with a preliminary estimate of 5.8 percent.
But analysts generally do not expect a repetition of the third-quarter jump in spending, saying that much of that surge came from automobile purchases encouraged by dealer discounts and financing incentives.
In another disturbing sign, the Commerce Department said today in a separate report that after-tax corporate profits declined a sharp 7.2 percent in the third quarter, matching the decline in the second quarter, which was the worst performance in three years. It was the third consecutive quarter that profits have dropped.
Most economists attribute the current sluggishness in the economy to a yearlong anti-inflation campaign by the Federal Reserve Board, which kept interest rates rising until the spring. Since then, the Fed has nudged rates lower, but the economy will not reflect the full benefit of rate cuts, and any further declines in the next few months, until later next year.
 
Improvement in Inflation
The Commerce Department also said today that inflation eased substantially in the third quarter as measured by the implicit price deflator, a price index tied to the G.N.P. The deflator showed inflation at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the quarter, the same as initially estimated. That is down from a 5 percent jump in the April-June quarter.
The department also said that business capital spending, a bright spot in previous quarters, slowed to an annual growth rate of 4.6 percent, compared with the advance estimate of 5.8 percent. Analysts say falling corporate profits will cause businesses to cut back further in this area.
Housing construction, which has been in a slump because of higher interest rates, fell at an annual rate of 8.4 percent, nearly double the advance estimate of a 4.8 percent decline.
A positive sign was that inventories grew at a $21.2 billion annual rate, instead of the previous estimate of $30.2 billion. The downward revision reduces the prospect that an overhang of inventories will lead to production cutbacks and layoffs.
The various changes left the economy, after adjusting for inflation, growing at an annual rate of $4.16 trillion in the third quarter, $27.7 billion higher than the second-quarter pace.
Data included in the revision of the gross national product for the third quarter of 1989 follow, with all dollar amounts in billions at seasonally adjusted annual rates. Percentage changes are from the previous quarter at seasonally adjusted annual rates:

CORRECTION-DATE: December 1, 1989, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the economy misstated the third-quarter change in two price indexes.
The implicit price deflator was revised to a 3.2 percent rate for the quarter, from the 2.9 percent initially estimated. The fixed-weight price index was unchanged at 2.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Expanding the Atlantic Air Lanes

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
In talks that could intensify competition among European and American carriers and clear the way for trans-Atlantic travelers to fly directly to myriad new destinations, the United States is negotiating new treaties governing international airline service with its four biggest European trading partners.
If the talks succeed, American Airlines, as one example, might be able to offer new service from New York to Manchester, England, or from Chicago to Milan, Italy, while Lufthansa, the West German airline, might offer flights to Detroit or Tampa, Fla.
In a tactic meant in part to speed the European talks, the United States has already proposed giving foreign airlines what it calls unprecedented access to American cities that do not have comprehensive international service, as a reward for loosening the restrictions in many bilateral agreements. This offer is widely viewed as a sign that the Bush Administration wants to foster economic growth and widen competition among airlines by encouraging more flights to more cities in this country and abroad.
 
An Official Viewpoint
''What we should be doing is talking about how we open the market up. What is different is the acknowledgment by the United States of the larger economic value of international aviation,'' said Jeffrey Shane, the Transportation Department's Assistant Secretary for policy and international affairs and previously the State Department's chief negotiator of international aviation agreements. 
In an interview, Mr. Shane also said American attitudes are being affected by the plans for the economic integration of Western Europe in 1992. ''As the Europeans pull together, it is beginning to look to us like there may at last be a market overseas that is as large and as robust as our own,'' he said.
Negotiators in London today began a new round of talks on modifying the British-American treaty. Talks are also in progress or beginning soon with West Germany, Italy and France, as well as with many smaller nations in Europe and elsewhere. Earlier this month, the United States signed a new agreement with Japan that should expand air service between the two Pacific powers by at least 30 percent.
International aviation, unlike trade in most other goods and services, remains tightly regulated under a series of bilateral agreements reached through talks in which each side seeks overseas business for its own airlines while limiting access to its domestic market. The talks involve routes, fares and limits on service between the countries.
Representatives of a number of American cities have pleaded for the United States to liberalize access to their airports. A single daily flight from Europe, they say, translates into hundreds of millions of dollars spent each year at the American destination.
Europe is particularly attractive to United States carriers as well, because the elimination of trade barriers between nations of the European Community, scheduled for 1992, could form a single market as large as the United States, both in population and in the number of cities in which airlines could operate profitably.
 
Varied Reactions at Airlines
Some domestic airlines, like American Airlines, are enthusiastic about the latest United States proposals, contending that they will offer more opportunity for airlines to expand overseas.
American wants to expand the service it offers from Chicago to Manchester and to inaugurate service from New York to Manchester and possibly London. American also wants to fly from Chicago to Milan and Rome, a request the Italians have been resisting, said Jim Brown, an American spokesman.
But other airlines, including Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, are worried that the United States may trade away valuable rights to foreign air carriers without seeking equivalent rights for American carriers in foreign markets. New foreign flights into the United States, they fear, would undermine their most profitable operations without giving them enough in return.
European nations, for their part, are increasingly demanding broader access to American cities - for instance, by carrying more passengers between cities in the United States, something they are allowed to do now only for passengers who are going on to Europe.
The Europeans are also asking to be allowed to fly to more American cities. For example, the list of cities that Lufthansa's would like to add includes Detroit, Pittsburgh, Tampa and Charlotte, N.C. Airlines from the United States already have substantially free access to West Germany.
 
'Commercial Disarmament'
''If Europe is to be open to U.S. airlines, the United States must be opened to European airlines,'' said Lord King, the chairman of British Airways, in a speech in Washington on Tuesday. He said he considers his company and his Government to be proponents of free trade, but he added, ''I am not advocating, and will not practice, unilateral commercial disarmament.''
Aviation treaty negotiators have historically respected the interests of individual countries and their airlines far more than the interests of local communities and groups of nations.
Among the most vocal groups pleading for the United States to change that course are 16 cities and airports calling themselves the United States Airports for Better International Air Service.
One of those cities, Charlotte, is a prime example of a city with a thriving airport beckoning to international airlines. Charlotte appears to be well positioned to take advantage of a rule proposed recently by the Bush Administration that would allow many cities to be freely served by foreign airlines on international routes when no United States airline is offering similar service.
The new routes could be granted without bilateral talks if the foreign country already had in place a liberal aviation trade agreement with the United States.
 
Hartford's Ambition
Another city striving to enter the ranks of international entry points is Hartford, where there is no European service and where KLM Royal Dutch Airlines has offered to begin service to Amsterdam. ''A foreign carrier is our only hope at this time'' for getting international service, Governor William A. O'Neill recently told the Transportation Department.
The complex process of reaching route agreements has been complicated by the scheduled removal of trade barriers within the European Community.
This development will allow European airlines to operate freely inside Europe, presenting them with a competitive advantage over American carriers. ''The integration of the market will make possible the development of hub-and-spoke operations in Europe just as powerful in marketing terms as Dallas-Fort Worth or Atlanta or Chicago,'' Lord King said. His company is negotiating with KLM and Sabena of Belgium to set up a hub in Brussels serving most of Europe, he said.
The big question will then become whether American carriers will win the right to carry passengers between European cities in different countries even if the passengers are not flying on to the United States, and whether European airlines will demand the right to carry passengers between American cities even if the passengers are not going to Europe.
Lord King said that for years United States carriers have enjoyed an unfair advantage in their huge domestic market. ''Disparity in market strength has enabled the U.S. to trade limited access to the American market for larger access to the European,'' he said. ''Do not expect the nations of Europe to continue to accept such an unequal state of affairs.''
 
A New European Market
Mr. Shane of the Transportation Department said that the United States had not decided exactly how to seek its objectives in air route negotiations between now and 1992. ''What we are thinking very hard about right now is the prospect of a single European market,'' he said.
The United States appears to have chosen to seek benchmark agreements with a few European nations, granting them new access to American cities in exchange for loosening their own restrictions. In theory, this would lead to other liberal trade agreements with European countries before 1992.
But if the current negotiations fail, an alternate approach would be to delay signing new bilateral agreements and instead hold out for a single comprehensive agreement with the whole European Community.
Whatever course is taken, Mr. Shane said, the United States is committed to expanding international aviation, even if that means relaxing the United States' historical insistence on quid pro quo agreements.
The group of American cities that is pressing for expanded international service agrees wholeheartedly.
In formal comments to the Transportation Department, the City of Charlotte rejected the traditional idea, detailed in American aviation laws, that foreign airline routes should be awarded only if exchanged for benefits of similar worth to American carriers. ''Under that approach, the needs of communities, not balanced in this equation, often have suffered,'' lawyers for Charlotte said.
Foreign airlines have been quick to side with the smaller cities, and they say their strategy is working. ''We sensed a change in mood with the change in Administration,'' said Rolf D. Hoehn, Lufthansa's general manager in the United States.
Talks with West Germany recessed in October without an agreement, but they resume next month in Germany and both sides appear optimistic. Even without a new treaty, the newly proposed United States rule might allow German flights to cities like Charlotte. That proposal, made after the bilateral talks recessed, ''put a whole new light on the negotiations,'' Mr. Hoehn said. Not every city Lufthansa wants to serve would qualify for the special program. Detroit and Pittsburgh, for example, already have service on American carriers to and from Germany, so additional flights would depend on a new route agreement.
 
Split Among U.S. Carriers
The United States' new flexibility appears to have split domestic airlines. Pan Am, in its comments on the proposal to liberalize service to some American cities, called it ''a logical extension of the United States Government's quest for the unobtainable - a completely free and open market for international air transportation.''
''Why should countries receive any additional U.S. rights for free?'' asked David M. O'Connor, the company's special counsel for international affairs.
But American Airlines, in its comments, endorsed the philosophy of the Transportation Department, which holds that the new flying rights, reserved for nations with liberal bilateral agreements in place, can be an important incentive during negotiations between nations.
''The department's proposal can serve as a tool for removing the shackles that presently exist in several significant markets,'' American said.
Robert L. Crandall, the company's chairman, in a separate letter to Mr. Shane, was more explicit. Referring to two nations with tightly restricted aviation markets where American wants to expand its service, he said, ''We shall hope for rapid progress, particularly in the U.K. and Italy.''

HEADLINE: Treasury Official Seen As Choice for Fed Seat

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
David W. Mullins Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, is the front-runner to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said that Mr. Mullins was the ''top candidate'' for the position, and that an announcement of President Bush's choice for the nomination ''could come any day.''
Other officials said Mr. Bush's top advisers on the matter, including Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, had recommended that Mr. Mullin be put on the Fed, but they could not say whether the President had made a final decision. 
The likelihood of the Mullins nomination was first reported today by The Wall Street Journal.
 
Popular in Congress
Mr. Mullins was an architect of the Administration's plan to rescue the savings industry and had primary responsibility for shepherding the measure through Congress. He is admired by many lawmakers and is not expected to have trouble winning Senate confirmation. The seat has been vacant since June, when H. Robert Heller resigned to become executive vice president of Visa International, the credit card company.
In recent months, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve have been somewhat at odds. The Treasury has favored a lowering of interest rates to stimulate economic growth and bring down the value of the dollar. The Fed, focusing on fighting inflation, has insisted on keeping interest rates relatively high.
Mr. Mullins, 43 years old, who would be the first person named by President Bush to the seven-member board, could give the Treasury a stronger voice in policy making.
On the other hand, Mr. Mullins, a former professor at the Harvard Business School, is a specialist in banking, capital markets and corporate finance and not in overall economic and monetary policy. As a result, he might be expected to concentrate on the Fed's regulatory responsibilities.
 
Central Bank's Duties
In addition to controlling the nation's money supply and thus affecting interest rates, the central bank is responsible for regulating banking companies and the margin requirements that govern the use of borrowed money to buy securities.
Two years ago, Mr. Brady retained Mr. Mullins and Robert R. Glauber, who was also at Harvard Business School, as senior staff members on the commission he headed to investigate the causes of the stock market plunge in October 1987.
After he became Treasury Secretary, Mr. Brady named Mr. Glauber Under Secretary for Finance and Mr. Mullins his assistant.

HEADLINE: Shift Urged In Controls On Exports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Business and labor advisers to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, called on the White House today to give the ''highest priority'' to streamlining its export controls.
They warned that if the United States did not move rapidly enough, Europeans would buy fewer American high-technology products and cut American companies out of cooperative research projects.
The planned removal of the European Community's trade frontiers by the end of 1992 and the march toward democratic capitalism of some Eastern European countries are already causing strains in the multilateral control system, the advisers said in a report entitled ''Europe 1992.'' 
 
Rising Tensions at Cocom
Europeans view a continuing American preoccupation with restrictive East-West technology transfer policies as misguided. Tensions have risen at recent meetings of the Allied control agency, the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom.
Mrs. Hills said she welcomed the report and added that the recommendations would receive ''careful attention.''
A European Community representative said the report would be ''looked at closely.''
''Our view is that the market will remain open,'' he said. ''We have no intention to raise barriers.''
In their 51-page report, the advisers said, ''The convergence of economic and political change in Europe is placing new strains on the ability of the U.S. to unilaterally control the flow of sensitive technologies that could enhance Soviet military capabilities.''
 
'Cutting Edge' of Trade Policy
Known as the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy and Negotiations, the group of business and labor representatives was set up by Congress in 1974 to advise the President on international trade negotiations.
In A letter to Mrs. Hills, James D. Robinson 3d, the committee chairman and chief executive of American Express, and Lawrence A. Bossidy, the director of the European task force and a vice chairman of General Electric, said that the issues raised by the European Community's plans for 1992 were the ''cutting edge'' of international trade policy and that their resolution would require ''innovative solutions in both bilateral and multilateral arenas.''
The report outlined other problems facing the United States as a result of the single European market, including the difficulties for American companies in breaking into such sectors as telecommunications and heavy electrical equipment. Because they are are largely Government-controlled, these European industries generally buy products exclusively from their national manufacturers.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops By 13.23, To 2,688.78

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices fell across a broad front yesterday as traders concluded there was no possibility of an imminent cut in interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 13.23 points, to 2,688.78, as volume on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to 147.3 million shares, from 153.8 million shares on Tuesday. Declines on the exchange ran ahead of advances by about a 3-to-2 ratio, with 892 issues lower in price and 595 higher. 
The Southwest Bank of St. Louis, which often takes the lead in prime rate moves, raised the level it charges its most creditworthy customers to 10 1/2 percent, in line with other banks. Southwest's reduction of its prime to 10 percent on Nov. 8 was not followed by other banks. Analysts said that Southwest's return to the prevailing level indicated that it realized that the Federal Reserve Board was not easing credit as expected.
 
Future Easing Expected
''I believe, however, that because the economy has weakened significantly, a Fed easing and a cut in the prime rate are likely to occur in the near future,'' said Theodore Tung, chief economist at the National City Corporation in Cleveland.
Analysts also cited concern over the Commerce Department's report that corporate earnings were off by 7.2 percent in the third quarter. The department also reported that the gross national product expanded at a revised adjusted annual rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter.
Among individual issues, I.B.M. dropped 1 1/8, to 97 3/4. The company said it was continuing its efforts to reduce its work force but that there would be no forced layoffs.
Telecom plunged 5 5/8, to 25, and was the biggest point loser on the Big Board. The company said that earnings per share for the year might be lower than many projections of $1.30 to $1.35 because of lower revenues caused in part by increased use of volume discounts by customers.
 
L.A. Gear Down 5 3/8, to 36
L.A. Gear tumbled 5 3/8, to 36, and was the second-biggest point loser. Merrill Lynch lowered its earnings estimate on the athletic footwear maker for 1989.
Philip Morris added 3/8, to 41 7/8. The company said that it would buy back up to $1.5 billion of its outstanding shares from time to time on the open market.
Active blue chips included Chevron, up 5/8, to 68 3/8; BankAmerica, off 1 1/4, to 27 5/8; Chemical Banking, off 1/2, to 32 1/8, and Penn Central, off 1/8, to 25 5/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index slipped 1.46 points, to 373.64, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dipped 0.85, to 455.81 Occupational-Urgent Care jumped 2, to 19 1/2, in over-the-counter trading. Analysts said investors appeared to be realizing the potential of an agreement between the company and a unit of General Motors.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225-stock index set a record for the sixth consecutive day. The bellwether measure rose 36.16 points, to 37,021.46, its first close above the 37,000 level.
Japanese stocks traded here fared well in response, with Hitachi up 4 3/4, to 109 5/8, and Matsushita Electric up 2 5/8, to 160.
In Taiwan, stocks recovered with a record one-day gain after their record plunge on Tuesday. The primary stock market index surged 590.19 points yesterday, to 9,630.28, more than regaining Tuesday's loss of 547.98.

HEADLINE: Holiday Sales: Mixed Pattern

 BODY:
Sales in the early part of the Christmas shopping season ''have been pretty good but nothing exceptional,'' with a mixed pattern and regional differences, Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the National Retail Merchants Association, said at a news conference yesterday. 
Ms. Wells said apparel sales were strong, especially in women's clothing. But she added that sales were weak in goods like furniture, curtains and floor coverings.
 
Business was strong in the
Northeast, she said, ''very good in the Midwest and weaker on the West Coast, some of which may be due to the recent earthquake in Northern California.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading Focuses on Mark As Dollar Finishes Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday as the West German mark continued to dominate the foreign exchange markets.
''The dollar was relatively neutral'' as most currency traders focused on the mark, said Ronald Holzer, the chief dealer with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. 
The mark fell amid profit taking in response to an increase since East Germany opened the Berlin wall on Nov. 9. The opening raised expectations that West German industry would benefit from the relaxation of East-West tensions.
Mr. Holzer said the dollar gained some support from a Commerce Department report that the gross national product grew at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the third quarter, slightly higher than the 2.5 percent rate originally reported last month.
In New York, the dollar rose to 1.7875 marks, from 1.7770 marks late on Tuesday.
The dollar weakened slightly against the British pound, which edged up to $1.5678 in New York, from $1.5670 late on Tuesday, and it fell to 142.86 yen, from 143.20 yen late on Tuesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Tuesday, included: 1.5920 Swiss francs, up from 1.5880; 6.0935 French francs, up from 6.0710; 1,318.75 Italian lire, up from 1,312.75, and 1.16525 Canadian dollars, down from 1.6645.

LENGTH: 546 words

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
On Course for Malta: Three Decades of Statecraft

 BODY:

 
September 1959: President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. The talks result in the ''Spirit of Camp Daivd,'' an effort to press for scientific and cultural exchanges and disarmament.
 
May 1960: Eisenhower and Khrushchev go to Paris. But the Soviet leader, angry after his country sights and downs an American U-2 spy plane over the Soviet Union, cancels the meeting. 
 
June 1961: Khrushchev and President Kennedy have heated exchanges in Vienna. There are no formal agreements. A year later, the Soviets send nuclear missiles to Cuba; the United States forces their removal.
 
June 1967: President Johnson meets in Glasboro, N.J. with Alesksei N. Kosygin to discuss the Middle East, the Vietnam War and nuclear arms. They come to no terms on those issues.
 
may 1972: President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Moscow, sign the first treaties setting limits on strategic nuclear arms, known as SALT I, and on curbing anti-ballistic missile systems. They agree to keep negotiating on arms, but regional issues divide them.
 
June 1973: Nixon and Brezhnev meet in Washington. They agree to try to complete a new arms treaty by 1974.
 
June-July 1974: Nixon and Brezhnev meet in Moscow and Yalta. They agree to a treaty banning underground nuclear-arms tests with yields exceeding 150 kilotons, and they arrange a 10-year economic accord.
 
November 1974: President Ford and Brezhnev, in Vladivostok, reach a tentative deal limiting missile launchers and bombers and lay a base for a second strategic arms treaty. The treaty is not completed before President Carter takes office.
 
June 1979: Carter and Brezhnev, in Vienna, sign the second treaty limiting strategic arms, or SALT II. Although the Senate never approves the treaty because of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in December of 1979, both sides agree informally to observe the limits.
 
November 1985: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Geneva for wide-ranging talks on arms control and other subjects. They agree to revive cultural exchanges and to enhance air safety, but no arms-control agreements are acheived.
 
October 1986: Reagan and Gorbachev meet in Reykjavik, Iceland, to provide momemtum to arms-control talks. The two sides speak of vast cuts in strategic arms and medium-range missiles, but the accord falls through because of disagreements over the American plan for a space-based missile defense system, or Star Wars, and over Moscow's insistence on putting all arms issues in one package.
 
December 1987: Reagan and Gorbachev meet in Washington. They sign a treaty to destroy intermediate-range nuclear forces, known as I.N.F., and agree to seek a treaty cutting long-range nuclear arsenals. But Star Wars remains a sticking point.
 
may-June 1988: Gorbachev and Reagan, in Moscow, ratify the intermediate-range weapons treaty but make no breakthrough on cutting long-range nuclear forces. Reagan says important work has been accomplished but Gorbachev complains of ''missed opportunities.''
 
December 1988: Gorbachev says farewell to Reagan and greets President-elect George Bush at a two-hour luncheon on Govenors Island in New York harbor. Reagan assures Gorbachev of continuity under Bush.
